THE ANARCHIST
The Anarchist
Spreading Anarchy
Psychrolutes marcidus. A melted human face with fins.
Periphylla periphylla. Avoids the light, as with so many of us these days.
Stomiidae. Normally dwells deeper than even submersibles can reach, but was caught when coming to the surface for oxygen.
Species Unrecorded. This species has not yet been categorised. Why not name it after yourself!
Watasenia scintillans. Very small, it uses counter-illumination to hide from predators, mimicking the surface water color.
Atractosteus spatula. The species has existed for more years than a person could count in their lifetime.
Centrophryne spinulosa. A deep-dwelling anglerfish whose lantern lights the prey that it minces with its many recurved teeth.
Mitsukurina owstoni. Captures the imagination with its extensive proboscis, much like the mythical goblin Tengu.
Chiasmodon niger. Stuffs prey larger than itself into a stretchable cocoon-like basket that dangles from its belly.
Cyanea capillata. The rapunzel of the sea, this great hairy stinger can grow even longer than the blue whale!
The legendary Kraken, captured! It propels itself wildly around the tank! Tiny human observers cower under its mesmerising gaze!
Latimeria chalumnae. Old Nate looks at you and says, "This isn't the only living fossil hanging around the sea bed".
The rotten prow of a ship that sank during the battle of Trelawney.
Awarded to an unknown sailor for bravery in a previous arena.
This well-preserved sculpture once led from the prow at the battle of Trelawney.
A medal belonging to a high-ranking officer, who may have died at Trelawney.
A colourful and talismanic bust that fronted one of the great ships that sank at Trelawney.
A fine military decoration of an experienced campaigner present at the battle of Trelawney.
The great strategist's blade. Last seen held aloft and glinting in the southern sun, just before the fleet cut through the enemy line.
A remarkable figurehead belonging to a resplendent imperial ship that fought in the battle of Trelawney.
Nadasky's dying wish was that this medal be recovered for his young son, who dreamed of becoming an admiral like his father...
A remarkable figurehead belonging to a magisterial La Corona ship that sank at the battle of Trelawney.
This flag formed the first part of a famous signal during the battle of Trelawney.
This flag formed the middle part of a famous signal during the battle of Trelawney.
This flag formed the last part of a famous signal during the battle of Trelawney.
Evidence of a long-lost civilisation? They say the Kingdom of Atlantis spanned a vast and fertile continent that, according to legend, tragically subsided into the sea.
This sunken shrine to fork-wielding Poseidon seems ironic now. Why did Poseidon not save his children, when the oceans were his to command?
No courthouse could bridle the hubris of the Atlanteans, and so it was left to the fates instead to condemn those peoples to the eternal abyss.
A statue cut from a material so rare that for millennia it has been known only by its name. It is quite possible that this is the only example of this mineral that remains.
The megalithic structure lends further credence to the existence of a lost continent to the west. Experts say this stepped pyramid could have been at the heart of Atlantean ritual.
A tablet so mystifying it will convince the vast majority of museum visitors that Atlantis existed, while leaving true scholars of the ancient world pretty sceptical.
Old Nate's basic prototype is the standard for exploratory diving.
Old Nate quirkily affixed a moon pool to the base of this diving bell, enabling better access to the abyss.
Old Nate's proudest work. A controlled flow of gas sent via its umbilical cable enables this bell to dive deeper than ever before.
Old Nate's first attempt at mapping the depths using sound.
An improved version of Old Nate's echo-ranger, with more bells and whistles.
Sound out even the most sunken of sunken treasures with this subsurface detector — an innovation in sea surveying far ahead of its time.
A new standard in diving cables.
The elasticity of these cables allows for more flexibility in the bell's carry weight.
Nate's most cunning cabling: durable under heavy loads, while supporting a variety of systems between the diving bell and its parent.
Attracts creatures of the not-too-deep.
Brings scores of fascinating marine creatures to the surface.
Has the miraculous power to draw the most bizarre abyssal creatures in creation to the surface.
Dinky magnet that draws up dross. Demagnetizes over time.
A big magnet that attracts the attention of some really great junk. Demagnetizes over time.
Nate stroked this monster magnet with his master magnet. Expect to find the ripest, rustiest junk going. Demagnetizes over time.
Sifts the seabed for ancient artifacts.
Sifts a large area of the seabed for obscure and ancient artifacts.
Sifts a very large area of the seabed, revealing remarkable artifacts that incrustations have long kept concealed.
For scraping the bottom of the barrel.
A slightly more ambitious dredge of Old Nate's, designed to plumb deeper water for sunken machinery.
Old Nate's most far-reaching scavenging dredge, designed to plumb the ocean's deepest trenches for sunken machinery.
This unpredictable prototype was originally built to gain an unfair advantage at steam car races.
A reinforced variant, which in spite of the minor combustion risk, takes all the labour out of warehouse work.
Old Nate's baby. Prone to the odd tantrum, but provides the lift everyone needs in times of logistical disconsolation.
Some say there's a tiny boy inside pulling the levers...
Compensates for its faithfulness in performing simple human tasks by being wilfully blind.
The nearest thing Nate has to a companion. Unlike a human servant, it won't complain when he kicks it for setting things on fire.
So the blue cable to the yellow pin... Oh wait... Or was it red?
The persistent screech this extra-powerful contraption generates cannot be normal...
The enthusiast's choice. Old Nate neglected to include an operating manual, meaning there's a chance of the odd accident.
Makes holes in people so their souls may escape.
"Don't blame me, I just make 'em! I'm not the one pulling the trigger..."
Even Old Nate seems to regret having begat a monster so mean and metallic. That's why he'll only give it to people he trusts.
Buckets of fun.
Grab even more with each fell swoop.
These tricky lobster nippers could sneak mice out from their slippers, or tip some salted kippers on some drippy tallship skippers.
Clever use of water's potential energy to generate electricity.
This advanced hydroelectric paddlewheel is immune to rust and corrosion, if not the odd explosion.
This unique hydroelectric generator has a gold plaque inscribed with its inventor's motto: "Consequences be dammed! Ha! — N8"
A double-barreled cannon that loads itself — and more worryingly, chooses targets itself...
A self-loading, twin barrel cannon with added vim! Simply point in the approximate direction of the enemy, and let her rip!
Old Nate has only just realised the destruction this double-barreled beast is capable of. A hint of regret? Naahh, can't be...
A lively auxilliary propeller that can be attached to any sea-going vessel.
The 'Cyclone' has several advantages over the 'Squall', with an enlarged inlet cowl, and it's being made from better quality materials.
It wasn't built for water, but having rescued the mighty propeller from a crashed zeppelin, Nate thought 'why not?'
Maybe first designed to make car races, who knows.
Maybe first designed to make car races, who knows.
Maybe first designed to make car races, who knows.
Blows up one in every ten passing ships (probably).
Bigger and prongier. Adds a bit of froth and fizz to the mix whenever its destructive services are called upon.
A mine of monstrous size and ferocity, whose horns really hertz. Look close, and you can see steam puffing from its wetted nostrils.
Cruiikk... Tchin... Chikachak... Ping!
Wheeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeee! Pafazz! Ping!
ScrimindolobaladolobaladoloBOOM-Bap-Scwizz-Schnarf...chug chug chug... chug chug chug... ...burp.
These modified fireworks are certainly going to excite in one way or another...
A highly experimental batch of fireworks, likely to cause pleasure and pain in equal measure.
If they're anything like the batch Nate prepped for the late King's Golden Jubilee, this shall be a night to glow long in the memory.
Increases your prospects of striking gold.
A bit of hip-wiggle in this iteration seems to attract even more gold.
This model is the gold standard. Simply pour black gold in and get gold gold out.
A sideline in copper and zinc.
A proper cropper of zinc and copper.
One of Old Nate's more down-to-earth inventions. Gathers precious metals at a remarkable rate.
Ensures not a drop goes to waste.
Gathers fossil goop the average sucker might miss.
Only five star crude will pass this extractor's exacting selection process.
This map marks the lost ruins of a small village in the Old World.
This map shows the location of an ancient trading post in the New World.
This map will lead you to the remains of an abandoned ship near Cape Trelawney.
The people who built this temple couldn't have foreseen the catastrophe that drove their place of worship to the bottom of the sea.
No one knows who built this pyramid, or how it sank to the bottom of the ocean.
This map reveals the place where a thriving city once stood, now resting below the surface.
The pleasure palaces of Baiea were pulled under the sea, along with their owners' luxuries and excesses.
This map appears to show the entrance to the legendary lost city of Paititi, but nobody has yet been able to find it...!
A cartographer and linguist studied this ancient manuscript to produce a map that leads to the legendary city of Atlantis.
This map will help you uncover the rare species that lie tangled in the kelp forest.
The rich fauna of the seagrass meadow awaits you where the X marks the spot.
This map will lead you to a coral garden, and all the different species that thrive in it.
Some of the mysterious species that roam the depths of this oceanic trench have yet to be discovered.
This map marks one of the richest ecosystems on the planet.
It's hard to believe that some of these creatures truly exist, and are not the stuff of dreams — or nightmares.
It's hard to believe this map will lead you to the colossal serpent deity ⁠— but the myths must have stemmed from something...
Could this really be the place where the Huacan God rests...?
Multiple sightings confirm that this may be the best place to capture the legendary Kraken — or be captured by it.
A map of a large naval battle that occurred in home waters recently. Some machines may still be at the bottom of the sea...
A map of a large naval battle that occurred abroad recently. Some machines may still be at the bottom of the sea...
A map of a large naval battle that occurred at Trelawney recently. Some machines may still be at the bottom of the sea...
A very rare map indicating the location of the wreckage of a wealthy merchant ship in home waters.
A very rare map indicating the location of the wreckage of a wealthy merchant ship in foreign waters.
A very rare map indicating the location of the wreckage of a wealthy merchant ship in the waters of Trelawney.
A unique map marking the location of Willie's special fortune. If there's anything down there, it will surely be of high value.
A unique map marking a vault of contingencies for Isabel's rebels. If there's anything down there, it will surely be of high value.
A unique map marking the wreck of Vicente's favourite ship. If there's anything down there, it will surely be of high value.
Knows what to look for, and how and where to look.
If there's a chance of recovering the past, she'll be the first to dive in.
Said to vomit at the sight of soot, Flinders' passion for keeping immaculate exhibits is both his gift and his curse.
He'd like to be under the sea.
Seems to speak the language of fish — at least, that's how she sounds underwater...
Has named zillions of marine lifeforms, receiving nothing but positives for her growing collection of underwater negatives.
Has no problem keeping his eyes open while underwater.
Nadia started dredging up machines after her father Igor's business took a bit of a dive.
A master machine dredger, Anchovy has travelled the seven seas, shrivelling above deck in the sun and salt.
Swings a pendulum in search of a fifth dimension.
Lamie accumulates fortunes as easily as he has the days, weeks and years.
Unimpeachable virtue has rarely been so well-rewarded. A heroine of the east, Mai is also no slouch with a sword.
In death, a ray of inspiration.
Bit off more than it could chew...
In the end, it was just too puffed out...
Tangled up in blue...
At least it had a good innings...
These stone pictographs contain, among other things, details of a cast iron water screw for the transportation of water to elevated gardens.
Anatomies and flying machines survive because the paper on which they were drawn is fibrous, and was preserved within a safe.
An ancient stone tablet covered in trigonometric ratios and other mathematical treats.
Insulated within a metal chest, this manuscript describes the various innovations in medieval warfare during the crusades.
Part of an ancient analogue computer capable of predicting cosmic events — such as eclipses — years in advance.
An ancient pirate talisman coruscating with wickedness. The inner band is inscribed "The dead never die".
May not necessarily lead to something good...
All the sparkle that remains of a resistance against an all-consuming empire.
Specially-designed by Old Nate for the systematic removal of sea mines.
Joined after you helped the Queen at Trelawney. Was in charge of logistics during the war, so expect military efficiency at the docks!
Joined after you helped the Queen at Trelawney. Formerly of the Royal Mint, the Queen sent Susannah to make your gold go further.
Joined after you helped the Queen at Trelawney. Fernando used to make Vasco's morning coffee, but King João put paid to that.

Dive at the specified location and protect your salvager from any harm.
Deliver the materials required to transmute Old Nate's request.
Sail to [AssetData([Conditions QuestCondition ExecutionObject]) Text] to receive Admiral Nadasky's military regalia.
Sir Archibald Blake urgently requests your help.

Dear friend, what you read in the news is true — Her Majesty is gone! My one consolation is that her absence seems by choice, for she left me this parting note: "Don't fret, Archie dear. I'm off South to restore our imperial glory — will return when that's done". Please, can I trust you to ensure her safe return? I must remain here, to allay the chaos in her absence.

Where has the Queen gone!? Worried sick and left to deal with a headless state, Sir Archibald Blake has come to you for help. You are his only hope in finding Her Majesty and convincing her to return to her royal duties. Organise an expedition south to go after her.
Sir Archibald Blake asks if you'd be willing to help him.
To start the expedition, go to the World Map and select the Sunken Treasures Expedition.
The Queen wants a metropolis to be built at Crown Falls.

Crown Falls, a rich and majestic land overlooking the bay of Trelawney, is where the Empire once won their much-heralded victory over La Corona. In other words, the perfect place to establish a new capital for the Queen.
The Queen offers you the materials to set up an outpost.
The Queen wants to commission a treasure hunter.

The spoils left behind by the battle of Trelawney have attracted many a treasure hunter. The Queen recalls spotting someone that may prove useful in her quest to retrieve the Sceptre of Capon, and wants you to find and commission him.
Old Nate welcomes you to Trelawney.
Old Nate offers you a diving bell — for a price.
You have acquired a diving bell from Old Nate. There's no way to know if the creaky prototype will hold up until you try it...
Old Nate wants to make sure that everything is settled before your first dive.
Old Nate advises you not to get rid of the scrap, and take it to him instead.

The test dive went well enough, but the bell came up with nothing but worthless junk. Old Nate won't mind, though — he has a knack for finding value in everything. Bring the scrap to him, and he may be able to make something useful out of it.
Old Nate advises you to take all the scrap you find to him.
Old Nate offers you the co-ordinates of a promising diving spot.
After your unfruitful diving attempt, Old Nate has taken pity on you. He'll let you have the co-ordinates of a juicy diving site, for what he claims is a reasonable price.
Old Nate asks if you're ready to pay.

Dive at:
Old Nate's co-ordinates
The Queen notes that you're not the first to buy Old Nate's information.
Old Nate wishes you luck.
Old Nate has given you the co-ordinates for a promising diving spot. Sail your salvager there — it's as good a spot as any to start looking for the Sceptre of Capon.
The Queen is surprised to have found the lost journal of Nadasky.
The Queen believes the journal may lead you to the sceptre.
The Queen says the journal needs to be restored, for which you'll need artisans.

You've recovered Nadasky's journal, but its pages are barely readable. Exposing the fragile pages to a long sea journey would be too risky. Instead, you must make room for art restorers at Crown Falls.
The Queen is pleased with your progress.

Attract Art Restorers:
[Conditions QuestCondition CurrentAmount]/[Conditions QuestCondition Amount] [AssetData([Conditions QuestCondition Context]) Text]
Artisans will begin the restoration of Nadasky's journal by rebinding it. They need flour for the glue, and sewing machines for the stitching.

We're lucky there's even a faint possibility of returning this journal to a semblance of its original condition. We must first see to the binding: people tell me a flour-based glue will be gentler on such a delicate manuscript than an acid one, and that we'll also want the precision and punch of modern sewing machines for the stitching.
The Queen requests a university, so you can train more art restorers.
While Nadasky's journal is being restored, the Queen wants you to establish a university in the region; its scholars should be able to help decipher the journal's contents.
The Queen is glad that the first pages are now legible.
The Queen is outraged to learn that Nadasky went against her father's orders.
The Queen encourages you to explore the locations mentioned in Nadasky's journal.

The first few pages of the journal are a first-hand account of the naval battle at Trelawney — it's evident Nadasky didn't think much of the King's strategy. The log also hints at the compass bearings at which you may find the sceptre.
The Queen recognises this as the spot from Nadasky's journal.
The Queen is disappointed to discover that the sceptre is incomplete.
Vasco Oliveira admits he too is looking for the sceptre.
Vasco Oliveira explains that the sceptre is not whole, but split into three.

Find the locations mentioned in Nadasky's journal:
The Guard Dogs
The Smugglers' Cove
The Watchtower
Read Nadasky's journal closely, and find the three locations he describes.

Nadasky pinpointed the great battleground of Trelawney in his journal as being somewhere to the east of Crown Falls. Chances are that part of the sceptre sank along with one of the many ships that fell during battle — but there are still active sea mines all over the area. Perhaps Old Nate has some apparatus that can help you navigate those dangerous waters.
We've just received the final versions of the next few pages of the journal. Be gentle with them, the ink is still fresh!
The Queen is engrossed in Nadasky's account of the Battle of Trelawney.
The Queen believes Old Nate can help you find the treasure and avoid the sea mines.
Old Nate can build something for you if you get him more materials.

Once again, it seems you're not the first to come to Old Nate for help; he's already used up all his materials putting something together for Vasco. Nevertheless, he is prepared to help you catch up, if you bring him the scrap he needs...
Old Nate presents you with the echo-locator.
The Queen urges you to use the echo-locator at the site of the battle.
Thanks to Old Nate's invention, you can now take your diving bell to the battle site without fear of stumbling into mines — old or new — and find the rest of the sceptre.
Vasco Oliveira announces that he has found the second piece of the Sceptre.
Reach the diving spot using an echo-locator.
Click on the echo-locator on your ship. The golden signal echoing back to your ship will tell you where to go.
The range of the echo-locator is finite. You may have to move around the map to find the signal.
Vasco Oliveira advocates a diplomatic solution to your conflict.
Vasco Oliveira proposes an all-or-nothing deal.

You were too late. The second piece of the Sceptre of Capon has fallen into the hands of Vasco Oliveira. But, unlike his cousin Vicente, Oliveira prefers to settle matters without violence. He has proposed a deal: if you are the first to recover the last piece of the sceptre — the Eagle — he will surrender the pommel. But if he gets to it first, you will have to hand over the rod section you found.
The Queen suggests you win the bet - or else.

At last, it is complete. After many days and nights of meticulous work, Nadasky's journal can be read in full for the first time. Here are the last pages, with the conclusion of his account of the Battle of Trelawney. A first-hand testimony of the Empire's history.

The scholars say Nadasky's Journal is about as good as they're ever going to get it. Hopefully, it will give you more clues about what happened during the battle, and what became of the last part of the sceptre.

Read:
[Conditions QuestCondition Context]
Click on the item on your ship to see its content.
If your ship's cargo was full, the item may be on the water.
The Queen wants to delve into what happened to Richardson and his crew.

Nadasky reveals in his journal that, despite his best attempts to avoid it, the King sent a frigate — the HMS Ajax — to chase after the Santíssima Vitória in an attempt to retrieve the Sceptre of Capon. No good came from this command: La Corona's flagship was never seen again, and the Ajax's crew all lost their lives after being stranded on an island without fresh water for a week. Her Majesty believes that you may find more clues about the whereabouts of the flagship if you look into the fate of Richardson and his sailors.
The Queen is sure the last piece of the sceptre sank with La Corona's flagship.

Follow Nadasky's hints to find:
[AssetData([Conditions QuestCondition Context]) Text]
Nadasky wrote in his journal about the place where Richardson and the rest of HMS Ajax's crew were stranded. Search the area.
The Queen asks if you've found any clues regarding the HMS Ajax's crew.
The Queen refers you to Nadasky's sketch of La Corona's flagship.

Thanks to Richardson's log, you know that the Santíssima Vitória crashed on the east coast of Crown Falls. Her Majesty is certain that the eagle section of the Sceptre sank along with the ship, but where exactly? There are many such wrecks along those cliffs. Luckily, there may be a clue — Nadasky was so struck by his first sight of the Santíssima Vitória that he sketched it in his journal.

Use Richardson's log to find:
[AssetData([Conditions QuestCondition Context]) Text]
Richardson's captain's log reveals the place where La Corona's flagship — the Santíssima Vitória — crashed.
The Queen urges you to dive down to the wreckage of the Santíssima Vitória.

The Santíssima Vitória — the magnificent ship-of-the-line that was the pride of La Corona — lies broken on the seabed, as if it were the skeleton of a colossal whale. Scour the bottom of the ocean, scrape every bone, and find the gleaming eagle — that timeless emblem of empire.
The Queen is exhilarated to have found the last piece of the sceptre.
The Queen examines the Eagle of the Sceptre.
The Queen exhorts you to collect Vasco's piece of the sceptre.

The contract is unequivocal: whoever finds the Eagle of the Sceptre first, shall receive the third piece from the counterparty. The Eagle is in your hands, so Vasco Oliveira has no choice other than to surrender the sceptre's pommel to you.
Vasco Oliveira cedes the sceptre to you, and leaves Trelawney.
The Queen is bemused at Vasco's sense of integrity.
Vasco is curious as to whether you've found the head of the sceptre.
Old Nate offers to restore the sceptre.

Despite Old Nate's attempt to lay his hands on the sceptre, the Queen has chosen to leave the restoration to the trained art restorers of Crown Falls. They will see to it the moment they have the special materials they require.
The Queen would never trust the sceptre to Old Nate.
The Queen suggests leaving it to the artisans.
Ahh, the sceptre! A wonderful piece! But it has suffered structural damage — we will need metal to restore it to glory!
The soul of the sceptre has returned, but it still needs plating in precious metals.

The Sceptre of Capon has almost been returned to its former splendour! There are just two final details missing: the inlay of pearl it once had, and the delicate filigree I have seen in the paintings.
We are finally finished. This is, without a shadow of a doubt, the greatest masterpiece we have ever laid eyes upon. We hope Her Majesty will be satisfied with our work.
The Queen thanks you for restoring the Sceptre of Capon.
Deliver to Art Restorers:
[AssetData([Conditions QuestCondition DeliveryObject(ObjectiveIndex)]) Text]
Old Nate suggests some diving spots where you may find gold and pearls.

Even if the Queen didn't trust Old Nate with the restoration of the Sceptre, he is still lingering to see how things will turn out. If you're short of gold bars and sparkling pearls, he knows some spots where you might find them.
Old Nate hopes you have found what you were looking for.
The Queen wants you to showcase the Sceptre of Capon.

The Sceptre of Capon has been recovered and restored — along with the pride of the Empire, apparently. The Queen has little use for it locked up in a vault: she wants her subjects to come from every corner of the nation to behold the sceptre in all its glory.
The Queen is very pleased with your powers of presentation.

Equip in Museum:
The Sceptre of Capon
You can only equip items in your museum if they are stored in your trading post. Make sure to transfer the sceptre to the trading post from your ship.
The Queen inaugurates the exhibition of the Sceptre of Capon.

The Sceptre of Capon has been recovered and restored — along with the pride of the Empire, apparently. The Queen has little use for it locked up in a vault: she wants her subjects to come from every corner of the nation to behold the sceptre in all its glory.
The Queen expresses her heartfelt gratitude for your service.
The Queen trusts you now.
The Queen grants you full ownership of Crown Falls.

Sustain for [Conditions QuestCondition TimeLimit >> time] in Museum:
The Sceptre of Capon
Keep the exhibition of the Sceptre of Capon open for the requested amount of time.
The Sceptre of Capon gives your city a lot of attractiveness!
The Queen honours Admiral Nadasky's leadership during the Battle of Trelawney.
The Queen awards you some of Admiral Nadasky's military regalia.
The Queen resolves to giving Admiral Nadasky the recognition he deserved.

The Queen's eyes have been opened to Admiral Nadasky's decisive role in her father's victory. She would like to award you his military regalia – his commemorative sword and medal – to continue to mark his memory and invaluable service to the Empire.
The Queen has one last request for you: escort her from Cape Trelawney.
The Queen wishes to honor Nadasky.

The Queen is satisfied with your work at Cape Trelawney and is ready to return to her domestic duties. She would like to be safely escorted from Cape Trelawney, just as you promised Sir Archibald she would be.
HMS AJAX — Captain Richardson's Log
IN RESPECT OF OUR PROMISE:
Sunday, 13th October, 1805

Following the King’s commands to intercept Admiral Silva’s flotilla, we arrived at Cape Trelawney at 1pm.
La Corona’s entire armada is here — their flagship, especially, being of imposing size and might. Such a disproportionate escort suggests that our informants were correct: they must be transporting the Sceptre of Capon that our King is seeking.

La Corona’s fleet is vast in terms of size and number, but ours is staffed with seamen both seasoned and loyal. We have a chance of winning a decisive victory against the enemy here at Trelawney — but not if we fixate on recovering the sceptre, as the King is insisting... I admit, taking the talisman would greatly damage La Corona's national spirit — but what of our own, when a thousand or more sailors are sent to their deaths for a trinket! No, we must have no other thought than employing the very best tactics to win the day.

Since the King will no longer leave the safety of his fortress atop the cliffs, we may be able to blame the fog for not complying with his signals.
There were a few other incidents today. At 3pm we intercepted two enemy gunboats, and ran them aground between two small islands to the Southeast, with cliffs like two guard dogs facing one another.
At 4:30pm we discovered a frigate bearing the emblem of La Corona, smuggling crates out of a pirate cove in the spiral-shaped cluster of islands that lie due east.
Lastly, we had a skirmish with a ship-of-the-line near an old watchtower, between the three large islands due west. She sank with all her cargo.
Tuesday, 15 October 1805

La Corona opened fire this morning. We engaged in battle at 10am, south east of the region — a conflict which lasted until seven in the evening.
We lost many good men today — the sly young Admiral Silva having deployed mines to protect the enemy convoy. It was the King's command that we attack in a single line, parallel to the enemy formation. Fortunately, I was able to persuade the fleet to ignore this instruction, and instead arrange themselves into two perpendicular columns to cut through the enemy line — and as a corollary, avoid the mines. Our lead ships were blown apart, but it left a path clear for the rest of us. The enemy fleet, being snipped into thirds, were vulnerable to broadsides. We proceeded to drive them toward their own mines, and though in the mayhem there were casualties on both sides, we knew victory for the Empire had been won.
We thank those brave sailors who lost their lives today that we ourselves survived, and shall never forget their sacrifice. The price would have been far greater had we sworn blind obedience to the King's strategy.

It will doubtless anger him to hear his orders were defied, but I stand by my decision. It may even please him to hear I have been wounded for my arrogance. It's likely my dress and decorations made me a conspicuous target, and I took a shot of musket to my side.
My arm still has full function — and my head is not half as foggy as the doctor thinks it to be — so I will continue my command until our operation here has concluded. La Corona may have suffered a defeat of magnitude today, but their flagship — the gargantuan Santíssima Vitória — managed to escape unscathed.
Wednesday, 16 October 1805

The King is, indeed, mad. He appears to care nothing for our victory, and was upset in the extreme to learn that we hadn't yet begun pursuit of the Santíssima Vitória, for he is adamant that the Sceptre of Capon is on board.
Having received word that the flagship was heading northeast, His Majesty ordered Captain Richardson — of the HMS Ajax — to go after her. Under no circumstances will he permit us to accompany them. I have tried to inform the King that the Ajax is ill-equipped for the duel, but my injury leaves me weak, and I have had to retire to my quarters. Santíssima Vitória may be the largest man-of-war ever built. Richardson knows he leads his men to their deaths, but he has always been a man unwavering in his sense of duty.
Thursday, 24th October, 1805

It is unseasonably, morbidly hot. A rowboat was found this morning, beached on the headland — brought in on the current, presumably, for its occupants are three days dead of thirst. In a clenched hand, one held a letter from Richardson — these men were sent to find help, the crew of the Ajax surviving a clash with the Santíssima Vitória only by swimming to an island south east of the headland.
We immediately dispatched a rescue boat, but it was too late: Richardson and his crew have met the same fate. We found no trace of the Santíssima Vitória, either. His Majesty's reaction is predictable. These lives were taken by his hands, yet he weeps only for the sceptre.
My wounds fester, and my fever worsens. The doctor says I must put down my pen.

In the best interest of both our nations, I, Vasco Oliveira Silva, servant of His Majesty King João of A Coroa, agree to surrender the piece of the Sceptre of Capon currently in my custody, namely the pommel of the sceptre, in the event of my failing to discover the final piece of the sceptre (the eagle) first — so long as the counterparty agrees to do the same in the opposite event.
Vasco Oliveira Silva

2 AM: Our patrol was uneventful. The night is calm. Thanks to Admiral Nadasky’s exceptional strategy, the HMS Ajax and many of her sister ships have prevailed in the battle of Trelawney.

9 AM: We have new orders. The Ajax has been chosen by His Majesty himself to chase and board the Santíssima Vitória, where we are to retrieve an object of great importance. The enemy have a significant advantage, but the HMS Ajax is a logical choice, being one of few frigates still in good condition. I must have faith we can achieve our goal, or else my men will not.

12 PM: We encountered the Santíssima Vitória south east of the mainland. She opened fire on sight. I commanded the Ajax to retaliate. We disabled their rudder, and saw the enemy flagship wreck against the east coast of the mainland, pulled in by a strong current. The sceptre has gone with her — and we too are filling with water.

HMS Ajax sunk. One rowboat, myself and rest swimming for shore. Desolate island, no fresh water. Heat unbearable. Current too strong to attempt crossing — sending rowboat to get help.

19th October,
No word from the rowboat. We will die here...

October 21st,
All hope is lost. Our King has forsaken us.
The Queen is upset that you lost Crown Falls. You have failed in the story of Sunken Treasures.
The Queen is ready to lay down the foundations of a new city at Crown Falls.
The Queen has entrusted you with building a new imperial capital at Crown Falls — a beautiful land that extends as far as the eye can see. But every great metropolis must begin as a humble village.

Reach City Status: Village
[Conditions QuestCondition CurrentAmount]/[Conditions QuestCondition Amount] [AssetData([Conditions QuestCondition Context]) Text]
The Queen spurs you on to expand your settlement on Crown Falls.
Your settlement at Crown Falls is promising, but as yet it's far from the grand metropolis the Queen outlined in her sleep. It's time for it to grow into a town.

Reach City Status: Town
[Conditions QuestCondition CurrentAmount]/[Conditions QuestCondition Amount] [AssetData([Conditions QuestCondition Context]) Text]
The Queen stresses the importance of establishing a city at Crown Falls.
Not only is Crown Falls a pleasant land that is of historical and emotional significance to her people, but the Queen has long-term strategic and commercial motives for establishing a city here.

Reach City Status: City
[Conditions QuestCondition CurrentAmount]/[Conditions QuestCondition Amount] [AssetData([Conditions QuestCondition Context]) Text]
The Queen is looking forward to having a capital at Crown Falls.

Your city is almost there! It still has some growing to do, but soon enough it will be granted the status of capital of the region. Of course, the Queen will not be satisfied until it's considered a Capital of the Empire, but it's a solid start!

Reach City Status: Capital
[Conditions QuestCondition CurrentAmount]/[Conditions QuestCondition Amount] [AssetData([Conditions QuestCondition Context]) Text]
The Queen longs to see the metropolis of her dreams.

The Queen had a very clear vision from the moment she set eyes on Crown Falls: to create a vast metropolis, the most beautiful and advanced in the whole of her Empire — nay, in the world. That dream is closer to reality than ever before.

Reach City Status: Metropolis
[Conditions QuestCondition CurrentAmount]/[Conditions QuestCondition Amount] [AssetData([Conditions QuestCondition Context]) Text]
The Queen revels in the metropolis you have built.
To reach the next city status, you must attract a certain number of residents. Build enough residences for them, and make sure at least their basic needs are fulfilled.
The Queen runs no secular state: if this city is to become an imperial capital, she needs a church to remind her people it was an almighty God who chose her for the throne.
The Queen wants you to build a church.

Standing at the southernmost tip of the Old World, Crown Falls is the perfect location for a commercial port to connect to the wider world. The Queen therefore insists on your improvement of the city's harbour area.
The Queen wants you to enlarge your harbour area.

The Queen is set on turning Crown Falls into a landmark of culture — a place to attract distinguished visitors from far and wide. Though they say culture is priceless, tourists tend to be quite lucrative too...
The Queen wants you to promote culture.

Since Her Majesty is resolved to show she is a modern Queen, and that Crown Falls is the spearpoint of imperial progress, there seems no better way to do this than with flashy displays of electricity.
The Queen wants you to light up the streets of Crown Falls.
The Queen envisions a World's Fair at Crown Falls.
Your city at Crown Falls is almost unparalleled! The one thing that could elevate it even further would be to hold the greatest World's Fair ever seen.
The Queen is exultant to see the World's Fair at Crown Falls.
The Queen is happy to see the World's Fair progressing well.
WHERE IS OUR QUEEN!?

Breaking news! Her Majesty the Queen seems to have vanished! No official statement has been released as yet, but Her Majesty's steward, Sir Archibald Blake, appeared frantic when seen descending the palace steps this morning...
BEHOLD THE SCEPTRE OF CAPON

An exhibition to show off the reclaimed Sceptre of Capon — an heirloom said to run in the blood of Her Majesty and epitomize the triumph over La Corona at Trelawney — opened its grand doors earlier today. The queuing was endless, for not only were there denizens of Trelawney in attendance, but curious and patriotic visitors from all corners of the empire.
WARDEN OF TRELAWNEY

After great service to both a city and a nation, [Participants Current Profile CompanyName] has been officially appointed Warden of Trelawney and Governor of Crown Falls at a grand ceremony conducted by Her Majesty The Queen, Empress Royal of The Southern Territories.
Sail to the specified location with your salvager.
Select your salvager and click on "Dive". Then just sit back and wait for your diving bell to return from the depths.
Obtain an item with echo-location from Old Nate and activate it.
Follow the signals from the echo-locator to find diving spots throughout the region.
Look for the island that matches the map and dive where the X marks the spot.
Old Nate can never get enough scrap for his projects. He'd be delighted if you could give him any you find during your dives.
Old Nate is after a specific bit of sunken machinery to help inspire his own designs. Be on the lookout during your dives — he'll no doubt be willing to give you something for it.
Old Nate wishes to conduct post-mortems on some of the more peculiar species of deep-dwelling sea life, knowing their many adaptations will be able to inspire his own designs.
Old Nate wants you to keep a lookout for any ancient technology on the seabed. This region was once a cradle of civilisation, and good ideas are timeless.
Old Nate wants you to recover a sacred pirate talisman before the pirates do, lest it bring about their reunification and resurgence. Either that, or because it'll sell for a lot of gold.
A peculiar society, believing themselves the descendants of Atlantis, will do all they can to prevent you discovering the city of their forefathers.
Old Nate has acquired a treasure map from a dubious source. The marked co-ordinates will lead you either to riches, or a whole world of trouble.
Old Nate has found an area for you to scan with an echo sounder. Believe it or not, one of his underlings claims to have seen an underwater city there, inhabited by nymphs.

Old Nate has found another promising spot for you to scan with the echo sounder. Up, up and away from the action as usual, he saw no reason to get involved until the fighting was over. While not unsympathetic towards the rebel cause, he sees no reason not to loot their ship now it's good and sunk.
A flotilla of mines surround a diving spot that Old Nate thinks very promising indeed. He just needs someone brave enough — or foolish enough — to go there for him.

Old Nate has asked you to avoid some mines laid by unscrupulous looter-rival Scofield, who is trying to plunder a popular trade route. If there happen to be any victims already though, Old Nate sees no harm in picking through the bodies.
The (very) elusive Scofield has been laying mines to snare unsuspecting ships again. Old Nate nobly urges you to do the right thing once more, and destroy them.
Old Nate wants you to bring him some soap, so that his employees can keep the automata in clean working order.
Old Nate wants you to bury him in spectacles, providing him with a stock of assorted lenses for his new inventions.
Old Nate has asked you to deliver some materials in their purest form.
Old Nate wants you to deliver some modern technology for him to examine and re-purpose.
Old Nate is missing that special something to bring one of his creations to life. He hopes you'll have what he needs.
Old Nate swears by fish oil as a daily supplement, and would like you to deliver some for him and his employees. There seems to be a silent accord that it'll do them all good.
Old Nate is desperate for some caffeine to keep him ticking through the night as he works on his inventions. Sounds like his employees are depending on it too.
Old Nate wants you to photograph a production facility in order to see how modern factories make things.
Old Nate is trying to recover some of the spoils of war, even while the fighting still rages! Wary of being sucked in, he has asked for your protection.
Old Nate is constructing a mechanical wonder — a lifelike automaton designed to go about its business like a human — and he needs your help with the parts.
Old Nate doesn't care for grand occasions, but the challenge of making elaborate fireworks is just too tempting for him to resist. He wants you to bring him all he needs to get started.
Just so you know, any old scrap you find, I'll be interested in it. The grubbier and tattier the better.
A paper company ship sank 'round here. Perhaps you can help me sniff out a story? Maybe a gummed-up print press...
Drill bits or bits of drill — not fussed — need 'em for me next bore. There must be some down there, what with all the quarrying along our coasts nowadays.
As a self-sustaining bloke, I'd be overjoyed to see any smashed-up hydroelectric wheels you find, alright?
Obsolete machines can tell us a lot — almost all the best ideas lie screwed up at the bottom of the paper bin.
Best to learn from other people's mistakes, I say. There's no shortage of ship turbines down there, thanks to all them accidents that made way for the steamships we know today.
We'll never surpass Mother Nature's powers of invention, I don't imagine. Not unless we start taking her weirdest creations apart, and stirring through their insides.
Fascinating food filters they have — all them little planktons bouncing off the blades in their gobs. I can use that!
Fascinating food filters they have — all them little planktons bouncing off the blades in their gobs. I can use that!
This one's not for science, by the by — it's for eating. I got a taste for it when I was out ballooning in the east. Now, which bit was the liver again...?
This thing is nine-tenths water! Imagine that! Boggles the mind it does — but as a matter-of-fact, I'm working on some organics myself...
Ancient-looking thing, eh? But that's a sign it's stood the test of time, like all the greatest inventions...
I accumulate know-how the same way I accumulate junk. Down on the seabed lie all the little tidbits of wisdom left to us by our forefathers — it'd be a terrible shame not to cannibalise 'em, eh?

The pirates are desperate for that ring! Fend 'em off, or the power of the old pirate kings will be restored, and piracy will rule the seas once more! Also, if they pinch it I won't be able to sell it.
Oh gawd, get yer tridents out — it's the Society of Atlanteans again! If they reckon their ancient city's down there, they'll stop at nothing to keep its entrance a secret.
I've got this one treasure map... And it's not that I don't trust the rotten human that gave it me, but... we won't know if it's a trap 'til we dive. That's where you come in...
I knew it! That map was as genuine as me back tooth. Here's your share of the spoils, me old bird.
Sorry about that mix up — win some, lose some. Don't let one dodgy tip-off dent your enthusiasm, or next time you could be missing out!

One of my... employees... swears they were 'nabbed by sea nymphs — wined and dined in the sunken court of a coral queen. Far be it from me to disbelieve them — why not sound it out with that ocarina I gave yer?

I took me seat up in the gods to watch Her Majesty drub another of her poor, oppressed colonies into submission — and I'm pretty sure I'm the only one that noticed that tragic beaut go down with all its plunder... Find the echo, it's down there somewhere!

Since I'm a poor frail old man who never leaves his workshop, (ahem) I need a brave navigator to recover something precious to me. Alright, I won't lie, there'll be mines everywhere — place is a ruddy lobster trap. The cache down there though, corr!

When villains like Scofield kill to deprive people of their possessions... I know I ain't so bad. He set mines on a major seaway — think of all those lives! ...'Course, anything wrecked already is fair game though, right?
Scofield's up to his old tricks again — fancy laying mines in a tranquil reef! You'll blow up those charges for me, won't yer? My only concern is for the welfare of the passing ships, y'see...
Lovely — now I can gather all the loose sea sponge I need! Eh? What, Scofield? Oh, right — THAT Scofield. Well, why didn't you say?! Ha! Showed him didn't we, eh? Hmm.
A bit of shine is dandy, but if the automata aren't kept clean, their mechanisms jam. They're a sorry sight when it happens. It's like they've lost all self-respect.
There's nothing wrong with my beady eyes — twenty-twenty vision, me! No, I want glasses for the lenses — for me telescopes and such.
It's good to have some alloys...
Gimme some spangly dust...
I'm on the lookout for metals in particular...
I like tearing new stuff apart with me talons. So much so I'll even pay you to bring it me — how about that?
I'm missing a few last bits and bobs...
A spoonful of oil a day stops me rusting up — and all me employees, too! They're made in my image, them machine-heads!
You can't expect to work all night without coffee to sip... My employees practically run on the stuff!
So how do you run them power plants of yours then?
I'd like a few more assembly lines of my own, and was hoping for some inspiration...
Clocks take a lot of fiddling about to understand, they does! Wouldn't hurt to save a bit of time, eh?

If you're a scavenger, you can't always wait for the battle to die down — and yet I don't bloody-well want them thinking I'm taking part neither. What I'm trying to say is — I need you as a human shield... Hahaha!

I've always dreamt of sophistication. Not for meself, you understand, but for me automata. They still ain't nothing like humans though, even after five-hundred-and-thirty-odd tries. Perhaps I could use your brains for nr. 531?
Nahhhh — even with your help, the 531 ain't anywhere close to being perfect. One for the scrapheap, methinks. Unless you want it, of course?

Right — this time, a completely different line of automata. I find it's always easier to get sense out of these bloody things if you put them in their place. Talking of which — ha! — mind giving us a hand?
After all that effort, this is one of the worst I've ever made! Ruddy thing keeps combusting on me! If you want to take it off me hands, I'm not going to stop you...
I bloody swear, this is my last try before I go back to making cars and zeppelins like any sensible person. Reckon I've learned me lessons from the Mk.8 — long live Mk.9!

I should've called it the IncinerN8, stupid ruddy thing! I mean it has its moments, I'll give it that, but I'm not risking all me other stuff on its behalf. If you want it, take it — I've lost me appetite for automata.
Nothing gives me a thrill like messing around with gunpowder!
Right! These ones are going to be even more spectacular...
And people say I'm anti-social! I'm about to provide something that'll warm the hearts of all them folks at Archie's next royal display! I promise it's no plot — I'm not that kind of guy.
The scrappiest possible kind of scrap.
Scrap that's not so crap.
You can already see these rare metals glistening in Old Nate's widening eyes.
[AssetData([NotificationContext CharacterGUID]) Text] presents you with a salvager.
[AssetData([NotificationContext CharacterGUID]) Text] offers you a new salvager.
[AssetData([NotificationContext CharacterGUID]) Text] offers you a diving bell quest.

[AssetData([NotificationContext CharacterGUID]) Text] offers you a diving bell quest.
The captain encourages you to find the treasure.
The captain informs you that the diving bell has returned.
The Queen speaks her mind.
Vasco makes conversation.
This retired diving bell was buffed and polished before being put on display, but it still has a faint salty smell.
In the honour of the brilliant inventor, Nathaniel Spoondr– wait, did the eyes just move...?
The artist's intention was to encapsulate the spirit of the industrial revolution, its technological advancements and the labour movement.

Do you really want to destroy all buildings and residences on Crown Falls?
This will immediately abort all of the quests for the story of Sunken Treasures.

Open Map
Treasure Hunt
SUNKEN TREASURES

Follow the Queen to Cape Trelawney; a new session with an immense continental island. Remarkable treasures are said to be buried in these waters— the remnants of a great sea battle. You're going to need a diving bell to get them— the newest invention of Old Nate, a nearby drifter. He'll also help turn any rubbish you find into inventions to fuel the growth of your territorial capital!
Explore the story of the Battle of Trelawney, and meet two new characters: Old Nate and Vasco Oliveira.
New Region
Explore and settle in a new session, with multiple islands and one vast continental island.
Diving Bell
Use your new diving bell to recover shiny sunken treasures.
Crazy New Inventions
Craft inventive new items at Old Nate's island with scrap you find.

Searching for a diving spot
Oh yes...King João will be gratified.
A most serendipitous development.
We are but servants to our respective masters…
You are rather subtle.
King João will be displeased…
How very unfortunate.
So…the worm turns…
Simply appalling behaviour…
I am Vasco Oliveira. I conduct the solemn and discreet business of none other than King João of A Coroa — that's La Corona to the plebs.
You have likely met my tedious cousin Vicente...
You can't imagine I wish to stay here at Trelawney, site of the most mortifying defeat in my proud nation's history, out of choice?
We are here on short business, and then we shall be out of your way.
Oh you've nothing to fear from us, we're not cousin Vicente's thuggish band.
That is welcome news.
Of course.
I think not.
Vicente's mother thinks he's too embarassed to come for a family dinner; I daresay I would be too.
I hope the thought of working with A Coroa doesn't disgust you so much to turn my offer down?
The battle of Trelawney is far behind our two nation empires, is it time we compromised?
You'd better dig deep.
I suppose I had better thank you.
Ah! Old scars must run deep.
You think that's bad, I saw Vicente lose an empire in just under a half hour.
Don't beat about the bush.
King João is not a patient man, and I have had to work so very hard for this thankless position…
We're only as good as our last…
Ah! Can I hope it's what we have been waiting for?
Why, pray, are you so keen to do us a favour?
We all have to choose a side sometime…
Oh, just passing through. These are neutral waters, are they not?
I am under no obligation to explain the outrageously expensive apparatus we happen to have aboard.
We have come only to pay our respects beside the grave of a once-great empire.
Strange to see our mighty armada in bits, teeming with barnacles and limpets.
In the years since Vicente's historic failure, our empire has been in steady decline...
Vicente was very green, they should never have given him command…
Domination and conquest. That is how A Coroa became known— and look where it got us.
This land was once the pride of A Coroa; King João's summer retreat, and the proposed location of...well never mind that…
Let you build there, did she? A modern ruler, your Queen, I wouldn't have minded working for her.
It's no great secret then, we are both looking for the Holy Sceptre of Capon...among other things.
If we both delve into the haycock for that very special needle, there's more chance at least one of us snags a bloody thumb.
We may be in a footrace, but there's no need for us to be in each others' way.
The Holy Sceptre of Capon is irreplaceable. Centuries it presided, in the hands of our rulers, the instrument of our glory.
Vicente thought it clever to split our national treasure, and the sceptre, across three different ships. But with the sceptre dismantled, belief evaporated.
Though it was originally forged in three separate parts, only a harebrain like Vicente would have the audacity to dismantle it.
The armada had never lost at sea while the sceptre was present and complete, but Vicente had to overthink it didn't he?
Vicente was supposed to move our national treasure to a secret vault. What could be more secret than the bottom of the sea!?
The bird atop is a proud eagle, what else can it possibly be!? It's the timeless talisman of empire!
Obviously, all of the lost treasure is of the greatest value, but King João has convinced himself the sceptre has the symbolic clout to save our fading empire…
We lost so much treasure, it is easy to become distracted from the main prize…
Oh, so Old Nate let it slip he has been unfaithful? Dirty little man.
We do not, as that oleaginous stinkerer does, refer to the holy staff of capon, as a "chicken stick".
Your Queen will no doubt claim the Sceptre of Capon runs in the blood of both our royal lines. A claim you can rest assured, is entirely false.
João has been an utterly incompetent King, but nothing compared to your Queen's father.
Your Queen certainly seems to have inherited her mother's traits.
I can't tell you how expensive all this diving apparatus was, and so far it has proved more than useless.
We were only to stop here briefly, but now it seems we will be stuck here the entire summer.
When are we going to dredge up something meaningful, I wonder?
Oh dear, I seem to have found some of the sceptre! But how will you piece it together now?
If King João can't have his sceptre, neither can your Queen.
I can only apologise, it seems our two sides are destined to be at odds.
You must know, the last thing I want is a repeat of the battle of Trelawney.
I'd prefer for us not to be at each other's throats like this…
We have circumnavigated each other too long, it is time we went head-to-head.
Ever feel you know exactly what is going to happen, but utterly powerless to stop it?

Oh, keep the wretched bird! This is the second time my family have been humiliated here, cursed place! I must return to face my fate at the hands of King João. None of your pity thank you, it has been a long time coming.
You gave it to that filthy mechanical bluebottle? The blasphemy! History's greatest treasure, now in the oily hands of one who calls it a "chicken stick"!

I'm perplexed and astonished by your kindness. The sceptre may not save A Coroa, but thanks to you, it may very well save me. I hope your Queen is more forgiving of you than her father would have been…

I am not here to escape domestic dissatisfaction, but to address it. Our nation has lost its pride! But pride can be restored! This place, Trelawney, is the site of my father's great naval victory over our rivals La Corona.
La Corona wanted to move their national treasures while they still had chance, but the fleet caught them in the act.
I am curious as to how father was able to relay these instructions so quickly from such a distance.
The child that was me played out the battle of Trelawney countless times in the parlour on a miniature campaign table.
Father's command from up on the cliff, that's what won us the day. Not the actions of the much-trumpeted Admiral Nadasky.
We were the victors here at Trelawney, yet all the spoils remain in the lap of Poseidon.
He may have been on the winning side, but father always said Admiral Nadasky's carelessness had meant the Sceptre being lost to the waves.
It was father's greatest regret that he was never able to hold the sceptre. I'm sure that insecurity about his position made him cling to power all the more perfervidly.
The Sceptre of Capon has long granted its bearers indisputable authority. But it sank to the depths, along with La Corona's fleet.
We share a bloodline, you know. I have as much right to the Sceptre as King João.
As this could easily be my last unofficial visit anywhere, I intend to enjoy my freedom.
I had rather a stuffy childhood. So being out here, free and incognito, has one feeling pretty giddy.
Ever been on a treasure hunt? Mother let me out in the garden on sunny days.
Dear old Archie has been like a father to me, but had I told him I was coming here, he'd have sent for far too many flowers and servants.
Finding the sunken Sceptre of Capon — the trophy we never claimed for that victory — will remind us of our past glories and restore the people's faith in their monarch.
It's obvious why they're here. It's the same reason we're here; for the emblematic power that sceptre will grant to whoever owns it.
One imagined if one was secretive enough, La Corona might not discover one's intentions — yet of course, here they are at the double.
I saw it from the deck: an impish little man dredging up bits and pieces. He may be exactly what we require…
If we are to find anything in this graveyard, we might as well commission the vulture.
I will happily shake those greasy paws if it means I get my sceptre.
But we can't afford a war with La Corona — feeble though they may be — so I'm afraid you'll have to rely on wits to beat this Oliveira to it.
Could this be…? This is the journal of my father's strategist, Nadasky!
Help me build it, and find the sceptre, and I shall designate you Warden of Trelawney, my official representative in these waters.
I see we are not the first to pay Old Nate for these coordinates... I only hope we are the first to find what's down there.
We shall build a new capital of the realm here, perhaps call it Crown Falls, in view of the sparkling cataracts you see the island posesses! This may be my greatest legacy.
Admiral Nadasky writes that he defied the orders of my father! That treasonous Jack Tar, father should have had his head!
This waterlogged log is in a terrible state. Did you not bring any art restorers with you?
When the exhibition is over, do remember to give it to my busbies, so I can toss it in with the rest of the bling.
Now, if it were the centrepiece of a grand exhibition, the people in these parts would be reminded of just how far-reaching the influence of an empress can be.
My mother had a great deal of trouble saying the words "ocean bottom", but I find I have no difficulty at all!
What a remarkable innovation! Can I have a go?
The empire needs these potterers; those willing to try new things.
He's with us, one hopes? Or is he the peculiar sort who doesn't take sides?
Isn't he the spit of those chaps in the beggar's opera? We do so want to like the poor.
Some of father's orders were utterly baffling…
Father should have trusted those with naval expertise… I mean, it's now quite obvious he had little of that expertise himself.
I always believed my father, when he claimed to be the unsung mastermind of the battle of Trelawney, but it was Nadasky all along that was saving his blushes.
I may have been wrong about Admiral Nadasky. Upon my return to the capital, I shall have a great big pillar built in his honour.
The facts here are plain. Had they followed only father's orders, La Corona would have won.
The King, my father, draws further away from his daughter with each new revelation in Nadasky's log.
This log is proof Nadasky may at least have had good intentions in his defiance of father's orders.
This entry shows that they persisted in deviating from father's instructions…
Another part of Admiral Nadasky's logbook… Fascinating reading…
One is no dunce-hatted imbecile, but I rather think we'll need a class swot or two to decipher this; a university with a budding college of palaeographers to decipher Nadasky's shameful handwriting.
Oh, it's all much clearer now! Do thank your expert bods at the University for all their brio.
So you're playing best of three? I hope you realise the seriousness of such a gamble — it seems you had better win.
If you had the guts to bet my sceptre, you had better get to it first…
What? We know the spot now. Or do you need a ducking?
It must be around here somewhere. Proceed with your... goobling, or however you call it.
We're groping in the dark here! How does that carrion bird know where to plunge?
This is one of the locations Nadasky mentioned in the journal. Prepare your diving bell!
What Nadasky writes of here… The heroes that tilted the battle in our favour were stranded! They never returned, but we may still learn what became of them.
A mere frigate against a ship-of-the-line...? Only Father's obsession with the sceptre could have clouded his judgement so! The last piece must be down there in the murk.
Nadasky sketched the Santíssima Vitória in his journal before it wrecked on the western coast.
Still, his detailed observations of the battle are priceless… We must investigate the locations he describes.
Don't you think this place resembles Nadasky's description?
According to the journal, this is where all those ships sank…
We found it! But wait — where is the grand Eagle at its top? This is but a portion of the rod!
The sceptre is worthless if it is not whole.
Why did their Admiral Silva think it prudent to break up a lucky sceptre?
Let us see if you have the prowess of Admiral Nadasky…
In a way, I would be excited to see the battle of Trelawney recreated!
This Oliveira reeks of defeat! You just have to tip the scales...
I dreamed of seeing such a battle at Trelawney every night as a child!
Marvellous! You know, now I that see it, it really doesn't look much like an eagle, does it? Oh well — none of my subjects will ever dare to question it!
My gratitude is heartfelt. This is a new emblem of state behind which my subjects will surely rally!
I hear it has been stolen from the exhibition?! Crime is becoming a terrible problem for the empire. I will find that sceptre, but for now, I'm sorry your efforts have gone in vain.
So the Sceptre of Capon has somehow made it into the hands of La Corona? Well-played… but it jolly billy better not have been you responsible!
But, in the end, I care less for the sceptre, and more for Nadasky's revelations concerning my father.
The father I saw — the great tactician — appears never to have existed; and yet a daughter's love prevails through the absurdity of his weakness.
Yes! Oh, for a second I thought he'd beaten us to it!
Now it's time for Vasco to hold up his end of the bargain.
We have the eagle! And Vasco promised to yield the pommel — he promised!
We have the pieces! Now it's time to puzzle it together...
I have not undergone all this trouble so that flea may lay his oily digits on it!
As if I'd leave my sceptre under his supervision…
Haven't we plenty of scholars versed in the art of restoration already?
There's no use owning such a treasure, unless it can be grandly displayed for my subjects. They shall see that — in ambition — I am at least my father's equal!
The most precious of cherries to top the cake!
Mr. Oliveira was truly a man of his word. Had it been me, I'd never have let him have our piece of the sceptre.
In particular I am indebted to you for helping me see the king, my father, as he really was — warts and all.
Well it's high time I returned to rescue poor old Archie — he may otherwise start chattering about his bowels. Look after Crown Falls for me, won't you? I only really care for the taxes now.
There is no mistaking it; this was once La Corona's great flagship. The eagle must be here.
A humble outpost now, perhaps. But it promises to become the largest capital of my empire!
I see the new settlement is progressing well. The empire needs to develop a lasting presence here in the south.
I can see it — a brilliant metropolis rising here, from the memory of the victory my father masterminded. A shining new jewel in the crown of my empire.
The warm southern air makes me feel strong and well. Purposeful, you might say.
I can still smell father's victory here at Trelawney, it is his greatest legacy.
It is far from being the capital I envisioned. There is much to do!
Once my capital is all set, Archie will let me return to these sunny shores any time I like!
My dreams — one's youthful imaginings of this place of triumph — so dutifully have you made whole.
This is it: my metropolis, standing tall and proud — forever a symbol of my greatness.
You call this a capital!?
If this is to become a radiant metropolis, we'll need to make some additions…
How could these people possibly go without this!? I know I couldn't…
Beautiful! And quite overdue!
The magic of the crown: I ask for it, and it appears!
This city is now closer to magnificence!
I have one last vision: a World's Fair, sitting atop this magnificent metropolis!
It will not be an imperial capital until the World's Fair is complete.
The World's Fair! This may very well be the finest city in the whole of my empire!
People will come from far and wide to behold the Sceptre of Capon — the ultimate exponent of my authority.
Welcome to Trelawney, graveyard to thousands; the gift that keeps on giving, he he.
Trelawney, site of one of the great naval battles, now a veritable trove of lost treasure.
There's plunder to be had if you sink down deep enough. I may be able to help you along a tad with that.
There's a lot of meat and cartilage left on the bones of these ships, especially on their underbellies.
Don't worry about what he's up to. You just concentrate on your own digging.
This Vasco looks stiffer than week-old bat kabob— on his last legs, like. No match for someone like you.
Work with Oliveira? Who said that, he he! No, no, no — I'm all yours!
Yaps a lot about his cousin, I find. Easy to boot a man when he's down, eh?
Even after all this time, you still see the odd eyeball surface, belched up from that tomb of a trench below.
Terrible, wars, ain't they? Well, for the luckless beggars who have to fight in them… ha ha ha!
Sometimes you'll see a skull on the seabed, watchin' you like. I just smile back.
If you're waiting for them dead sailors to give you permission, you'll be waiting a long time, ha ha ha ha!
Don't plan on fixing yourself there too long — this place is like a thoroughfare for conqueror-types.
Your peninsula might be under Queenie's umbrella for now, but I know from experience — nothing ever lasts.
If you don't pick a side, you can't wind up on the wrong one.
While the big boys and girls are duking it out, the likes of you and I can sneak stuff away while they ain't looking.
=char(39) Course, my expertise costs a pretty penny, he he.
What your Queenie wants is a diving bell. I could uh… lease you my prototype.
Tired of coming back up with nothing but scrap? I can point you to the good stuff, for a reasonable fee...
Do you think I got this far by throwing stuff away? Bring that rubbish to me, I'll polish it up.
Not half bad, eh? I can turn around your junk, so long as I get to keep the odd smidge of gimcrackery.
Alright, you got me. I've been helping Vasco. Now, don't take offence, old mucker — it=s only common sense to back both horses.
How's about I do you a special favour — just for you mind — to make up for my heinous betrayal of trust…
I'm more interested in all the other sweet collector's items down there.
All so hung up on that chicken-on-a-stick — what about the rest of the Trelawney hoard!
Forget all that old flannel about her father — old Queenie's in it for the loot just as much as we are.
Don't forget — Admiral Nadasky disobeyed his King, and it all paid off.
Being a prototype, I will ask you sign a waiver for yer life, before you use it.
Without the metal shell, you're as vulnerable as a homeless hermit crab.
The Trelawney hoard's a diversion — everyone's forgotten all the older, more valuable finds.
I have a personal asphyxiation with underwater treasure.
Watch out for them octopuses, they like to keep all the good stuff under wraps.
The diving bell gives them sharks something to chew on, at least.
See anything shiny down there, then?
Any mermaids open their purses of pearls for yer, then?
Never be too sure that the life's all gone out of something.
It'd cost you an arm and a leg to buy that new.
Waste not, want not.
It's been reincarnated!
Looks like it was made to be split into three. Shouldn't be too hard to put back together...
There you have it! One reconstituted chicken stick, good as new.
The maiden descent for me beautiful diving bell! I've got all three of me fingers crossed for you, you little ocean-going guinea pig, you.
Botched the dive, did ya? Glass all get misted up or something?
Hopefully the water won't gush in like the only other time I tested it. Well, good luck!
Either you've got the bends, or you've come back disappointed.
Corr, that'll fetch a few clams…
Now here's something; a proper pressure gauge. You'll be able to go to much deeper and darker places now…
This balloon is a rather special innovation of mine! Gives you a much better view of them hidden reefs!
Now this is arguably my greatest invention to date! 'S'like invisible hands reaching through the air, and… there! That sound will keep you true.
I can put something together for you, but Oliveira dropped by a while ago asking for the same thing, and I'm all out of rubbish.
He's quite clever that Vasco, I'll give him that.
Maybe I'll wait until you two finish each other off before diving in.
Another battle of Trelawney? Oh goody!
There you go! I told you I'd give you special treatment.
There! Never say I don't care about you — even if it is true.
The spaniel fetches the stick for its Queen then, eh? Well, a man like me can't afford to be loyal.
It'd be funnier if you gave the three of us one bit each…
Give me the sceptre? Corr, I'm honoured! And rich! Haha, good on yer — my absolute gamble on you has paid off.
You do realise I'm just going to sell this sceptre to the highest bidder, right? So no moral victory for you, if that's what you thought it was.
You gave it back to La Corona, 'cos it was theirs to begin with!? Whatever happened to finders keepers?
Maybe that miserable geezer Vasco will be happy now. Or maybe not. That's how it is with miserable geezers.
Exhibition royalties? Blimey, you're really milking that chicken stick for all its got, ain't yer?
I swear something funny's going on down there!
Something's amiss with your diving bell.
If anything's happened, I'm not liable.
Old Nate's Workshop
Old Nate's Harbour

Reef Aquarium
