Salvage with Diving Bell
Diving spot discovered
Phragmites australis. Whispers along the edges of estuaries.
Abies Lasiocarpa. Grows near the timberline.
Digitalis purpurea. Chopping a spike of foxglove bells will spite the fairies.
Taraxacum officinale. Make a wish and blow its puffballs on their way.
Vaccinium myrtillus. Dyes the mouth a sweet, deep purple.
Sambucus nigra. Home to hummingbirds and warblers.
Mentha balsamea. Leaves a fresh tingle on the tongue.
Cannabis sativa. Weave it into anything — linen garments, rope, even candlewicks...
Convolvulus arvensis. A.k.a. 'field bindweed', which says it all really.
Papaver rhoeas. Bright red dots among the wheat.
Hevea Rigidifolia. A New World spurge producing resinous rubber.
Acropora Cervicornis. A hard coral that reaches out like a tree.
Dendrogyra cylindrus. Figures huddling in the water's gloom.
Nymphaea alba. Frequently accompanied by the croaking of toads.
Saxifraga Oppositifolia. Breaks out among rocks after the thaw.
Roystonea regia. Its giant leaves magically detach in tropical storms.
Cyperus Papyrus. Once used as paper, but also for boats, clothes, and even as food.
Rhododendron. A genus of bold-coloured shrubs so diverse, botanists can't agree on a taxonomy.
Eichhornia Crassipes. An extremely determined invader.
Prunus serrulata. Clouds of graceful blossom to drink and picnic beneath.
Cocos nucifera. Make sure a falling drupe doesn't bonk you on the coco.
Jasminum multiflorum. Unlike its common cousin, the flowers of this eastern star open in the winter.
Magnolia champaca. Its fragrant flowers may be used to adorn statues of Goddesses.
Ocimum tenuiflorum. Its aromatic purple leaves have religious and medicinal uses.
Limonium perezii. They grow in saline soil, dappling coasts with violet corymbs.
Salvia pratensis. Covered in vivid indigo flowers, it's perfect for seasoning meats.
Armeria maritima. Its globes of pink flowers resemble balloons floating along coastal cliffs.
Victoria Amazonica. 'On unbent leaf, in fairy guise... stands Annie, Paxton's daughter.'
Metaxya Rostrata. A primitive fern whose abaxial sori appear in uniform lines.
Montastraea Cavernosa. Its lumpish colonies are likely to trigger trypophobes.
Althaea Officinalis. Its roots may be combined with egg white to form 'pâte de guimauve', a scrummy treat.
Eucalyptus Pauciflora. The cream-cocoa twist of its trunk is reminsicent of inter-muddled putty.
Nelumbo Lutea. A forest of leafen trumpets and soft lemon flowers, stilting up from the water's bed.
Lafoensia acuminata. The bark of its stem is a proven panacea in traditional tonics of the rainforest.
Sarracenia purpurea. Lures careless insects into the digestive soup at the bottom of its pitchers.
Espeletia schultzii. A montane yellow flower living the monastic life with the cacti up in the Páramo.
Puya raimondii. A queen-sized bromeliad producing a multitude of regal red-white flowers.
Entada gigas. Swing howling through the rainforest on these sturdy monkey-ladders.
Phalaenopsis amabilis. This rare and splendid orchid puts one in mind of a nun's cornette.
Polystichum polyblepharum. Its crosiers unfurl pleasingly, bending backward to form tassels.
Eucalyptus caesia. A mallee of the drylands, flowering with cerise and tassel-like weepers.
Protea Susannae. When crushed, the leaves of this bold and bullish flower give off an eggy pong.
Phlomis fruticosa Named in earnest reference to the sacred lands from which they originate.
Nelumbo Nucifera "Perry's Giant Sunburst". The yellow flowers burst open at dawn, like suns floating on the surface of the pond.
Ceiba Samauma. Mesoan stories claim that its twisted limbs are commanded by the evil spirits that dwell in it.
Nymphaea Caerulea. Stone carvings depict the sun god of the delta emerging from its flower bud each morning.
Nymphaea Lotus. The bright red variegations in the foliage resemble the stripes of a tiger.
Nelumbo Nucifera "Angel Wings". The pristine lotus flower that grows over the murky waters symbolizes purity of heart and mind in many religions.
Saraca asoca. The vivid colours of the ashoka blossoms are often mentioned in south-eastern literature as a symbol of love and seduction.
Sansevieria trifasciata. The leaves are sharp and taut, their patterning snake-like.
Stanhopea insignis. A remote speckled orchid that relies upon the goodwill of bees to pollinate.
Ceratozamia mexicana. A mezoan oddity defined by the horn-like protrusions upon its cones.
Echium candicans. A hardy plant needing comparatively little water that blooms electric blue.
Ziziphus Lotus. Eating its flowers and fruits causes a pleasant drowsiness that made legendary sailors forget their natal shores.
Taxus Baccata. An earthly remnant of the Northern mythical Yggdracca, rising tall from the temple of Uppsidaisi.
Ficus Religiosa. It was beneath its heart-shaped leaves that Siddhattha sat for forty-nine nights and attained enlightenment.
Amorphophallus Titanum. Sometimes known as the corpse flower, this foul-smelling rarity looks rather suggestive.
Echium wildpretii. This eye-catching red bugloss is endemic only to a smattering of volcanic islands in warm seas.
Polypodiopsida Sõnajalaõis. A quasi-mythical pearl of the winter forests, showing only for lovers at summer solstice.
Unclassified. If you've been transformed into a pig, this herb will help return you to your human form.
Asphodelus Infernum. Fields of its ghost-white shade greet new arrivals as they journey down to the underworld.
Ficus Benghalensis. Temples are erected under the immense canopy of this sacred fig.
Bertholletia Excelsa. A gigantic nut-bearing tree of the rainforest, frequented by capuchins.
This piece takes one back to the times when the first Old World explorers arrived on the shores of the New World, and discovered its many wonders.
This old song sparks memories of south-eastern spices and a never-quite-forgotten fascination with the vibrant cultures of those parts of the world.
A piece composed for a speculative future, covered in snow, in which humans have to endure life on the harsh poles of the Earth and colonise the moon.
This melody evokes a world swallowed by the ocean in retaliation for humankind's abuse and floods the audience with a gentle urge to care for the environment.
The song of the century! One of countless progress and discoveries, but also one preocuppied with exploring and embracing the past.
Thematic Exhibitions
Increased attractiveness for cultural items that belong to: [ItemAssetData([RefGuid]) ItemSetUpgradesFormatted].
Construction in Cultural Buildings
BOTANICAL GARDEN INAUGURATED

Morning-glory sprinkled archways welcome visitors to our city's first botanical garden, a glorious haven for nature in the midst of our municipality. Horticulturist and curator Maxime LaFleur guarantees that the garden will be able to foster species from all around the globe.
NEW GROUNDS FOR BOTANICAL GARDEN

New gardens take root in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName]. Perfumiers, poets and costumiers are already drawing inspiration from the intoxicating fragrances, vivacious colours and delicate herbaceous shapes.
MUSIC PAVILION OPENS UP
Brand new music pavilion sets the tone for [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName]'s merry residents. Nearby streets will be flooded with delightful tunes and contagious humming.
PARADISE IN THE CITY

A passageway to wonderland was opened today at the World's Fair Botanical Exhibition in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName]. Get lost in a fantasia of coiled vines, kaleidoscopic colours and feasts of fragrances!
AUTUMN FALLS ON BOTANICAL EXHIBIT

Garden of delights being uprooted after great botanical exhibition ends at the World's Fair in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], leaving only vivid colours in the imagination of the enchanted attendants.

A finely sculpted piece of marble, turned a cradle for blossoms.

A tranquil pond for nature-gazing and verse-writing. Although they're actually geese...

Like other cultural buildings, the botanical garden provides attractiveness to your city.
The botanical garden displays plants in its own module: the empty plot.

Interesting plants can be found in many ways: launching botanical expeditions, completing quests for certain characters, browsing Madame Kahina's stock, or organizing botanical exhibitions at your World's Fair!
You can connect your cultural modules using pathway ornaments. Pathway ornaments must be built from the cultural building's menu to connect its modules.
You can build one music pavilion per cultural building. Keep an eye out for sheet music to equip it with, and enjoy the melodies!
Music will set the theme for your cultural building. Try to choose one that goes well with your exhibits!
A splendid haven for flora from every corner of the world.
Ready to nurture whichever botanical species.
The perfect acoustics for any sort of melody.
Trees and Flowers
A marvelous display of unique plant species, spreading their scents and colour throughout your city.
It's no mere horticultural fair, but a triumph for all the senses! The colour, the perfume — some are even edible! I declare this a modern 'Hanging Gardens'!
The plant was colourful and beautiful, but I'm afraid it turned out to be a smelly and carnivorous denizen of the jungle!
New little tenants for our public flower pots!

Half trees, half flower, but wholly beautiful.

Big Botanical Garden

Botanical Garden Modules
BOTANICA

Be the first to build the grand botanical gardens of the era: dreamlands of sinuous trees, impossible colour and scented blooms imported from afar. Send out botanical expeditions, or take the botanical craze to your World's Fair to get your hands on the rarest specimens to complete all the garden sets and inspire new applications of botany — such as extended fertilities! Let your botanical garden blossom with the new pathway ornaments and revel in classic Anno themes with the new music pavilion.
New Botanical Items
Collect over 50 different plant species for your botanical garden.
Pathway Ornaments
Beautify and expand your cultural buildings with a new type of ornament.
Music Pavilion
Revel in delightful orchestral arrangements of classic Anno themes in the new music pavilion.

Enables upscaling using AMD FidelityFX image sharpening. This improves the game's performance and is especially useful on large screen resolutions (e.g. 4K).

Enables larger subtitles.

Lady Faithful introduces herself.
She is launching a rescue mission to find her husband's lost expedition.
Lady Faithful offers you a reward if you aid her in the search for her husband.
Old Nate is lending his mechanical expertise to Lady Faithful's rescue effort.

For two years, Lady Jane Faithful has been preparing to find her husband's expedition, which got lost in the Arctic while looking for the Northwest Passage. She hopes you will agree to become the last and most crucial member of her rescue team, and is offering handsome rewards in exchange. But the journey will not be easy: if you don't want to meet the same fate as Sir John and his crew, you'd best prepare for a difficult expedition.
To start the expedition, go to the World Map and select the Passage Expedition.
Click on Sir John's old trading post to take it over
Clear:
Lady Faithful wants to establish a base of operations at Sir John's abandoned camp.
Lady Faithful asks you to clear the remains of the camp.
Lady Faithful rewards you for your progress.
Lady Faithful notices a heap of stones in the camp.

You may have survived the journey to the Arctic and found Sir John's old camp, but the search for his lost expedition has only just begun. Lady Faithful has suggested establishing a base of operations at the place her husband picked to winter, before continuing the search from there.
Abandoned Tents
Click on the abandoned tents to remove them. This will take a little time.
Pick up the marked object by left-clicking.
Lady Faithful is eager to learn the contents of Sir John's Log.l

November 14th, 1847:

Made camp on King William Island, it shall shelter us for the winter.

January 3rd, 1848:

Met a group of Inuit to the Northwest. They were reluctant at first, but later approached us to trade for iron. They offered us dead seals, which o.c. we civilly declined —having enough fine canned food aboard Styx and Hades to last a lifetime— but instead they may know of a route to NW passage.

March 11th, 1848:

The Inuit led us to a channel heading deeper into the ice. Inuit look worried, but our instruments report freeze is thinning by the day — time for our mighty icebreakers to prove their prowess! Soon we shall be the first to cut the miracle shipping canal bridging East and West! We set out tomorrow.
Logbook of Commander Sir John Reginald Patience St. Smythyn Faithful K.C.H. F.R.G.S.
You have found part of Sir John's log in a heap of stones at the centre of their abandoned camp. It must surely provide some clues as to where they headed next.
You'll find the log in the Items section of your Trading Post.
Old Nate tells you to start by building shelters and a canteen.
It's time to set up camp in the Arctic. As per usual, the first step is to provide some housing for the explorers, and a canteen for them to warm up between shifts.
Heaters run on coal. Select the heater to check the status of its transport cart.
The charcoal kiln is already warmed up! You don't need to worry about building it within reach of a heater.
Factories and shelters require heat. Make sure the heating system reach them.
Old Nate urges you to fire up the heaters.
Sustain [Conditions QuestCondition CurrentAmount]/[Conditions QuestCondition Amount]% of [AssetData([Conditions QuestCondition Context]) Text] supply for [Conditions QuestCondition TimeLimit >> time]

Build near Heater:
[Conditions QuestCondition CurrentAmount]/[Conditions QuestCondition Amount] [AssetData([Conditions QuestCondition Context]) Text]
Old Nate warns you to build your buildings close to a heater.
Old Nate urges you to keep the heaters well-supplied with coal.

The Arctic cold is no small challenge. If you don't want your recruits to freeze to death, you'll have to keep them warm. Old Nate has devised a heating system that runs on coal, but watch out — that heat won't travel far!
Lady Faithful is keen to find the Inuit mentioned in the log.
Find the Inuit by studying Sir John's log
Follow the Inuit boat
The Inuit Qumaq is willing to show you where the lost expedition went.
Qumaq says that ice blocks the path the lost expedition took.
Lady Faithful wants you to find a way to continue the search.
Lady Faithful gives you funds to help clear the channel of ice.
Qumaq warns you that visibility will be low in these conditions.
The log Sir John left in the abandoned camp mentions that the Inuit gave them directions. Perhaps if you found the Inuit, they would be willing to lead you to the lost crew.
Sir John's log speaks of the whereabouts of the Inuit people. Read it carefully.
When following a ship, you must stay within range, so as not to lose sight of it.
Lady Faithful asks you to equip a team of explorers to clear the ice.
The explorer is glad you provided pemmican for the mission.
The Explorer asks if the ice-breaching operation is ready to commence.
Thick ice has frozen the channel to the lost expedition. Lady Faithful has given you funds to equip a crack team of explorers, so they can blast a way through.
Lady Faithful is keen to begin the operation.
Lady Faithful wonders how far the icebreakers could have got.
The explorer is aghast at their obstinacy.

Find:
HMS Hades and Styx
Lady Faithful wonders why the expedition left their ships behind.
Lady Faithful ponders how the search can be continued.
Old Nate says you must continue the search by air.
Old Nate says you need technicians and a hangar to build your own airships.
Lady Faithful gives you the funds to help build an airship.
Lady Faithful has spotted the icebreakers.
The channel the expedition took has now been cleared. Follow the route the expedition ships took deeper into the ancient ice.
The technician introduces himself.
Old Nate is glad to see that you've made a start on a hangar.
Lady Faithful believes airships will help you find the lost expedition.
Lady Faithful commends you for building the hangar.
Lady Faithful is astounded at your achievement in building a hangar.
If you want to find the lost crew of HMS Hades and Styx, you're going to need airships. For that, you'll need technicians and an airship hangar.
Old Nate is willing to provide the gas you need to inflate your first airship.

Pick up near your Trading Post:
Gas
Old Nate gives you gas for your airship.
Old Nate congratulates you on building your first airship.
Lady Faithful is delighted the search can continue now that you have an airship.
Now that your hangar is finished, you can construct your first airship — although you will need gas to inflate it. Just this once, Old Nate is willing to provide it for you.
You can build an airship at your brand new hangar. Use the gas Old Nate provided you with.
Old Nate says that there are gas deposits beneath the islands to the north.
Settle an Arctic Plateau
Old Nate is glad you can extract your own gas from now on.

Old Nate provided you with enough gas to build your first airship — but if you want more, you'll have to extract it from the islands up north. Good thing you can travel by air now, because steep cliffs render them unreachable from the sea.
Fly over an Arctic plateau with an airship loaded with enough timber and steel to build a Sky Trading Post.

Fly to:
[AssetData([Conditions QuestCondition Context]) Text]
Lady Faithful wants the search to resume where the icebreakers were abandoned.
Qumaq offers to guide you.
Lady Faithful will not be joining you and Qumaq on the search.
Qumaq asks if you are ready to begin the search.

Now that you have an airship to soar above the clouds, your search for the lost expedition can finally continue. Lady Faithful asks that you pick up the trail from their last known location: the abandoned HMS Hades and HMS Styx.
Read Sir John's notes to track him down

April 26th, 1848:

We've been forced to abandon the HMS Styx and HMS Hades. We waited the entire summer for the thaw, but the weather gods were against us: they're still stuck fast in the ice. I am certain we can still find the NW passage by foot, walking inland. We've filled two lifeboats with essential supplies, and will pull them over the snow like sleds. When next we find water, it will be a passage to the east! Then the lifeboats can row us to a safe haven.

May 4th, 1848:

The men tire. Dragging two lifeboats was perhaps ambitious, so they've been stopping to rest at regular intervals.
I have ordered that all remaining supplies be trusted to one of the lifeboats from now on, giving us double the pulling power.
Despite setbacks, morale is good, and we've lost no men since winter on Baffling Island.

May 11th, 1848:

We are at a crossroads. To determine the best way forward, I sent a team led by Cdr. H. Sturgeon through the canyon to the north. A second team led by Lt Cdr. R. Des Yeux went over the snow dunes to the west. The last team, led by Lt Cdr. E. Couch, went towards deep chasms in the east.

May 14th, 1848:

No team has yet returned. Camp supplies are becoming rather scarce, and there's little out here to hunt. I think we'd even gobble up those seals the Inuit offered us now.

May 16th, 1848:

Only two of the three teams have returned. I fear the worst has befallen Edgar Couch's men — a risk we all took the day we volunteered. It's hard out here; cruel. The rest of us are to move without delay; their sacrifice will not be wasted if we make it.
Cdr. Sturgeon reports that his canyon tapered to a dead end. Des Yeux, God thank him, reports something more promising. We will take the path he took. The ground looks too weak for the boat, but I'm sure we'll think of something. We always do.

June 21st, 1848

Perhaps the warnings of these Inuit had worth. The ice desert has been treacherous, and we have lost both men and equipment. I see darkness in the eyes of the living, now that their companions lie buried. If you knew that we are also at the end of our supplies, you might understand their anger.
But they are loyal men, and know they cannot hope to survive alone. They will only challenge me if I admit defeat, and that I refuse.

A sheer mountain lies ahead. I have had to stifle my shock at its sudden appearance, and at the perilous climb we must now undertake, for morale among the men is already low. I would not appear in my right mind as their leader if I asked them to turn and face the horrors of the desert we had all thought behind us. No. We climb. And meeting us at the summit, I believe, will be a view upon the shimmering water of a Northwest Passage that shall sate the hunger.

June 30th, 1848:

Lost my best man, Cdr. Sturgeon, in the mountains. Poor man was too anxious to prove me right. Some made it, but all hungry and desperate. You need shovel-loads to fuel your belly up here, and we have no food at all. There were grunts and growls in the night. Either we eat the resident bears, or they eat us.

August 3rd, 1848:

Sir John has entrusted me, Lt. Cdr. Remi Des Yeux, with the completion of his log, as he no longer has the strength to put pen to paper. Still, there likely won't be many more entries left for me to write.

We are no longer killed by bears, but have been lost days and weeks in high valleys that all look the same, having lost our compass. We are now only six: Captain John Faithful; Sargent, the first mate; Little, an engineer; Hodgson, an assistant surgeon; Irving, a ship's boy; and myself. The boy lives because he is a good lad, and none of us could suffer to eat of him. The bear meat never was going to last, you see. Sir John did have us swear never to speak of that shame, but who does he think we will tell?

August 7th, 1848:

Sir John speaks again. He says the silhouette of a great wolf came to him in his sleep, and that he wishes to meet us.

Our pack is down to three. Sir John, the boy Irving, and me, Remi Des Yeux. We shall remember Sargent, Little and Hodgson. We shall remember the others who tripped and fell, who froze, who fell ill, who starved, who drowned, who were maimed by bears, who slipped on high, or fell through the cracks. And we shall remember those who, when we ran out of food, drew the short straw... in vain!

If a passage exists, we have not found it. But though he is mad, I will accompany Sir John to the end. The ferocious ship's boy, Irving, is our guardian spirit — the same who, with superhuman strength, was able to fend off grown men in the snow who were after his legs for supper.
Qumaq suggests you follow the tracks near the boats.
Qumaq wonders which way they went next.
Qumaq says the expedition had to drop their supplies.
Qumaq says there may be bears about.
Qumaq holds little hope for Sir John and his crew.
Qumaq doubts whether Sir John's crew could have made it.
Lady Jane is delighted to hand you the reward she promised.

Lady Faithful has taken a step back: it is now up to you and Qumaq to scout the vast northern ice cap from above in search of the lost expedition. Your first clues are the icebreakers they left behind, and the eerie tracks that lead away from them...
Zoom in to scan the terrain and look for tracks that may lead you to the lost expedition.
Read the notes carefully to get more clues as to what happened to the crew, and where they were headed next.
Follow the tracks from the icebreakers

Read the notes
Follow the tracks in the snow

Read the notes
Find out which way they went

Read the notes
Find out what happened to them after the climb

Read the notes
Look for the bears they mention

Read the notes
Find out which path they took

Rescue:
The Lost Expedition
The Inuit cannot understand how any of them survived.
Old Nate questions the accuracy of the newspaper coverage.
The lost expedition's odyssey has finally come to an end. All that remains is to bring them safely back home, and collect your final reward.
Old Nate offers advice on building in the Arctic.

The explorers are understandably fed up with pemmican. Although bread wouldn't last a day in the Arctic, tunnbröd — a typical Northern flatbread — would be easy enough to cook on the fire and alleviate their craving, but it requires flour.
Ah, I miss bread... Pemmican is convenient, but- hey, I know! We could make some tunnbröd! I've read about it — it should be easy enough to cook, if we had flour...
The Arctic is dangerous enough without having to worry about slipping in a puddle of melted snow at every step. The explorer has asked you for felt, to line their soles and keep their feet in place.
I learned my fair share of tricks back when I traversed the Pampas. Fishermen lined the soles of their boots with felt to stop them slipping. We could use anything that would help us stay in place!

It looks like you may be staying in the Arctic for quite some time. In that case, the explorer has a suggestion to better insulate the floor of the camp from the cold: laying a thick layer of cement between it and the frozen ground.
Will our mission in the Arctic last much longer...? If so, we might want to look into improving the thermal insulation of our tents. Cement is cold, but the frozen ground is colder!
The explorer has asked you to bring some saltpetre. It looks like she has something in mind.
I have an idea! Could you have a ship bring me some saltpetre?
Yes! Now we only have to spread it on our roads to keep them free of snow! Wait, what do you mean saltpetre isn't the same as salt? Oh...
The explorer's dear little brother is turning eleven! She has never once missed the celebration before, so she has asked you to take a picture of her family, to help her cope with the homesickness.
My family will be celebrating my little brother's birthday. If only I had a tiny window, so I could feel like I'm there at the pub with them... Could you bring me a picture?
The explorer's family is celebrating at a pub in the Old World.

From its endless dreamlike landscapes to its mighty predators, the explorer has grown fascinated by the Arctic. She has asked you to take a picture of one of its wonders, so she can keep the memory close to her heart once the adventure is over.
Harp seal pups are some of the most endearing creatures I've ever come across. Granted, they don't exude the most pleasant of smells, but you can't smell a photograph, can you?
There's a colony of seals at the vast northern ice cap — you'll need an airship to find them.
I wouldn't want to remember whales for the long hours we've spent elbow-deep in their blubber, but rather swimming free — gargantuan yet majestic — breaching off the icy ocean...
Whales can be spotted swimming all across the region.

Polar bears hold an enormous significance to the Inuit people. Not only are they essential for their subsistence, but they honor them as if they were human — nay, gods. Could you capture one for me? I-In a picture, of course!
There is a bear cave at the vast northern ice cap. You'll need an airship to find it.
Icebergs are born when ice shelves break apart. A dazzling giant block of ice floating away — that's a sight I would love to keep with me for the rest of my days!
There is an iceberg slowly floating around the region.

The reality of the Arctic is very different to what the explorer had dreamt of. Still, she is determined to make her family proud. She has asked you to take a picture of her and her colleagues, and she will do her best to pose with her biggest smile.

Mother and father have been nothing but supportive of my dream of exploring the Arctic. Yes, it is tougher than I anticipated here, but I will not let them worry. They shall only see my beaming smile!
Take a picture of the explorer and her colleagues.
I know Narwhals don't possess the magical properties the black market for their tusks might claim. But I do feel an indescribable awe upon seeing them...
Narwhals can be spotted swimming all across the region.

One of the passions the explorer has inherited from her father is sketching the fauna during her travels. There are some species she is still missing in her Arctic sketchbook. You can help her find them.
My father drew the most beautiful wolves when he hiked through the fjords. I would like to make a sketch of my own, but I have yet to actually see one...
Wildlife abounds near mineral deposits.
Have you heard the rumours? They say a moose has been spotted near the mines! That would be an incredible addition to my sketchbook...
There is one animal my father never got the opportunity to draw: the great polar bear. It would be the best gift I could ever give him if I found a model.

Find and point the explorer to:
[AssetData([Conditions QuestCondition Context]) Text]
The explorer has suggested that you recruit an Inuit specialist, and put their knowledge to use at one of your Arctic lodges.
It is pure arrogance to think we know more about the Arctic than the Inuit. They should be put in charge — of our administrations!
You can recruit an Inuit specialist at their trading post.
Equip an Inuit specialist at an Arctic Lodge.
The explorer wants people back home to know about the Inuit and their culture, so she has decided to leave the gift they gave her in your custody, to be displayed in one of your museums.

If people back home knew half of what I've learned from the Inuit, they would stop acting as if they were better than them! Here — they gifted me this after I stayed with them for a fortnight: display it in a museum, and spread their culture!

Equip in Museum:
Inuit Relic
The explorer's friend Arno and the rest of his research group went to the vast northern ice cap to track a colony of seals — but they haven't returned, and she is getting worried about them.
My friend Arno went on a field research trip to study seal social behaviour. We should have received news from his team by now...
Take an airship to the colony of seals to find out what happened to Arno and the rest of his research group.
The explorer wonders where the researchers went.
The explorer worries that a bear may have attacked the group.
The explorer is worried about the researchers.
The explorer is happy that you found Arno and his team.
The explorer thanks you for saving her friend.

An exploration party will set out to try and reach the North Pole using dog sleds. They only need a bit of help with the first part of the journey, and one of the explorers has promised you wouldn't mind giving them a lift in your airship.

An exploration party is gathering to reach the North Pole by sled. I told them you might be able to help. Th-They only need you to take them to the ice cap to the north! They will continue on from there on their own…

Looks like the exploration party that was trying to reach the North Pole using dog sleds has not yet returned. The explorer is getting a little worried about them, and has asked you to go looking for them on the ice.
Remember that party of explorers who set out for the North Pole? We've had no news from them in a while... Do you think we should go look for them?
The explorer wants to look for the North Pole exploration party.
The explorer recognises this as the location where the explorers set out.
The explorer is worried about the exploration party.
The explorer identifies this as the ice the explorers used to build an igloo.
The explorer is concerned for the sanity of the exploration party.
The explorer thanks you for saving her colleagues.
The explorer cannot believe her eyes.
The explorer wants to find the remains of the HMS Angry Wrath.

The great Sir William Perry got further north than anyone had gone before, long before the Styx was even assembled. But his ship, the Angry Wrath, became icebound. He left it behind to save his crew. It's still out there somewhere...
The explorer recalls the exact coordinates of the HMS Angry Wrath.
The explorer thinks Old Nate will make the most of what remains of the HMS Angry Wrath.
The explorer wonders if you might be able to find the remains of the HMS Angry Wrath, the ship Sir William Perry had to abandon in the ice during his expedition to the Arctic long ago.
Old Nate recognises the scrap from the HMS Angry Wrath.
Old Nate tells you to keep an eye out for more scrap from other failed expeditions.
The explorer proposes you look for the remains of failed expeditions.
Many have tried their luck at exploring the Arctic — and almost all have failed. The explorer proposes you take to the skies in search of the remaining parts, which could be repurposed by Old Nate.

We shared stories on the ship. A gruff man said this was his second time sailing the Arctic — the first time around, his crew had to leave much of their equipment behind in order to make it out alive. Do you think it's still out there?

The Arctic may seem barren, but it is no junkyard! Every bit of scrap left behind in the ice throws off the balance of this delicate environment! We can — no — we must collect and recycle as much of it as we can find!

I always kept an eye on the newspapers for reports on the Arctic expeditions. Sadly, there were very few updates on most of them... Such a loss of resources! We should honour those brave explorers, and not let their efforts go to waste!
The explorer reminds you to take the scrap to Old Nate.
The technicians need pocket watches. In the Arctic it is light all day, and they need accurate reference as to the hour.
Confounded Arctic summers! Hard to know what time it is when it's light all day — we need pocket watches.
The technician has asked for champagne. Apart from a little home comfort, the bubbles may prove influential in scientific circles.
Now there's champagne, Fritz won't hesitate to name me co-author on his magnetism paper! I may even get a mention at an award ceremony.
The technician wants some coal and steam carriages to fuel his theory that the Arctic climate can be manipulated. He is hoping you aren't the type to doubt the experts...
I posit that warming the Arctic will have a startling impact on the climate back home! In my latest paper, I want to prove the potential benefits of pumping smog into the Arctic sky!
The technician wants his picture taken alongside his instruments and equipment, just in case his seismic contribution to science isn't given the attention it surely merits.

I want my picture taken so that I receive due credit for this earth-shattering discovery. We are now a step closer to understanding how the world came into being, so naturally I deserve to be the centre of attention.
The technician who wants to be photographed is the one who gave you the quest.
The technician wants a picture of a specific crevasse and mountain to prove he conquered it. Sssh! Don't tell anyone that you took it from an airship, and he never bothered to make the ascent.
I'm no mere hobbyist — I want a proper photograph of the high glacier. Then perhaps people will realise just what I am willing to endure for my research.
Click the jump-to button to see the technician's preferred photo location. You'll need to clear the fog around it with your airship.
The technician wants wild Arctic animal subjects for dissection, such as wolves or elk.
We should dissect and scrutinise every furry beastie we can snare. It's a great opportunity to get at them before people start whipping out the red tape.
Wild animals can be found on your island close to the mines.
The technician wants to see a glacial serac up close for his privately-funded research project.
If I tried to explain the formation of glacial serac, you probably wouldn't have the foggiest notion. Well, to simplify — serac are pillars of ice formed from the glacier...
Click the jump-to button to discover the location of the serac. You'll need to clear the fog around it with your airship.
A group of technicians want to set up a research station in the remote north. If you drop them up there, they should come back with some interesting new findings in due time.
We've found something utterly fascinating, and we want you to construct a field station for us. Something up in the far north is sending our instruments haywire!
Drop the scientists at the specified point in the far north. Use your jump-to button to locate it.

You dropped a team of researchers in the far north to set up a research station, but a technician informs you that nothing has been heard from them in some considerable time. He suggests you go looking for them.
We've not heard a peep from the field station in ages... I do hope nothing is amiss. But if something IS amiss, perhaps that's the very thing we've been looking for...
The technician found a note that may point to the site of the research station.
The technician lampoons you for searching the wrong site.
The technician is dumbfounded by the odd happenings at the research center.

Proposed locations for our research station:
Upon a cliff of ice east of here. Pros: Isolated. Cons: Melty.
In a curved depression near the top of a small mountain, northeast of here. Pros: The mountain will shield us from storms. Cons: Signs of human activity — we may be disturbed by the locals.
On the edge of an icy canyon to the north. Pros: I can throw Musgrave into the ravine if he interferes with my research again. Cons: Musgrave might have the same idea.
Go back to the location you transported the researchers to. Use the jump-to button to locate it.
Pick up the journal from the cairn, and read it to find the research center.

Have a once-Pyrphorian flamethrower close at hand to light up that thing should it return! I spent the afternoon hosing Musgrave's superior collection of cacti with flame. I don't suppose he'll mind now, Musgrave, but he failed my little test. How was I to know if it was the real him?
I hear barking outside, yet all the huskies are dead! Aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaah!

A technician explains that mammoths would have roamed free all over the northern hemisphere during the Ice Age. He is excited by the prospect that some might be found suspended in ice to the northwest.
I'm on the trail of the woolly mammoth. I have a hunch some may still be trapped in the ice to the northwest.
Find the mammoth trapped in the ice by following the mammoth bones in the far north. The trail begins where the technician has indicated.
The technician has found mammoth bones, which appear to lead off somewhere.
The scientist is thrilled to find a perfectly-preserved mammoth.
The technician is amazed by the prehistoric human you found in the ice.
Find the prehistoric man trapped in the ice, and bring him back to your trading post.

A technician is bursting with excitement, having seen what he believes to be a human trapped in ice from your airship. He thinks you ought to take it back to your trading post for a more thorough examination.
Qumaq has asked you for whale oil to fuel the "Kudliks"— lamps to light the dark of endless night.
We need more blubber for the kudliks. Their fire will lift the darkness.
The rite of passage for many young Inuit is a test of their hunting skills. Normally it would be seal or caribou, but Qumaq's son Aput, being a late developer, has been tasked with hunting a bear.
A boy who provides is a man, and my boy has yet to provide. Can you find out how Aput's hunt is going?
Seal or caribou would be easy for me, but a bear? I just see Nanuk, and the soul of grandpa "Grey Bear" before me... I can't do it. Please, help me!
Thanks. I should feel guilty, but I don't. What adult sends a kid to catch a bear? I never want to grow up.
Contact Qumaq's son, Aput
Qumaq has asked you to help him catch some seals.
Hear the ice cracking? Time to hunt seals — it's easier in the spring.
Qumaq has entrusted you with delivering some goose feathers to his community. Geese are animals — like many others — that seem to have a great many uses for the Inuit.
Want to help us catch geese? A few more feathers for our pillows would be nice. I hope you can use the rest of the bird too...
Qumaq's experienced huskies Ernouk and Tortu died in a dog sled accident. Having decided to get back in the saddle, he hopes you can repair his sled, and find him some new dogs.
I loved those dogs... But the accident cost Ernouk and Tortu their lives, and my best sled is still broken.
Qumaq would like to shear some New World Alpacas to make parkas, and see if they are an improvement upon seal and caribou lining.
Alpaca wool is warm you say? Warmer than our parkas? Prove it!
Qumaq has asked you to deliver some sails for his old umiak. He hopes they will be an improvement on the rotting oars.
Can sails have value here? My umiak has seen better days, maybe these sails will help?
Qumaq is willing to take some pigs from you, to see if they are able to survive in the Arctic circle.
You think we should keep pigs? Okay — send us your pigs!
Qumaq is willing to take some fish oil from you, to see if it suits the Inuits' needs.
Fish oil you say? We need oil for a lot of things. Let's see if it's tasty too.
Qumaq has asked you to deliver some glasses, to see if they might be useful to his community.
Do you mean snow goggles, or something else? Show me these glasses of yours!
Qumaq is open to you delivering coffee to his community, in case it helps with the long Inuit workday.
A black drink called coffin? If you think it will keep us alert, I suppose we can give it a try.
Qumaq asks you to find some Inuit children and send them home.
Some children snuck off to see your city — please, can you send them home? Whatever made them leave, we can talk about it later.
Qumaq has entrusted you to make a photo of the mystic clouds.
One of the trader has discovered some mystic clouds, colouring the northern lake. He's too afraid to take his way home. Please make a photo.
Qumaq asks for a photo of a natural formation exactly like the one in their camp, lost somewhere in the vast northern ice cap.
See that natural formation near the camp? Our elders tell stories of it being one of two twins. Do you know of any others like it?
The natural formation is at the vast northern ice cap. You'll need an airship to find it.

Find and photograph:
[AssetData([Conditions QuestCondition Context]) Text]
Qumaq asks you to photograph an anomaly on the southern coast.
One of our people saw something terrible washed up on a beach. Can you get me a picture?
Qumaq asks you to use your diving bell to look for a troublesome sea monster that has claimed some of his community.
If I could see down to the depths, I would find the monster that has claimed so many of our fishermen...
Qumaq is glad the monster appears to have been banished.
Qumaq thinks it safest to retreat.
Qumaq asks if you could recover a beloved amulet from the deep.
Can your machine find my amulet? I lost it to the sea in a storm. As I tossed and turned in the waves, my special amulet came loose...
Qumaq asks you to rescue the missing crew and their boats.
A great wave took many hunters. Higher than a mountain, it was. Unfortunately, we are still missing some hunters and their umiaks...
Qumaq has asked you to monitor the progress of a group of young hunters who have disappeared in the north.
Ah, daring youth! The young hunters' search for seals began in the north.
Find the young hunters in the north
Follow the young hunters through the ice desert
Find the young hunters' prey
Find the makeshift camp
Bring the young hunters home
Zoom in to scan the terrain and look for tracks.

Qumaq has asked you to give three lamps life. A thick fog has fallen — the essence of a female giant. If all braziers are burning at the same time, the fog should lift, providing better conditions for sledding.
The giant drank so much water, she literally burst open — and so, fog was born! Give the lamps life. Fire the old braziers in the ice, and the fog will lift for sledding!
Light the third brazier
Light the first brazier
Light the second brazier
The fog has lifted. Thank you. We can go sledding now!
The braziers are located in the far north.
Qumaq wants you to track down a thief — for the thief's own safety as much as anything else.
The thief ran into the mountains. I am worried for him. He's taken one of our best Umiaks, and many of our most precious things.
Find the Umiak
Follow tracks in the snow
Follow the canyon
Find the thief
This is his first crime. We will talk to him, and make sure he feels loved. Good hunting!
Zoom in to scan the terrain and look for tracks.

The Inuit have asked you to track down a missing elder, who went to find some cranberries that grow on the far side of the mountain. Many Inuit are quite ill with sore throats, so they really need those berries!
Everyone has bad sore throats. The elder went over the mountain for cranberries, but he hasn't returned. I am worried for him!
Find the camp
Follow the elder's tracks
Follow the snowshoe prints
Bring back the cranberries
Fuel a fire to warm the sick, and mourn the elder
Zoom in to scan the terrain and look for tracks.
Follow the trail and find the next clue
Fly to the first position indicated by the resident
Find the research center to learn what happened
Pick up and read the note to guess where they built the research center
Pick up the lost cargo: [Conditions QuestCondition CurrentAmount]/[Conditions QuestCondition Amount]
These Prime Hunting Cabins gather fur four times faster than the ones in the Old World!
Deep Gold Mines here in the Arctic yield more than twice as much gold as the regular ones, hehe...
Gas can be drilled in the Arctic, and you can burn it for electricity and all! Try me gas-fired power plants! You don't even need trains to get it working!
Old Nate says goodbye and will be back later.
[AssetData([NotificationContext CharacterGUID]) Text] offers you an exploration quest.
[AssetData([NotificationContext CharacterGUID]) Text] offers you an exploration quest.
Qumaq rewards you for the kind thought.
Ovibos moschatus. Musk ox males emit a strong odor during the seasonal rut, hence the name.
Rangifer tarandus. The largest of the caribou, this forest-dwelling species is extremely sensitive to human disturbance of their habitat.
Vulpes lagopus. Its snow-white fur keeps it warm — and nearly undetectable to the untrained eye.
Odobenus rosmarus. Its vibrissae — the stiff bristles around its tusks — give the walrus a whiskered appearance.
Pusa hispida. This small, earless seal is one of the pillars of life in the Arctic — known as nattiq by the Inuit.
Ursus maritimus. Nanuk. A hypercarnivore adapted to the Arctic, who navigates sea ice in search of seals.
Pagophila eburnea. This small polar gull has many vocalizations, including a warbling fox-call to warn about predators.
Canis lupus arctos. Born an ashen grey, its coat turns white as it matures.
Monodon monoceros. The imposing spiral tusks that protrude from their jaws have been harvested and sold as unicorn horns since ancient times.
Pinguinus impennis. A very rare bird these days, perhaps because their eggs are so highly prized. Aukward.
This small pre-Thule carving was recovered in exceedingly good condition.
A collection of odds and ends from Sir John's Lost Expedition that the Inuit have rescued from the ice.
Oftentimes confused with the simpler inuksuks, this stone structure resembles a human with wide open arms.
This pyramidal inuksuk was built to mark a cache of caribou meat that had been stored for the winter.
A miniature children's version of the traditional Inuit sled, complete with gruff husky.
An assortment of seemingly worthless miscellaneous items that belonged to the crew of the lost expedition.
A meticulous replica of the real HMS Hades, which along with HMS Styx, was wrecked during the Faithful expedition.
Traditional Inuit dwellings built with blocks of ice acting as insulation, trapping the body heat of the people within.
A well-dressed Inuit mummy that's over 400 years old. Freeze dried, she looks as if she could have died yesterday.
This frozen wolf pup is 50,000 years old, predating the emergence of the domestic dog by at least 10,000 years!
A paleontologist's dream. A bit mangled after thousands of years in ice, but still partially furred and fleshed!
This map leads to an old Inuit settlement.
One of the many Huddlesome Bay Company trading posts in the Arctic, yet mysteriously closed...
A land of giants beyond the North Wind, where the sun never sets. Could it really be...?
Seals don't seem to have a problem finding prey in this spot.
Hard to believe how much wildlife thrives in the depths of the frozen ocean.
Expeditioners exchange stories of the prehistoric giant shark, still frozen in time at the bottom of the deepest, darkest trench of the Arctic.
Long ago, these peaceful people also engaged in tribal conflicts.
A young whaler swears they boarded the three-masted vessel and saw her frozen-stiff captain still sitting at his desk, pen-in-hand.
Old Nate's first attempts at touching the sky melted his wings prematurely. Prototype X plunged into the depths of the ocean after making some very peculiar screeching sounds.
Sneak up on poor snoozing whales.
Perfect for navigating narrow channels where whales come to sleep at night.
So smooth in the water, the bowhead cannot hear you as you approach its shoreline bed. Poor whales.
Good for trapping seals.
An effective Inuit harpoon when sealing, says Qumaq.
The most effective tool for skinning seals, incorporating thousands of years of Inuit knowledge and practice.
Soft and silent, the arrow buries itself.
The arrow flies higher and higher, further and further.
This mighty bow from the north west is powerful enough to bring down a fully-grown moose.
A safety precaution to kill bacteria before curing.
A safety precaution to kill bacteria before curing. Now with improved temperature control.
Reaches the exact temperature required to kill bacteria prior to the curing process, but preserves the moisture in the meat.
Skins must first be treated, or clothes made from them will stiffen and rot.
Awls make holes for needles to pass through to prevent them from breaking.
The Inuit store needles in these carry cases so they don't get blunted and are always close at hand.
Relatively durable snow goggles.
Snow goggles that are both comfortable and durable.
For those who spend a lot of time out in the snow with the critters, and who wish to feel at one with them.
A decent tool for shaping wood in Arctic conditions.
Useful for smoothing wood surfaces in Arctic conditions.
Useful for smoothing wood surfaces in Arctic conditions, and extremely comfortable in the hand.
Trade faster with this splendiferous pulley, which encourages everyone to hurry up and get the job done!
An average Inuit seamster is likely the best seamster you've ever met.
Knows all the patterns perfectly, and doesn't waste a scrap of the animal's skin.
Once the incomparable Arnarunn has knitted a superlative sleeping bag, it will never need replacing.
The dogs and geese won't bite him any more.
The geese and the dogs know him as their father.
She knows that strong dogs make the best companions, and strong geese have the best feathers.
Knows all the best spots.
She knows all the best spots, and breathes more quietly than an Arctic hare.
Toklo respects his prey, taking only what he needs. Collects feathers from bird roosts.
A traditional craftsman.
Learned the craft from his father's father, who learned from his father before that.
When trees are few and far between, you learn the places driftwood prefers to end its voyages.
Has made pemmican many times before.
In touch with the origins of pemmican, among the native peoples of the plains.
Naturally, he is aware that pemmican must be high in fat, but Sandro manages to put some excess to other uses.
A lovely warm squiggle.
It's no headache to operate.
Irritate coworkers by cranking out the same tunes over and over and over again.
Drop a thick walrus steak on the angry red bars, and watch the place sizzle up.
With such squat and portly candles stomping off the production line, your lamps can go without brass.
Not only current, but futuristic too! Old N8's futuristic zapper carbonises logs so you don't have to.
Spice, booze, a few twists of the handle, and winter no longer seems quite so cold.
The little machine that can. N8 once canned a batch of horse meat with it to sell it in bulk as beef.
A crisp and comforting exterior that masks a complex heating system within. Also offers deep storage options.
A mule so assiduous in its quest for gas, it is willing to pause only for copper and zinc.
Nate didn't have post office employees in mind when he came up with this scalding-hot coffee conveyor, yet they're lapping it up!
Old N8 was inspired to rejig his engines after Nordic salmon rained from the sky and beat up his airship.
The Royal Airship Service being relatively new meant Old N8 could get his hands on official stamp designs.
A chance for employees to soak up all the latest gossip.
Old Nate tested the sensors by setting fire to his sleeve.
Nate was vexed to find the yak milk butter in his larder had turned a rancid orange, and knew something must be done.
Flips and replaces shellac records automatically from a collection of popular music hall tunes.
Old N8 grew tired of having to go to an underground cave every time he needed rocks for his whiskey.
Old Nate spends his free time playing billiards against a version of himself, commentating every play.
No time for the pub? Take a selection of sophisticated ales back to work with you in an artisanal carry-box.
Old N8 was inspired to create one of these after one of his many trips to the Far East.
A coffee machine that disgorges the most treacly, eye-opening thimblefuls of hot bean juice.
Produces a whirligig of soda and vegetable extract, which may become a popular alternative to coffee someday.
There are new ways to have fun now we have a better understanding of the noble gases.
Doesn't matter what you pile into your cigar: tobacco, hay, dog hair, the weeds around pumpkins...
The children don't care for chocolate now that they can eat scrummy ice cream every day...
Metals are sucked into the stratosphere, clinging to it, until finally it comes crashing back down to earth.
Harvests gold and potatoes simultaneously. In the future we'll all be stupid rich, sitting on mountains of potatoes!
Stripped to the bare essentials, this new type of airship gondola will grant your zeppelin that extra bit of zip.
Offers accelerated cargo loading and improved weight distribution for your skybound pride and joy.
Their eyes are listless, their faces gaunt and grey — Qumaq was right — the survivors barely look human anymore.
The writings of Sir John Faithful upon his expedition's departure inland from the initial camp at King William Island.
A team of hardened explorers, raring to shift the icy impediment between them and Sir John's expedition.
A fragment of Sir John Faithful's logbook, from a fraught leg of the expedition.
Keen to construct a research station in the far North, and understand recent strange phenomena.
Not the popsicle flavour I'd choose...
Contains clues as to the whereabouts of a certain research station.
A bit chilly after being thrown overboard, but still in good spirits.
Inexperienced now, yes — but in time, they'll learn.
A delightful hair separator of great sentimental value.
The emptiness...
A tart berry with well-documented healing properties, which the Inuit eat to relieve colds and sore throats.

COMPANY SETTLES IN ARCTIC
[Participants Current Profile CompanyName] settles first island in the Arctic.
AIRSHIP HANGAR COMPLETE

The people are giddy with excitement in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName] now that the new airship hangar is finished, and wonder when peculiar flying contraptions are likely to start rumbling through its doors.
NEW AIRSHIP

Townsfolk are raising their heads in disbelief to stare at the newly-constructed airship, whose shadow now envelops them. Dwarfing even some of the largest buildings, the airship is a windborne warehouse; a depot flotante; and a mechanical, mercurial, trans-continental, aeolian zephyr!
NEW HOPE FOR LOST EXPEDITION

Lady Jane Faithful is gathering the world's best to conduct a full and final search of her own! Two years since Sir John Faithful's expedition to the Northwest Passage was declared lost in the Arctic, the Captain's strong-willed wife says she will not rest "until they are fed, bathed in hot salts and tucked up in their beds".
SIR JOHN FAITHFUL FOUND!

Sir John and Lady Jane reunited! Lady Faithful praises crucial work of [Participants Current Profile CompanyName]. Three heroic survivors returned to loved ones at long last! Sir John Faithful decorated for his courageous leadership! Claims they partook in anthropophagy vehemently denied — they definitely did not eat one another!
HUMAN ORIGINS IN THE ARCTIC?

Zeppelin technician in the Arctic claims the human race began there, "If I told you the many rock and ice formations we found look eerily human, you'd probably laugh," he tells us, "but we know the human body is eighty-percent water, so you do the maths."
WHAT A PINNACLE!

Arctic braggart keen to show off his mountaineering prowess foiled by the obvious fact that the photograph was taken from the air. Nevertheless, his research on the mountain chain and glacier looks promising, according to sources at the Goldfurt Geographical Institute... (article continues in this week's natural science supplement)

Airships
Arctic Lodge

Dare you face the challenges of the Arctic? Venture to the edge of the world; conquer the most hostile of environments with a brand new heating system; build monumental hangars to claim the sky with your very own airships; and assist Lady Jane Faithful in her quest to find her husband, Sir John, and his lost expedition to the Northwest Passage...
Conquer the Arctic's extreme conditions with new residents and production chains.
Look for the Lost Expedition alongside new and familiar characters, like Lady Faithful, Old Nate, and the Inuit shaman Qumaq.
Gas-Fired Power Plant
Light up your megapolis with a much more efficient gas-fired power plant that doesn't require a railway connection!
Airships
Construct your own airships and be the first to rise above your competitors!
HOLIDAY PACK
Bring the spirit of the holidays to Anno 1800 with this new cosmetic DLC pack, which includes 23 new ornaments.
You'll find the Holiday ornaments under this category in the construction menu:

The airship hangar is built in phases. Once complete, it can produce trade airships if you have a supply of gas.
Hardly more than a dream traced in the snow, for now. But the foundations of the hangar are ready to be ploughed and consolidated in reality — taking you one step closer to the clouds.

The ice-cold steel structure of the hangar juts above the ground like the stranded carcass of a colossal whale. Yet one mustn't be fooled by the striking morbidness of the image: this whale will give birth to airships!
The vast dome is nearly finished. Once the canvas roofing is stretched over the skeleton and the technical equipment installed, the assembly of airships will commence.
Requires Heat
A trading vessel that flies! Especially suitable for long-distance trades. Has fewer cargo slots, but can travel much faster. Even better, no technology exists that can shoot them down... yet.
Extracts raw gas from gas deposits.
Provides heat over a limited area if supplied with coal.
Provides heat to connected residences and factories.
Connected residences and factories are no longer being supplied with heat.
Heater Outage!
Only useful if equipped with items. Attach items here to provide bonuses to residences and production.

The most ambitious rescue I've had the honour to be part of.
I hoped and feared I might one day have the privilege of such an undertaking.
Can we do worse than the Arctic council? They're afraid of the ice in their whisky!
I will not rest while fellow seamen succumb to the cold, we are with you!
The Northwest passage is uncharted, Admiral. More than preparation, we need luck.
I don't want to join the many that tried and failed to find them.
Seaman's intuition tells me they came this way, but I've been wrong before.
I fear we may be as lost as the original expedition.
Let's hope we warm mother nature's frozen heart soon.
The chill already gnaws at the bones of our crew.
If I know Sir John Faithful right, I'd say he came this way.
If these men seem impervious to cold, it's Lady Faithful's fire we have to thank.
I've met few so hardy as Lady Faithful, we can't let her down now.
And I thought the Arctic Council's efforts were pathetic.
We might have turned back long ago, had the mysteries of the ice not drawn us in.
Even I have rarely seen such extremes, and worse may be yet to come.
It's a cairn o'rocks stacked by human hand! We have stumbled upon Sir John Faithful's last encampment!
We've found no trace of Sir John and his crew, let us hope there is time to try again.
We must be better prepared if we are to follow in the fateful footsteps of Sir John.
I knew another captain who ventured this far north, but I know him no more.
We all know this could be our last expedition, so may it be a fine one!
If we die in the attempt, it won't be for a lack of commitment.
It'll be the stuff of folklore if we succeed and bring back Sir John.
Bears, vicious whales and restless spirits await us, if the tales are to be believed.
It's a lot to ask, but to a seaman there's no challenge to rival the Arctic.
A wise seaman would trust the Inuits. They know their land better than we ever will.
I myself have little experience of the Arctic, but stand beside you.
We shouldn't expect to find them right away...this is a vast wilderness.
It's been two years, the Admiralty say they have tried everything, but then, they haven't lost a husband.
—nor did it occur to them to search King William Sound— There! A camp!
Abandoned.
But we imagined as much, didn't we?—and my John picked a fine spot—perhaps they left some sign as to where they went…
My name is Lady Jane Faithful, and it is my husband, Sir John, whose expedition is lost in the Arctic.
In two years, the admiralty haven't done much about his rescue, but fortunately, I have.
I have gathered men and resources to conquer the ice, and to you I offer a handsome reward for bringing him home.
My John's camp shall serve for us. From here we can search to any length and breadth.
Just as they left it. We'll rake over the remains, and then make a refuge for ourselves.
Hold hard! A craig, heaped by highland hand, is well worth our time.
I did say there would be rewards. That's for finding my John's camp.
John's log, open it!— He knew we would come for him.
If HMS Hades and Styx came this way, the Inuit must have seen them; maybe they can help us.
That's the hangar? How marvellous! Sir John will be the first to congratulate you when we find him.
The Hades and Styx came this way, if it take our last breath we must find them.
Here's something more. It'll take our best efforts to clear that frozen channel.
We pick up our crumbs and prepare an especial ice-breaching brigade.
Either we break through that ice, or else we go home now.
Are our ice-breachers ready?
What does it take for a captain to abandon his ship? To cross the ice by foot?
How far did they really expect to take those boats?
*gasp*
No ship, even an icebreaker, can carry us from here, nor will we cover enough ground on foot...
Expensive yes, but with airships you'll be the one to find my John and his boys, I'm certain of it.
The cost and scale of that structure is staggering. But have faith— my John is a risk-taker also.
Now the search can really begin. From high above, this white expanse may seem more finite.
Recommence the search where we left it; at the place the Hades and the Styx were abandoned.
Follow their aura, as others have done, and we can still find them.
One of the Inuit is offering to lead you north, I..I'd only be a hindrance, I'll wait for you on the other side.
John? My John?
Say whatever you like John, I did everything I could to find you, and have absolutely no intention of giving up now.
I am sorry about Sir John. He's had a hard time, they all have.
I am ever so grateful to you, and do not think I have forgotten your reward, but for now I must get my dear husband home.
Old Nate has his quirks, but he is the best, and that is precisely what we need.
Young and brave are our volunteer Explorers, they will soon have the measure of the place.
The Technicians are a difficult lot, but their confidence does appear justified.
...something extra to keep everyone's spirits up...
To ignore the wisdom of the Inuit is an arrogance we cannot afford.
It is bitterly, bitterly cold. Make sure everyone keeps wrapped up.
This encampment must embody hope, our one comfort in the wilderness.
Last night I had a disquieting dream— we cannot allow time to run out.
No small disappointment can cause me to give up hope.
I'll not rest 'til my John is fed, bathed in hot salts and tucked up in bed.
The ice is as old as time, and more stubborn than I ever believed.
My husband is a stubborn man, I hope he was not too proud to heed the Inuit.
I promised I would reward you, and now I have. And thank you, thank you for bringing back my dear John.
I have no idea how expensive that will be, but here. Here, I hope that's a start.
Our efforts should not diminish until the missing are all accounted for.
You have proven all is still possible.
You endure where others have not.
Just when I was beginning to lose faith.
If we all pull together, who knows what we can achieve.
We cannot allow this to stop us believing.
We have let a chance pass us by.
Now I feel the wind begin to bite.
Found something?
Some hope for us?

Too late, too late, they’re all dead. My impudence before the gods; we were doomed from the beginning. My stubbornness— my vile, reckless ambition. I should have died out there with them. I should have died!
John no more, I am a phantom, my love; an exile condemned to this twilight plane for eternity.
Ha. I never could argue with you.
So help me god, get the fires started or the lot of us will freeze!
You might want to start looking for coal.
Wotcha! I'll be joining you. Lady Faithful's engaged me for some practical advice— gonna be dead cold up there.
S'cold enough to freeze the balls off a brass monkey, gorr, get the coal fires burning posthaste.
Ahh, that's nice on the hands, keep it stoked or we'll catch our deaths out here.
First get all ye faithful some shelter, and a canteen where they can warm each other up.
The heat of them heaters don't travel far, and most of your buildings'll need heating and all.
You need a bloomin' airship, you do. Eh, what do you mean "borrow mine"? Get out of it!
Why not build yer own airships? You'll want to employ a lot of fusspot pseuds though, so watch out.
Build a hangar first; good thought. Better hope the ice don't melt, or that'll be the first thing to go.
What's that you say? No gas? Gorrr... Very well, I s'pose I'll have to lend you some.
Pffft Pffft Pffft, can't stop gassing out here, got to keep chattering to stay afloat.
Your first ruddy airship, I bet you feel lighter-than-air!
If you can't squeeze it out of old Archie, I've seen gas come out the ground to the north.
There! Glad I don't have to be yer pump attendant no more, the cheek of it, I ask yer…
Didn't eat each other?! Got to be pulling my leg... Oh, too soon?
Oh! This is some scrap from William Perry's failed expedition— still good for a lot of things.
Bet there's more scrap out there from all the other failed expeditions, bring it 'ere, and I'll transmute it.
We've a responsibility to Sir John to gather up his valuables as we go. Hehe.
Lady Faithful hopes to revive her marriage, but Sir John's got cold feet, hehe.
Gorr those Explorers are keen, actually no, they're stark raving mad.
Jumped-up little gits them Technicians, dunno why I put up with 'em.
I like that the Inuit use every part of the animal.
One good thing about the Arctic, equipment don't decompose like cadavers do.
A lot of people tried before Sir John Faithful, left a lot of scrap up in the ice channels.
Got me own Huddlesome Bay Company.
Hurry up, it's cold.
Got to be resourceful up here, eh.
Keep an eye out for scrap from lost expeditions.
If you take yer eye off the heaters, temperatures'll plummet.
Gorr, turn the heating up!
The coal's keeping everyone alive.
The heat don't radiate far.
So cold, you can hear their bones starting to creak.
Been a lot easier if Sir John'd had airships in the first place.
Airships don't come cheap.
It's expensive enough running one airship.
What can I say, hangars take up a lot of space.
I don't like 'em neither, but you need Technicians to have airships.
It shows we have conquered our fear.
Seems the balance is restored.
These are good signs.
You have done well, and you smell nice.
When the ice breaks, I want you there with me.
The wolf has kept you strong, caribou.
There is much to be afraid of now.
I must consult the spirit now.
It is an ill wind that blows nobody any good.
You have damaged the balance of things.
You are meddling in witchcraft.
You have let many people down.
A shaman must help those in need. We will share what we know.
We were afraid you would come for them. Now you are here we must help you.
To know where you are going, you have to know where you come from.
An annuraaq should be watertight.
A fur hood would help shake the snow from your face.
We do not camp anywhere long, the season changes fast.
The igluit are made with anything we can find.
During the long dark winter, we will play games and tell stories.
Seal is important to us, we are careful to waste no part of it.
Take only the whale and bear that you need.
May we repay this kindness.
We are thankful.
Nakurmiik; thank you.
Yes.
Ee.
Good.
Not good.
I am sorry.
Nakka.
May you have warmth in your iglu.
May you have oil in your lamp.
Go with peace in your heart.
Skins can be sewn into clothing with bone needles.
You need a lot of good fat to reach the heart of ice.
Old Nate reminds me of Keelut— he leaves no tracks when feasting on the dead.
We value iron.
Let us trade.
We share what we have.
Act not for yourself, but for the community.
Waste nothing.
I'd prefer to be in a kayak.
I fear they went looking for the heart of ice. We have not seen them for a long time.
I can set you on a path, the rest is down to you.
If you tread carefully, then perhaps a way can be found.
That is the way. Their breath still hangs in the air.
Without belief, answers do not yet exist.
I don't know if your icebreaker will vanquish the ice, but we will not stand in your way.
None of us have much time.
You need to make the best of all you have.
Such strength can redeem your people.
This place is all-powerful, ever-changing, you have to adapt.
We have sighted vessels stranded in the channels. They too will be lost without help.
Better to let others learn from their own mistakes.
Your countrymen will soon become snowbound, and easy prey for Akhlut.
Those men underestimated this place, but you can show them their failings.
They will be glad to come back to light and hospitality, and think on their mistakes.
Seals are everywhere; know how to look for them.
Nanurjuk says they didn't seem right. They said little as if their tongues were cut.
They refused the seals we offered them.
They would not trade, or drink soup with us.
We built them a shelter, but they were already gone, deep into the ice.
Never have I seen beings so pale.
They went beyond the old ice, to a place of danger.
We are afraid Anguta has taken them to the underworld.
There are many ways to survive here, we have learned since childhood.
I will trade with you.
We were scared they were possessed by demons.
They brought sickness with them, and devilry.
We knew you would come for them, we have been waiting for you.
If these are indeed humans you pursue, I will do all I can to help you.
There are many things I could tell you, but I don't think they will help.
There are many sea mammals here, Sedna is their keeper.
We do not meddle in the business of others.
Don't expect to learn everything in a day.
The Council have praised our knowledge, but never respected it.
The vessels you seek are near yet far. Best prepare for terror.
If their vessels drifted to a dark place, maybe they are there still.
They could not have escaped the channels, you will find them there.
We too want answers, you are brave to keep digging.
This is a place of death. You can die here without knowing.
I will not go with you. I hope it is men you find, at the end of your journey.
When wise men die, the heavens lament.
You are on the last floe now, but the most fragile.
You have brought men back from the edge, you have earned our respect.
If you cannot save them, their souls will be trapped in the upper world to starve for eternity.
The lights in the sky cleave heads from the unworthy.
Where the ice between the dead and the living is thinnest, you float across.
I have no power to protect you, when you go to that place.
You have stirred the wrath of the moon!
Do not hunt alone, in darkness, or the wolf will take you.
This is a celestial place, be wary of taboo.
Fear this place, or it will take you smiling.
Nanook decides if you may hunt, or if you violate this place.
Inuksuk said he saw the white people carrying human meat.
I remember they were so dirty, they had lost all humanity.
If you hear a whistling, it is their ghosts, trapped in the upper world.
You saw Amarok. He preys upon those that stray too far from the path.
I cannot say. The spirits become restless when strangers enter their realm. If we stay too long, they will never let us leave.
Glorious it is when wandering time comes.
If you walk on thin ice, you may as well dance.
Be the lead dog, and show where to go.
Find this seal hole.
Watch out for bears.
The strong qimmiq pulls through.
You have a good nose.
We should do what we can to survive.
We should take gifts when they are offered.
It is easy to underestimate this place.
This is a harsh land.
We waste no chance we have here.
Now is your time.
That was only the beginning.
The day is young, there is more to do.
Do you share with the hunting party?
Should I heat some tea?
There is nothing more to be said.
It is a time of silence.
We need more blubber for the kudliks.
A boy who provides is a man.
Hear the ice cracking? Time to hunt seal.
Want to help us catch goose?
I loved those dogs...
Alpaca wool is warm you say?
Warm, but not as warm as a parka of seal or caribou skin.
Can sails have value here?
No wind, no need for sails.
Pigs are so friendly, but will not survive the cold.
Your fish oil tastes like it's bad for you.
Do you mean snow goggles, or something else?
Very clever things if you have bad eyesight— I don't know anyone with bad eyesight.
I drank it and couldn't sleep! If you work all day, you need to sleep.
Some children snuck off to see your city, please can you send them home?
Good, I don't want them to pick up habits. Our community will make them feel loved again.
What kind of weather is it out there? What shape are the clouds?
No clouds? Then Silla has been kind, and we have good hunting weather.
See the natural formation near camp, do you know of any others?
You found a lucky spot. When we next move camp we will move there.
She is one of Sedna's great sharks, I wonder what happened to her.
The creature is gone. Our thanks to you for driving it away.
Look! Something damaged your boat! Maybe the wolf-whale Akhlut, come away!
Can your machine find my amulet? I lost it to the sea in a storm.
A great wave took many hunters.
Built a camp and killed a bear to survive? We underestimated them, they have grown up fast.
The Giant drank so much water she burst open, and fog was born.
The fire is clearing the fog.
The lamp has run low, the fog will not clear.
The fog is lifted. Thank you.
More clues, you are getting close.
This track leads in a new direction.
This is his first crime, we will talk to him and make him feel loved.
He who stole ran into the mountains. I am worried for him.
Everyone has bad sore throats. The elder went over the mountain for cranberries, but he hasn't returned.
Footprints! Why did the elder abandon his sled?
He came to this cave to die. When you have covered him with stones, gather the cranberries.
The cranberries will make us better. Will you help us light a fire for the elder?
Our community won't forget the elder's sacrifice, or yours.
I feared you would come. I will show you where those men went.
Ice has closed the way forward, to the place they took their boats.
The storm makes it hard to see.
Do not become them— I will help you find them.
They abandoned their boats... Will you seek them with this bird of yours?
I dislike it in the clouds. There— clear tracks leading away from the boats.
Styx is a strange name.
Hades has an ominous sound.
They stayed here for a time. But then where?
A dead end.
Too steep. Choose another way.
They took this path— tough with things to carry, I fear for them.
The snow dunes... I fear for them.
We warned them about the dunes. They did not listen.
They dropped it all to make the difficult climb.
I don't know how, but some of them made it.
Bear country. Hunters must be strong to come here.
The bear deserves respect. Nanuk is like one of us.
A storm rises. Your bird will rock like a feather in the wind.
Gone is hope, the domain of night belongs to Amarok.
The men who followed your Faithful here, can be men no longer.
Where did he think he was leading them?
There! Long dead, but moving still.
Amarok spared them so that their story may be retold.
Ah, wonderful!
Ooof, that's very good to know…!
I can rest easy knowing that's settled!
Uplifting!
That's… reassuring!
Thank goodness!
I... really needed that.
There's something to write home about!
What a turnaround!
That's heartening.
I'm not sure that's how it's supposed to be…
Is that so…!?
I wish I'd known when I signed up...
I couldn't have foreseen this...
Oh, no… Oooh, noo…
How will we get through this…?
As if we didn't have enough worries…
No, it can't be!
Mustn't give in to dismay...
Appalling…
I always knew you could make it.
I'll follow your footsteps in the snow!
I will do my best too!
You're a doer!
I will make you proud as well!
How did y-…!? How could y-…?
Why would you...!?
Please, we depend on you…!
You're leaving us all out in the cold!
Are you sure you're well…?
Thank you, thank you so much.
I deeply appreciate it.
Thank you for thinking of us!
You're an immense help!
We couldn't do this without you!
Makes my day a good bit easier.
Nah-koor-meek… Did I say that correctly?
We look out for each other.
That greatly eases things.
A much-needed comfort.
Y-yes!
Very good!
Oh, this? It's only a sketch. My father used to draw the birds he spotted on our trips and I followed suit.
I'm very glad Old Nate's around, his chuckles are contagious.
I never saw stars as sharp as they are here…
Yesterday I didn't burst into tears at any point, must mean I'm getting used to this.
I've been meaning to ask the technicians about their work, but they keep shooing me away…!
Is that technician gone already…? Good...
I'm sure technicians know what they're doing, but do they have to say things like that…?
