Bente is the young heir to the Jorgensen Trust, a philanthropic venture of her late father's. She is an alarmingly friendly individual, caring for all around her. An intrepid traveller, she believes the world exists for all to delight in and explore! Naturally, she is friends with almost everyone...

Princess Qing is a young and uncertain envoy of the Imperial East. Struggling to bring about the very different diplomatic wishes of the Emperor and Empress here in a new and unfamiliar place, she takes consolation in writing wistful poetry on the nature of home.

Behind the bold swish of Willie's conjuror's cape lives a fragile mouse, desperate for the affection conferred upon him by his late mother. Above all, it is fear that grips him — of some unspeakable and ghoulish reprisal — for Willie seems to have acquired his great fortune suspiciously suddenly!

George Smith was, long ago, a slave. An explosion in the mine took his father, and rendered George deaf. Finding freedom, George seized the chance to make something of his life, and has now apparently done it all. But don't let that fool you — he's not finished yet.

Beryl O'Mara was a goodly soul once — back when she believed her meek shopkeeper husband would escape the debtor's prison. He didn't. Years later, it is now her that's running the street game, with the help of her many eyes and ears. She'll invite you in for tea, but don't get too cosy — that's a sawn-off under the floral tablecloth!

Artur Gasparov is a self-proclaimed visionary, francophile, and pursuer of architectural perfection. Breaking from the mirror only to schmooze with the most important critics, Gasparov has little patience for others, or indeed, any empathy at all. As he himself has said, 'Every great city is ruined by its people.'

Carl is a repugnant, industrialist fat-cat. Blaming his parents for allowing the once-great name of Von Malching to fade from view, he is ever desperate to rub up with the nobility — and of course, to pile up the gold. His philosophy is "money equals reputation", so take, take and take some more!

Alonso Graves is a man disturbed. A former soldier of the Empire, war transformed his soul forever. The disdain and misanthropy within him can only momentarily be silenced by the blood of his former masters. Believing himself now to be a god, he is intent on 'freeing' all he can from the shackles of human existence.

Admiral Vicente Silva is an experienced, calculating and humourless conqueror. His noble upbringing, and education at the finest military academies has primed him for a life in power. A staunch traditionalist, his conviction is that the crumbling empire of La Corona - in whose service he profits - will prevail against a world in rebellion.

Lady Margaret Hunt's influence cannot be overestimated. A member of the Royal Council, she is trusted by all, rarely seeking sympathy for what has unquestionably been a difficult life.
After all, she was born a Harlow — a name now synonymous with treason — but then, that was all buried long ago.

Anne Harlow is the vengeful leader of a forsaken band — the last hurrah of piracy. She was born into nobility, only to see her father Benjamin hung for speaking against the King. In exile, Anne's lust to destroy the crown and social order has only grown with the arrival of a new and vulnerable Queen.

Jean La Fortune escaped a life of slavery to become the leader of a fledgling nation on the isle his people call High Mountain. But his people cannot hope to grow while the Empire refuses to recognise their independence. With few allies in society, it seems Jean has little choice left but to fight.

Isabel Sarmento is the passionate leader of a rebellion in the New World which people call "The Movement", striving for independence from Old World empires. She lost her brother to the violence, but this only seems to have strengthened her resolve. She knows her people will have to fight clever if they want to build a lasting future for themselves.

Eli Bleakworth is a deeply resentful servant of the crown, charged with governing Wormways Prison, a depraved and isolated facility. Taking great pleasure in carrying out punishments, he is strict and unbending, believing the scum receive only what they deserve. Suspicious to the core, he will no doubt be keeping his beady eyes on you too!

To even browse Kahina's emporium can feel like a privilege, so luxurious are her exotic displays. But to Kahina, this whole enterprise is rather humdrum - a compromise for her comfort and safety, and one that seems desperately dull in comparison to the daredevil life of intrigue and prestige that she once led.

Sir Archibald Blake is the steadfast counsel of Her Majesty the Queen. Optimistic, tactful and yet frequently awkward, good old Archie just wants everyone to get along. Years of diplomatic dinners have cultivated in him a great predilection for small talk, which can lead the unwary into believing he is not as wise as he truly is.

Nathaniel Spoondrift, A.K.A. "Old Nate", is a drifter, opportunist and inventor. His life's work is his zeppelin, and the island at which it is moored — both hodgepodges of parts he's spent years scrounging for.
Aside from his mysterious employees, Nate rarely crosses paths with others — not unless they're willing to help him strip a corpse.

Vasco Oliveira is the emissary of King João of La Corona, outranking and outdressing his cousin Admiral Vicente Silva. Yet he often cuts a jaded figure — a man loyal to an empire upon which the sun is setting. Whatever happens, he is sure to maintain his discretion and dignity until the very end.

Qumaq is an Inuit elder who, given his aptitude for languages, is the perfect person to welcome visitors to the Arctic. Although his previous encounters with the peoples of the Old World might reasonably have left him with a poor opinion of you, it is not in his nature to judge. Treat the Arctic with the awe and respect it deserves, and you can expect a very warm welcome at his iglu.

Lady Jane Faithful is convinced that her husband, Sir John, can still be found. His expedition went missing in the Arctic while seeking “The Passage” — a fabled shortcut to the far side of the world. The Arctic Council, who commissioned the expedition, seem to have given up all hope of finding any survivors — but Lady Faithful hasn’t. Using her considerable influence and funds, she is recruiting the world’s best to make a thorough and conclusive search of her own.

Follow the Queen to Cape Trelawney — a new session with an immense continental island — and scan the oceans for remarkable treasures using Old Nate's newest invention: the diving bell.

Build the first grand Botanical Gardens of the era, with dreamlands of sinuous trees, impossible colour and scented blooms imported from afar. Let your Botanical Garden blossom with the new pathway ornaments and revel in classic Anno themes with the new Music Pavilion.
Conquer the Arctic's extreme conditions with new gameplay mechanics, characters and production chains. Be the first to build airships to soar the sky and find Sir John Faithful's lost expedition.

Save as:
Residences don't need to be located close to factories. Your workforce is available wherever your factories are on an island.
You can build multiple residences, farm fields or ornaments by clicking and dragging.
Request to purchase any product from your Trading Post menu, and visiting trade ships will conduct the transaction automatically.
Check what trades have been carried out lately in your Trading Post's trade history.
Hold shift while building farm fields to override the farm's module limit.
Use the upgrade tool to upgrade multiple buildings at the same time. Drag to cover your selection, or hold Shift to select adjacent buildings.
You can also use the upgrade tool to repair multiple ruins at the same time. Simply drag to cover your selection, or hold Shift to select adjacent ruins.
You can use the upgrade tool to finalise multiple blueprints at the same time. Simply drag to cover your selection, or hold Shift to select any adjacent blueprints.
Hold Shift while upgrading to upgrade as many buildings of the same type as you can afford.
Click the middle button on your mouse to rotate any building in the building preview. It even applies to roads!
You don't need to fulfill your residents' luxury needs in order to upgrade their residences.
Fulfilling some of your residents' needs will greatly increase your income, while fulfilling others will increase their happiness.
Hold Shift while using the demolish tool to demolish different types of buildings at the same time.
Right click at any time to exit the building preview.
Lumberjack's Huts don't need to wait for a forest to grow if they're already built in a lush forest.
Load your expedition ships with different types of rations to maintain a good level of morale among your crew.
Check the captain's recommendations before launching an expedition. Prepare your ship as best you can to face every possible threat.
You can change the working conditions of your workforce on farms or in factories to increase their productivity, or decrease it to make their lives a bit easier.
Visitors can't arrive on your island via your Trading Post! You'll need to build a public mooring for them.
Be careful not to upgrade every residence! You'll still need the previous level of workforce for your production buildings! Use the downgrade button on the residence menu to correct any mistakes.
Did you know? Investor residences add influence!
You always get back the influence you invest, even on expert difficulty level.
Check the captain's recommendations before starting an expedition. Try to prepare your ship with the most appropriate supplies, equipment and personnel.
Change the working conditions at your farms or factories to get more productivity out of your workforce.
Build a public mooring to attract visitors to your island.
The right-click menu stays open if you make use of the lock symbol.
Did you know? When you hold shift and click the pause/play button on a factory, it will pause or start all factories of that type.
If you don't keep your people warm in the Arctic, they'll be more likely to suffer from illnesses. Heaters have a limited heat radius, and require a constant supply of coal.
Gas power stations are more efficient. Harness gas in the Arctic, and build power stations that don't even require a railway connection!
Deep Gold Mines and Prime Hunting Cabins in the Arctic produce more resources than their Old World counterparts.
If you run low on coal in the Arctic, don't forget that you can bring in extra coal from other regions!

A collection of some of the most elegant and refined architectural models throughout history.
A showcase of modern innovation through astonishing devices.
A cabinet of curiosities bursting with antique sculptures, writings and art pieces.
These splendid artifacts from the past will make our curator happy!
These new devices will drive our industry forward to never before seen heights!
These construction plans are now free for us to use! They will enrich our city for sure!
The exhibition is wonderful, but sadly there's no-one here to admire it!
Have you seen those vast sculptures? No one can convince me humans built them - but they might just still fit in my garden!
The World's Fair is a trove of wonder. Not of the past, but of the future! Who knows, maybe we'll even land on the moon one day!
Columns, exotic motifs and other monumental architecture! The World's Fair has become a portal to other, more beautiful worlds!
There is a problem at the World's Fair. Everything is on hold until you find a solution!
The event will be starting a bit later than expected; more investors would help speed things up.
I'm not sure if it really was any better back then, but these remains of past civilizations are breathtaking nevertheless. Hopefully the mummies and dinosaurs won't come to life and escape!
We have entered a new era! Our technological and industrial progress is so fast, I worry we'll run out space for all these new inventions!
I can already imagine the symmetry and elegance the designs of these contemporary architects shall bring. Oh, it will be a delight for all those who can see.

A bit of signage to cheaply embellish your city.
A few signs and paving variations.
All you need to design a small plaza in your city.
A very elegant pack of mosaics and colonnades for a beautiful esplanade.
The latest creation to bring clean water to your city with a flourish.
Columns and channels to match the ancient style.
A couple of unique buildings for the gates of your city.
A few aesthetic additions for the water features of your city.
Buildings and pavillions to create a beautiful annexe for your World's Fair.
Mostly mechanical tools of little value.
First-hand equipment to reinforce your buildings and production.
Low quality seeds that still ensure your crops grow where you desire them to.
Some advanced technology to enhance your production.
The product of the latest research in chemistry.
The best tools and structures to reinforce your production.
A selection of newly designed machines that use electricity to achieve miracles.
All you need for a very efficient and modern farming industry.
The latest inventions of the most talented engineers of the era.
A few old possessions and statues of little value.
The spartan possessions of an ancient warrior.
The remains of a modest tomb.
Old writings, some of which are now of great value.
Some remains that once belonged to a wealthy person.
Funerary textiles buried with a noble in her tomb.
A pack of bones from creatures long gone.
Legendary artifacts that no one thought could be real.
The remains of the greatest constructions of the past.
It was an abysmal decision to come here!
I should have given away my tickets!
That was a real disaster!
The organiser should be brought before the court!
The organiser is a fraudster!
The worst exhibition I have ever visited!
That's going to give me nightmares!
The most depressing event ever.
The less said, the better.
This sort of dupe should be forbidden!
It left my children in tears!
I can't believe this sort of rubbish exists.
I can't believe all the problems that were overlooked!
Please, for everyone's sake, stop trying to organise events!
A disappointment.
I expected much more.
I probably won't come back.
Definitely not state of the art!
Next time, I'll check carefully before I bother with an event like this.
I had more fun reading the invitation brochure.
A long and gruelling day.
I have rarely been so bored.
I won't recommend it to my friends.
The event was pretty bad.
It really was amateurish.
A waste of time.
Could still have been better.
Shows potential for future events.
A good experience, but incomplete.
Not quite as much fun as I had expected.
The event had some good moments.
It fell a bit short.
The whole thing still feels slightly naive.
Hopefully next time, there'll be a bit more inspiration.
Not great, not bad.
The food was acceptable.
If I hadn't met my friends there, I might have left earlier.
I'm saddened it's already over!
Almost perfect! The food, the drink, everything!
A very enjoyable event!
A great moment!
I look forward to the next one!
A beautiful experience.
I stayed for several days!
All my acquaintances enjoyed it, too!
A great occasion for the whole family!
I liked it greatly. And I'll come back!
Worth every penny spent!
Very impressive!
The best event I've ever visited!
Everyone was singing its praises on the way back home!
Truly state of the art!
A sublime, outstanding experience!
I desperately want to come back!
This will go down in history, for sure!
The best trip of my life, by far.
A really awe-inspiring exhibition!
I've never seen so many happy faces before!
Wandering through the exhibits was like a waking dream!
My water closet is better designed than that!
The exhibition map wasn't even drawn correctly!
There were gross underestimations of quantity in the organisation!
The very foundation of our civilisation is being affronted here!
You don't build an event like you build a house of cards.
An architectural event that can't stand firm? That is the height of hypocrisy!
Architecture has nothing to do with magic, and neither does this exhibition!
It gave me some ideas for refurbishing my drawing room, at least.
The gardens were somehow... the best designs.
An exposed mosaic in my bathroom might look nice. I really enjoyed that aesthetic.
Intricate designs becoming pieces of art!
An exhibition that truly lives up to the quality of its exhibition space.
I hope the city council will take some inspiration from this fine exhibition!
A modern wonder of the world, is this event!
The first stone that paves the way to an extraordinary new era in architecture!
Monumental!
According to my calculations, the verdict is precisely... one out of ten.
This exhibition is enough to convert a scientist into a creationist.
A complete insult to the scientific progress of our contemporaries.
I learned more at school than I did here, and my school was dreadful.
It took inspiration from bacterial growth for its organisation: it was completely out of control!
Perhaps they could invent replacement brains for the organisers.
The door to the truth opens!
Our inventors deserve a bigger stage.
A stable element. Not great, not bad.
The exhibit with a refrigeration machine was my favourite!
Taking a daguerreotype picture was the best way to immortalise this fabulous moment!
Incredible machines in an incredible place!
This could bring an end to all those illogical belief systems!
Eureka!
This will show the world who leads the industrial revolution!
This exhibition is pushing the boundaries of what we presume to know!
Ancient peoples might be rather embarassd to see what we've become...
I felt like a skeleton by the end of it...
The exhibition space on its own would probably have been more interesting.
The organisation is as outdated as the exhibits on display...
Maybe they found the exhibits in a children's sandpit?
There are more antiquities in my mother's bathroom than there were in there!
It was just a load of stuff you can find anywhere else: a bunch of pebbles and broken crockery!
Something like those ancient mosaics might look nice in our bathroom.
Those mosaics might have looked quite pleasant out on our veranda.
Quite the cabinet of curiosities!
A true homage to our ancestors.
I'm pretty sure those mummies were delighted to meet us!
It's far more interactive than the museum!
I want to become an archaeologist now! One with a whip!
The excellent organisation really allowed the exhibits to sing!
Perhaps the remains of this exhibition will be held up one day as an artefact of a great civilisation!
The event was lacking ambition.
It was rather a modest event...
Even for a small event, security should be better!
Rather a pifflingly small event, don't you think?
I was disappointed there were no delicate fruits and sweetmeats to eat.
Not even a single caviar canapé!
I think it's just about the right size of event, but nothing more.
The event seemed no more than ordinary thanks to its mediocre organisation.
There aren't quite enough nibbles to go around.
Even a modest drink selection can make for a successful, albeit unexceptional, event!
You might think of organising bigger scale exhibitions!
The display of fruits! It was glorious!
Bigger events could learn a lot from this well-organised affair.
The organisers will go on to create even bigger and better things, I'm sure!
A very safe bet: a modest event, but optimal organisation!
They shouldn't organise a large event if they can't ensure their visitors' security!
Where was the banquet? There was hardly any food for such a large event!
Such a large venue, but with scarcely a decoration in sight! What a pity!
I have a sweet tooth, so I really wish they had something for dessert! Something exotic!
Maybe they should scale down to a smaller event...
I really missed some kind of banquet.
It was missing something, but I don't know what... Some booze? Some decorations?
Large events require much more organisation!
If only this large event were less boring, I would have stayed longer.
The little decorations did make the place more welcoming!
The exotic desserts were astonishing!
The generous drink selection contributed to the general feelings of mirth!
A very sizeable banquet! I saw many jolly faces around!
Everyone agreed that the organiser should make it even bigger next time!
You rarely find large events that are quite this good!
Investing so much money in such a grand event, only to end up failing like this... What a waste!
The organisers should be investigated for wasting all this money.
Nothing to eat and drink at an event that was supposed to be "sumptuous"! A farce!
If only there had been games and amusements for the visitors!
I read "banquet of great extravagance" on the invitation, but there was no such thing!
The decorations were not up to the mark!
Still some work to do for the next one. We want more than just a banquet and some booze - we want games and pastimes!
I can see some potential, despite the long queues for the buffet.
The decorations could have been a bit better. It was a bit lacklustre.
I enjoyed the luxury alcohol - there just wasn't enough of it!
The dignitaries really enjoyed the extravagant banquet and leisure activities!
Did you see the desserts? Towering centerpieces of culinary art!
The visitors' jaws dropped when they saw the selection of drinks!
A masterpiece of organisation. The grandest and most beautiful event I've ever visited!
We had only the best in this monumental place. The success of the century!
The quality, the refinement, the abundance! This event will go down in history!

The foundation of something monumental. This vast dig site marks the first step in the journey towards the World's Fair, an exhibition space to dwarf all other celebrations of human endeavour.
The World's Fair is beginning to take shape: the foundations have been laid, the scaffolding erected, and now the walls are springing up. Anticipation is building!
With the World's Fair superstructure almost complete, careful work has begun on the distinctive glass and steel canopy that will make this grand exhibition hall so very unique.
The waiting is nearly at an end! The World's Fair needs only electricity, insulation and a few last-minute touches to its majestic roof, before the ribbon can be cut to a triumphant fanfare!
In order to blow a way through to Ditchwater's iron deposits, these abandoned tunnels will first need to be secured with scaffolding, before any explosive charges can be placed.
With the tunnels now secured with scaffolding, an expert in demolitions is needed to make sure the dynamite is all correctly wired and strategically placed!
An empty plot of land chosen by the Queen herself as the prime location for the Empire's flagship Court of Justice, upon completion of which the nefarious traitor Edvard Goode is to stand trial.
The steel framework for the new Court of Justice is near complete, as are the foundations of the wings. Already, it is beginning to look like an edifice of integrity and incorruptibility.
The Queen's new courthouse is missing only a roof, and skylights through which the divine rays of justice may flood, exposing all who would dare to betray her.

All Population Tiers
This dazzling lighthouse is a place where characters will offer you quests from time to time.
A link with nature in the middle of the city.
A young washerwoman rests under a vast, vast tree. She's secretly in love, but she only dares carve her beloved's face within the wood, for the boy is very busy person, and he must not be disturbed.

A young painter sits alone in his vast, vast workshop. He wishes he could trade the painted flowers for their actual fragrant selves, but he cannot, for his every waking moment must be spent in service of his art.
The painter was devoted to his art, but his strokes failed to invoke the real world. So one day, the painter chose to abandon the brush, and engaged in a walk in the shade of the orchard.
The washerwoman quivered at the glimpse of her beloved above the hedge. "This will be my only chance", she told herself, "either he'll notice me now, or he'll notice me never".
Quite faithful to the famous royal garden.
A haven of peace for ducks and dragonflies.

The painter would gaze at the water for hours, but never seemed to see her. So the washerwoman put down her basket, clasped her hands, and prayed that he might remember her. Slowly, she walked into the pond, never to return.
Perfect for sunbathing.
Fluffy blobs of green.
Provides enough shadow for an afternoon of reading.
Ancient elegance.
Sunbeams dance through its leaves.
Nature in the middle of the city.
Colourful and with a delightful fragrance.
A tall man takes a knife to his mother's favourite tree. In memoriam, he carves.
Artists like to take a walk in the shade of the orchard.
Inspiring walks through the orchard.
Loved by historians and birds alike.
A small girl ruffles her black dress and smiles up at her father. "I hope Nana likes it", she says.
A tall man sits on a bench and cups his face in his hands. Unseen, he weeps.
A fascinating power emanates from its eyes.
Throw a coin - maybe your wish will come true?
An old woman beholds her reflection on the water next to her granddaughter, separated only by decades.
A haven for dragonflies.
Boys usually throw coins into the water, and wait for their wish to come true.
A favourite meeting point for lovers.
Perfect for children's games and leisurely strolls.
Pleasant shade and a hot cup of tea to last the whole afternoon.
Provides the latest news for residents, and charming souvenirs for visitors.
Handy to satisfy a thirst.
Lets couples stroll in peace.
A beautiful border for a beautiful place.
A beautiful entrance to the piazza.
The sight of this statue lightens the heart of hard working women.
"How long do I wait until I end this terror? How long, I wonder?"
"How long can I accept a fate filled with dust instead of pure water? How long, I wonder?"
Separates the properties from the street. Can also serve as a bench.
"How long can I continue to pursue a life enclosed by borders? How long, I wonder?"
Local and exotic goods mixed together.
"How long can I transport those crates for the good of their rich owners? How long, I wonder?"
"How long can I bear these buckets full of water? How long, I wonder?"
The sun reflects on its polished surface, and dazzles visitors and residents alike.
Step on art.
Finally, a place to rest our feet after all this sight-seeing!
In loving memory of someone not many people remember.
It grows with every poster added.
The best place to keep up with the latest theatrical productions.
It flaps gracefully in the coastal breeze.
Provides the latest news for residents, and charming souvenirs for visitors.
A memorial to the glorious deeds of the year 1602.
A favoured retreat for any self-respecting strategy player, like good old Geri!
Elegant and serene.
There's no heart that can't be appeased by the sound of the gentle lap of water.
What could be more romantic than contemplating your reflections together?
A modern architectural landmark to accompany the finest events.
The most impressive entrance to the World Fair.
A magnificent addendum to your monument.
There's a real sense of enormity about them.
A beautiful border for a beautiful place.
A gateway into wonderland.
Lets couples stroll in peace.
How many times do we have to tell you: there is no time-based achievement!
The greatest movement of the industrial age!
Break the shackles of the establishment. Anarchy for all!
Discover the marvels that lie beneath the surface.
Mother Nature's masterpieces in the heart of your metropolis.
Be the first to reach the edge of the world — open The Passage.
All you need is Anno.
United under one flag.
Acceptance is the first step.
Fire up your jack-o'-lanterns and fill up your baskets with witchy treats, Samhain is here.
Ho ho ho! Keep your chimneys swept for Father Christmas!

There's always a chance of fire. Areas with high building density are more likely to suffer a fire. Fire stations reduce the chance of fires.
Unhappy residents may riot. Rough working conditions multiply the probability of riots. Police stations reduce the riot chance.
The chance of illness is reduced when all needs are satisfied. Dense cities are more prone to illnesses. Hospitals reduce the chance of illness.

After the tin rush, the place went to dust and decay.
They came here for salvation; never did they find it.
The ghostly shadow of a marketplace, but not a spirit of togetherness lingers.
When the price of copper rose, Ditchwater was no more.
The tin drew them here. There was no other reason to come.
Even in the boom times, the tin men preferred to drink alone.
Just a sad, dark hole remains, from whence the tin ants once crawled.
The farmers were the last to leave, but by then there was no town to feed.
Dutiful waters continue to turn the rusty blades of the waterwheel.
The bailiffs' housing. They were here to confiscate, to devastate.
The tin-pot dictators were the first to leave when fortunes turned.
These ruins are more stubborn. Your farmers have neither the tools, nor the skills required to demolish them.
You need more people before you can demolish these ruins.
A town cannot blossom if it's built on lies.
Even the local hermit gave up his refuge and fled.
Hard to imagine children at play in this wasteland.
Strong liquor kept the tin men digging blind.
No bleating of spring lambs, just the creak of bolted shutters.
Even in the good times, the place always lacked a soul.
That it was once a lively place to live, this ash and debris cannot attest.
The whole idea was a rush of hot blood; now but a scab on the land remains.
Greed is hollow, like the smashed-up local saloon, and its pilfered lockboxes.
Bats in the belfry, knives in the walls, the ghosts of haunted faces in the filthy mirrors.
Even the rats have fled, leaving droppings and litter behind them.
The tin men had no unity, no power to protest.
The lights went off here long ago.

The most gleefully-anticipated festival! The beer flows freely, and joy and good humour follow! Some like to call it Oktoberfest!
This traditional festival manifests in a magnificent feast for your citizens, celebrating a bounteous end to the harvest!
The cultural heart of your city is throbbing! Theatrical, musical, and literary events have gripped the place, to the great delight of your visitors!
Your population have rarely showed as much faith in their esteemed leader as today! They express their patriotism in honour of your great accomplishments.
What's better than a bit of official mayhem once a year? Masked and fancy-dressed, your citizens can forget themselves and really cut loose!

NO LOCA MetaSession
The Old World
The New World
Calico's Rogues Snare a Merchant Ship

A helpless merchant brig is being pillaged by despicable pirates. Its captain is a friend to many of your crew, who are ready to die in order to save him. The pirates answer to Calico Roberts - the last terrible pirate - but the light is dim, and they have not noticed your ship.
Ask the advice of your former pirate

'I knew this would come in handy someday,' the old cove mutters, as he unravels the flag of Calico Roberts. 'They wouldn't dare tear their master's cloth!' As your ship steers into view with the new flag, the pirates do nothing. They fully believe you serve the same master! Your guns fire and surrender is quick. The merchants are grateful and offer considerable compensation!
Fire cannons at the pirates' ship

Success comes quickly. Volley after volley of ordnance so cleanly perforates the pirate hull, it is turned into alpine cheese. The surprised pirates are suddenly waving the white flag, and the skirmish is won. The merchants are thankful to see their goods returned and offer a fitting reward.

The attack is an abysmal failure. Almost every cannon shoots wayward, giving the pirates ample time to prepare their own onslaught. They laugh and cheer, and shout awful things as your tattered ship is forced to flee in shame.
Try to board the pirates' ship

It's a good fight in which the crew hold their nerve. At first range-finding proves difficult, alerting the pirates to ready their own guns. But after a few exchanges it is clear who is better-equipped, and the pirates raise the white flag. Although some of the men sustain injuries, the merchants are able to offer financial recompense.

The courageous crew triumph, rushing aboard quickly enough for it to be a surprise, before blowing half the pirates to dust with their blunderbusses. The remaining pirates drop their weapons, and the merchants are able to come out of hiding. 'A great reward is in order', they say, giving you a generous portion of the recovered loot.

Victory comes at a cost. Luck often plays a part in deck skirmishes, and your crew, unable to surprise the wary pirates, must take many casualties before asserting dominance. The merchants are indebted, and reward your rash heroism appropriately.

Boarding the ship is a grave mistake. The pirates are too quick and already have the initiative. The men are forced to retreat, kicking the boarding plank away. [AssetData([ExpeditionEventRequirement]) Text] and the others are condemned to a no-doubt gruesome fate.
Avoid the trouble spot entirely

'We're bloomin' cowards!' cries a furious sailor, as your ship whisks about, and sails briskly from danger. With the merchant ship left to the dogs, the crew fume at such a display of weakness at their friend's time of need.
Dockyard Dupe

Robbed! Having thanked the generous innkeeper, your ship departed what seemed a most hospitable port. Even at the time, your crew were surprised to see so many smiling faces gather at the dock to wave you off. A mere hour into the onward journey, however, it's discovered that a great deal of valuable property is missing from the hold. You must now decide if it's worth going back for.
Have your detective investigate

The detective already knows the culprit. "I was waiting to see if our crew were complicit, but I am satisfied they are not." Your ship returns and lays out a watertight case to the local authorities, incriminating the local innkeeper. He is arrested, your equipment is returned and your ship receives a resupply. It seems that hospitality was genuine after all!
Return and plunder the Harbour

Swift justice. The petty harbour defences crumble in the morning light. Your ship streaks unopposed into what remains of the smouldering harbour, and turns its guns upon the harbourmaster's office. "Please, take anything!" he yelps, "You'll find all your things in the warehouse, and more besides." You profit from a scheme that has been running for years.
Your assault is too slow. Just as you begin to gain the upper hand over the defenders, the cavalry appear. Cannons pop from the west; a slew of artillery reinforcements.

An absolute shambles. Your men couldn't even best a few locals with a primitive demi-cannon. "Who shall have our guts for garters next?" yelp those who survive the barrage, "A small gang of angry turtles?" Your ship sails hurriedly away.
Fight them all

You put an end to the corruption! Brought to their knees, the local authorities admit a conspiracy in which all were complicit. "It was never meant to go this far. We vow our people shall never rob innocent travellers again!" Proud to have effected change, you take back your possessions and leave.

The enemy force is vast. "There's too many, Captain! We must turn back!" But it is too late. The western cliff lights up with cannon fire, and your ship follows suit. Many lives will be lost before you finally crawl out of range.
Make peace, and reason with the officials

Despite your earlier aggression, they are willing to listen. After an exasperating few days, you are finally able to prove your losses. The authorities take in any dockers who are found to be guilty, and most, if not all of your possessions are returned.

The authorities stand with their own. Following a ceasefire, you make your case as best you can, but it's not enough. Furthermore, you must answer for the damage you've caused. Unfortunately, this will mean leaving some of your best sailors behind to help with repairs.
Return to the inn in disguise and bait the robbers

You rumble the schemers! The crew set aside superstition, and paint the ship with a different name. The most cut-throat of your sailors pose as wealthy officers, cabin curtains for sashes, so as to appear perfect victims. Taken in by it all, the innkeeper and his dockside associates are caught in the act. You make sure to relieve them of far more than they stole.

The disguises are unconvincing. A lick of paint, and the ship differs enough to blend in at the busy port, but moustaches and a change of clothes aren't enough for the sly innkeeper. "Thought you could fool us?" he scoffs.

Your disguises are comically poor, and yet the innkeeper is the picture of cordiality as he ushers your men to retake their seats. Your men exchange hopeful looks, but the other patrons start laughing. Almost in unison, they draw their pistols. "What were we thinking?" mutter your men. "I wonder where you'll end up!" the innkeeper cackles, as he has your crew stripped, bound, and pushed off to sea.
Take back what is yours by force

Sometimes a fistfight is the only way. The inn is a hurricane of chairs and glass, as your crew express themselves the only way they know how. Once the locals are subdued, the innkeeper is dragged outside, his life used as a security against whatever plunder you please.

The locals are brutal. Home-made knuckles, knives and cudgels scrape open the faces of your crew. Some are left to bleed out on the sticky hostelry floor, while the bloody remainder are packed off by the authorities for disturbance of the peace. Eventually they will be released, leaving you lighter on both goods and personnel.
Threaten to expose their scheme

The innkeeper agrees to negotiate. "We've got a good thing going here, and I don't want you spoiling it," he sniffs, "take what's yours and leave." Glad to avoid further trouble, your crew recover their possessions and leave. One can but feel sorry for the next poor victims of this villainous scheme.

"Get out, before we scratch you out!" growls the innkeeper, his true colours plain to see. It seems every surly thug in the port is on his side. The expedition must take this loss of time and equipment on the chin.
Appeal to the local authorities

You make the case well. "You are quite right. Terrible corruption such as this must be put to an end!" says the governor, "And of course, you shall have back what was taken." His disingenuousness stinks to high heaven, but you don't have time to go digging any deeper.
They are completely corrupt. "What an extraordinary tale! I am so glad our little country has fired your imagination!" smiles the governor.
Risk implicating the governor

"Clever. Very clever," admits the medal-draped governor, as he puffs solemnly on his cigar. "How did you know the innkeeper was my brother?" Your emissary doesn't let slip it was pure guesswork. "Go ahead, take whatever you want," he gestures to a warehouse bursting with confiscated goods, "so long as you keep quiet about all this— can't have my superiors finding out."

"A grave last mistake," chuckles the governor, as the poplar-lined grounds of his palace swarm with militia, "arrest these fops!" Your delegation try to resist, but are armed only with the toothpicks that came with their canapes. Your expedition must now manage without them.
Resort to violence

"Alright, alright!" says the amused governor, bayonet to his neck, "take back what you lost. But then you leave." Since the harbour is now so well-guarded, it feels rather an achievement to have forced any sort of compromise.

'That was a mistake,' chuckles the governor, as his poplar-lined palace swarms with militia, 'arrest them!' Your crew would rather die than be locked-up for life, so they fight their way out. At least, one or two of them do.
Give up and leave

There's widespread frustration among the crew. "Those instruments were vital for my research!", "You let the beggars off scot free?!", "This expedition is an embarrassment!" It's hard to argue with their assessment, and bad for morale.
Take the loss on the chin

There's widespread frustration among the crew. "Those instruments were vital for my research!", "You let the beggars off scot free?!", "This expedition is an embarrassment!" It's hard to argue with their assessment, and bad for morale.
Iceberg

Your ship is stranded on an iceberg! It is night. The meek light of your vessel seems to dissolve into the moonless blackness. Even at easy sail and under constant vigil, your ship is running the risk in these waters, for slumbering ice giants lurk in the darkness in all directions. "Dead ahead!" comes the cry, but it's too late. A low growl shakes the boat, as a wave dumps it atop an iceberg, which is shaped like an upturned molar. The ship is undamaged, but beached — if only it could be returned to the water...
Break free with dynamite

Nothing in nature can prevail against human endeavour, it would seem. The crew watch with trepidation as the fuses burn down to the stick, before an ear-splitting series of detonations ring across the vastness, sundering the icy claws that had held your ship hostage. A small blizzard of debris blankets the deck, to the hilarity of all on board, for they are free once more!
Bombard the icy prison

Ice crumbles all around courtesy of some impressive firepower. Any cannon that can be swiveled at the target is put to use, chipping away at the icy dungeon in which the ship has become wedged until the way is clear. Then, like a cheerful sea lion, the fair vessel slips down an escarpment and plops back into the water. The crew cheer.

The iceberg fights back. Though the way is almost clear, the relentless cannon fire seems to have woken the ogre below — and to the horror of the crew, the vast berg rolls slightly to one side. Great shards of ice detach and bounce over the deck, injuring your men. Quick action is needed.
Get out and push the ship free

Your men live for such challenges, and scarcely need telling what to do. Leaping down from the boat, they get behind her, knotting guy ropes as fast as they can. As they work, the berg rumbles suggestively, but it is your quick-thinking crew who prevail. Once clear of the ice field, the crew will be able to treat their wounds.

It's an uphill struggle. The pitching of the unstable berg does not help one jot, as the men tumble and slide to find grip. Such is the effort required to pull the ship successfully down from the iceberg into the sea, that no-one notices one of the teams is missing. It appears they have fallen through a thin part of the ice to their deaths...
Let the rolling iceberg toss you into the sea

Your ship performs a rather messy dismount. After that initial roll, the iceberg halts long enough to suggest it wants to stay in its new position — but then everything happens all at once. The berg spins violently, and the ship goes with it! The ship strikes the water at such an angle that very serious damage is done to much of the lee-side. Fortunately, the crew emerge unharmed.
Build something to help you escape

The crew assemble a dozen hardy levers to free the ship. Flexible hickory planking is cut and reshaped into wedges, before being inserted into the ice at intervals of five paces, until they surround the stern. On a count of three the men lift, and to their surprise, so does the hull! Once it starts moving, there's no stopping it, and it clatters through the icy obstructions to the sea. Your sailors embrace in the wake of their success — they have been very resourceful.

The crew choose the wrong wood for the task. They select a decorative mahogany veneer, stripped from the captain's cabin. "Whatever it takes," the captain says with laudable magnanimity, but the whole business is futile. Despite the wedges being placed in great number at the stern of the ship, no amount of pressure from the crew can encourage the ship to move, since the levers lack the requisite spring. They'll need to find another way off this iceberg.
Pray for divine intervention

The crew realise they are blessed! "If God has seen fit to place us here, we should trust in him," says the ship's holy man, thoughtfully, "I would not discount the idea that this very iceberg has sentience! I know of at least one explorer whose expeditions ride bergs by design!" Indeed, the navigators observe that the iceberg is itself moving, and at fair speed, in a desirable direction. This shall make a fine home for a time.

The days melt into weeks that melt into months. Even the probable agnostics among the crew take to prayer, for each passing day there is some fresh cause for optimism, some sign that someone is listening. As spring approaches, some of the berg thaws. One day, a migratory bird is spotted. At long, long last, a vast chunk of the iceberg separates, leaving the ship mere metres from open water. A day of heaving has it afloat again, though your men have lost all notion of time.

There is no-one out there. After a week perched atop the pink-white berg, with supplies diminishing, the crew cannot bear to wait in the gnawing cold any longer. Any help will have to come from within.
Sea of Sargassum

A ship in need of rescue! The vast floating tapestries of algae in these windless waters have long been thought impassable. Just when you thought your own vessel had managed to avoid the yellow-orange plants, you see another ship stuck fast! They must also have seen you, as their alarm begins to sound. With no proper rescue equipment aboard, your own ship risks becoming entangled if you get too close. Should you try to help?
A steamship should have nothing to fear here

Your steamer glides effortlessly through. The crew lean from the rails to peer at the sargassum colony, which is thick with sealife like crabs and tropical fish. The algae parts easily before your ship. The absence of wind presents no difficulty as it would for a sailboat, and indeed, as you tug them into open water, the crew of the ship in distress explain it was not the algae, but the calm that had stalled them. They are delighted to have been discovered, and several of them offer to join your expedition.
Harpoon them and tug them away

A good shot, but there is too little wind to tug them clear. Having signalled your intention, the gunner sends the harpoon crunching into the other ship's hull. A fine shot, considering it was at the limit of the harpoon's range. However, the calm prohibits them pulling the ship out of the brown mass of algae, so the crew consider their next steps.
Throw them a 'life-line'

The breeches buoy guarantees a safe rescue. The crew transform a lifebuoy into a harness, and attach it to runners which allow it to zip between the two ships once the harpoon rope is drawn taut. The stranded sailors take it in turns to enjoy this rather daring form of escape. Having been lifted from the doldrums, they are keen to assist however they may for the remainder of the expedition.

The breeches buoy shears off into the water just as the first sailor climbs onto the contraption, leaving it dangling perilously from the rope between the two ships. Desperate for rescue, the crew of the stranded boat decide to swim for it instead. After thrashing the distance, the mariners eventually slop aboard, their bodies jaundiced with algae. "Five years we've been stuck here," one stammers angrily. They're going to be quite a burden on your expedition.
Inspire them to traverse the rope

A surge of belief animates the stranded sailors. "You are saved!" cries your lookout, "your ordeal is over!" Under the encouragement of your lieutenants, the other crew grab the rope, and with the desperate strength of hope, they cross the distance to reach your ship. Your crew's goodwill has shone through, and the grateful survivors join your expedition without a second thought.

They take no strength from your crew's silent prayer. If only someone had offered a few more words of encouragement — anything positive at all. First to cross is an old man so thin, you could fold him up and tuck him in a drawer. Clutching the fibrous rope is challenge enough for his frail wrists, and after a brief struggle, he drops off. His crewmates jump in with him, and commence a desperate thrash through the brown sargassum. The few that make it to your ship will only be a burden on your expedition.

Panicked sailors toss themselves into the algae, as your stray harpoon crashes wildly through the lower deck, and seawater rushes in through the breach. She's going down! "We brought them to this," yells one of your officers, "we have a responsibility to do something!"
Send your best swimmers to the rescue

Your swimmers are strong and fit enough, but the malnourished crew of the sinking ship need all the help they can get. The algae weighs like a lion's mane on your heroes, as they relay the castaways on-by-one. Once all are accounted for, they lie on the burning deck, panting. This whole episode has been exhausting.

The rescue is a tragedy. Your men paddle like puppies in the densely-packed sargassum — it's hard to understand quite how sailors could be so lacking in practice. Gasping, they reach desperately towards the castaways they should be rescuing, as if for support, only for the undertow of the sinking ship to pull them under. This was all your fault.
Leave them to their fate

"We did what we could..." the lieutenant trails off, "...and we couldn't do much!" answers your steersman darkly. There is so little wind here, it takes an eternity to pass the sinking boat by. Hands reach desperately towards you, but the pull of their sinking ship soon drags them under the surface. It will take an awful lot to lift your crew out of the doldrums.
Don't risk it

"Don't leave! We've been here for ten years!" Reads the message in semaphore. There's so little wind here, it takes an eternity to pass the stranded boat by. A drift of shame. Your crew, as yellow-bellied as this sea of sargassum, will need a lot to lift them out of the doldrums.
Jolly Roger

Pirates! The torn black flag bearing a skull and crossbones is a shock to those on your expedition who thought they were a dying breed. The weather-worn ship emerges from the mist with prepared to plunder. Astride her bow stands her colourful captain, axe raised; along her rails, the spectral silhouette of her starving crew, hungry to feed.
Manoeuvre into attack position

You swivel on a sixpence, ready to blow them away! Quickly setting sails to curb momentum, your ship turns in the shallowest possible arc for a vessel this size — a manoeuvre only a tactician well-accustomed to risk would attempt. Meanwhile, some of the crew have improvised a few grenades, should you want to make use of them...
Fire the cannons!

The pirates are sunk before they have chance to do any damage at all! Your ship's guns target the most mould-ridden flank of the corsairs' ship, smashing it through. The antique vessel collapses in on itself, and your sailors enjoy the resulting plunder almost as if they themselves had been the pesky picaroons.

It's a disappointing salvo. Despite being in a strong position, your cannons are miscalibrated, and end up firing short. The pirates know they cannot win this with their outmoded gunnery, and between shots they draw in close, latching onto your ship with their boarding hooks.
Defend against the boarding pirates

Today is not the day you are vanquished by pirates. The rowdy band charge aboard only to find your resolute crew arranged in a classical shield wall, with percussion cap pistols poking out of what few gaps remain. Although your crew sustain fairly gruesome injuries from pirate axes, all but one survive. That young lad is given a funeral, unlike the poor dead pirates.

You're lucky they don't leave with your ship! Some of your sailors are equipped with old flintlocks, whose inaccuracy permits the enemy to engage at close quarters. The swordplay proceeds so terribly on your side that a section of pirates are able to reach the lower deck, and pilfer all they find. Satisfied, their captain bays "fall back!" and the scourge are gone, leaving your crew to count the dead.
Surrender to them

"Take all you want, but please, don't hurt us!" your officer pleads. The pirate captain grins, revealing a jumbled set of shark teeth, before proceeding to strip the chap of his ear. "Sounds fair," he says, still smiling. Your ship is then relieved of its supplies without further violence; the pirates no doubt bound by some arcane code to honour your surrender. You wonder if your expedition can survive on what the little they leave behind.
Bombard them with handmade grenades!

The pirates weren't expecting such a crafty attack. "I was saving these for a special occasion," your weaponsmith burps. The 'special brew' he's concocted consists of a bottle filled with powder, a hemp fuse, and a nail surprise. There's a shimmering sound as they explode, and when the smoke clears, your crew frisk the punctured bodies littering the deck, singing "Rollicking band of pirates, we!"

Ineffective to say the least. The improvised grenades are duff fireworks, and when landing on the pirate deck, they fail to discharge. There is no time to apportion blame, for the tide of battle has swung again in favour of the pirates, who have hooked the two ships together for boarding.

The turn is not sharp enough. There was nothing wrong with the idea, but whatever tactical advantage your ship may have had is lost with the rather cautious turning circle it plots, out of which the ship emerges a slow-moving target.
Position for attack anyway
You make the best of a poor position. At the last moment, your maverick navigators cut inside the approaching pirates, who had been hoping to board you. Your crew have the breathing space now to act!
Fire all cannons!

After a long exchange, the pirates are sunk! Damage is done to both ships, before finally your men "cross the T" by releasing a full broadside into their prow. Immediately, the enemy ship is guzzling water. Any plunder floating above the wreck can serve as compensation for the minor damage you've received.

It is a damaging encounter. The rotted exterior of the pirate vessel invites cannon fire, but their movements are too clever, never exposing their flanks to a broadside. Keen to corner them, your officers overcommit, and in doing so, leave themselves open to a devastating barrage. The pirates take the chance to flee — which is fortunate, because your ship is almost dead in the water.
Board them!

Your crew go beserk for the fight. Most of the ramshackle pirate crew fall in the first bloodthirsty charge, while your raiders suffer only one or two casualties. While the pirates bleed out, your men deprive them of any ill-gotten plunder they have. You then scupper the barque, and watch as it disappears, black flags and all, to meet Davy Jones.

Your crew don't seem too keen. Perhaps they know they won't stand a chance going hand-to-hand with seasoned pirates. As the two ships adjoin, it's the pirates who make the charge. Almost immediately, a pirate swings an axe and lops off a head. Horrified, your steersman hurriedly spins your ship away, with fighters on both sides falling into the resulting chasm. Your depleted crew flees at full speed.
The navigators fail to recover from the initial setback. Your helmsman has no tricks left up his sleeves, and cannot pick up speed to outrun the approaching pirates. They intend to board you!
Fight them to the death

It is a saddening scene. To see this many brave fighters put to the sword is regrettable. Fortunately, the losses are largely on the other side; the pirates' antique weaponry ever more a disadvantage in the modern age. When the last scrawny dog is dead, you set their ship alight like a funeral barque. Your own sailors, still twitching from the skirmish, pour themselves long jars of rum, and remember the fallen.

You are no match for the pirates. The attackers pour in like beetles from all sides, a many-legged brood washing over your forces like some unstoppable plague, crushing all resistance. "I know it's a good'un, but we ain't taking the ship..." the pirate captain is heard to utter by a few survivors, who were cowering behind a locked door, "...just everything on it!" When the sound of looting and cheering has died away, the survivors emerge to find the expedition ship stripped of pretty well everything it had.
Listen to reason and surrender

Should have waved the white flag sooner. Your weapons drop and the pirate captain saunters aboard. She is tall and surprisingly aged, dressed in the dashing clothes of a bygone era, "For our trouble, we'll have some of yer crew for slaves," she growls, "all of 'em left of this line." She swishes her cutlass and portions off several of your crew as her playthings. After that, she turns more amicable, as her horde loot your ship. As they leave, she drops a feathered glove to show her gratitude.
Surrender

"Take all you want, but please, don't hurt us!" your officer pleads. The pirate captain grins, revealing a jumbled set of shark teeth, and proceeds to strip the chap of his ear. "Sounds fair," he says, still smiling. Your ship is then relieved of its supplies without further violence; the pirates no doubt bound by some arcane code to honour your surrender. You wonder if your expedition can survive on what the little they leave behind.
Have an officer make a rousing speech

Your men are resolute following the speech. Your acting lieutenant points his sabre to the sky, defying the heavens themselves. "If I, born with gas lighting, heated water, and a silver spoon in mouth..." with each fresh admission a cheer goes up, "If I can enjoy chopping through these mangy pirates, then you lot will bloody well be in heaven!" There is a raucous cheer as the men prepare for their orders.
Board the pirate ship!

It is indeed a heroic charge. Led by the acting lieutenant, your sailors hurtle down the boarding bridges and storm the pirate ship, leaving a mangled trail in their wake. The black flag is ripped from the mast, and the pirate's booty is plundered. Unexpectedly, however, your lieutenant then impishly permits the survivors to go free — "Come now, be humble in thy victory! For how dull would the world be without these old pirate salts!"

Pirates are always ready for a skirmish! Having delayed boarding until they were properly armed and ready, your men fail to make use of their conviction. On seeing the pirate planks fall first, your lieutenant backtracks, urging caution in the face of the oncoming horde!
Stay put and pick them off

You only take a few losses between reloads, when wild pirates set upon the soldiery with cutlasses and handaxes. Suddenly there is a cry from the pirate ship. The pirate captain has been hit! Clutching her chest, she is borne away below deck on the shoulders of her shipmates. The pirates immediately withdraw so that they may attend to their queen.

The first round of rifle fire misses, and there is no time to prepare a second before the horde are on top of your crew, binding the strongest first, and maiming those who resist. When the hurly-burly's over, the pirates prop your bound survivors against each other as they trawl the ship for goodies, before they wish you "fair winds" and depart, cackling with glee.
Charge anyway!

Your men don't hesitate having come this far. There is a din as the two packs collide, like rugby players, over the divide between the boats. Blood surges over the wooden boards, as men fall on both sides. Finally, the pirates are driven back, at which point they retract their boarding planks and raise their sails to the breeze, spinning away to prey on victims less chewy.

Your men hesitate a second too long, and the pirates have made up the distance between the ships. Now they've been allowed on board, they have the upper hand, and are soon on top of your crew, binding them and maiming those who resist. When the hurly-burly's done, the pirates prop your bound survivors against each other as they trawl the ship for goodies, before wishing you "fair winds" and departing, cackling with glee.
Fire all cannons!

The pirates are sunk before they have a chance to do any damage at all! Your ship's guns target the most mould-ridden flank of the corsairs' ship, smashing it through. The antique vessel collapses in on itself, and your sailors enjoy the resulting plunder almost as if they themselves had been the pesky picaroons.

It's a disappointing salvo. Despite being in a strong position, your cannons are miscalibrated, and end up firing short. The pirates know they cannot win this with their outmoded gunnery, and between shots they draw in close, latching onto your ship with their boarding hooks.
Defend against the boarding pirates

Today is not the day you are vanquished by pirates. The rowdy band charge aboard only to find your resolute crew arranged in a classical shield wall, with percussion cap pistols poking out of what few gaps remain. Although your crew sustain fairly gruesome injuries from pirate axes, all but one survive. That young lad is given a funeral, unlike the dead pirates.

You're lucky they don't leave with your ship! Some of your sailors are equipped with old flintlocks, whose inaccuracy permits the enemy to engage at close quarters. The swordplay proceeds so terribly on your side that a section of pirates are able to reach the lower deck, and pilfer all they find. Satisfied, their captain bays "fall back!" and the scourge are gone, leaving your crew to count the dead.
Surrender to them

"Take all you want, but please, don't hurt us!" your officer pleads. The pirate captain grins, revealing a jumbled set of shark teeth, and proceeds to strip the chap of his ear. "Sounds fair," he says, still smiling. Your ship is then relieved of its supplies without further violence; the pirates no doubt bound by some arcane code to honour your surrender. You wonder if your expedition can survive on what the little they leave behind.

There's neither spirit nor courage to be roused. Your crew instead seem transfixed by the approaching spectre of doom. Even as the horde board, the defenders' minds seem elsewhere, hypnotised perhaps by the tall and angular captain with greying hair and a wizened visage, who stalks the deck juicing your sailors. Once the pirates have taken everything they desire, they leave just as mysteriously as they appeared.
The Breakout

Unfair imprisonment! While enjoying some well-deserved shore leave, a local militia seizes a dozen members of your expedition without explanation. They are taken to a fortress that's been hollowed into the sandstone cliffs that dominate the harbour. The charges against your crew prove spurious to say the least, and when a hefty sum is demanded in exchange for their release, the militia's intentions become all too plain.
Pay the outrageous fine
This is preposterous
Confirm

The fine is duly paid. Of course, your crew boil as the militia counts the payment and divides it up between them, all while flapping without remorse about the noble old art of bribery. Yet your sailors take comfort that they have been allowed to leave safe and sound, and mark the harbour on the map with the noble intention of forewarning other seafarers of the ruse.
Cancel
No fine, no prisoners. The militia make it clear: your crew members will not be freed unless their ludicrous demands are met.
Try to break the prisoners out

You secure an early release! Your men return to the ship and wait for nightfall. At the sight of a signal flare, the prisoners anticipate your course of action and place a lit candle by the bars of each window. After careful calibration of the cannons, a second flare goes up signalling the imminent blast. The candles extinguish in acknowledgement before the ship's guns sound. The cliff wall of the fortress crumbles away! Taking their chances, the prisoners launch themselves into the water below, just as your ship passes by. Tales of the daring rescue will be going around for years.

You make a mess of the fortress — and the poor people inside. The cannon fire impacts the cliff, but your artillerymen have not taken enough care in their calculations. The fortress walls crumble easily enough, but the occupants of the cells are either killed in the blast, or plunge to their deaths on the rocks below. As your expedition makes a hasty exit, the crew try to come to terms with what they have done.
Leave without the captive sailors

"I think that's the last we shall ever see of them," lament the sailors that night, as the anchor is raised and the westerly breeze tears them away from the unforgiving fortress. As they depart, candles appear at the bars of each cell, signifying — in the imagination of your crew at least — a unanimous verdict of reproach.
The Ghost Ship

After weeks of hot weather, supplies of drinking water have become dangerously low. It therefore seems a minor miracle when a fellow ship appears on the horizon, for surely they have water to share? But as it draws near, the crew are aghast, for there is no sign of life aboard. 'It is a ghost ship, we must flee before it is too late!' they cry.
Send a diver to check it out

The diver does remarkably to spot the fiends furled in sails, or waiting under barrels to ambush, should your men have boarded. Your ship draws alongside the vessel as if to pass, but then unleashes enough cannon-fire to drown it. The crew are elated, believing they have done the oceans a great service.
Heathen superstition! Board the ship!
Heavens shine upon you, for whatever caused the crew to vacate this ship seems no longer a concern. Better yet, the lord has seen fit to provide the water you seek.
The ship's hold contains an unholy mound of corpses. 'God hath forsaken these men', says the doctor, 'but how?'
Have the doctor investigate what happened
'We are lucky indeed, for malaria cannot reach us now.' says the doctor confidently. This swift diagnosis confirms the crew are pleased to load up the drinking water they have been gasping for.

'Touch nothing! Get off the ship,' frets the doctor, who believes a dreadful plague has taken the crew of this ill-fated vessel. Perhaps drinking water is itself the cause. The crew are miserable time has been wasted, and that their thirst is still not slaked.

The doctor is inconsolable, 'it is plague. I lanced a bubo, and it ruptured suddenly upon my person!' That the water be contaminated is misery enough, but to have to abandon the good doctor is a disaster! Your expedition drifts glumly on.
Leave the ship immediately

No relief at escaping the grotesque mound of corpses, can compensate the terrible thirst of your crew. There are murmurings that no such expedition can succeed if 'gift horses always be looked in the mouth.'

The crew are so faithless, that every creaking plank aboard the ghostly ship raises a whimper. So when a banshee howl erupts from below deck, every sailor runs for their life. One poor soul trips in a coil of rigging and cracks their head upon an iron capstan. The death exposes all the more the crew's foolishness.
Leave and hope to find an island with drinking water soon

No relief at escaping the disturbingly empty ship, can compensate the terrible thirst of your crew. There are murmurings that no such expedition can succeed if 'gift horses always be looked in the mouth.'
Terrifyingly, the ship takes after yours in pursuit. Who knows what dread hands operate its multifarious controls!
Try to outrun the awful vessel!
Your ship manages to escape the ghoulish clutches of that unwholesome adversary, but have no drinking water, or anything else, to show for the ordeal.

Your ship is not agile enough. Men pour into the waves from where enemy cannons punch holes. Seemingly contented with this sacrifice, the dread sentience commanding the vessel calls off its dreadful pursuit.
Turn and face it, whatever it is!

Pirates! But trickery cannot match the power of a modern seaship! Summarily demolished, a few of them are left clinging to wreckage. They beg to join your cause - unpaid. Such are the dwindling prospects of piracy in this day! The crew will jibe at them, but secretly all must be elated to have acquired such sea-wisdom for free.

A pirate nuisance! Though their scurvy deception gives them advantage, they are like many of their creed, rather jaded. By the time their ship is sunk, it has cost you a few good men. Yet the recovery of precious drinking water in among the flotsam, assuages the grief of your crew.

Bloody pirates! A terrible menace even in this day and age! Your crew are outmanoeuvred, outsmarted, and your ship is reeled-in for boarding. Many are killed in valiant defence of the company, but to no avail. Your vessel is duly ransacked for supplies, before the villains are again on their way.
The Visitation

An undesirable visitor haunts the ship. Fleeting silhouettes, knocking and screeching sounds. Each morning the ship appears in utter disarray. 'A night fiend,' gulps the hardiest of old crewmen, as he sweeps debris from the deck. As night draws in again, you realise something must be done.
Listen to your expert

Every right to a little joke. 'These claw marks!' the naturalist feigns horror. 'Is it something terrible?!' asks a fearful sailor. But the naturalist can bite tongue no longer, and succumbs to laughter; 'No! Good heavens. We have a mother and kittens aboard!' The cat family is found in a barrel, which, it is agreed, shall serve as their home for the duration. The crew dote on the little rascals, their presence a great comfort.
Perform an exorcism

Each sailor strides with inner conviction, as they form a procession of candles behind the smug-looking priest, flooding holy light into every heathen crevice. The priest's ritual is unfaltering, and not only are the crew rid of the night-time menace, but now believe it is god's plan the expedition will succeed.

The crew has its sceptics, even though the exorcism seems at first to have worked. Two days later a sailor cries, 'It had glowing yellow eyes!' upon having sighted the demon near the hold. The unholy thing must be caught.
Bait the thing with food

It is nothing so savage. All are concealed around the strip of meat, expecting the worst. But what descends from the rafters of the hold, silent and gentle winged, is a luminous white owl. It is an ambiguous omen, according to those that know, but the sailors are content to keep it aboard.

Whatever it is, it is far too clever. It avoids the bait, but continues its night raids. Rumour this is an offended Klabautermann are substantiated by several separate accounts. Little voices overheard, brief sightings, even the discovery of a miniature table and chair. Some can live with the impish nuisance, but many will jump ship at the next port..
Build a trap to catch the thing

The cage-trap is well-made, and daybreak reveals an unlikely specimen encaged. 'A sort of badger?' is the first analysis, which in actuality, is fairly far from the mark. The compendium of animalia in the ship's library reveals it a 'northern raccoon', also remarking that is 'quite edible.'

The snapping trap is weak and flimsy. The crew are excited by a sharp sound, but rush to the scene, only to find the bait gone, and the trap in disrepair. A piece of bright red felt caught in the spring explains all. 'Klabautermann!' they despair, for it is a terrible omen to offend a sea goblin as they have done.

The crew don't have much belief, and the priest makes a hash of the exorcism. If anything, his fragmented delivery only agitates the creature. The next night, a sailor is adamant he has sighted something 'irrefutably demonic.'
Gather arms and confront it

Rather excessive. The soldiery tense as strange noises draw near. Fingers itch upon triggers. The moment demon wings flap into view, the night is lit up with powder. Finally the smoke subsides, and the mangled thing is revealed to be nothing more than a bat. Troops thunder heavily about the ship, before discovering the rest of the hog-nosed critters in the hold. Everyone is left feeling utterly stupid.

Your lily-livered cowards quiver like jelly! Fear chokes them as they spin wildly about looking for something to shoot that they can't see. Two are so panicked they bump together, causing the other to suddenly fire. Shot hits an angelic young sailor, killing instantly. The night terror is gone, but has taken for payment the most undeserving of souls.
Sate the demon with a sacrificial offering

A man's finger for a stowaway weasel! In good faith, a pious sailor volunteers the pinkie of his right hand as a votive offering. But at the smell of blood, it is a slinky little mustelid that appears. With the weasel caught and caged, the night terror is over, but the sailors will not forgive or forget the loss of a good man's finger.

Sacrilege! A prohibited tome is consulted, the vile solicitations of its pages consuming the crew! Unspeakable acts are performed upon a man, so that the demon can be assuaged. Yet still the menace remains, and worse, the crew's sacrificial victim bleeds out from his injuries.
Don't anger the creature further

The practical joke is ruined. The bored sailors bemoan the pathetic response to their little entertainment. That the senior officers have been duped by an obvious ruse, makes all severely doubt their fitness to lead.

The faithless crew never take any part of the exorcism seriously. 'What's the point of hocus-pocus when its but greedy sailors stealing?!' yells one man. Accusations fly between conspiracy theorists, until a violent brawl breaks out. At the next mooring, the injured parties desert your godless expedition.
Find the culprit

Your sharp-nosed hunters pick up a scent. Pungent droppings demarcate a perimeter, in the centre of which is a crate with a hole. A sailor reaches his arm bravely in. There is a brief struggle, and a whine like the ones at night, before the troublemaker is pulled out. It is a common garden fox. The cunning little creature becomes the crew's talisman for the remainder of the expedition.

Hunters find tracks, but can't say what made them. The marks are indeed strange - disturbing almost. Claw marks that go deep in the decking, as if the unspeakable thing that made them was in some frenzy.
Smoke it out of hiding

Reassuringly human coughing comes from within. It turns out you have a stowaway - a young girl wishing to escape a life of hardship. She is spirited., and the crew take to her quickly. She is given work to do, and food to eat. All believe she shall prove their good luck charm.
Build a trap to catch whatever it is

Knowing its habits helps. The box is made to measure, and along with its clever latch, is placed where the fiend seems most often to be. The box is found in the morning, with a gigantic rat inside it. The trap appears to have killed it, and that is the end of the matter.

The ramshackle trap box is in bits the next morning. While to some they appear benign, the claw marks appear more frequently. Once a man wakes with his cheeks gouged. Some are so perturbed by the night demon, that they slink off the ship at the next available harbour.
Pray together against the spirit

A feeling of calm descends upon the crew. The prayer seems to fill the spiritual void in the sailor's breasts. Approaching the world with a new perspective means even if the unexplained episodes at night persist, they pay it no mind.

The communal prayer is broken by more wild shrieking. It matters not that, apart from vanishing supplies, the mischievous spirit seems fairly harmless. The crew are deeply troubled, and worry their souls are lost.

The hunters stumble guilelessly into its trap. The night is unfeasibly pitch, and the hunters' lamps extinguish. Who knows why, without a breath of wind? A scratching draws near. Then a commotion... and screaming, followed by silence. Just like that, the fiend has gone forever, returning to the air whence it came. Three men lie dead in their own blood. Their livers have been removed.
Ignore the menace
The menace is very persistent. Restless nights, devoured food, and stolen supplies shall go unexplained and unresolved for the remainder of the expedition. The crew are at their wit's end.
Baptism of Fire

Everything points towards the fiery gate. It appears like a hallucination, an ancient stone doorway suffused with blue flame set into the rock face. Perhaps a long lost people constructed it, as a shortcut through the high ridge dividing the region. Your men consider it an auspicious sign, and would like to enter it, but perhaps it would be safer to take the long way through the dense jungle.
Have the scientist inspect the gate
Have faith and leap through the flames
Wrap up in something before leaping through
Cut through the jungle instead

The scientist banishes the illusion. "The fire that you perceive around the gate is simply an agglomeration of azure glow-worms." Laughter becomes delight, as the party take the pulsing creatures in hand. Indeed, they are of great help in navigating the dark tunnel to the far side of the ridge, saving you days of trekking.

If anything the flames are cool, like bundles of ribbons brushing the skin. This gate is, without question, an earthly manifestation of the divine, for not far along the tunnel, the light breaks in once more, and your party arrive on the far side of the ridge, spiritually tranquil, and having saved days of trekking.

Some of the crew remain doubtful. Drawing a little closer to the gate, they are surprised to feel no heat coming from the fire. One leap of faith and they would be through! Still, they hesitate, for a perfect human skeleton lies just the other side of the threshold.

Alas! Fire and brimstone! Some of the crew seem entranced by the glowing entrance. The temperatures are volcanic, but the diabolic procession of fanatics are numb to the pain. The others watch horrified, as fabric, skin and flesh renders before their eyes. It makes the long way round seem a miracle of mercy.
Try to determine how the person died
Order them to charge through!

The doctor forms a decent hypothesis, and the crew are convinced. "Even from afar, I can see the bones are in poor condition; not burned, but malnourished." Anxious not to end up the same way, the crew take a gamble, and are astonished to discover that leaping through the gate does them no harm. They follow the tunnel to the other side of the ridge. "I wonder if it was those frogs we licked..." the doctor mumbles.

A little knowledge is a dangerous thing. Your doctor makes several sweeping assumptions, finally concluding, "exhaustion, I'm quite certain. That they died at this particular place is only a coincidence." As the first volunteer crosses the threshold, flames grasp his ankles, then shoot rapidly up and over his body. He drops upon the stone floor, taking his place beside the last poor fool. Horrified, your expedition must go the long way round.

"Ouch!" The men yelp, rolling in the stone passageway beyond, until they are sure they are no longer aflame. With the strange gate behind them, your brave soldiers compare their ugly burns as they march through the tunnel to the far side of the ridge.
"Cowards!" Your men lack the discipline to follow a simple order! You will have to find another way.

They make it. Rolled-up like carpets, they skip over the strange and fiery threshold.
