As they wend their way through the passage to the other side of the ridge, their worst complaint is the overwhelmingly sweet pong of sweat that is sure to follow them for the rest of the journey. Still, all remain curious as to what that gate really was.

"That he died like a sausage?! What else can I tell his family!?" Either way, your volunteer leapt through the fire and paid with his life. Who knows — perhaps dousing his mantlecoat in a protective layer of paraffin was a mistake! Your expedition will have to trudge the miserable way round.

The crew have no regrets in plotting what they perceive to be a safer, more rational course. Sweaty jungles are the devil they know, snakes and spiders notwithstanding. They make good time, and soon find a shallow incline that leads them up and over to the far side of the ridge. Still, many are curious to know what sorcery was governing the gate they saw.

The jungle thins out to a precipice, which seems to form part of the ridge you are trying to cross. A long and shoddy-looking bridge stretches to the other side, if you want to risk it, or else you could attempt to take an even larger detour.

There is no way through, thanks to your shambolic map reading, as the jungle grows thicker and danker. The group tire, having many disagreements, and separate into factions. The sensible ones stick together, and decide the only realistic option is to backtrack for several weeks. The rest will die among the roots and ferns.
Take the bridge
Circumnavigate the ridge

Inspection shows it to be in passable condition. There are a few nerve-wracking moments during the crossing, as the wind whips up and the rickety bridge begins to sway. In any case, all are rather pleased to reach the other side, from which they succeed in reaching the far side of the ridge.

Only a fool would ever set foot on it! Of course, it's nothing if not dramatic as the bridge cables twang, and one after the other, your men pile into the gorge. The craftsmen who had been so very confident in the deathtrap structure's safety choose hang back in shame, as the expedition sorrowfully wends the long way round the ridge.

It is a long trek, yet one that could have been so much longer were it not for some sound map reading and compass work. The vegetation is thick and stubborn. Your expedition hacks their way through with irritation, marking yet another hiccup for the expedition log book.

Imbecile orienteers! There's no way to cross this river valley for a hundred miles! You've covered half that distance before you realise, but having wasted a lot of time and provisions, your men may as well see this major boo-boo through. It takes almost three weeks of struggle before your expedition is back on track.
Song Of The Sea

The lookout is sure of himself: he has sighted a mermaid. In the hot noon sun, sailors suspend their duties and rush to inspect the mirrory waters for a sign of the creature. Lo! There is something — a glimmer of silver tail, and a sweet yet melancholy melody that follows behind it. Surely it's a mermaid's song!
Ask for expert opinion

"Something just as rare, and no less magical!" chuckles your zoologist, who proceeds to dive after the creature, resurfacing a short while later. "Poor little soul seems to have been separated from its mother," your zoologist splutters, clutching a juvenile specimen of an obscure sea-dwelling species. "Would you chaps kindly run her a bath? I think we'd better take her with us." From now on, whenever your crew feel sad, they can stop by the creature's tub and enjoy its special warblings.
Answer the mermaid's call with a sailor's chant

Not one, but a dozen strange sea creatures answer the spirited shanty, swimming and leaping joyfully alongside your vessel. Since they seem like no creature you've ever seen, it might be an opportunity to catch a specimen for the benefit of natural science...
Try to catch one alive

A fine catch! Taking care not to hurt the beautiful creature, your fishermen haul the great net from the water, and let her slop into a tub they've prepared in the hold. The crew take to calling her "Mermaid". Though she has been separated from her pod, she seems to enjoy being doted upon, and will certainly be kept well fed.

The men aren't used to catching fish alive. They trap one of the creatures alright, but hoist the net so roughly it provokes the creature to struggle. It contorts desperately, striping its flippers a glistening red, before finally wrenching itself free. Reunited, the 'mermaids' flee to the depths, and your sailors are left songless but for the howl of the winds.
Leave the poor creatures be

An otherworldly duet. The creatures dance over the waves, as your sailors' song reprises, "I dreamed a dream the other night/Lowlands, lowlands away, my John/My love she came all dressed in white/My lowlands away". There is no greater source of pride for a sailor than having made peace with the ocean.

The mermaid vanishes. The sailors drawl a patriotic war ballad they are fond of, but it has a threatening air, and the siren does not deign to answer. Blue in the face from trying, the sailors mourn the ill omen of the mermaid's disappearance, permitting themselves no more thoughts of she and her sisters, or their undersea kingdom.

When the mermaid disappears, a sailor dives in after her! Your irreverent sailors pick a lewd shanty to sing. Angry this moment of innocence is being spoiled, the impassioned young man tosses himself into sea to pursue the fleeting creature. He is not much of a swimmer.
Save the poor boy!

He's coughed up a lot of water, but he'll live. The navigators scream for someone to jump in after him, to give them time to bring the ship about. The boy is already sinking by the time his comrade catches up with him, but he's hauled to the surface where the ship is now waiting. When he finally comes to, the boy describes how beautiful the mermaid was, and how invitingly her tail swished. The sailors are so jealous of the boy, they instantly regret having bothered to save him.

Pursuing in the ship is a mistake. You lose sight of the boy, until someone realises he must have slipped underneath the keel. Divers emerge with the pale dead boy in their arms. The stories of mermaids are true — but that's not the only hard lesson your crew have learned this day.
Let the fool go if that's what he wants

The smitten boy drowns. He paddles himself to exhaustion, driven on by the hope of something better. Whatever that noble feeling was, you're fairly certain it won't be the emotion written on his face as he asphyxiates. His letters later show a preexisting disillusionment with life aboard the ship, describing a "culture of bullying most uncivil."
Convince the sailors to ignore the creature

Duty trumps distraction. Awoken by the earnest plea of the presiding officer, the sailors return immediately to their posts. The officer makes the case that it "can be a great source of pride to have not given in to temptation," and that "this is our way of life at sea." Plugging their ears with wax like the heroes of an ancient tale, the men now seem more concentrated than ever on overcoming the far greater challenges ahead.

Curiosity gets the better of your crew. If the fable is true, it would be against all superstition to ignore it. The men ignore the squawked orders of their superiors and begin muttering among themselves about how best to catch the mermaid's attention. When one grabs hold of the wheel to change course, it is clear things have got out of hand. The bo'sun, finding this challenge to authority thoroughly unacceptable, brandishes the whip.
Have the sailors flogged

The sailors grumble back to their posts. Resorting to such primitive naval discipline has left a bit of a bad atmosphere, but you doubt it will last forever. Besides, the bos'un only gave them a very gentle bruising — anything more than that is frowned upon these days. At least those silly thoughts of mermaids have been well and truly banished.

What you have done is illegal, and the crew have no difficulty making their displeasure known. After the bo'sun has beaten a man's back to a pulp, the crew gather on the top deck, where the cries of the mermaid can still be heard, although it sounds like weeping now. "That act was outlawed a half century ago. We hereby notify you of our forthcoming testimony against the bo'sun in a court of law — that is, if we ever manage to return." Morale aboard stoops to a new low.
Drop the issue and let them be

Discipline aboard this ship is lax. Convinced that their misconduct will go unpunished, the sailors take to negotiating, and even outright ignoring the tedious instructions of the officers. The use of "mermaid" as a keyword becomes synonymous with this rebellious undercurrent, which is sure to blight the rest of the voyage.
Call Of The Devil

Can it be the voice of a child this deep in the jungle? The expedition has taken a several-day sojourn inland, looking for citrus to save them from scurvy. Taking shelter during a particularly heavy cloudburst, they are sure they can hear children's voices through the pitter-patter of rain. Your men strain to see where it may be coming from. "It is Lucifer, of cloven hoof, leading us astray!" whispers the priest, "Pay him no heed!"
Let your zoologist speak

"Hush you insufferable fool, it is a marvellous species of talking bird!" exclaims the zoologist. Following a trail of excrement on the rainforest floor, the zoologist soon finds a colourful feather. "Raaawwwk!" splutters something in the trees above. The expedition crane up their necks to find the most colourful avian peering sidelong down at them. The specimen is duly captured for the benefit of the natural sciences.
Ignore the devil voices

The sailors close their minds to the voices. With the stubbornness of true believers, your crew convince themselves it is devil speak, repeating "I renounce him, his demons and his works!" Their faith is affirmed when the rain stops, and the voices desist. Later that day, they stumble across Eden; a thicket of Camucamu fruit trees. "Very tart fruits indeed," says the doctor, "precisely what we've been wanting."

The voices are too persistent for them to ignore. "I must know what they are!" one man cries, and the priest cannot seem to dissuade him or others from venturing from the shelter to seek them out. The further they go from the camp, the clearer the child-like chatter becomes. It feels inevitable something terrible is going to happen.
At least let the priest go ahead

The priest's incantations subdue the Devil. The priest swats his flickering torch in front of the party, bellowing incessantly "God is my salvation, the Lord be my sword and shield!", his mouth brimming with rainwater, until someone shakes him by the shoulder. He startles, but his comrade reassures him. "The voices have ceased! You have saved us — saved us from temptation!"

The devil noise drowns out the priest's prayer. As he anoints each sailor hastily with holy water, a voice identical to his screeches "Get away devil!", and raucous laughter erupts from the forest all around. Men and women run for dear life, only for the jungle to swallow them up. The ship feels very empty on the onward journey. "Led to the underworld," the captain prods the disgraced priest in the chest, "by the agents of Lucifer!"
Run for the ocean

The voices are gone, but the scurvy is terrible. Scarpering from the jungle, the crew leave all their supplies behind. In addition, the expedition has not found the vitamin-rich fruit it so badly needed. It will be several weeks before new land is sighted, and the crew's teeth and hair are already falling out.
Find a more rational explanation

It's not children they've heard, but birds! The hunters among the crew know it right away, signalling to the others to be quiet as they scan the trees for the cacophonous culprits. Before too long, one of the brightly-coloured beauties makes itself known. The hunters manage to capture it, and bring the little marvel back on board for the benefit of the natural sciences.

Fear incites a rash decision. The majority tremble in silence, as the eerie voice draws ever nearer, except for one cocksure officer who jabs his pistol every which way, looking for something to shoot. Seeing movement among the trees he fires, only to see his bullet graze the shoulder of an indigenous girl, perhaps five or six years old. It is likely she has never come across the white devil before, and she disappears into the trees wailing. She will survive. The officer, however, is clutching his chest — he has had a heart attack, and he dies.

The Treasure of
Hassan Ben Sahid

An old man claims to know the location of a great treasure. You've stopped over at a sandswept port. A gaggle of officers are enjoying sweet cardamom-infused coffee in the morning sun, when one of the patrons approaches. He is old and blind; his clothes dirty. "I have need of adventurers like yourselves, for the treasure of the pirate Hassan Ben Sahid is here! It is just waiting to be found!"
Believe the old man and follow him

He trusts you, and proffers a crinkled map of the town. It is annotated with an unusual script. "Take it! I cannot read it," he says, swatting flies from his milky and crusted eyes, "but then, I never could solve it, even when I had my sight!" It turns out the only thing he is absolutely sure of is that the treasure is hidden nearby.
Try to decode the map

One of the officers makes the map talk. She is an educated woman — a graduate of a fine old university, who snuck into the navy by shaving her head. "Arabic," she says, "but here it's written from left to right, like a mirror image." It reads:
"Hassan Ben Sahid breathes his last,
Upon you these spoils fairly won,
As I enter that lavish garden,
may your own thirst be quenched."
Read it spiritually, go to the cemetery

The treasure of Hassan Ben Sahid! The cemetery is modest; just unmarked funeral stones jutting up from the dust. Each is pointing in the same direction. "We need not disturb the dead," your officer says, pointing to a lush grove of date palm, "for our thirst has been quenched!" There, in its centre, is a working noria that might have been running for centuries. "Lower me down," she says. At the bottom of the well is the most extraordinary golden hoard! You go to thank the old blind man, but he has vanished...

Your officers rigidly uphold their beliefs. The old blind man leads you to the modest cemetery — a square of unmarked funeral stones jutting up from the dust. Each is pointing in the same direction. "We should not disturb the dead," the officers agree. There are simply too many stones to know where to start — and no way of guessing which belonged to Ben Sahid. The crew return to the ship, believing that at least they tried.
Read it literally and seek out a garden

The treasure of Hassan Ben Sahid! "The map smells sickly sweet with something," says one keen-nosed officer, "dates, perhaps!" After hunting around, the officers come across a lush grove of date palm. "Our thirst is quenched!" they cry, for there in its centre is a working noria, which might have been running for centuries. One of them is lowered down to the bottom of the well, where they find the most extraordinary golden hoard! You go to thank the old blind man, but he has vanished...

Though pleasant, the search is fruitless. There are many gardens between the arched babs of the old town, and none any less sweet-scented or busy-with-bees than the last. The crew give up their efforts to find the spot where Ben Sahid's treasure lies buried, instead preferring the less tangible rewards of exploring a new and unfamiliar place.

No-one can work out what the message says. "Looks a bit like Arabic?" offers one of the confused officers. The old blind man sighs a bitter sigh, snatches back his map, and departs. As the ship leaves port, rumours spread of the gold, sapphires and rubies that have been passed up. The crew can't help but feel disappointed.
Try to read the map

A treasure cache! Matching the landmarks of the city to the crude objects depicted on the faded map, one thing in particular sticks out. "An old fort!" a smart young officer exclaims. The blind man follows the eager beagles in amusement, as they set off at a giddy clip. He knows the fort cannot be where Ben Sahid's treasure is buried, since it belonged to a great enemy of his who came from the far north. Nevertheless, it is full of unclaimed riches!

The map appears worthless without the annotations. "We could have just remained in that wonderful old square under that marvellous arched gate, and sipped our coffee on this beautiful sunny day. Instead, we've sweat our braces off on this childish treasure hunt! We've seen the whole city, and yet we've seen absolutely nothing at all!" So much for relaxing shore leave...

The old man leads you into a trap! He chatters amiably all the way to a hammam — a steam bath — where he insists a descendant of Ben Sahid now works. Before they can realise how misplaced their trust in him was, your officers, naked and relieved of their weapons, are surrounded by a gang asking for payment.
Fight your way out

It's a bit of a wrestling match. "How do you like that eh, sirrah!" blares your punchiest officer, emerging from the fight the victor, his adversary left gasping and bloody-nosed on the marble floor. "What do you think you're doing!" rages the proprietor of these fabulously frescoed baths, "this is a place of peace you have defiled!" So much for relaxing shore leave...

An officer drowns in a sweat-filled bath. Punches are thrown in every direction, and no-one sees him hit his head. The thugs hold up their hands, "we never thought it would come to this," they say, when it's discovered he is dead. There is a sombre mood as he's carried back aboard ship, and the others have to explain how he came to such a bizarre end.
Give them what they want
They watch as your embarrassed crew empty their pockets
Accept

You trade various goods in return for safe passage. Not so much a trade as blackmail, your sailors feel the shame of ridicule as their clothes are returned. What kind of rational being believes in the existence of Ben Sahid's treasure, and permits a blind man to lead them to it!?
Cancel

Your men offer far too little, so the bathhouse thugs help themselves to it all anyway. Their ringleader, the old man who led your treasure-seeking officers here, turns out not to be blind at all. He gives your officers something rather less pleasant than a massage until they agree to write a note ordering supplies be released from the ship's hold. Once the exchange has been made, your shame-faced officers are finally allowed to go free.
Decline the promise of riches

Fantasies of pirate treasure belong to another century. Your crew ignores the blind man, who becomes rather angry and beats the backs of the officers with his fists. The officers pity him, and do not try to retaliate. Eventually he hobbles off, muttering to himself. As the ship leaves port, rumours spread of the gold, sapphires and rubies that have been passed up. The crew can't help but feel disappointed.
Too Good To Be True?

A delicious-looking banquet, with no-one around to eat it! Rising smoke encourages the crew to put to shore, but upon their arrival, they find the hamlet of conical stone huts to be deserted. Nevertheless, after months on jerky and biscuits, the sight of the fresh fish, cassava, and bananas wrapped in banana leaves that have been left out has the crew salivating! "It's too good to be true!" a sage old sailor warns.
Heed the old sailor's warning

The expedition have absolute faith in his words. "We may yet be allowed to eat, if we appease the spirit of this fair glen," the old sailor croons, gesturing towards a stone marked with white chalk that appears to have fallen on its side. The crew have absolute faith in his words. "That's what mother always told me about fairy circles, and I never knew her to be wrong..."
Study the chalk spirit on the stone

Your crew study the chalk symbol with due reverence. It has three points like an arrowhead, and the smiling face of a deity at its centre. The crew interpret the slight angle of this triangle as a sign, since it points roughly towards a distant and cloud-wreathed peak.
Let your anthropologist piece the clues together

Your men are soon enjoying every hospitality. "It is a three-pointed zemi," the anthropologist says excitedly. "The inhabitants of this village have departed to the mountain yonder, to thank the spirit for a plentiful harvest." Your men put away their weapons, and sit cross-legged by the stone awaiting their return. The locals are surprised and afraid to have foreign visitors, but sensing only good intentions, they invite you to their hearty feast. The chief enjoys your company greatly, and insists you take an amulet and some bananas as a parting gift.
Follow the arrow towards the mountain

Your men are soon enjoying every hospitality. You're following the trail when your sharp-eyed scout remarks "The villagers are returning from the mountain! They're armed with nothing but palm leaves!". You await them in the open, making sure to keep any weapons out of sight. The locals are surprised, and afraid to have visitors, but as this is an auspicious day, they invite you to a hearty feast. The chief enjoys the company of your knowledgeable woodsmen greatly, and insists you take an amulet and some bananas as a parting gift.

Your crew find some bananas at least. You're following the trail when your scout says in agitation, "The villagers return from the mountain! They're carrying fearsome weapons!". Heeding the scout's worries, the crew detour through a banana grove, where they stock up on fruit and return to the ship. Later, upon hearing the scout's description of the weapons, some crew members begin to wonder if they might not just have been the branches of a royal palm...
Leave while you still can

The expedition party are content to gather their own food. Leaving the strange village and its untouched banquet behind, the crew soon encounter a banana grove. "A fitting reward for our having left the spirits of that village undisturbed," the old sailor says with a satisfied air, evidently in favour of the rather pious restraint your people have shown in this place.

"It's just a child's drawing," is the cynical analysis offered by the ship's quartermaster, which no-one else has sufficient conviction to debate. "And what's it got to do with whether we eat that food or not?" Spiritual nourishment seems to be the last thing on the minds of your crew...
Lift the ritual stone back up

Back in its correct position, the chalk symbol looks like an arrow pointing towards a distant mountain. Showing their fine physical condition, your men lift the stone on a count of three. It must weigh a ton, but they still make short work of it. The symbol is a three-pointed star, with a face in its midst, which seems to the trackers to suggest the direction in which the villagers must have departed.

The statue won't budge. As many men whose hands can fit around the slab attempt to lift it, but to no avail. "And what's it got to do with whether we eat that food or not?" pipes up one of your scrawny soldiers. Spiritual nourishment seems to be the last thing on the minds of your crew...
Leave while you still can

The expedition party are content to gather their own food. Leaving the strange village and its untouched banquet behind, the crew soon encounter a banana grove. "A fitting reward for our having left the spirits of that village undisturbed," the old sailor says with a satisfied air, evidently in favour of the rather pious restraint your people have shown in this place.

They should have had more faith in the old sailor. Taking his words with a pinch of salt, your men swarm the miraculous banquet, turning the food over in their hands, as if to divine if it is real or not. Before anyone can take a bite however, the villagers reappear looking rather cheesed off.
Food fight!

A greedy, but profitable raid. Neither side wants to die for a picnic, so they come at each other with whatever they can find; palm branches, rocks, even handfuls of dirt. Needless to say, the scuffle is a very odd spectacle indeed, but eventually results in the villagers fleeing into the forest. The feast, meanwhile, has been almost entirely trampled and smeared into the raffia matting on which it had been laid out — but the crew do manage to pillage a few handfuls of bananas that they found in a store hut.

Too awful to be true. As the villagers rush forwards, your men fire wildly, only to realise the tribe are unarmed, and intent only on recovering their food. One of them is hit — a woman. There is nothing your medics can do for her. The sense of shame is only compounded upon returning to the ship, when a group of your men are found to have stolen supplies belonging to the villagers, in spite of everything. Your expedition can barely look one another in the eye.
Try to apologise

Your people are very diplomatic. Immediately stepping away from the feast, they raise their hands above their heads and offer a few reassuring words that no harm was meant. The villagers lower their weapons. Though they seem disgruntled at your invasion of their home and ritual, their chief offers you a generous quantity of bananas to wish you peacefully on your way.

Your expedition leaves safe, but hungry. The villagers stare, silent and disapproving, as your men raise their hands slowly and back away. As the expedition boards the ship, the captain raises a spyglass to the village, high up in the lush green valley. He can see the villagers still watching, waiting, until they are sure the thieves are gone.

Your expedition leaves both hungry, and several men lighter. Not only have your men desecrated the feast in honour of the spirit of cassava, but they remain unapologetic, poking and prodding the different dishes as if the villagers weren't even there. When one man takes a carved ritual spoon and starts digging in, smiling as he does so, he seems surprised when a villager shoots him. A brief exchange of gunfire follows, before your men flee to avoid taking further losses.

Your band of fools mock the old sailor. "Old wives' tales!" they guffaw, savaging the feast like locusts, stuffing their mouths with a fervour that would be unthinkable back home. But when one of them suddenly turns pale, the realisation dawns on the others — the food has been poisoned! Who did this? And why!? Your crew survive, but the poisoning is very serious, and requires weeks of recuperation before they are ready to depart this cursed place.
Scan about for danger

A watchful lookout spots the enemy before they attack. It seems the indigenous people who built these huts were dispossessed of them long ago, and that they now serve as a refuge for pirates and brigands. Forewarned is forearmed, and the crew stage a small ambush of their own. You bait the curs out before overpowering them, taking all the food and supplies they have.
The command to go ahead and eat is given in error. The lookout has barely given the all clear when she spots the inhabitants of the village rushing in from all sides.

The savage bandits find the expedition before it can find them. It seems the indigenous people who built these huts were dispossessed of them long ago, and that they now serve as a refuge for scoundrels. They whoop and holler from the trees and descend upon a few valiant defenders, as the rest of the expedition turns to flee for the ship.
Grab the food and run

It's a trap, of course. As soon as one of the sailors touches the cassava, a hooting resonates around the village. It seems the indigenous people who built these huts were dispossessed of them long ago, and that they now serve as a refuge for pirates and brigands. As soon as there is gunfire, your sailors scatter in a panic and flee to the ship, empty-handed and badly wounded.
Apostasy

The crew need some common ground. It is a fact that your crew were recruited regardless of their origins or beliefs, and your officers now wonder if this was a mistake. After weeks of lasting rainstorms, the more devout sailors raise their voice: this constant punishment is testimony to His obvious displeasure at the heresy aboard. Something is needed to bring the believers and apostates together, before things get out of hand.
Consult the Norse Sagas

The Old Norse has much wisdom to share.
“Men brave and generous live the best lives, seldom will they sorrow; then there are fools, afraid of everything, who grumble instead of giving.”
The Sæmundar Edda serves as a gentle reminder to your sailors that their grievances are shallow and foolish. Having heard the captain quote it the previous evening, the crew awake with open hearts and minds. And what's more, the sun is shining again.
Consult the Song of Odysseus

The Odyssey's wisdom seeps into your sailors' souls.
"For a friend with an understanding heart is worth no less than a brother."
The sailors can't help but compare this tale of camaraderie with their own quest, adventures and misadventures. Having heard the captain quote it the previous evening, the crew awake with open hearts and minds. And what's more, the sun is shining again.
Consult the Song of Ilion

The Iliad's wisdom seeps into your sailors' souls.
"Come then, let us give each other glorious presents, so that any of the Achaians or Trojans may say of us: 'These two fought each other in heart-consuming hate, then joined with each other in close friendship.'"
Hector's speech reminds your sailors of the things they do have in common, rather than those they don't. Having heard the captain quote it the previous evening, the crew awake with open hearts and minds. And what's more, the sun is shining again.
Consult Skaldic poetry

The epic poem puts your crew's petty bickering into perspective.
"The battle continued from day to day; and all they who fell, and all the swords that lay on the field of battle, and all the shields, became stone."
The crew themselves are petrified as they hang on the captain's every word. It's a bit of a saga, but they emerge the next morning to blue skies and fair winds.
Consult an ancient romance

Your sailors bond over the bizarre love story.
“There was never any yet that wholly could escape love, and never shall there be any, never so long as beauty shall be, never so long as eyes can see."
The captain closes, leaving the crew to ponder the fate of Daphnis and Chloe, and all the goats. Even the zealots crack a few bawdy jokes, and all emerge the next morning to blue skies and fair winds.
Consult an ancient myth

All are enchanted by the Book of the Dead.
A speculative translation of the Ptolemaic illustrations leaves the whole crew weighing their own hearts. Regardless of their beliefs, your crew share dreams of Anubis and his scales, and the mysterious spells that may transport one to the underworld Duat, to meet Osiris. All emerge next morning — to blue skies and fair winds.
Encourage the apostates to have faith

A message of forgiveness relieves the tension.
"For the Lord your God is gracious and compassionate. He will never abandon you, even if you have abandoned him."
The priest speaks to a common morality — the universal lessons of kindness to your fellows, love conquering all, et cetera. The anger of those with other beliefs, or none at all, softens enough so that everyone can get on with the expedition.

The priest further inflames those in opposition.
"If your friend who is as your own soul entices you secretly, saying, 'Let us go and serve other gods,' your hand shall be first against him to put him to death!"
Needless to say, the tensions that a few kind words might so easily have relieved, now threaten to sabotage your expedition.
Convince the zealots to be more tolerant

Your representative chooses her words carefully.
"We must believe so that we may triumph. God is a circle whose center is everywhere and circumference nowhere,"
quotes the former barrister, setting aside her own particular beliefs for the greater good. The crew listen intently, and agree that the expedition will not benefit from scepticism, towards matters of faith, or indeed anything else.

The diplomat makes things worse.
"When it is a question of money, everyone is of the same religion!"
A line of argument both insulting, and untrue, since the clergymen aboard only stand to receive a small church stipend for their efforts. "Faithless lot! We do not do this for greed as you so plainly do!" Needless to say, the tensions that a few careful words might so easily have relieved, now threaten to sabotage your expedition.
The Haunted Castle

"A-Anyone home...?" Seeking refuge from a thunderstorm, your people dash for the tumbledown castle. A flash of lightning illuminates its stark towers, barred windows and the solemn stone gryphons either side of the gate. As the last of your party crosses the threshold, an iron portcullis drops and clangs shut behind them! Despite their best efforts, your men cannot seem to lift it. The castle and its courtyard appear empty, but there is a sense that someone — or something — has been expecting you.
Cry out that you come in peace

The officer refuses to give in to his fear, but calls out steadily "We mean no harm! We only seek refuge from the storm!" As if by magic, the castle's great door creaks open. Your men accept the invitation to shelter, but with palpably less enthusiasm than would be customary on a night such as this. Inside, a once-opulent dining hall greets them, its few flickering candles burned down to a nub. But the attention of the crew is frozen upon the head of the long table, where a vaporous woman appears to be hovering several feet in the air!
Refuse to believe it is real

"It must be a trick, for it most certainly is not real!" says a young woman, who rushes forward, hand raised towards the figure. Just as she is about to touch it, it vanishes. "There's a pane of glass here... a mirror!" she exclaims. "Impressive, isn't it!" A diminutive and smartly-dressed man emerges from the shadows, hands aloft, "I'm Jean-Eugène Poivre, and this is my latest invention!" Relief turns to wonder as they marvel at the life-like mannequin he's created for the illusion. "Permit me to make it up to you!" he beams, flipping a switch which fills the hall with electric light. "Geoffery," he calls up to the rafters, "inform the cooks we have guests tonight!"

"Disbelieve your eyes...!" The unconvincing advice only serves to startle the crew even further. The moment one of the crew plucks up the courage to take a step forward, the apparition abruptly vanishes. "What manner of horror is this that we have just witnessed? I will not stay here a moment longer!" he says. Finding the portcullis in the courtyard has mysteriously returned to the raised position, your crew take the chance to make a run for it.

"It-it cannot be...!" An officer's hand quavers towards the apparition, but the faceless woman mirrors him, pointing her claw-like finger as if to single him out. At this sinister omen, everybody dashes for the entrance, screaming, trampling and shoving one another in their haste to flee. Finding the portcullis in the courtyard has mysteriously returned to the raised position, your spooked crew take the chance to make a run for it, only for the portcullis to suddenly fall. No-one but that marked man is crushed under its weight.
Shoot at the apparition

The ghostly dinner guest shatters! It was just a pane of glass, angled to reflect an old mannequin! "Please!" A dimunitive and smartly-dressed man emerges from the shadows, hands aloft, "I'm Jean-Eugène Poivre, and this is my latest invention!" Relief turns to wonder as they marvel at the life-like mannequin he's created for the illusion. "Permit me to make it up to you!" he beams, flipping a switch that fills the hall with electric light. "Geoffery," he calls up to the rafters, "inform the cooks we have guests tonight!"

Horror! The bullet passes through flesh and blood!" "Patricia...! Patricia!!" wails the illusionist, as he rushes from the wings to be beside the actress — his dying wife. "Oh, lord! Whatever have you done, sirs!" A moment later, she dies in his arms. That your soldiers were duped by a bit of make-up and a costume doesn't say much for their judgement. The expedition leaves the poor man and his tragic theatre set, and departs into the rain, which seems to fall harder and louder than ever before.

The first mate's tremulous voice returns no answer but its own echo, somehow distorted and corrupted by the castle walls. Could it be that whatever now inhabits this place, no longer has the power to speak? Or perhaps it is merely biding its time...
Look for a way out

There's a way out over the walls! Strangely, no ladder or stairs are found leading up to the high battlements, but the upper part of the keep appears attached. Through a maze of shadowy rooms and hallways, lit only by the occasional flash, the crew discovers a staircase to the third floor. From there they emerge onto the wall, and descend the dark and lush ivy on its exterior, welcoming the feel of the pouring rain from which they had so recently sought to hide.

This castle was clearly designed to keep people in. Strangely, no ladder or stairs are found leading up to the high battlements, but the upper part of the keep appears attached. After what feels like hours wandering the labyrinthine corridors of the keep, a peculiar door swings open. It appears to lead to a master bedroom. A soft, plaintive song rises from within, where a young woman is found at her mirror. She sits combing her hair, her bridal dress soiled and torn, and her face impossibly pale.
Refuse to believe she is real

Faith steadies the soldier's hand as he approaches the bride, but then he stops abruptly. "You should see your faces!" cackles a diminutive and smartly-dressed man, emerging from the shadows. Suddenly the room fills with electric light. "I'm Jean-Eugène Poivre, and this little beauty is my proudest invention." He winks and twists the bride's head one-hundred and eighty degrees. The automaton is so lifelike, it chills your men even now. They do not take well to learning the illusionist has been toying with them, and leave early the following morning, still very upset.

Their faith cannot prepare them for this. Her head suddenly spins on its axis, her face not young and pale as in the mirror, but shrunken and grey — a thousand-years old! — its empty eye sockets seething with a colony of larvae! The sailors run, rushing through the dark, dark halls, trampling the rickety stairs, and out into the rain. Finding the portcullis raised, they rush for the beyond; a lifetime of insomnia.
Shoot at the apparition

The phantom bride shatters! It was just a sheet of glass, angled to reflect a mannequin in a hidden alcove! A small man storms in from the shadows. "Who do you think you are, destroying my precious illusion?" he screams. "Have you any idea how much effort — not to mention expense — I'd invested in this pure sheet of glass, and the lifelike skin of the mannequin you've just pierced with your bullets! Get away from this place — away!" Your people trudge out into the rain.

Horror! The bullet passes through flesh and blood! "Patricia...! Patricia!!" wails the illusionist, as he rushes from the wings to be beside the actress — his dying wife. "Oh, lord! Whatever have you done, sirs!" A moment later, she dies in his arms. That your soldiers were duped by a bit of make-up and a costume doesn't say much for their judgement. The expedition leaves the poor man and his tragic theatre set, and departs into the rain, which seems to fall harder and louder than ever before.
Try again to force the gates

Success! Unable to resist the sailors' immense strength, the portcullis raises just the fraction needed to get everyone underneath. It takes good teamwork on the far side to get the last stragglers under, and the crew emerge shelterless, but free of this nightmarish place.

It's useless. Everyone tries their best, but they simply don't have the strength. Two men strain their shoulders, but still the portcullis cannot be raised an inch. Someone notices a cable leading from the top of the barbican where the portcullis is held, up to a high window on the keep.
Try to scale the walls instead

Finally free of this nightmare! The sailors are able to help each other up to the battlements, despite the interior walls of the castle being smooth and featureless — almost as if they've been designed to keep people in... Once they've clambered down the ivy on the other side of the thick walls, your expedition party begins to look for somewhere safe to sleep — if it's not too cold and wet, that is.

Only the able-bodied make it. The interior walls of the castle are smooth and featureless — almost as if they've been designed to keep people in... However, only when the skilled climbers reach the battlements do they realise that there's no easy way to help the rest up. "We'll come back for you in the morning," they say. Returning after a damp and sleepless night, they find the portcullis raised, yet can see no sign of their comrades. A thorough search of the castle is conducted, but the devilish place is found to be completely deserted.
Shelter in the castle courtyard

It's a foul night in the rain. There's minimal shelter from the elements within these smooth and featureless walls, and the rising moan of the gale is unbearable. Finally, at dawn, the storm relents. At about half past the hour of ten, the castle door swings open, and a friendly-faced man emerges from it. "What in blazes!" he laughs, "What are all you fellows doing out here!" He explains that he is the heir to this castle, which he claims survived a siege in 1422, and that the portcullis is a rather sensitive beast these days. Your men are pretty peeved, not to mention a little feverish, at the thought they could have spent the night in a comfortable four-poster bed.
La Isla de los Muertos

"They say the isle of the dead is not dead at all; that a bone legion guards its secrets..." The rock that dominates the island looks like a skull — at least, if you squint and tilt your head. Marrow-pink stone rises a hundred and fifty feet above the forest, pitted with lofty caves that could be mistaken for a multitude of eyes. The dark scar of a mouth at its base could lead somewhere rewarding, if indeed, you are brave enough to delve....
"Those stories you loved as a child — this is your chance to be part of one."

"People in those stories had the chance to turn back, yet they never did. A spirit of adventure kept them going — and that is something we explorers should have in spades!” Galvanized, the crew agree to enter the caves. In this underworld, where day lives in permanent exile, lamps are lit but die by turns; suffocated by forces ageless and unseen. Your men hesitate to light them again; "The old light burns the eyes of the deathless," a voice whispers, "it will anger them."
Ask them to trust in the person ahead to find a way forward

Their conviction in one another is soon rewarded. The air thins, and a soft greenish light grows out of the darkness. Before long, a cavern has opened up before them. Fingers of limestone glisten up towards the aperture from which that faint and unnatural light gently falls, shining like a spot lamp upon the large stone sarcophagus that weighs at the cavern's centre, sealed firmly shut. It is marked with the words "Here lieth Ernesto Barragán, king of skull and bone."
Force the tomb open

The mighty lid topples off revealing a sensational treasure! Your party have shown remarkable strength, and now delight in having cheated the wretched pirate Barragán and his followers in death. "No rest for the wicked!" the captain chuckles, though the adage may just as well apply to his own crew. "Gather what ye may and let us leave this foetid boneyard behind."

The sarcophagus won't budge, but your expedition leaves the isle of death with their pride intact. "The unnatural cold was enervating..." one officer is quick to clarify, "...and those who built that tomb in honour of this ancient king of bone clearly meant it to last unto eternity, so determinedly was it sealed."
Blow it open with a bomb

A buccaneer's hoard! The detonation goes off with a pleasing muffled thud, thanks to the care taken when packing the bomb. "Ha-ha!" the captain rasps with glee, "Pirate kings be damned!" Through the fissure the dynamite cleaves comes a first glimpse of the sarcophagus' sensational gilded interior, and the many riches within!

The bomb creates chaos! Loosely packed, and poorly positioned, the amateurish bomb brings the whole roof down. When the cloud, zinging with debris, finally clears, fallen rock is discovered to have sealed the tomb for all eternity. Though the crew leave empty-handed, the experience will have done them no harm.

Lack of belief forces your party to retreat. The chain suddenly stops moving forward, and the echoes of a disagreement at its head filter back. "Snap out of it! Keep moving!" "But sir, I swear, that thing had no eyes! I won't move another step!" Despite their efforts to continue, the feeling your party are trespassing only intensifies, and they depart the dreaded rock, drained and deeply perturbed.
It's only the wind and damp, light the lamps again!

Your party's craft is rewarded, albeit not with the fountains of gold they had anticipated. The lamps are first cleaned and supplied with new wicks and fuel, before being relit and carefully shielded from the wind. The fractured cavity is exposed — adorning its bone-white walls, a pictoral history of the career of the mighty pirate Barragán, who once made this imposing rock his refuge. Feeling enlightened, the expedition leaves with a spring in its step.

The smoke and soot force your party to retreat! While the refuelled lamps now remain lit, an excess of kerosene in the mixture produces dirty clouds that fill the lungs and sting the eyes. All further investigation of the skull's interior comes to an abrupt halt over fears the smoke may have done the expedition's health some permanent damage.

The expedition party seem all the more doubtful."Children's stories? Is that the best we've got? And besides, it's precisely this sort of unchecked curiosity that brought the heroes of those stories so much trouble!"
"Surely the promise of treasure outweighs mere superstition?"

Your diplomat rattles off a fine argument. "Which is more likely? That an army of the dead protects that treasure, or that pirates invented the fable to scare adventurers like us from stealing it?" Galvanized, the crew agree to enter the caves. In this underworld, where day lives in permanent exile, lamps are lit but die by turns, suffocated by forces ageless and unseen. Your men hesitate to light them again; "The old light burns the eyes of the deathless," a voice whispers, "it will anger them."

Your officer's argument is bare bones, his voice increasing in pitch with the realisation that it falls on deaf ears. In desperation, he lays a hand on the first mate's shoulder, whereupon the debate is resolved with a punch to the face. "I thought he'd never shut up!" someone laughs ― but after this episode, humour is likely to be in short supply.
"We're going in. You don't have a choice..."

The crew pull themselves together and enter the cave — a bit of a grilling from the expedition's most intimidating officer has done the trick. The cave is dank and stifling. In this underworld, where day lives in permanent exile, lamps are lit but die by turns; suffocated by forces ageless and unseen. Your men hesitate to light them again; "The old light burns the eyes of the deathless," a voice whispers, "it will anger them."

The first mate's threats are weak, and any punishment would be better than facing an army of skeletons as far as the crew are concerned. "If... if you refuse... you will be whipped, do you hear? I don't like doing it, but I will if I have to!" The crew laugh, "Admit it sir, you don't even want to go into that skull yourself!" With the first mate's authority undermined, confidence in the expedition's leadership reaches a new low.
Treasures and bone armies?! What nonsense!

The crew are sad to have passed up an adventure. At first it's a relief, of course, not to have to confront a giddy army of bone sailors, whom if tales be true, are holed up within that skull-like rock, perhaps swigging spectral rum and grinding their teeth over the life they spent as flesh and blood. Perhaps. But what would your men know? They were never there.
Give up. It's clear your crew are no heroes.

The crew are sad to have passed up an adventure. At first it's a relief, of course, not to have to confront a giddy army of bone sailors, whom if tales be true, are holed up within that skull-like rock, perhaps swigging spectral rum and grinding their teeth over the life they spent as flesh and blood. Perhaps. But what would your men know? They were not there.
Blow it open with dynamite!

Delicious desecration! What better way to enliven this truly oppressive place? As the fuse is expended, there seems a longer-than-expected pause... only for the boom to sound all the mightier. "Ha-ha!" the captain rasps with glee, "Pirate kings be damned!" Through the fissure the dynamite cleaves comes a first glimpse of the sarcophagus' sensational gilded interior, and the many riches within!
Love Island

A matter of the heart. The crew have been enjoying some island hospitality, but many are now refusing to leave. They have fallen in love with the sons and daughters of the local king. Perhaps he can be convinced to allow them to come with you? You can attempt to come to an arrangement, or else wait for him to consult his copper oracle.
Offer a wedding gift

The king is not only surprised, but moved to tears by the romantic composers he hears via the gramophone. He insists on a grand banquet to celebrate the union of his children and your crew. Both traditional music and a few cranks of the new-fangled gramophone accompany the beautiful ceremony, and then its bon voyage!
Convince the king your crew's affection is genuine

The king is delighted to see his children wed. Delicate understanding of local custom and a smattering of their language allow a message of true love to be conveyed. The king evidently thinks his children in good hands. Feasting, and to the amusement of all, terrible dancing, follows. For his departing children, it shall be the longest, most fascinating honeymoon.

Something is lost in translation. Yet the king smiles benignly, as if your crew still have a chance to prove themselves. 'He suggests a great hunt,' says your diplomat, 'or else we may await arcane judgment.' His eyes flick to a copper oracle on a dais.
Capture the king a prize animal

The hunt goes quite well. Beautiful boars inhabit the woods, and though tricky to catch, are little trouble for your experts. Though the king will still not allow you to leave with his children, the feast of boar brings everyone together in the moment. The lovers understand this moment is all they have, and the next morning there is an acceptance that it is time to part ways.

The hunt is not perfect. The crew show courage in pursuit of a tiger, which draws the king's admiration. Sadly, they cannot catch it, which leaves the king wondering if your men will be able to provide once married. Thus, he decides not to let his children leave. Some of your crew remain committed to staying behind, and it is with regret you must continue without them.

Your naive hunters fail the test. Forest deer are everywhere, and hunting them hardly seems a challenge. Had your so-named 'hunters' any respect for nature, they'd have realised the sacred deer were not what the king was after. Instead they gather them up greedily. The king makes it perfectly clear your expedition must move on. With heavy hearts, the sailors return to the ship.
Face the verdict of the copper oracle

The oracle predicts a reassuring fate for all. Those who wish to remain for love will live fulfilling lives, but the same shall be true for those still committed to your expedition. All parties feel a sense of peace. Your voyage shall continue without any resentment towards those it leaves behind.

The copper oracle is disappointingly undecided. The king cannot, in good faith, allow his children to leave to an uncertain destiny. His ultimatum is that your crew become part of his extensive family or else they must leave alone. Though understandable, it is nevertheless regrettable when some decide to stay behind.

The copper oracle predicts that your souls cannot be saved. With your crew rotten to the core, the king makes it clear there can be no union with his children, and that you are no longer welcome. Heart-broken and bearing the burden of sin, the crew return to the triviality of duty.

The awkward gestures and diagrams in the sand prove highly offensive to the king and his people. Sensing outrage, the crew back away towards the ship. The angry locals fire arrows at their former amours. Fittingly, one is struck in the heart, and bleeds out into the brine. The rest return lovelorn, to their dreary maps and compasses.
Await the verdict of the copper oracle

The copper oracle sees only purity in your crew's hearts. It predicts a bounteous future for the king's children, and so with tearful pride, he gives the couples his blessing. The traditional ceremony is both spiritually uplifting and wholesome.

The copper oracle reveals a little doubt in your crew's hearts. The king interprets that his children will only be happy if they remain on the island., and that some of your sailors are not in love, but merely infatuated. Still, you must lose the fine crew who have formed genuine bonds.

The copper oracle reveals great doubt in your crew's hearts. The king does not for a minute believe that your inconstant crew are as deep in love as they claim. If they cannot demonstrate otherwise, it might be better if your people left.
Try to convince the king your crew are worthy

Careful diplomacy has him thinking twice. Perhaps there is a way for the crew to prove themselves. A lean champion steps forward. Fighting him may impress the king, or else you can try and outhunt him.
Propose a contest of champions

You have your champions. One-by-one the suitors fight the king's champion. Those who prevail, it turns out, are permitted to take their lovers to sea. Some fail, but can at least drown their sorrows during the farewell celebration that follows.

It is not a pleasant sight for the faint of heart. Your best champion is put forward, and subsequently knocked about the head for the entirety of the contest. At the end a cloth is needed to conceal the disfigured face. The king expresses his condolences for your loss, but all is fair in love and war.
Propose a hunting competition

It is close but the king's champion is outfoxed. By sundown your best hunter has claimed six boars to their five. The king will still not allow you to leave with his children, but the feast of boar brings everyone together in one moment. The lovers understand a moment is all they have, and the next morning there is an acceptance that it is time to part ways.

Lacking the skill, your hunters try to cheat. Without knowledge of the island's fauna, they decide to follow the king's hunters in the hope of poaching the animal they are tracking. But they are led a merry dance. Three days pass, and your champion is missing presumed dead. The crew have no choice but to depart, tail between their legs.

The king is offended by your insolence. Without a word he boards a boat and heads out to sea. Some foolishly follow, believing he can be reasoned with, but they have even less knowledge of local boats than local customs. Their bodies will be dredged from the reef as your tactless expedition struggles on.
Order the crew to leave at once

Paradise lost! The expedition may be back underway, but the mood is abject as the beautiful island becomes but painful memory. Too painful for one, who is discovered dead, it is said, by way of a broken heart.

The copper oracle proclaims your crew's hearts sinful and wicked. Arm-in-arm with their new-found amours, the sailors await some happy answer. But the moment the king's arm is raised, daggers unsheathe, plunging into the hearts of the would-be lovers. Speechless and unharmed, the rest are free to leave the island, pondering the grave cost of faithlessness.
Leave without the crew who've fallen in love

It is a significant blow. Any happiness the crew might feel at their comrades finding love is consumed by feelings of resentment. How could they have been so selfish? The expedition goes on, but those who are still a part must take on twice as much work.
Temple of the Monkey God

With water supplies so low, the sight of an island waterfall elicits a mighty cheer from the crew. But up close, high temple walls adorned with monkeys shield access to the water, and the temple entrance is obstructed by a crowd of devotees, deep in ritual.
Have [AssetData([ExpeditionEventRequirement]) Text] shed light on the meaning of the ritual

'Nothing to fear from this ritual,' beams the anthropologist, having consulted a bound volume entitled 'Creed of the Monkey God'. 'If I am correct, the devotees gather to disperse the malefic spirit of envy. It would be excellent form for us to join in.' At which remark, the crew begin to look a little hesitant.
Join the ritual

Sure enough, the ritual unfolds into a jolly dance. With the shaking of rainsticks, and gentle swaying must come broad smiles, for this is how the monkey himself defeated the spirit of envy. A feast of grouse and soursop follows, and [AssetData([ExpeditionEventRequirement]) Text] is presented a monkey-tooth amulet as a gift. Next morning, fresh water is collected from the waterfall and having waved goodbye, the happy crew set sail.
Just ask to get some water

[AssetData([ExpeditionEventRequirement]) Text] negotiates the much needed-water, through a lengthy exchange of sound and gesture, not all of which the crew can be certain is relevant. Having collected the water, the crew are content to leave the unanswered mysteries of the Temple of the Monkey God behind them.
Have the first mate convince the devotees to let you through

The first mate does enough to persuade the locals - with flamboyant intimations of the hands - that the crew should be allowed to pass. Once water has been collected from the waterfall, the crew are able to put the adventure behind them.

The first mate cannot make himself understood, despite employing the most outlandish gestures. The constant waving of the hands and legs unsettles the local people and there is suddenly an air of tension.
Have your men threaten them

The men seem slightly uneasy. Still they charge, and the locals do disperse, clearing the way to the waterfall. But long after the water is refilled, and the ship has sailed, the crew have nightmares in which vengeful monkeys bedevil them for defiling their sacred temple.

Before the sorry men can ready their weapons the devotees have attacked, and yet more rush from the undergrowth. The party desperately dashes for the ship, but several are skewered in a rain of javelins, each hilted with the howling visage of the Monkey God.
Stay calm, and offer them a deal instead
The locals look expectant
Deal
The local people are spellbound by your offer. They enthusiastically invite you to join their ritual.
Join the ritual

The ritual unfolds into a jolly dance. With the shaking of rainsticks, and gentle swaying must come broad smiles, for this is how the temple's monkey god defeated the spirit of envy. A feast of grouse and soursop follows, and as a celebration of trade and friendship, a monkey-tooth amulet is given the men as a gift. Next morning, fresh water is collected from the waterfall and having waved goodbye, the happy crew set sail.
Just ask to get some water

Water goes without saying, seems to be the message from the enterprising devotees, who aren't offended the crew won't participate, but seem now to want to resume their ritual. The crew return to the ship, leaving the unanswered mysteries of the Temple of the Monkey God behind them.
No Deal

The locals are at first interested, but the foremost of them, clad in monkey skins and wearing a linen monkey mask begins scolding his peers, violently knocking offers from their hands with a monkey-pommelled stick. All parties are now just as agitated as before.
Have your men threaten them

The men seem slightly uneasy. Still they charge, and the monkey-mask and his devotees do disperse, clearing the way to the waterfall. But after the water is refilled, and the ship sailed, one of the crew reports nightmares in which vengeful monkeys bedevil him for defiling the sacred temple.

Before the sorry men can ready their weapons monkey-mask has led an attack, and yet more devotees rush from the undergrowth. The men desperately dash for the ship, but several are skewered in a rain of javelins, each hilted with the howling visage of the Monkey God.
Have your men retreat to the ship

Your crew run fearfully from the temple where the devotees stand so firm. The monkey-masked one is heard uttering hard and undecipherable words that many of the crew later become convinced is a curse dooming the expedition.
Offer the devotees some goods in order to pass
Avoid the temple and find another route to the waterfall

The men succeed in finding an alternative route to the waterfall that is also satisfyingly swift. All are happy that they have managed to refill the water so efficiently, and without having to disturb the ritual at the monkey temple.
Your crew tries to find a different way, but it would seem the only option is to reach the high precipice from which the water cascades. The jungle is very dense, and there isn't a clear route up.
Search for a route to the waterfall source

After some scrabbling amid bristly vegetation, the tired crew finally get up to the water source and fill the barrels. The journey back down with the heavy burden is equally exhausting, and scarcely feels worth it.

The men lose their way terribly, becoming separated as they try to prove themselves in the ascent. A dreadful thud sends a squawk of birds from the trees - it is one of the crew, impaled upon a monkey-pommelled javelin. The rest flee for the ship, but few will make it that far.
Give up and return to the ship
'What a waste of all our time' bellows a vexed sailor, and he is not the only one. The word failure is becoming synonymous with this expedition.
Avoid the island altogether and return to the ship
The crew troop sourly back to the ship, disgruntled at being so near, yet so far from this much-needed water source.
The Mysterious Artefacts

The discovery of several strange artefacts aboard spooks the crew. Tied to the rigging, bunks, boards, and even atop the captain's desk. A warning, a threat? And who put them there? Since the nearby island is uninhabited, it is sensible only to think the perpetrator must be aboard. The crew must know or have seen something last night!
Ask the anthropologist

'For good luck,' remarks the anthropologist, inspecting the spherical red dolls, 'for the setting of goals, and perseverance in achieving them. Some people or spirit of this place believe they can help us home.' At this, your crew are beguiled.
Ask the crew who did this

Your crew are beginning to bond. Someone comes forward, not having expected to cause such a bother. 'They're for me old mum,' he sighs, 'birds - that one's a little robin. Made 'em together when she was ill. Now she's gone...I...' The others are quick to put an arm round his shoulder; they're all in this together.

No one has anything to offer but the priest. It is his belief that some unholy chapter has opened. The next morning, more of the eerie things have appeared. 'Cleanse the idols in holy fire!' he shrieks. 'Nonsense,' says a soldier. "Set guards within, and we shall have this rat."
Side with the priest and prepare a holy fire

The priest gloats over his success. With a maniacal grin, he sets the mound of idols alight. The fire consumes rapidly, shifting vermillion to viridian. Some say they hear the wood scream as it goes. 'Expurgation is God's work, and I am chosen.'

The fire is chaotic, and the buckets of water seem not to extinguish, but provoke. The flame leaps to the priest's cassock like spring-heeled jack, and as it sweeps up his back, he is heard to utter his last words, 'forgive me father, for I have sinned.'
Keep guard and capture the perpetrator

The teenagers are remorseful. 'It was a jape, a piece o' trickery sirs, we regret t'were not received so.' The crew are forgiving - the youths merely wished to contain their homesickness - and call for just fifty strokes of the birch per bottom.

That night, dire musket-shot is heard. A dead boy on deck, local. A second is seen diving to blue. Next morning a rhythm comes from an armada of river boats, armed with guns. There island is inhabited, and they know what you have done.
Engage in battle.

One warning salvo is enough. The river boats cluster and slow. Though they lower their weapons and allow you to leave, the anger that your crime goes unpunished couldn't be more marked in their faces.

Your ship is a sitting duck. Your crew cannot man stations fast enough to fire or manoeuvre. Enemy boats surround your ship, before scaling its sides. The blood shed on both sides will stain this ship and expedition forever.
Leave immediately
Once your ship is underway she is free. Nevertheless your adversaries are excellent shots, and do damage to the sails and aft. The crew will have to make repairs in the days that follow.

A traumatic escape. In the hurry to leave, your ship is spun broadside and exposed to gunfire. There are injuries, but none so deep as the sight of the dead boy's accomplice below. He weeps, and clutches one of the idols - a good luck charm.

The sun is solemn that morning. The bodies of the dead guards are borne to the hold for burial, but not here, upon this cursed rock. Who killed them none know but the sinister effigies. The expedition fumbles on.

A destructive episode. No one has information, or perhaps they withhold it. Consensus tends towards the latter. Someone wants this expedition to fail, and these effigies are a threat. Paranoia festers. At the next port, a large part of the crew opts to quit.
Throw them overboard and move on.
Chilling. As instructed, the crew collect the dolls and throw them overboard. But relief lasts only until the following morning, when the dolls are found returned, placed exactly as they had been.
Mutiny!

Clear skies, calm seas, and mutiny! The tension has been building. The everyday strains of an expedition — the rationing of supplies, a lack of recognition from the officers — it has all become too much for the lower-ranks to take. They are refusing to take further orders, and have united behind a charismatic spokesperson. It won't take much to push them to a full-blooded revolt!
Arrange a meeting with the leader of the mutiny

They soon reach an understanding. After all, the demands made by the mutineers are perfectly understandable. The officers address each of the criticisms of the running of the ship, agreeing where possible to make adjustments — and where they find it's not possible, they take the time to explain exactly why things must stay the way they are. Everyone seems most satisfied with such a fair and democratic resolution.

The threat of mutiny is gone, for now. The negotiations begin well, but ultimately remain unresolved, with the first mate too stubborn to make compromises for his inferiors, and the mutineers seemingly unable to see the bigger picture. After a long and tiresome debate, the mutineers agree to disagree, and grudgingly begin taking orders again.
Their leader insists you meet on his turf. "The officers will join us among our squalid bunks, or there'll be no meeting," he says with more than a hint of threat.
Agree to meet in the sailors' quarters

The leader of the mutineers listens to reason. That an officer is willing to meet on the lower decks already shows progress has been made, and the humility he then proceeds to show, while listening to the many gripes and grumbles of the crewmen, is enough to defuse the situation — even if nothing has really changed at all...

The meeting goes nowhere. It is clear the problem lies with their leader. He is a force of nature, too incendiary for any of your officers to handle. With each new compromise offered by your representative, he makes further, more unreasonable demands. Something must be done, and fast.
Quietly poison him

The doctor agrees to be an accomplice, and his complicity proves vital. Dispensing with his moral objections, your medic produces a poison that causes rapid respiratory failure. A man known to be loyal to the captain secretly administers it, and within a few days the chief firebrand of the mutineers is dead. "Cancer of the lung," says the doctor, "most probably caused by stress." No-one suspects a thing, but the officers must keep a terrible secret.

It is obvious you tried to poison him. The doctor refuses to help, objecting, "It's despicable — and besides, I know nothing of poisons." Instead, you're forced to rely on the help of the ship's cook. The "wine" he concocts is discoloured, and obviously reeks of death, but the poor fellow is too drunk to notice. Unfortunately for you, the doctor chooses to issue an emetic, and saves the firebrand from his untimely demise. "The bastards tried to kill him!" scream the mutineers, as they converge upon the captain's cabin.
In a final attempt to keep order, offer a bribe
This will be costly.
Okay

They take the bribe, but their loyalty cannot be bought. The trust between the commanding officers and the crew has been shattered. Since there appears no single culprit, it is agreed that all senior officers be put on probation so that any member of the crew may hold them to account for their actions henceforth. Needless to say, the general mood among the officers is low.
Cancel

Blood is the only payment they will take. Weakened by the poisoned wine, the leader of the rebels appears on a crutch. His followers part in taciturn awe, as he hobbles forward. "Name your scapegoat," he says. One of the junior officers draws the short straw. "Cut out his eyes!" And with two gruesome oyster scoops, the hierarchy aboard your ship is turned upside down. The captain has no choice now but to grant several of the rebels positions of authority aboard ship.
Fight them: officers vs. sailors

It's a bloody end, but your officers can fight. Their academy training stands them in good stead as the dissident rabble charges. The sailors, equipped with hooks, nailboards and anything else they can find, are no match for your sabre-slashing redcoats. Although the mutiny is over, and its leader, too ill to fight, is safely in the brig, it's unlikely all those radical ideas have simply died with those who had held them.

The officers show themselves unworthy of power. Without loyalty, pride, or even discipline, the redcoat defenders are broken by the rabid horde. The leader of the mutineers, still groggy, makes an example of one of the officers, forcing him to drink the same deadly wine he was given. The captain has no choice but to grant the rebels positions of authority aboard ship. It will be a rocky ride from hereon.
Have him arrested

The leader comes quietly, perhaps because soldiers loyal to the expedition have knocked and asked politely — it's more dignified that way. He is on his own now. Guards are stationed all along the route to the brig, separating him from his followers. Without their leader to organise and motivate them, the threat of mutiny becomes little more than a grumble.

The rebels are ready to die for their leader. It could have been a quick and clean arrest, but the mutineers crowding around outside their leader's quarters don't seem afraid. When a fracas sparks into life, they are vicious. The officers jab their swords nervously into the pack, knowing that what they do is wrong. With the loss of life, and the loss of trust, things look grim for this voyage.
Ignore him

The mutineers leave the expedition. The captain and the officers, having failed to provide a solution, cannot hold them to their contracts. Equally, as the senior ranks have refused to negotiate, the leader of the mutineers is now honour bound to take some formal action. An uncomfortable week of silence passes before you make port, and a large portion of the crew leaves as soon as you dock, taking food and other supplies with them.

Your representative is utterly tactless. It is late, he has had too much gin, and he barges into the sailors' quarters barking insults and commands. The crew toss aside their paperbacks and swing down from their hammocks, laying into him with their fists. Perhaps they don't intend to kill him, but nevertheless, that's what they achieve. To settle the matter, the captain agrees to keep their crime a secret, so long as there's no more talk of mutiny.
That's enough disobedience — arrest the chaplain

The leader comes quietly, perhaps because soldiers loyal to the expedition have knocked and asked politely — it's more dignified that way. He is on his own now. Guards are stationed all along the route to the brig, separating him from his followers. Without their leader to organise and motivate them, the threat of mutiny becomes little more than a grumble.

The rebels are ready to die for their leader. It could have been a quick and clean arrest, but the mutineers crowding around outside their leader's quarters don't seem afraid. In fact, when the inevitable fracas whirls into action, they are vicious. The officers thrust their swords nervously into the pack, knowing that what they do is wrong. With the loss of life, and the loss of trust, things will never be the same again.
Give the ringleader a raise
The ringleader looks on greedily
Okay

A pragmatic solution. The amount offered to the man to buy his obedience is enough for him to ignore the incongruity of a monetary settlement — a bribe, as it's more often known. What's more, he's willing to spread the lie that change is afoot. It's not long before the storm of mutiny has passed overhead.
Cancel
He refuses, insisting you negotiate on his turf. "Give us what we ask, or this mob'll turn, I guarantee it," he threatens.
Make an example of the ringleader

The budding mutiny is crushed. The first lieutenant and two loyalists are all it takes to seize the ringleader and present him before the captain for judgement. The man is condemned to a marooning on the next island they encounter. The swift arrest and punishment impresses the sailors, and renews their respect for their superiors.

The loyalists find it difficult to act against their friends. "Go on then, arrest them!" blares an officer, when they show a moment's hesitation. The ringleader is eventually captured, made a scapegoat and marooned at the next port, but weakness has been shown. A few little cracks have started to appear...

The rebels are ready to die for their leader. It could have been a quick and clean arrest, but the mutineers crowding around outside their leader's quarters don't seem afraid. In fact, when the inevitable fracas whirls into action, they are vicious. The officers thrust their swords nervously into the pack, knowing that what they do is wrong. With the loss of life, and the loss of trust, things will never be the same again.
Ignore the threat of mutiny

The mutineers leave the expedition. The captain and the officers, having failed to provide a solution, cannot hold them to their contracts. Equally, as the senior ranks have refused to negotiate, the leader of the mutineers is now honour bound to take some formal action. An uncomfortable week of silence passes before you make port, and a large portion of the crew leaves as soon as you dock, taking food and other supplies with them.
The Amazons

The splendid warriors are all women. Exploring this deserted settlement — which appears to have been the scene of a revolt — seemed a good opportunity for some looting, but your crew aren't the only ones to have had the idea. As they pass the barricades of barrels, tables and chairs, they happen upon a group of warriors, with not a man among them. Indeed, the long-trousered women assume a defensive formation so fluently, it's possible they are more than human.
Let a woman do the talking

She fascinates the warriors, almost as much as they fascinate her. "Many stray into our territories, but rarely does a woman lead them," says the tallest of the goddesses. Neither she nor the others make any further mention of these territories, how far they span, or if their people dwell in towns and cities. Your crew are invited to share in what they have found, however. As the women lope into the trees, eyes ever watchful, you wonder how they will repurpose all they have harvested from these ruins. It is your belief they may have stumbled into this chaos, from a distant, more noble age.
Present your peaceful intentions

They too share a love of exploration and discovery! Though they know nothing of your language, your envoy takes great pleasure in unravelling his sea chart. Curiosity soon loosens them from their formation, as they crowd around him, sitting on their shields to get a better view. He describes the ship in gestures, and when he gets to the sails, for some reason they fall about with laughter. One of them snatches the map, and makes a suggestion as to where you might think of going next. It could be a shortcut!

The behaviour of your diplomat is disgusting. Instead of trying to communicate your good intentions, the belching toad circles them, looking them up and down as if to appraise their value. When he places a greasy hand on one of the warrior's cheeks, another woman breaks from the pack and plants her lance in his thigh.
Respond to their violence in kind

Firing a few shots skyward is enough. The warriors have only shields and jagged lances, coming as they do from some nobler age. Yet the way they fearfully scurry away suggests they are no strangers to firearms. It feels like a missed opportunity to have got to know them better. All that's left is to tend to the sorry diplomat, whose leg has a very severe bleed.

They are too fast. The distance between your small scouting party and the warriors is made up in moments, as the lithe women dive and roll, and thrust their lances. All your men are killed. The warriors spare your women, however, giving them only wearied looks as they stalk away. The survivors return to the expedition ship, and report the massacre to the others.
Placate them with gifts
The warriors seem interested, but watchful
Confirm

Your exotic supplies intrigue the warriors. Their curiosity overtakes their anger, and seeing how fascinated they are by the crew's maps, the sailors guess that the women might share in their taste for exploration. Sadly, it appears too late to earn the warriors' trust, and they depart looking cautiously over their shoulders. You must tend to the sorry diplomat before you leave, as the bleed from his leg looks severe.
Cancel

The warriors take great offence. One of them spits on the jacket of an officer. He responds by moving to draw his weapon, but the women are too fast. The lithe warriors dive and roll, and thrust their lances. Every man in your small scouting party loses their lives.
