The women are spared, however; the warriors giving them only wearied looks as they stalk away. The survivors return to the expedition ship, and report the massacre to the others.
Bow before the goddesses

Your crew's deference pleases the warriors. Surprised by the sailors' genuflection, the women giggle and lower their guard, lifting your explorers' chins with the tips of their lances. They may not speak your language, but their body language is unequivocal — they are fellow adventurers, and wish to celebrate your meeting. A huge bonfire is made from the wooden barricades, and all enjoy their boozy punch and haunches of venison — which the women insist on eating raw. The wild party lasts long into the night.
Not everyone in your party shows respect. Some are snickering about something, and the warrior women presume it concerns them. They spit at the men, who reach hot-bloodedly for their weapons.
Challenge them to a fight

This pleases them, since out of everything, they are always most fond of a good fight. Your men are honourable and choose to fight hand-to-hand. It is a noble and even contest, punctuated by the metallic rasp of sword and spear, ending in stalemate. Both combatants have suffered injuries, and the two sides part with greater respect for their foes. Still, their wounds will need looking after...

They are too fast. The distance between your small scouting party and the warriors is made up in moments, as the lithe women dive and roll, and thrust their lances. All your men are killed. The warriors spare your women, however, giving them only wearied looks as they stalk away. The survivors return to the expedition ship, and report the massacre to the others.
Accept humiliation and leave

The sailors, especially the men, feel humiliated. "Those warrior women were strident," says one, "I had absolutely no idea how I should respond to such provocation. They wanted us to draw our swords, which of course would have been wholly inappropriate!" The women, on the other hand, can't help but dream of escaping this suffocating ship, to take up a lance and shield of their own.
The Fugitive

Local authorities come aboard looking for the fugitive you've taken in. A man in rags offered you his services in a port, saying he'd do any odd job for some food and the chance to join your crew. The captain agreed to take him on. He soon grew on your sailors, working hard and filling in wherever needed. But above all he has proved a man of principle — a champion of the vulnerable — and as such, the crew have learned to respect his silence on the matter of his past.
Pretend you haven't seen him

Your crew stick stoically to the same story. "This man," the officials say, holding up a picture of their new friend, "have you seen him?" "Oh no, no," your sailors reply. Still, the officials conduct a cursory search, but the man of many talents has no difficulty in hiding from them. When they've gone, there is a hearty cheer. "Glad to have you with us!" bellows the captain. You have a new recruit!

Your attempt at deception fails. The officer in charge lies that your ship has never docked at the port in question, yet the officials present a logbook stating conclusively that it did. This only serves to further rouse suspicion that he is somewhere on board.
Quickly, hide him!

Hidden in plain sight! Sensing how thorough the inspection is going to be, there's only one possible bolthole for your runaway. "Get in the lifeboat, and keep your head down," the crewman whispers, while his pursuers are being detained on some pretence in the captain's cabin. To complete the plan, the lifeboat is then winched above the eyeline, where sure enough, the authorities never think to look. Not wanting to cause further trouble, he insists on leaving at the next port.
"There he is! Seize him!" The fugitive is still trying to make himself comfortable among a pyramid of barrels when his pursuers appear. They tackle him and clap him in chains.
Don't let them take him

They don't give in easily. Your sailors wait until the officials pass them by before knocking them to the floor, and confiscating their weapons. A shrill whistle sounds from the other ship, and armed men in smart navy uniforms pour up the boarding plank onto your deck. There follows a heavy skirmish, but your sailors gain the upper hand. The authorities surrender and retreat. Though grateful, your fugitive wishes to avoid causing further injury by his presence, and insists on leaving at the next port.

The fugitive dies, along with his pursuers. When your men try to lay hands on the port officials, they put a pistol to the fugitive's head. "Try to stop us, and he gets it," they say. When your men try to be clever, they blow the fugitive's head off, then do the same to one of your men, before they themselves can be subdued. The dead prisoner was very popular aboard ship, and your crew wonder if things could possibly have turned out worse.
Let them take him

Your crew offer no resistance. They part before the two officials as they frogmarch the fugitive over the gangplank to their vessel. He tries to express his thanks to your crew for their efforts, but the official growls "no more of your activism", and slaps him sharply across the chops. The prisoner was very popular aboard your ship, and your crew believe more should have been done to defend him.
Threaten to destroy their ship

Your threat is impressive indeed. Rows of dark, iron mouths poke from their hatches, ready to fire at point blank range! "You must be mad!" says one official, as they skip back across the gangplank to their own ship, suddenly most anxious to leave! Your fugitive is thankful, but does not wish to endanger your expedition further, and waves a warm goodbye at the next port.

Your men hesitate at the order, because they can see the neighbouring ship is not one to be trifled with. Eyeing your sailors as they not-so-secretly prepare for battle, one of the officials sounds his shrill whistle, and a troop of navy-uniformed soldiers rush up from below deck. They fully intend to board you.
Fight them!

They don't give in easily. A second shrill whistle sounds from the other ship, and the navy-uniformed brigade pour up the boarding plank and onto your deck, where your men sit ready for them. There follows a heavy skirmish. Some are injured, but your forces prevail. The authorities surrender and depart. Though grateful, your fugitive wishes to avoid causing further injury by his presence, and insists on alighting at the next port.

There's no time. Your men, still concerned with preparing for the sea battle, are thrown into disarray. "To deck, men! To deck!" is the cry, as they dive for their guns and rush to the deck, only to be cut down, one-by-one by the men in blue. "Fools!" smirks the official, as the fugitive is trussed in chains, "To think so many died for this worthless streak of spittle... Take him away!"
Let them board ship and take the man
They'll have to fight you for him

You have a new recruit! "You're welcome to him!" says the more senior of the two officials brightly, "We had no idea he was so important to you." His colleague glances at him nervously, before wrinkling up a fake smile of his own. It's obvious they only chose to call off their pursuit because your vessel is far more powerful than theirs. With your ship free to continue, the former fugitive raises a glass. "Thank you all," he says, "here's to a triumphant expedition, and beyond!"

The officials seem undaunted. "Oh, I think we have little to fear from a ship as ill-equipped yours. Still, from your hostility, it's clear you're hiding the man we seek." They signal back to their own vessel to ready arms. "Now... think carefully. Do you really want to refuse to give him up?"
Demonstrate your firepower!

It's a point blank exchange, in which your ship manages to get the first shot, disabling half the men opposite. As such, the return fire is not so crippling as it might have been— although significant repairs will still be needed. As the two ships drift apart, the officials are left in helpless, comic isolation on your ship's deck. Someone gives them a good old shove overboard, forcing the other ship to return to rescue them. Your crew make their escape. "I will burden you no further," says the fugitive wearily, "please, allow me to alight at the next opportunity."

It only serves to demonstrate your crew's incompetence, because they are still not ready! The vessel belonging to the local authority fires first — and at such close range, the effect is devastating. Half your gunners lie maimed, and your ship is shredded through. You wave the white flag. The fugitive leaves with the officials of his own free will — after all, he has better chances of survival almost anywhere else!
Surrender the fugitive to them

Your crew offer no resistance. They part before the two officials as they frogmarch the fugitive over the gangplank to their vessel. He tries to express his thanks to your crew for their efforts, but the official growls "no more of your activism", and slaps him sharply across the chops. The prisoner was very popular aboard your ship, and your crew believe more should have been done to defend him.
Offer to pay the fugitive's bail
The fugitive wears a look of stoic resignation, as his terms of release are discussed.
Confirm

You have a new recruit! "I will repay your trust in me tenfold!" says the talented fellow, as the local authority departs with their payment. He raises a beaker of navy rum, "Thank you all! Here's to a triumphant expedition, and beyond!"
Cancel

You can't afford him. Seeing that your men are still reluctant to let the fugitive go, the order is given to lower the footbridges, and a troop of navy-uniformed soldiers file into line, ready to board your ship.
Hand over the fugitive

The fugitive does not resist. With a look of stoic resignation, the man offers the officials his hands to be shackled. He turns back one last time before he goes, to say "Thank you for everything," — dignified until the very last. The crew shall miss his company greatly.
The Coral Island

The storm came from nowhere, wrecking your ship on coral-strewn shores. For a time your crew feel like children again — dancing along the sand and bathing in the sun, as they await a verdict on the damaged hull. When it comes, the news is not good: extensive repair is needed, and with supplies so short, there is considerable disagreement. Why concentrate on repairs, given how long that may take, when bothfood and water are so urgently needed?
Your naval architect has a grand plan...

The architect unveils a breathtaking sketch for the repair. Seeking shade and isolation almost from the moment of the shipwreck, the architect devotes every ounce of concentration to their art. The result is a watertight schedule of renovation for the damaged hull, that aside from securing your swift departure, reminds all of the incredible talent committed to this expedition.
Explain why fixing the ship is paramount

You make good progress on the ship repairs, by offering a specific motivation: "If we can get her fixed, there's a friendly port not far away." While she's not yet ready to depart, the crew are reassured that it won't be long before the ship is back underway. It might be an idea, meanwhile, to send a small party to look for food and water — you never know when the next chance will come.
"Don't be distracted now — not when we're so close!"

Everyone is in agreement that the ship, their home, is of the greatest importance. By the time the repairs are done, she looks an absolute picture. A sailor has good fortune and finds an equally beautiful conch on the beach. "A keepsake for my son, Ralph," he says, "he'll love it".

You can forgive the crew for being slightly distracted; the work is hard, and they've been at it constantly. No amount of encouragement can speed things up. When the ship is ready, the expedition leaves immediately in order to remain on schedule.
"We can spare a small hunting party"

You find great quantities of exotic paw-paws — and something else with paws! "It was alone and frightened, so we decided to adopt it!" says the chubby bespectacled sailor. The crew rejoice at having a new friend aboard, and as if inspired by the little pup rolling around, they finish the repairs in double time.
The ship has been repaired, but the hunters still have not returned. You'd better decide if it's worth the risk to go after them.
Go after them

You should have sent the second group first! Your team have no difficulty tracking the original hunting party to the dense heart of the island, where they have somehow managed to get themselves lost. Perhaps it was all that fermented sapodilla fruit they've been eating! The captain jokes that the woozy-looking bunch should finish the repairs alone, but everyone is just glad that they've been found.

Prey to themselves! The deeper inland the search party venture — and this island is far larger than first they thought — the more animal they become. "The beast... the beast!" they say, believing something terrible stalks them, when all the while it has been within them. A huddle of the original party are found in a cave: scratched, kicked and bit. Neither group will speak of it when they return to the ship.
Wait for them

They return just as those waiting on the beach have started to lose patience. Everyone can see the hunters are rested and well-fed, having taken advantage of their little excursion at the expense of the many — and yet they claim they have found nothing. The ship sets off under a small grey cloud.

The reaction is lukewarm, and so is the effort: days pass and the work barely seems to move on. The remaining supplies are scarce. In the place they've been logging, one of the sailors finds some exotic mushrooms and brings them back to camp. Could this mysterious fungi be key to survival?
Ask the botanist

Your expert happens to take more than a mere amateur interest in mycology, and recognises these to be excellent-tasting mushrooms. Those fussy about fungi will have to learn to see them as fuel, because that breach in the hull needs fixing! Within a few days, the ship is ready, and your expedition can resume.
Try to discern if they're harmful

Your precautions are sensible. A volunteer rubs the mushrooms on the back of the hand, and finding no visible reaction, touches it to his lips, then tongue, before tentatively holding it in his mouth. By this process it is adjudged safe, but the men boil it up just in case: rubbery but nutritious. Within a few days, the ship is ready, and your expedition can resume.

Yes, they are harmful. "Go ahead and eat — the white ones are usually edible," says the doctor, who is no expert in caution, let alone fungi. Alarm bells ring when a sailor clutches his belly, and drops to his knees. To which do you attend — your sick or your boat?
Persuade the crew it's not worth the risk

The crew see sense and wade through the repairs. By the good fortune of being waterside, they also happen across the odd fish, crab or mollusc, which keeps everyone going until the work is done. Within a few days, the ship is ready, and your expedition can resume.

The crew won't listen, and eat the doom 'shrooms. "We're good for nothing on an empty belly!" they say, but alarm bells ring when a sailor drops to his knees. To which do you attend — your sick or your boat?
They look angelic, take a gamble

They are indeed heavenly, if lacking in quantity. Your crew's trust in the divine appears well-placed, and the repairs proceed without further incident. Within a few days, the ship is ready, and your expedition can resume.
These are Destroying Angels. Alarm bells ring when a sailor clutches his belly, and drops to his knees. To which do you attend — your sick or your boat?
"The sick must be our priority!"

The doctor is competent enough, at least, to purge those affected with castor oil. It's a deeply unpleasant experience, but the crew bond, and take some determination into the repairs. Within a few days, the ship is ready, and your exhausted crew are able to drift towards the nearest safe harbour to recover.

"A harmless experiment!" says the doctor quickly, whipping some ricin seeds from a coat pocket. "Normally it would be castor oil used to purge their bowels, but I wonder if the seeds wouldn't do the same?" Unfortunately, the doctor's seeds are extremely poisonous. In just a few hours, the patients are all dead. Devastated, and far fewer in number, the survivors take forever to complete the repairs. Exhausted, they drift to a safe harbour to try and recover.
"We're all running out of time: fix the boat!"

The crew understand this is all about survival, and take a newfound determination into the repairs. Those poisoned by mushrooms are close to death, but show grit and determination in self-treatment, and manage to pull through. Within a few days, the ship is ready, and your exhausted crew are able to drift towards the nearest safe harbour to recover.

The words serve to scorn the sick and the weak, their meaning in effect being, "if you can't defend your share of what's left, you don't deserve to survive." It is only much later, when the ship is in port, that your brutes rediscover their compassion. They realise the expertise they've left for dead — those misfortunate enough to have been poisoned by mushrooms, or indeed, for having shown any other human frailty.

Sadly, the absence of belief comes through in those words. No-one seems to think repairing the ship on the remaining rations is possible. "We're all going to die here!" they say, "unless someone stronger takes charge!" You'd better offer a more democratic process, or else keep them fed, or there's going to be trouble.
Organise life on the island democratically

The new system does ease the frustration a little. In order for every opinion to receive due consideration and respect, only one holding a conch shell may speak, and they cannot be interrupted. Though the bureaucracy is both frustrating and incongruous in the circumstances, it at least allows everyone to have their say. Gradual progress is made on the hole in the boat, and the expedition eventually resumes.

Democracy doesn't hold for long. "It's stupid that I can only talk when I have a shell in my hands!" says one, "I'm the one who found the fish that fed us yesterday — I should have the right to decide!" Before long, the crew is lost in needless quarrels. The ship repairs barely progress in the coming weeks, and by the time the sailors can finally depart this vexatious coral island, they are close to starving.

The system creates confusion and division. "Listen to someone because they're holding a shell? What do you take us for?" The first mate leans raffishly from a rock wall, "If you want to do things properly around here, come with me!"
From this moment on, things deteriorate rapidly. The island turns into a battlefield, with hoarded resources becoming motives for murder and betrayal. Only a chance passing ship, seeing smoke signals, comes to the rescue. They are kind enough to repair your ship, and wish the encrimsoned dregs of your expedition better fortune in their future endeavours.
They just need to eat, that's all

The food does ease the frustration a little. Since fish and fruit now seem so easy to find, there is disgruntlement that this wasn't made the priority on arrival. Grudges aside, the crew are a lot sharper, and manage to get the work on the ship done despite a general lack of expertise. The expedition eventually resumes.

The hunters find a piffling amount of food, and with blood sugar levels low, the arguments are relentless. Fights and scuffles break out over the most trivial things, and the ship repairs barely progress in the coming weeks. By the time the sailors can finally depart this vexatious coral island, they are close to starving.

There's nothing to eat, anywhere. Repairs to the hull seem inconsequential when people are dropping like flies. But if hunger is the devil, those fallen bodies are the deal: best eaten while they're still fresh. From this moment on, things deteriorate rapidly. The island turns into a battlefield, with hoarded resources becoming motives for murder and betrayal. Only a chance passing ship, seeing smoke signals, comes to the rescue. They are kind enough to repair the ship — and wish the encrimsoned dregs of your expedition better fortune in their future endeavours.
Agree to hunt for food and water

The island is alive with animals. While trapping a few pygmy deer, your hunters encounter a pig's head on a stick. It is rotten and buzzing with flies. As the crew move close, a filthy old man with a beard to his waist cavorts from the trees — surely a castaway who has never been found. "Don't touch him, don't touch him!" he shrieks, before turning to the pig head, "My lord, I hope these troublemakers didn't disturb you?" You aren't sure this loon can be saved.
Talk to the old mariner

Something changes behind the old man's eyes upon hearing the spoken word again. "Forgive me — my Lord receives few visitors to his kingdom. Pray, from what kingdom come you?"
When they describe his own homeland, the old man begins to weep. "Home! They want to take me home!" He bows to the pig head. "My Lord, with your permission I would leave your service and... Oh really, my lord? Thank you, thank you so much!"
There are plenty of supplies for the ship, and over the next few days' voyage, the old man slowly recovers his humanity, regaling the fabulous tale of his marooning.

The onslaught of words seems to rile him up,"Get away, devil interlopers!" He dances towards a keen-tipped spear, and jabs it at any who draw near. "We don't believe you! My Lord does not believe you! You had better leave before he gets angry!" The crew feel so claustrophobic with this man, and the fly-coated pig's head, that they run back to the ship. The voyage resumes without the extra supplies that all had hoped for.
Leave him to his pig-on-a-stick

The hunters ignore the madman, and return to the boat. "Fresh venison!" they cry up the beach, provoking a small cheer from the repair crew. Meat turning on a spit provides a good incentive, and the hull is finished in no time. When all settle down to eat, there is much curiosity about the wildman of the forest, and his pig's head. The expedition continues.
Since they have found precious little food here, the men start to fight over who needs it most. Tension is growing, and they will be at each others' throats if nothing is done.
Calm them down

Though it only takes a few words to remind them of how things would be done in the halls of government back home, the sailors have no choice but to suffer through the ship repairs on dreary rations. After weeks of hard work, the crew are finally able to sail away.

The argument is rational to a fault. "If, like you say, it's all about survival, what are we waiting for? Let's weed out all the fat ones!" Fearing mutiny if they do not comply with the wishes of the strong, your officers condone the malicious exile of the weak, allowing them to be left behind when the ship is finally ready.
Confine dissenters to the ship

Thuggery rules out here, and following a nasty scuffle, those with the most extreme views are seized and tied up in the ship's brig until the repairs are complete. The remainder get the hull job done, but it's a chore working under the lingering hostile atmosphere.

Unfortunately, the most outspoken also prove the most savage — it's about survival, and none of the normal rules hold here. They take vital charts and supplies from the ship to a stronghold up on the hill; a rock formation they have come to call "the castle". Your men lay siege and break through, but lives are lost. Before the expedition resumes, a small memorial — of coral — is erected for the dead.

They make the island seem a barren hell, their desperate thirst for meat finding no quarry. Repairs to the hull seem inconsequential when people start dropping like flies. But if hunger is the devil, those fallen bodies are the deal: best eaten while they're still fresh. The ship may be recovered, but these men will never be the same again.
Risk mutiny and demand the repairs

It's good that your craftsmen are so adept, because the impatience of the entire crew is palpable. Fortunately, by giving everyone something to do, those in charge of the repairs exude a quiet authority. Everyone learns to take pleasure in the details, and before long the ship is at least as fit for the expedition as it was before. They escape the coral corral with a profound sense of togetherness and achievement.

"Another week? Can't you see we're all going to die here!?" The beefy sailor rips the hammer from the carpenter's hand. Survival instinct has thrown the existing order into disarray, and from this moment on, things deteriorate rapidly. The island turns into a battlefield, with hoarded resources becoming motives for murder and betrayal. Only a chance passing ship, seeing smoke signals, comes to the rescue. They are kind enough to repair the ship — and wish the encrimsoned dregs of your expedition better fortune in their future endeavours.
Permit A38

Not a step forward!" says the harbour master of the big merchant harbor the crew stopped at. "You need to register your galley before doing anything here! Go to the harbour office, the red building, on the first floor corridor B last door on the right." A group of sailors volunteer to go but when they arrive there is no door on the right, only on the left.
Open the left door and ask for direction

The diplomat is the nicest consumer the administration officer has seen in a while. The old man holds up the group, rambling about his life for long minutes, visibly happy to have somebody to listen. Eventually, he stamps the official paper and wishes the bush a nice day. The crew leaves happy, they can be among the happy few who have a great experience with administration.</br></br>Diplomat beat them at their own game, understanding the administration system.

The diplomat is already bothered by what seems to be a boring administrative procedure. He opens the door without knocking and startled a man who was swinging on his chair, clearly not working. "Who gave you permission to come to my office?! I am not a guide, take care of your own problems! And close the door, impertinent!"
Threaten him to get the information

Visibly intimidated, gives direction. They walk long corridors and start to believe the man fooled them when they arrived in front of the door marked Gallery Matriculation. Enter, they get the permit.

"Such bad manners! Go to window 1 second floor fourth corridor"</br>One of the sailor notices a smirk on his face but is too happy to finally have a direction to question it.</br>At window 1, two ladies talking and refusing to answer the sailors request, they claim they are not abilited but the official stamp is on their desk.
Win them over so they deliver the authorization / Be nice, not usual costumer

The sailor listens carefully to their conversation and notices the exact right moment to get into it. "You are so right! It is shocking that she had to let her maid go because she has no more money? I am utterly chocked!" </br>"Exactly!" answers the lady, "but she claims she fired her because she prefers to do the housework herself but I know that..." </br>The conversation goes on for a few minutes then one of the ladies command the sailor on his niceness and politeness. She agrees the sign the authorization.

Sailor push himself into the conversation. Feels really rude. The two ladies refuse to help them out and order them to leave their office immediately. The sailors lost hours for nothing, the ship is forced to leave the harbour.
Slam a fist on the desk
"Gentlemen please call down, some of us are trying to work! You want to immatriculate a galley, here is your paper. Now be kind to leave!"

The demonstration of strength is not for the least intimidating for the ladies. "Jesus, how rude people are these days! No way I am helping you!" "Give us the Permit!" screams a sailor. "No we are here to immatriculate a galley!" screams the other.</br>"Out, all of you!" the lady screams. The sailors lost hours for nothing, the ship is forced to leave the harbour.</br></br>Shut the metal window
Take the stamp on their desk discreetly
Pretend to check on papers on the desk and succesfully manage to grab the stamp while the ladies have a lively discussion. Stamp the official paper and put the stamp back in place unnoticed.
Fail, see them try to steal the stamp. The sailors are carried outside. They lost hours for nothing.
Leave the office and look for a map

The crew is extremely careful in order to spot anything which might look like direction. They end up finding a confusing map in a remote corridor but they manage to make sense of it. Spot the Galley Matriculation office on it. Go there, get the permit.
Climb all the floors, look everywhere. "These stairs are pretty steep!" complains a sailor. Unfortunately no map is on sight. The sailors are very tired and a bit discouraged.
Ask for help to the first passerby
Despite his exasperation, the diplomat remains nice. The person gladly gives direction but once at the office one of the clerk say the person they are looking for is gone for lunch.
Persuade the lady present to take care of the request
"Aren't you a dove" giggles the old lady as she take the stamp on her colleague desk. She provides them with the galley registration paper.

The diplomat is rude, the old lady refuses to help them. They wait for the person in charge for two hours and when he arrives, the old lady whispers a few words to him while looking at the sailors. The administrative officers lets everybody else go first and when it's finally the crew turn the officers shot "End of office hours, please leave the building!" The crew has last hours for nothing, go back to the ship which is forced to leave the harbour.
Wait for the officer to come back
After two hours waiting the officer comes back and sign. The crew lost a lot of time but they had the permit they were looking for.

"Fly you fools! I have been trapped in this house for hours today and it is already the third time I come back for the same document! I don't know what to do!" He storms out of the corridor screaming. Without direction, the sailors keep roaming for hours for nothing until they give up and go back to the ship which is forced to leave the harbour.
Give up
Lost time, the rest of the crew is angry at them, think they are stupid to not be able to perform a task as easy as this one. The ship has to leave.
Look for a map

The crew easily spots a piece of paper on the wall which looks nothing like a map to the untrained eyes. Though confusing, they manage to make sense of it and find the galley registration office., ground floor, first corridor on the right.</br>"We need to register a galley". "You didn't need to come here" says the office lady, "a stamp from the harbor master would have been enough. Luckily I have one here, here you go". The crew feels lucky to be done with an administrative procedure so fast.</br></br>Beat them at their own game
Climb all the floors, look everywhere but see nothing. "These stairs are pretty steep!" complains a sailor. The sailors are very tired and a bit discouraged.
Too bad for the planned nice time on land, administration is one of the circle of hell
Have to leave the harbor immediately without being able to relax and enjoy life on land before having to come back to the sea.
The Predator

'A fearsome predator stalks us!' the cabin-boy whispers. Perhaps he is right, for this resupply has not been as uneventful as hoped. Only the first evening moored in this bay, and a man goes missing - tracks up the beach into jungle. Many wonder how work can be expected to continue...
Bait the creature

With the perfect lure placed enticingly in the crook of a tree, there is an inevitability about a capture. Sure enough, yellow eyes pierce the darkness, and a mighty beast pads softly over to the bait. A net is hurriedly cast about it and secured, thus leaving the expedition free to resupply unthreatened.
Send hunters to track it

Your huntmasters are expert, and trace with great care, the soft hollows imprinted by feline paw. Led to a clearing, they correctly judge this to be a lair, where they stand ready with a net. When the cat returns, heaving hot breath, the hunters pounce. With net secure, the expedition is free to resupply unthreatened.

At least one hunter did the right thing, and kept his eyes open while they traced the beast's pawprints. Another was not so wise, and was heard to let out a scream. His comrades were drawn to the spot, and struck the majestic beast down. But not before the damage was done.
Three days pass, and still no word. There is a common feeling something must be done to save those men.
Send a rescue party

It is only something of a relief when the rescue party return. It's bad news... the hunters are dead. The rescue party described the bright and long-maned beast, and how in a tussle, they slayed it. With the bodies of the hunters buried, the expedition is able to resupply in an atmosphere of respectful silence.

'Horror! It's picking us off one by one!' bawls a fearful sailor, for now the rescue party too, have failed to return. There is nothing for the disconsolate remainder of the crew to do, but leave this sorry place behind.
Wait a bit longer
Doubtful prayer brings no news of the lost hunters. The men have nowhere to look for guidance, and there is a burdensome feeling that a decision must be made.

Conviction in the lord is of little use here, it seems. Two days later a hunter, whose leg is mangled, limps back into view. After the necessary amputation, he is heard to groan that the others perished. All must leave this savage place.
Leave the island without them

'We leave them for dead, when they could be right there now waiting for us!' cries a furious old tar. Like so many others, he is disgusted that good men should give their lives for nothing but impatience!
Speak with locals

'Absurd magic, but it works!' say officers sent to the inland village for help. Having described the beast, they were referred to a witch. She encouraged them to ingest live scorpions, one of each colour; yellow, red and black. This they did reluctantly, but found when they confronted the animal, it took flight. All promptly follow the witch's advice, and sure enough, remain undisturbed for the remainder of the resupply.
'Our plight means nothing to the locals,' bemoan the officers sent as diplomats. 'Telling them beasts stalk the jungle, is as like alerting a hatter to the presence of hats on his hatstands.'
'Their deity is desecrated!' urges the officer sent as diplomat. All around the bay, daubed faces appear, bows raised to the expedition camp.
Teach them a lesson
'A hollow victory', say the men. For the locals lie dead, but the jungle beast stalks on.

Odds against them, the men fight as best they can. Fought back onto the sand, they deflect the rain of arrows with whatever they can lay hands on. A relay is able to return precious equipment to the ship and set sail, but not without a number of casualties, of whom some do not make it.

The onslaught is deadly. Few among your crew have the requisite experience to defend themselves, and so the sand reddens with their blood. Of those who make it as far as the expedition ship, a number succumb to the poison-tip arrows. It is a massacre.
Run for the ship!

'Run!' comes the panicked cry. The men drop their work, and tramp desperately through the shallows to the ship. A volley of arrows pierces three, squirting crimson into the clear blue. 'Dead aside, we have lost a great deal more in provisions than we have gained,' laments the quartermaster, as your ship departs that wretched bay.
Lay a trap

The ingenious powers of the craftsmen among your crew have fashioned a pitfall for the beast. There is not long to wait before there is a tinkle on the handbell, and all can gather above the trap to see the monster growling at its bottom. The resupply may now happily proceed, knowing that danger is averted.
The beast is too intelligent to fall for makeshift traps. It is clearly evading the pitfall prepared by those supposed to be the expedition's deftest craftsmen. 'Little more we can do,' they shrug.
Leave the island

'It's a considerable setback,' say senior officers. Fresh water, wood for burning, plants for medicine - it does no good to list what myriad opportunities are missed in bypassing the bay. And all for the sake of fears over one measly wild animal.
A Grizzly Encounter

Bear attack! The party ponder this very real possibility as threatening grunts stop them dead among the firs. Fifty yards ahead, a huge specimen lurches up on two legs like a totem, standing between them and escape. More grunting echoes nearby. The party stay silent, awaiting guidance.
Scare the bears away
Boooooom! The valley shudders with the sweet stench of exploded dynamite. The bears hurry away, leaving the crew thoroughly entertained at the superiority of mankind and the power of invention.
Use hunting knowledge to get the better of the bears

Trust in the expert hunters never feels misplaced, even when they recommend the party break into passionate song. For singing the shanty 'Cheerly-ay-oh' brings the crew together, whilst also dispersing the wary bears deep into the forest.

The hunters lack guile. They have enough to lead the crew on a route silent as a church, but not enough to stop a bear sniffing them out. It's easy to believe from its vacant eyes, that it sees you as a potentially delicious kind of threat.
Attack the bear

The bear's face proves a good target. Ducking the terrifying whooshes of its paws, someone manages to prime their pistol and shoot it through the eye. The bear drops dead. No-one feels particularly good about killing it, but the way ahead is now clear.

Adaptation is good when a fight isn't going well. The bear flinches but does not drop after the first round of gunfire. There is no time to reload, before it is upon them with its paws. Knocked down the men are smart enough to play dead. After an hour or so facing the floor, the bears lose interest and leave. The crew are able to lick their wounds, and move on.

It's easy to underestimate mummy bears. As the soldiers fluff the loading of their weapons, the bear nonchalantly grasps one by the wrist, and sinks her jaw into his neck. The others panic and flee with their arms in the air. She pursues a second, striking him dead against a rock. Now she and her cubs can finally be left in peace.
Outmanoeuvre the bear

Sometimes it helps to know your hill contours. The crew carefully fall away, circumventing the bear's position, and keeping their backs to the mountainside. With the higher ground, the bear appears to lose interest. Hearts pumping, the crew hurry to safety.

Stupidly the crew decide to run, and reach a dead-end. The bear pursues at a leisurely speed, yet with no less menace, and the crew are forced to seek refuge in a cave, or else try climbing the trees.
Hide in the cave and pray

Against all anxiety, the Bear doesn't follow. Still, the men in the cave are too afraid to light a fire, or sleep through the night. Shattered and hungry, they emerge the next morning, only to find their sacrifice was wholly unnecessary.

Bears can see terribly well in the dark, and since your crew have stumbled into its house, where its vulnerable infants sleep, it is not very happy. The crew that do manage to break for daylight have clothes ragged and torn, and cannot speak, for it is clear they were the lucky ones.
Climb the trees

The crew climb the trees well enough, but the bear isn't going to make their lives easy. It is a full day and night before it gives up shaking trunks, or climbing halfway up towards the dangling crew. When it finally leaves, the exhausted crew descend, their nerves in shreds.

Bears are awfully good at climbing trees, and as on this occasion, it is not uncommon to see them strike their adversaries from the branches. Its hapless victim plunges from the canopy and lands like a sack of red berries on rocks below. Others injure themselves as the men drop from the trees in a desperate escape.

Call themselves hunters! The tracks thought to lead away from bear territory go instead to a clearing at its heart. The bears at first seem alarmed their picnic is disturbed, until they realise your crew are on the menu. The sound of crunching bone rings in the ears of the few that manage to flee.
Attack the bear blocking the way

The lone bear's haunch is picked out with expert marksmanship. It staggers before bounding off into the woods. Your crew are delighted to return to the safety of the ship, whilst also having done the mighty beast no lasting harm.

The first volley of shots miss, and the bear attacks. A second shot finds its mark, and the wounded bear escapes into the trees, but a man lies dead. His brother cries revenge, and is already off into the woods to hunt the grisly killer.
Track the wounded bear with him

Bittersweet. Your fine tracking skills allow the crew to catch up with the bear and watch it from hiding. It is a she-bear, and is now nuzzling its young cubs. 'That is why she killed him,' says the brother, gone all vitriol. 'Let us leave, and hope my brother's spirit may somehow live on in this place.'

The hot-headed hunt is a success none celebrate. Once found, the bear no longer has strength to defend itself. As the brother drives a stake into its heart, it gives over with a last sad sigh. In that moment a tiny cub pads into the open, crawling weakly under the limp arm of its mother. If only they had understood, the crew could have saved the heartache.

Hunting is impossible with passions running this high. When another man snaps a twig, the vengeful brother attacks him wildly, and the others fail to intervene. The brother's eyes glaze as he slides to the earth, bayonet in his back.
Leave the fool behind

The decision is unpopular. 'Stubborn 'til the end,' say those in the minority. But the greater part have things to say on the subject of dishonour. 'Those brothers loved each other to the end,' remarks one old sailor, 'and what little love did we show for them...'

Out here, bears rule. The wildly inaccurate gunfire serves only to rile the bear into a frenzy, and draw attention to your position. Then a second, larger bear thunders from the undergrowth and mauls a man to death. A few of your piffling soldiery manage to escape with all their limbs attached.
Use camouflage

The bears have no chance. Indeed, the camouflage is so good, the crew can barely see one another! Thickly daubed in the colours of the forest, the chameleon crew bypass the bears with ease. A story of ingenuity at which their grandchildren shall marvel!

Even the most hardened sailors find the smell unbearable. Not to mention the indignity of covering oneself in bear excrement for longer than is perfectly necessary. Eventually though the bears depart, leaving the reeking crew free to have a much-needed wash.

Dressing as pantomime trees is a bad idea, and as the bears attack, the flimsy branches the crew intended to cover their faces prove no more effective in self-defence. The ensuing scene might have made for an impressive spectacle on the stage, though only as the most gruesome of tragedies.
In the Grasp of the Tentacular

Could it be the kraken?! What else could possess "tentacles wide as a barrel and long as bowsprits", as your lookout claims to have spotted protruding from the treacle-black swell? Creature of legend or not, a shadow below the surface is hurtling towards your ship at full speed!
Fire a torpedo at the thing

The hulking cephalopod is no match for the torpedo! The self-propelled projectile requires no special effort to dispatch, and yet its underwater prowess is indisputible. It crashes into the kraken with a wallop that sends a profusion of octo-bits frothing to the surface. The crew are delighted to discover the flesh is cooked, yet not at all rubbery.
Kill the monster

THUNK! An excellent shot! The harpoon lodges into the creature's amply-sized brain. It takes little effort to haul the reddish mantle and decimette of long pulpous limbs aboard. No-one is going to believe this trophy when they see it — or that something of this size swam at such threatening velocity! Its eyes alone are half a metre wide!

Sloppy shooting from your pod of suckers. The twisting aberration slinks and jets obliquely, its mantle engorged and thrumming with arcane energy. Its lip-like suckers pucker and latch onto the hull, levering its beaked face up above the starboard rail in a game of peek-a-boo. It is vast!
Slice its meaty tentacles!

The monstrosity detaches violently! Your men hack fiercely and without relent at a key tentacle until it severs. The loopeyed beast blubbers a pained raspberry, coating the deck with plankton-infused clamminess, before tearing itself back into the sea, with a large section of your ship in tow! Some repairs will be needed!

There are just too many legs! Having been interrupted at dinner, your sailors try to improvise a dissection with their knives and forks, but the monstrosity refuses to become calamari. Its innumerable tendrils cavort, punching holes and tossing sailors at whim! One unfortunate sailor is flung so perfectly that his return trajectory lands him directly, and fatally, atop a flagpole. Having satiated itself on flesh and timber, the kraken detaches, and bolts away with typical flourish.
Blow it away!

Right in the mandibles! The kraken inhales the slew of heavy artillery and is propelled outwards and star-like, before plummeting to the depths with a good part of your ship still in its grip. Repairs will be needed! You cannot think why the creature was so offended by your presence, but at least it now has some memento of your meeting to clutch onto.

Your gunmen cannot keep their feet long enough. The ctenidious cephalopod rocks the ship to and fro, shaking your boys from the big guns, before sealing itself over an open window and sucking up men as if it had a straw in an ice cream sundae. Eventually, after deciding it's poked and prodded enough, the monstrosity relinquishes its goily grasp, and flops back to the deep to digest the better part of your crew into a liquid.
Outrun the thing

A powerful spurt of propulsion! The unnatural power of your steam ship eclipses the jetting shadow from the far, far depths. The ship's horn sounds a farewell salute to the creature, who those present swear is equipped with two clocktower eyes, within which ink-black pupils swim delirious. For now, it seems, its wait for a suitable mate must go on.

The wind is with you. Whatever that bird-beaked nest of serpents below actually is, it relaxes in its piston-like pursuit of your ship once your crew have succeeded in catching the best of the prevailing breeze. Those present swear it was equipped with two clocktower eyes, within which ink-black pupils swam delirious. For now, it seems, its wait for a suitable mate must go on.

Your crew cannot manage to disentangle themselves, for the creature is in search of a mate, and filled with frightful lust. Only once it has clambered up the side, and attached its hectocotylus to your ship, does it begin to have misgivings about the romantic potential of this union, and start thinking about dinner instead...
Teeth of the Mountain

A track leading over these impenetrable mountains should be a blessing, yet your men are having doubts. Your guide, for a start, absolutely refuses to follow the path. In fact, the very idea scares him. At the base of the mountain, which juts ferrous and fibrous above the greenery like a chunk of braised meat, is a stone head carved in the rock. It grins awfully, and between its huge square teeth is what appears to be a severed arm.
Follow the track

The trail leads through the centre of a hilltop village, the straw shelters improbably nestled between steep-sided slopes. But it is the appearance of the inhabitants that astonishes: unlike all the other peoples of this great rainforest, they are tall and pale, blond-haired and blue-eyed. "But why? What can their story be?" someone chuckles, only to find their companions are oddly tense.
Approach the inhabitants

Your diplomat establishes a common heritage! At least, their language certainly suggests as much. There are familiar sounding terms such as "gonne" and "gun", for example, although their words for water, tree and mountain are consistent with local dialects. Their mythology appears to centre around a tall, blue-eyed ancestor, who came long ago from the Old World, and eloped up this mountain with a local woman in order to conceive the eagles who now circle its peak. Your party receives the stories with great interest, and are made to feel very welcome.

Your envoy's approach is based upon an assumption. "Hello!" she exclaims suddenly, "What brings you to these godforsaken hills?" But the villagers cannot understand her. They begin to close in on her.
Rescue her

She is saved, at least. "Feels like we killed one of our own today," says a soldier, in reference to the villager they shot. "Not really..." another replies, "...but it's terrible he had to die, nonetheless." Your expedition leaves the mountain pass quickly, so the pale and mysterious community can mourn this violation.

The enemy take the high ground, their guns and projectiles proving rather effective for them. They rush their hostage to the neck of the pass, and up onto a large rocky outcrop. It's the perfect cover from which to assault your party, exposed as they are on the bald crest of a slope. Men are dying — it's hopeless to remain. Later, when imagining the fate of the poor diplomat, the survivors cannot help but remember the stone head they saw, and the human limb in its jaws.
Leave her

It's a dreadful feeling. Scrambling down the mountain, your expedition hears a sudden and piercing scream. "You never know, she might yet survive," someone remarks — but later, as they are imagining the fate of the poor diplomat, your survivors cannot help but remember the giant stone head they saw at the foot of the mountain, and the human limb in its jaws.
Watch from a distance

It is an opportune moment that your expedition chooses, skirting around and rejoining the mountain track further ahead. Aside from what is most likely to be some distant Old World heritage, there is nothing especially remarkable about the daily business of this tribe, except that they are far too focused on collecting honeycomb from a very tall tree to notice you.

Not too clever. Fearing exposure up on the slopes, your men opt to tiptoe through the village. Perhaps they just smell too delicious, because the pallid, hungry-looking villagers emerge from their dwellings as one, equipped with all sorts of sharp-looking implements...
Apologise for trespassing

Your diplomat finds common ground, although not what you might expect. It just so happens that these people are about to tuck in to a feast of human remains. Your diplomat reassures the expedition, "It is their practice to eat their loved ones when they die. Rather beautiful when you think about it." Nevertheless, your crew are rather pleased not to have to partake, and continue on their way.

Your diplomat fails to control her nerves. She breaks down whimpering, and one of your manly men muscles in front of her. "Now listen here!" he bellows, "Get back you fiends! Get back or I'll cut you down!" Yet, pale and uncomprehending, still they come. Your brute wavers, and looks as if he's seen a ghost. He turns and runs down the mountain with the others. It will be a hard road on from here.
Draw your weapons!

Where discretion fails, force prevails. Your crew are unfazed by the singular appearance of the villagers, and spring into action. The villagers' expressions remain resolute, even as they flee up the mountain to take refuge with the condors. But there is sadness behind those eyes: this isn't fair. Your men loot the village.

Many amongst your expedition will be eaten, or so your survivors believe. They should have fought as if their lives depended on it, but the ferocity and ingenuity with which the mountain ghosts took them was a great shock. The question as to the provenance of the local people has only become cloudier, but those who fled the mountain will not forget them any time soon.

Your explorers find themselves surrounded. Those leading the group have their heads so buried in their maps, they fail to notice they've blundered right through a village. The villagers are oddly tall and pale, with blue eyes and blonde hair. They look hungry, and are equipped with all sorts of sharp-looking implements...
Avoid the tracks

A shortcut may have been ignored, but fair progress is made regardless. Declining the invitation to enter the territory of whomever made that gruesome stone carving, your crew feel a sense of relief, despite the extra effort the alternative route will demand of them. Along the way, your officers surmise that transgressing into the territory of the local people is seldom necessary, or desirable.

Avoiding the tracks means getting lost, the steep contour of the valley overwhelming what limited grasp of the geography your explorers have. They emerge a week of aimless wandering later, devoured not by the cannibals rumoured to inhabit these parts, but by the mosquitoes and leeches so at home near the flooded river.
Cities of Gold

The faded ink... The gold leaf... Could this map lead to El Doodah? It fluttered into the hands of your sailors, who believe it to be the most bona fide clue in centuries as to the location of the city of gold. They're already dreaming of the hulking neckchains they'll find, and how well they'll set off their earrings. Why, even the captain has suggested hiring a guide! Yet the greedy have come this way before, and it never seems to end well...
Hire a guide
El Doodah, you say? Yes, I know something about it...
Confirm

He has been searching for the Mesoan city his whole life, and the intensity with which he examines the map suggests he is on the verge of a breakthrough. "Further west than I've ever been," he looks to the forest "but there's no reason it couldn't lie beyond Lake Guavatita". A few days' hike up the river basin and Lake Guavatita shows herself, just like the jagged dagger of water on your map. Beside a high waterfall, your guide shows you a stone marked with Mesoan glyphs. "This marks the end of the trail," he says.
Cancel
Looks like you're on your own. The guide scoffs at your valuation of his services. "Everyone from here to Porto Tristeza will hear what a greedy bunch of conquistador pigs you are!"
Read the map yourselves

The trail ends at a stone covered in glyphs. Following the confluence of high waters, as they weave in and out of one another, you arrive several days later at the lake marked on the faded map. A keen-eyed young whippersnapper notices some unmarked stones have been placed at regular intervals, which culminate at a waterfall, besides a stone whose inscription must have been made long ago.
Interpret the Mesoan glyphs

You strike gold! Metaphorically, at least. Your anthropologist reads from the glyphs, and scampers off yelling, "The fourth rain god! It means North!" When the archaeologist wades back through the small lagoon, they have a big smile on their face, having found a hoard that's of far greater archaeological value than its financial worth! This may not be the city of El Doodah, but it's remarkable enough!
Survey the area

A secret passage! In a nearby rock face you find a gap, scarcely wide enough to slip through, that might easily have been missed but for the thoroughness of the search. One-by-one, the expedition enters to find themselves in a natural cavern, through which a cool wind whips. A little light reveals a rock fall blocking the way ahead, and crawlways branching in all directions.
Clear the rock fall

What wonders laid bare! A sturdy scaffold is built to support the ceiling, before a human chain clears the debris. The antechamber ahead radiates with shining metals! It is a hoard of far greater archaeological value than its material worth! This may not be the city of El Doodah, but it's quite remarkable enough!

The whole roof seems to give way! Perhaps they should have thought to secure the ceiling first, for as they move a large stone, a primeval bellow comes from above. "Run! RUN!" is the cry, as they all rush out. When the noise subsides, the crew return to discover the passage has been sealed. In any case, some have been injured by the falling debris, and must urgently be taken to a doctor.
Investigate the crawlways

Your cavers triumph! The clammy confinement of the narrow tunnels makes them hard to negotiate at first, but your potholers never lose their sense of direction, pushing forward on their tummies until a fresh breeze tingles. "There! A city!" The cavern opens out into an extensive underground ruin, preserved by its clay surrounds. El Doodah or not, there are no doubt some remarkable finds to be made!

Few have any experience of caving. The route they take is clammy and claustrophobic, and seems to be leading nowhere when there's a sudden and awful screeching of bats! A man loses his footing and falls through a gap, breaking his leg. The confined space means his rescue is especially tiresome, and takes several hours to complete — the narrow cave filling with moans whenever anyone so much as grazes the injured leg. You are forced to abandon your search for El Doodah.

"Not so much as a glimmer of this golden city! Not even behind the waterfall," the lieutenant teases, "and besides, these 'glyphs'..." He drops to his haunches and feels the grooves in the stone, "Looks like plain water erosion to me." The captain nods. "Alright men, you heard the lieutenant. Time to give up this fool's errand." Your expedition leaves disappointed.
Divine the meaning of the glyph stone

Praise be, a secret passage! One of the men is unexpectedly knowledgeable on Mesoan theology. "That symbol's in my improving bunk book sir, Cap'n, sir — means god of the underworld." Sure enough, in a nearby rock face, your crew find a gap scarcely wide enough to slip through, and one that might easily have been missed. One-by-one, the expedition enters to find themselves in a natural cavern, through which a cool wind whips. A little light reveals a rock fall blocking the way ahead, and crawlways branching in all directions.

The glyph stone provides no inspiration. "It's a myth! A lie!" Your frustrated lieutenant kicks at it. "Did we expect this golden city to simply descend upon a cloud for us?" The captain sees only one way to dispel the frustration. "Alright men, you heard the lieutenant. Time to give up this fool's errand." Your expedition leaves disappointed.

Your men succumb to their greed. The map must have been a cruel hoax! The worst thing was that it raised their hopes. Some of its landmarks — a high waterfall, a boulder improbably perched — are found to really exist. Beyond that, there's nothing — yet gold fever has already set in. Weeks, months go by before some of your people get a grip of themselves again.
Refuse to believe in a city of gold

Everyone is disappointed. Aside from those in it for the riches, many believe a gilt-edged opportunity to unearth important discoveries has been passed up. After all, that is the whole purpose of expeditions such as this, is it not?
A Fistful of Doubloons

The ship's coffers have been emptied! Your purser knew these new recruits had a wicked air about them... As soon as the ship reached port and the sailors were allowed some rest, the three landsmen merged with the local crowd and disappeared - and with them went weeks of pay! The theft was planned in every minute detail - your sailors have been robbed by professionals.
Track the thieves down

Their fleeing footprints are easily found. The tracks of the thieves' limping leader stand out in the dust. The grazing light of the setting sun highlights the path for your huntsmen to follow, leading them away from the town and closer to its river, where the tracks disappear into the water. The hills rise sharply on the other side.
Look for a ford to cross on foot

A safe passage! The crew's expertise shines as they rapidly spot a shallow part of the river, and cross it without much inconvenience. They go up the sharp hill of the opposite bank and happen upon a vast enclosed field: a pen for horse breeding. A quick discussion with the owner confirms that the thieves stole several animals mere hours ago. The land beyond is barren and unfit for explorers on foot. Your crew needs horses.
Attempt to catch wild horses

The tamed horses easily catch up with your prey. Your hunters lasso the wild animals and break them, before launching through the barren plains. The blurry hot air parts to reveal the thieves' horses, whose speed is no match for wild ones. Your riders surround them, and the menace of both your numbers, and your drawn pistols soon hushes any resistance. The sailors, satisfied and avenged, retrieve their loot and entrust the scoundrels to the local law.

Your sailors are not made to catch land animals. The hunt ends in failure, the most your crew saw of a wild horse being the weathered tracks on the dry roads. Instead of leading your hunters to a herd, the tracks point them to a run-down town of wooden buildings - several houses and a single saloon - its lanterns brightening with the growing darkness. Night is well on its way, and tracking the thieves seems almost impossible now.
Ask the locals for help

The locals agree to help. Your diplomat carefully raises the subject of thieves with a man of imposing authority, the sheriff in charge of the small town. Their modus operandi is familiar to him: a local gang is famous for sneaking around foreign businessmen, but he never would have imagined they'd be so bold as to rob a ship. If the robbery was today, he says, the thieves are sure to come and celebrate at the saloon tonight.
Wait on the town's balconies, ready for an ambush

A clean job. As soon as the thieves come into sight, your sailors stealthily lay their firearms on the guardrails of the balconies, aiming and firing in rapid succession. The shots resonate through the quiet town: one shot, one permanent sleeper. When the sound and smell of the gunshots settles down, the sheriff salutes your crew's help in getting rid of the local pests, and ensures your sailors that their reputation will be made well known throughout the West.

Rout. Your sailors fire as soon as the gang comes into view, taking little time to aim and even less to observe their targets. The bullets graze past the thieves and upset their horses, who rear and jump before running away, along with their riders. A night drizzle starts falling, and soon drowns the bandits' tracks. Ambitious yet inefficient, that's as far as the crew's efforts can go.
Wait at the saloon, ready for a fight

Honour and wages are retrieved.When the gang slams the saloon's doors open, the place is devoid of its usual chirpy atmosphere. Moonbeams disclose the presence of your crew, sat on every possible chair, table and stair step, and already reaching for their guns. The fight is brief. Your sailors overwhelm the thieves and drag them outside, bound and gagged. They pause to salute the sheriff for his help, before heading back to the ship with the satisfaction of a job well done.

Your crew are no match for the criminals. When the gang barges into the saloon, the sailors are still arguing over how to handle the fight in such a closed space. The battle is short-lived. Your sailors lack the rough training and ability of their opponents, and can barely fling insults at them, even less punches. The roughed-up crew is thrown outside, and scampers away from the town - very aware of how lucky they are to still be alive.

Your crew are held responsible for the deserters' actions. Instead of probing around to get an idea of the runaways' reputation, your diplomat immediately asks about the thieves. The men are well-known - in the worst way - and the locals are shocked to hear your crew hosted them, regardless of the theft. The sailors are forced to leave when surrounded by stern-looking gunslingers. The track ends here. More than money, your sailors have lost morale.
Avoid trouble and simply give up

So much effort for such a meagre reward. Feeling the pressure of unseen stares, your crew avoids the shady town and backs away to the harbour city and their ship. Better to decide on your own to withdraw than to be forced to, the sailors tell themselves. Frustration nibbles their thoughts as they set sail.
Buy horses from the breeder
You can choose either to rent, or buy a mount
Confirm

The horses catch up with your prey in no time! In a flurry of dust and whinnying, the mounts assail the barren plains. The blurry hot air parts to reveal the thieves, perched atop horses that are already exhausted from their mishandling. Your riders surround them, and the menace of your superior numbers, and your drawn pistols, hushes any resistance. The sailors, both satisfied and avenged, retrieve their loot, and entrust the scoundrels to the local law.
Cancel

Your crew will make do on its own. The price of the withered mares reeks of a scam, and your sailors refuse to pay a single pound for the animals. Their observations might be influenced by the light weight of their purses.
Get on your horses

Your crew find no guarantee of safe crossing. The sailors quickly get tired of the senseless search: the river's depth cannot be appraised by their untrained eyes, and each segment of the water seems both deep and shallow at once. The crew are too reluctant to try their luck, and abandon their search, disgruntled.
Create a raft to cross the river

A safe passage! The raft is basic but sturdy, and it crosses the river without losing so much as a plank. The crew board the opposite bank safely, and climb the hill that rises beyond it. On the other side, they happen upon a vast enclosed field: a pen for horse breeding. A quick discussion with the owner confirms that the thieves stole several animals mere hours ago. The land beyond is barren and unfit for explorers on foot. Your crew need horses.

The raft can't even float. Your sailors bind logs and dead branches together with sturdy knots, but with little actual knowledge of how to assemble a raft. The raft's apparent stability tricks the builders into climbing on to it, and it swirls over the river, wobbling under the weight of sailors and the pressure of the current, before breaking and diving straight into the icy waters below. Few sailors can be rescued from the wreckage.

No tracks are found. The bustling harbour and the late evening conspire to hide the thieves' tracks. Your sailors aren't skilled enough to pick up the faint trail inside the town itself, but they might have better luck around the outskirts.
Keep searching

Finally, tracks to follow! Amidst the numerous footprints left by your sailors, your best huntsmen manage to find the dotted lines left in the dust by the fleeing thieves. There's no mistaking the bent pattern of their limping leader. The prints waddle to the nearest river, where they fade into the water.
Isn't this humiliation enough? Your crew keeps foraging through the outskirts of the town, but they still cannot find any tracks.
Stop these futile efforts

Your purser protests, but the decision is final. Going after the thieves, in a territory they seem to know by heart, while the crew itself is in foreign territory? It's a risk you're not willing to take. As the ship sails away from the harbour and the villains it hosts, your sailors mourn the plundered funds.
Let them be

Your purser protests, but the decision is final. Going after the thieves, in a territory they seem to know by heart, while the crew itself is in foreign territory? It's a risk you're not willing to take. As the ship sails away from the harbour and the villains it hosts, your sailors mourn the plundered funds.
The Devil's Trumpet

The sound of a human scream alarms your expedition as they pass through a small forest village. Good conscience obliges them to investigate, either openly or in secret, unless of course they feel it best not to interfere in local affairs.
Investigate in secret

You choose two of your best, who casually separate themselves from your group. The people in this region are used to western visitors, and suspicions are not raised. Peeking into a cabin, your agents sight a woman being held by two men, while a third appears to be forcing her to drink some sort of herbal concoction.
Burst in and stop them

You take them completely by surprise. In moments, the men are down and out for the count. The woman is eloquent and alert, and she asks to join your expedition. Once she is safely out of the village, she explains with sadness that the angry young men of a rival family have seized control of the region, and that it would be dangerous for her to remain.

The odds aren't good - two against three - and your scouts are knocked violently to the floor. The prisoner is forced to drink, and the vial's contents appear to make her compliant. The three young men push her out of the cabin. When your scouts have themselves recovered, they wonder what they should do.
Call for reinforcements

Keen reinforcements arrive at the double, only to discover that the gang of abductors has grown. They must be fifty-strong, a miscellany of raiders who've been terrorising the region. They are, however, wary of your capabilities, and agree to relinquish the captive woman in return for your immediate departure. Her relatives soon carry her to safety - but with two casualties of your own, you'd best move on quickly too.

Your reinforcements charge idiotically into an important local ritual, causing needless bloodshed. When the woman captive is seen being pushed into a grave of bodies, your men have no sense that this is just the theatre of the occult, and — to the bewilderment of the locals — they open fire. The realisation of what they have done will traumatise your men for the rest of their lives.
Let her go, it's not worth the trouble
A dark silence falls over the village, but for what sounds like the grim clink of shovels on soil. Your men better run for it before they quiver to jelly.
Better to stay out of it after all

Your men try to remain objective, but the scene makes for uncomfortable viewing. The drugged cup, made with the white devil's trumpet flower that grows all around, puts the woman into a somnambulant state, ensuring her compliance. She is taken outside and herded together with the other women, who appear to exist here in patriarchal servitude. You leave feeling depressed that negative stereotypes of other cultures appear to have been reinforced.

It's likely to be an international scandal. Your numbskull spies are caught snooping about, which as it turns out, is an act in breach of a treaty between these people and Her Majesty's government. The leader of the protectorate vows to tear up the treaty and ban all westerners from these territories in future. Your officers all let out little screams inside.
Ask the locals what's going on

Your envoys are sensitive to the particulars of the region, and the locals feel relaxed enough to talk. It seems it was the scream of a young boy: he had been misbehaving, and was given medicine so that ancestors in the spirit world might admonish him, but the medicine seems to have had a bad effect. He is trapped in his nightmares, sweating and screaming all the while. The locals are worried, and look to you for help.
Make a medical diagnosis

The doctor knows botanicals. In the dregs of the medicine cup, the doctor finds Brugmansia, also called Devil's Trumpet — a hallucinogenic plant known for its power to terrify. Though often used in ritual here, the dosage seems high for a child. The other villagers don't seem surprised, because his parents are the local idiots. The villagers are glad the doctor is able to help pump the poison from the boy's stomach, and after a few days he is back to his usual impish self. Your expedition are proud to have been of help.

The doctor puts his hands down the boy's throat. It isn't clear what he is trying to achieve by this, but it causes the boy to thrash violently from side to side. "Damnation!" cries the doctor, yanking out his arm, for the boy has bitten it. Then blood begins to pour from the boy's mouth, and a wriggling pink triangle flops to the floor. He has bitten out his own tongue, and you are shooed angrily from the village.
Consult your knowledge of world faith

"Must be Brugmansia — also known as the Devil's trumpet." Your clergyman is acutely aware of the local religion, and knows the flower is used to induce spiritual delirium. "Once the demon trumpet has been exorcised from his belly, I shall lead both the boy and his parents to a higher place," he says with a self-satisfied air, "and this sort of thing need never happen here again." Rightly or wrongly, your expedition will leave feeling it has done fine missionary work.

Instead of helping the poor boy, your clergyman gets carried away with his proselytising. Being ignorant of the boy's exact affliction, he falls fearfully back to the age-old redoubt of the cleric: that all around them are wicked heathens. It takes several strong soldiers to drag him away, and your expedition leaves feeling it may have tarnished Her Majesty's reputation.

Your representatives don't approach it in the right way: "We heard screaming, and we demand to know the cause!" These people see no reason why they should have to explain themselves to you, and produce a document with a royal seal granting immunity from such unwanted attention. Your leadership feel embarrassed and undermined.
Ignore the screaming and carry on

It sure sounded like torture, and the sanctimonious among you waste no time in reminding everyone of that probability. While good fences make good neighbours, it doesn't hurt to be nosey and neighbourly from time to time.
Trespassers

An ambush of missiles! This unmapped region of the great forest is home to an indigenous people, whose policy is to pre-empt the hostility of trespassers into their territory. Suddenly a man grips his shoulder, where a feathered dart now hangs. It could have come from anywhere. Do you hide, fight, or if all else fails, flee?
Find cover!

The rain of darts comes to an end when your group quickly and cleverly diffuses, each finding their own space. Out of respect, perhaps, your ambushers decide to retreat — or do they simply believe the damage has already been done? Those who were hit begin to wheeze heavily, collapsing to the floor, for the darts are tipped with poison!
Identify the poison

The doctor is praised for their quickness of thought. "Wolf's bane, of the slopes above," words pour out, "classically lethal, but by Jove, I have an idea!" An extraordinary antidote is proposed — a posset of deadly nightshade — and its effect is remarkable. "Don't ask me how, but it's worked!" the doctor says cheerfully, as the victims of the poison darts begin to return to normal. Your expedition marks the territory on the map for the sake of anthropology, before taking the long road around it.

Anxious to avoid misdiagnosis, the doctor is slow to react. Before long, the one who took a dart to the neck suffers opisthotonos — his back arching in spasm, before giving out to exhaustion. The death sparks the good doctor into life. "Ah, so it's strychnine!" he says gesturing to the trees, "Sourced from breadfruit." Chloroform relaxes his patients for a cleansing irrigation, and somehow, they manage to recover. Time to leave this place.

No-one has the faintest idea. Those who took darts wear expressions confused and melancholy as they melt into darkness, wondering, perhaps, what the point of their sacrifice was. Your expedition bury the dead as fast as they can, lest the hostile peoples of this particular territory return.
Knowledge of local practices may yield answers

It's what the locals know as 'ourare'. Accounts from the region frequently reference it as a lethal coating for arrowheads, or in this case, blowpipe darts. A treatment is also mentioned — a form of mouth-to-mouth in which the resuscitator acts as an iron lung for the patient. And it works! There is no childish awkwardness, with an excess of volunteers offering to save their fellows. The victims of the poison are saved, and all emerge from those (often dark) hours with a new feeling of togetherness.

"You always hear stories about poison dart frogs out here," says one of the officers. He doesn't seem to know much more than that, except that in a 'Boy's Own' adventure story, chloroform was used to treat frog poisoning. No-one seems to know where the medicine box is, but by the time it is found, someone has already succumbed to convulsions. It is only a slight relief then, that the chloroform does indeed relax the other victims sufficiently to keep their hearts beating. Time to leave this place.

Your barbarous dimwits are ignorant of local customs. "Do they tip arrows with cyanide, perhaps?" Your officer snaps, wiping sweat from his reddened face, "How the devil would I know what these primitives use?!" Those who took darts wear expressions confused and melancholy as they melt into darkness, wondering, perhaps, what the point of their sacrifice was. Your expedition bury the dead as fast as they can, lest the hostile peoples of this particular territory return.

Unfortunately, the darts continue to find their mark, for the hostile tribe know the forest too well. It is fortunate that your ambushers, perhaps seeing the sort of weapons you're carrying, decide to retreat. Or do they simply believe the damage has already been done? The men who were hit begin wheezing heavily, and collapse to the floor, for the darts were tipped with poison!
Identify the poison
Knowledge of local practices may yield answers
Root out and tackle the ambushers

It takes all of their calm for your men to fan into the forest. There's a thud as one of the dart-blowers is struck down with the butt of a rifle. Whistles all around signal a retreat, leaving your men to examine one of the six-foot blowpipes: perhaps they left knowing the damage had already been done? Sure enough, those hit begin wheezing heavily, collapsing to the floor. The darts are tipped with poison!

Your men make themselves easy targets, desperately trying to pursue and isolate their adversaries, to no avail. As more of the feathery darts hit home, so too does a realisation of their function. Whistles all around signal a surprise retreat, as those who have been hit begin to wheeze heavily, collapsing to the floor. The darts are tipped with poison!
Make a desperate run for it!

The people of the forest will do all they can to protect it. As your expedition flees, the poison darts that have stuck in their backs begin to take effect. There is nothing to do but leave the unlucky ones contorting in agony.
The Beast of the Swamp

"There's no other way, we must wade the swamp." It doesn't look too deep at first, but soon the party are up to their waists in muddy water and too far in to turn back. A sinister log, seemingly adrift, mutates into the jaws of a dragon. "A gator!"
Take the shot
