The doctor falls sick. You can only assume the attempted vaccine has failed the locals also, because two weeks into the onward journey, its creator is in the grip of smallpox. Once the disease sets in there is no cure, unless you choose to trust the poor doctor's survival to God.
God will help where medicine cannot

A brave few serve as guardian angels, praying, washing, comforting the doctor. The acrid smell of the pustules, so particular to smallpox, is soon masked by haloes of incense. After several weeks the doctor's fever goes down and the rashes become less pronounced. While no miracle— the skin will forever bear the scars— it does mean the doctor's survival.

Smallpox spreads with a missionary zeal. Following the priest's foolish suggestion that the crew all visit the doctor to offer their prayers, it is hardly a surprise when a spate of new cases are reported. Three weeks after the doctor dies, others are just beginning to experience the first agonising symptoms. Had your crew heartlessly abandoned the doctor, it would surely have been the better option.
Abandon the doctor

With regret, the doctor must be marooned. Men in gloves carry a stretcher up the beach beyond the tideline to a place in the shade where it seems likely the doctor will live out a few more days. "Fresh air might revive you," says one optimistically, but already the doctor has no strength to reply.
Try to prevent further spread

The instructions are followed to the letter. The local people have never come into contact with smallpox before, but agree to adopt your measures against it. Your crew need reminding too; mouths covered when coughing, the avoidance of skin contact, and the frequent washing of hands in alcoholic solution. It is chastening that your mere presence has caused the death of that poor girl, but after two weeks without further cases, it is certainly a relief it does not appear to have spread.

Your people find it impossible to get the message across. The locals go about their business as usual, disregarding the strictures you have tried to put in place. Sensing the coming epidemic, and as fears for the health of your own crew mount, it may be time just to leave...
Experiment with a vaccine

Saved by a cow with cowpox. Your doctors remember that the "vacca" of vaccination means cow, and extract cowpox from the pustuled udders of a local beast. Everyone receives the injection, which due to the lack of appropriate facilities the doctor is unable to purify. Fortunately this only results in a number of outbreaks of other, much less destructive infections.

Things take a severe turn for the worse... Your doctors have little idea what they are doing, and their extraordinary decision to use a sample from the pustules on the poor dead girl to create their vaccine only accelerates the spread. In desperation, those still in health agree to board the expedition ship and escape while they still can.
Leave as quickly as you can

Smallpox has wiped out entire civilisations. That is the pervading anxiety as the expedition prepares for hasty departure. The locals seem unaware of the danger, perhaps thinking the death of the young girl an isolated case. Before leaving, one of your scribes grimly documents the customs and traditions of these peoples in case it should have to serve as the sole record of their having existed.
The Flower-Eaters

The blue flowers have put the members of your expedition into a frightening delirium. Among the tranquil villages of this delta, your crew had seen the water plants — baskets 'laden with flower and fruit' — everywhere, and had been curious to try them. "You see, it does them no harm," the Captain had said encouragingly, as they made friends with some locals upon the riverbank one sleepy afternoon. But not long into the delicious feast of flowers, your expedition party are experiencing wild hallucinations!
Have the doctor intervene

The doctor chuckles. "Here," he says, dosing each stricken soul with a concoction from his medicine bag, "that should ease things." Soon everyone is sound asleep, and they awake the following day feeling refreshed. Unaware you've cheated, the flower-eaters are impressed! No-one normally handles their first encounter with the flower so well. Taking it as a sign, they offer you something equally precious.

The worried doctor issues an emetic, "Throw it up, it's a poison!" he says. Afterwards, the crew feel extremely weak, but the effect of the drug does indeed begin to fade. "We just didn't have the guts for it," a sailor wipes his mouth. You have shown a weakness of constitution. All around, the flower-eaters share jokes at the crew's expense. You leave humiliated.

"I have just the tonic!" your wild-eyed doctor quavers, pulling a bottle of Vin Mariani from his satchel. However, the mix of wine and coca leaves only serves to heighten the delirium. Some awaken from the incoherence; others don't. The flower-eaters are clearly puzzled, and offer their condolences, for no concoction so ill-advised or unfortunate has ever been seen before — or since.
Ask the locals what's happening

You are somehow able to communicate that you are suffering. Many of the flower-eaters are seeing visions themselves — the effect they expect from consuming the plant. The locals interrupt their own lucid dreaming to help your expedition through it, realising your lack of experience in such rites of passage. The next day, your cosmic travellers feel relieved to return to the more familiar rocking of their ship.
Your men become aggressive. Unable to communicate, they resort to grabbing the locals. "Drugged!" one cries, "What have you done to us?!" There is every danger this is about to turn nasty.
Do nothing

The behaviour of your expedition is shameful. One of the flower-eaters is shoved to the ground in front of her children. When several others pile into the scrum, one of your crew, who shall go unnamed, decides to set fire to a watermill in protest. This doesn't help anyone still having hallucinations. The next morning when they awake, everyone claims not to remember a thing.
Command them to fight their hallucinations instead

They battle bravely against their shadows! Heeding the officer's commands to resist, each of your veterans summons their inner strength to endure the sway of the little blue flower, drenched with sweat and thrusting their hands into the empty air. Eventually the horrors give way to narcosis, and a deep sleep lasting several days. This land of water lilies will take valuable time from your odyssey.

Nightmares reveal truths. The paranoia of their hallucinations centres on each other — a history of indiscipline and bad blood, grudges never properly settled. The drug has liberated those who feel they have been wronged. At daybreak, one of your expedition lies drowned in the river. Officially, the influence of the sinister blue flower will likely be blamed, but others are already telling a different story.
Let them go with the flow

Your party open their minds to visions of the divine. The horrors fade from view, and in their place come forest creatures, nymphs and dryads. Grand cities swirl as if formed of cloud, and golden ships voyage up to the moon.
When the visions disappear, the crew realise they've experienced something extraordinary, and relate what they've seen to their hosts. The flower-eaters offer a token of their appreciation for a shared spiritual experience.

Ahh... the intemperance of addiction. Although they soon grow accustomed to the devilish hallucinations, your men now develop a profane appetite for the pleasures of the flower — slumber's holy balm. Procrastination, and apathy towards the supposedly 'materialistic objectives' of the expedition are the products of these indulgences. When finally dragged away from the sleepy waters, the crew weep bitterly, and swear to be idle for the remainder of their commission.
Sunstruck

Vampirical injuries!? The path through the forest was barely visible beneath the lush vegetation. It isn't until they emerge from the pleasant shade of the trees that sunlight falls upon the crew, swelling up the skin of a few crew members with red rashes and throbbing blisters. Surely there must be a scientific explanation for their sudden photophobia...
Purify their skin

The cold water soothes the burning almost immediately. Your expedition party enjoys a little break away from sunlight, as they gently wash the rashes off with soap in a forest pool of fresh water. The blisters are gone after a few hours and the group is ready to continue.
Identify the cause of their pain

Looks like your doctor did his homework! "I read about something like this during my research of the hazards we could encounter in this region. They must have brushed against a giant hogweed!" The treatment is simple: enjoy a little break away from sunlight and gently wash their skin with clear cold water. The blisters are gone after a few hours, and the group is ready to continue.

The doctor dismisses the throbbing blisters as simple mosquito bites. "Just try not to scratch them. If you can't help yourselves, rub them gently, that's all." But a few hours later, the vesicles have already extended throughout their entire body. They collapse, unable to take a step further, whimpering with unbearable pain.
Reconsider the diagnosis

This time, the doctor takes the symptoms seriously. "It looks like a chemical irritation. I wonder..." The doctor rummages through the nearby flora and in time, he finds it: a tall stem crowned by an umbrella of small white flowers. "A giant hogweed! Of course, its sap causes phototoxicity." Fortunately, the treatment is simple: a cold bath and a long break in the shade. Once they're clean, the doctor heals and bandages the lesions. But it comes many hours too late — his negligence will leave leathery red scars on the wretched few.

"It must be a rare breed of smallpox!" Your squeamish doctor doesn't even lean close enough to the pustules before squealing: "Stay away from them! These people are doomed, there is nothing we can do but avoid contagion!" Panic ensues, and those untouched by the rashes stampede away. The aching bunch are irresponsibly abandoned and left behind.
Expel the vampirical curse

A miracle! The priestess sinks the cursed crew members in a forest pool and blesses their foreheads with the symbol of the cross. "Exsúrgat Deus et dissipéntur inimíci ejus," she recites, and the men and women exhale a sigh of relief as the burning fades away. Although they will have to live with the devil's taint on their skin for the rest of their days, each and every one of them feels thankful and blessed.

The ritual is a most unholy sight. "Sunlight will purge your curse, bear the pain as evil oozes out of your body!" The cursed few writhe under the scorching sun as their blisters slowly morph into aberrant lumps of fluid. Everyone's beliefs are shaken before the nauseating vision. By sundown, they can barely move. It takes days for the throbbing bags of liquid to pop and peel off, leaving the hosts with bright red festering wounds. Massive scars will forever remind them of how they were forsaken by the gods.

"It must be a rare breed of smallpox!" Your squeamish doctor doesn't even lean close enough to the pustules before squealing: "Stay away from them! These people are doomed — there is nothing we can do but avoid contagion!" Panic ensues, and those untouched by the rashes stampede away. The aching bunch are irresponsibly abandoned and left behind.
Ignore the blisters and continue

The most upsetting weeks of their lives ensue from the thoughtless decision. The constant wailing of the aching bunch wrecks everyone's nerves. Their blisters become as unbearably painful as nauseating to behold — they continue to swell, covering up most of their bodies. It takes days for the throbbing bags of liquid to pop and peel off, leaving the hosts with bright red oozing wounds. Massive scars will forever remind them of their harrowing pain.
The Dynamite Tree

The ominous black spikes that covered the tree's trunk were far from the only danger it posed to the crew. As they were carefully circling around it, a loud bang was heard and a man was sent to the floor with a painful yell. One of the tree's fist-sized wooden fruits had exploded, sending surprisingly sharp splinters into the man's right flank. Moving him could be fatal, but the shade of a tree that drops grenades is not the safest place to perform a surgery.
Rapidly remove the shards on the spot

Your doctor's fingers move as a prestidigitator's. He quickly feels the man's abdomen and locates every shard, pulling them out methodically before stitching the patient up. The crew escape the hazardous tree's vicinity within the space of a few minutes — just in time to elude two new explosions.

Stress and inexperience slow your doctor down. With trembling fingers, he slowly pulls a piece of wood out of the man's abdomen — but there are many left to go, and the menacing creaks above his head makes the young doctor shudder even more violently. Before long, another pumpkin-shaped grenade blasts both patient and doctor with wooden shrapnel. The latter manages to shield himself from the brunt of it with his forearms, but the patient is now coughing up blood.
Finish the surgery

Despite his wounds, adrenaline steadies the doctor's hand. Aided by two members of the crew, he decides to perform a laparotomy and open the patient's abdomen up. It's a gruesome, painful procedure, which curdles the blood of everyone present — but nevertheless, the shards are successfully removed. With the surgery finished, half the crew may be left covered in blood and viscera, but both men can now be safely taken back to the ship for recovery.

The surgery was doomed to fail. The doctor attempts to pull out another shard, but his own wounds make him shake uncontrollably, and he punctures a major blood vessel. A nurse tries to stop the haemorrhage, but he is too late: the patient bleeds out by the murderous tree. The crew help the sobbing doctor up, and dolefully walk away from its blood-soaked roots.
Follow the same military protocol as if you were under grenadiers' fire

"I've witnessed more grenade injuries than I'd like to remember; this is no different". A grizzly sailor comes forward and pushes the injured doctor aside. "We can't repair the damage, but we may be able to contain it long enough to get him to a clinic." He ties a firm knot around the critical areas and tightly braces the wounded man with cloth and bandages to prevent any potential haemorrhages. It is not perfect, and the man's howls clearly state that it is in no way painless, but he survives long enough to be treated at the nearest village.

If the crew were truly under enemy fire, they would all perish. Not one voice is heard above the heated discussion. "Getting away from danger is the priority, just help him up!", "He'll bleed out!", "Just swathe him together and let's get out of here!". Unable to reach an agreement, and with the explosive fruit dangling above their heads, a grizzly sailor decides to take matters into his own hands — quite literally. "Better out than in!", he grunts, as he dips his bare fingers into the man's open wounds and pulls out the gory pieces before the horrified gaze of the doctor. But it's too late to stop him — there's a ripping sound, then a gurgle, and blood starts gushing out the man's mouth. Nothing can be done to stop the bleeding, and the dreadful scene is over within a minute.
Fashion a stretcher to move him safely

An easy feat for your handy crew. They get to work immediately, and — in the blink of an eye — two long branches, two coats and a symmetrical tangle of knots become a rock-solid stretcher. The wounded man is carefully removed from under the grenade-bearing canopy and carried back to the ship, where the surgeon is able to safely extract every piece of timber shrapnel.

Stress only serves to highlight your crew's lack of skill. Eager to get away from the lethal tree's canopy as fast as possible, they hastily tie two branches together and call it a stretcher. The precarious device barely holds the weight of the wounded man, and it collapses almost immediately. The man hits the floor with a thud, and his howl of pain forecast the worst: a fragment has pierced his liver. The man writhes in a feverish agony for days, before drawing his last breath.
La Manzanilla de la Muerte

An officer has taken a bite out of a fragrant, but deadly fruit. By the time your guide alerts the crew to "stay away from la manzanilla de la muerte", its sweet taste has already been rapidly followed by a peppery tingle, then an excruciating burn. Soon, the officer is frantically gasping for breath, his throat and tongue having tripled in size.
Puncture an airway

The crew are hypnotised by your doctor's precision. Without wasting a single second, she lays the officer in the sand, commands two men to pin him down, feels her patient's Adam's apple and makes one steady incision. She then inserts the handle of the scalpel and rotates it to open the new orifice up. The sudden suction sound as air rushes back into the officer's lungs triggers a communal sigh of relief. The whole crew can finally resume breathing.

The crew stir before the grisly scene. The panicked doctor — who's clearly never attempted such a procedure before — stabs the officer in the throat with her knife in an attempt to poke a hole for him to breathe through. Instead, the patient's blood spurts out onto her face. Her piercing shriek makes the whole crew shudder. The man falls to his knees and bleeds to death within seconds.
Calm the officer and steady his breathing

Your diplomat's voice soothes everyone around him. He firmly grasps the officer by the shoulders and helps him lie down on his side. He gently instructs the officer to picture a toy horse, rocking softly back and forth with his every breath. Now that the man is not panicking, a small stream of air finds its way through his swollen windpipe — but urgent treatment is required to remove the toxins from his body before it causes more damage.
Perform a stomach pumping

Before receiving the command, your doctor was already preparing to treat the officer. She had clean warm water, ready to be pumped into — and back out of — her patient's stomach through a rubber tube she'd expertly passed through the tiny gap left in his swollen pharynx. The gastric lavage is successful, and the officer's windpipe slowly clears out. It isn't until he's out of danger that the whole crew realises everyone had been holding their breath.

'Negligent' falls short of describing your doctor. In an attempt to purge the poisonous fruit from the man's stomach, she pours seawater into the poor officer's mouth. Not only does he howl in pain the second salt touches his inflamed throat, but the seawater makes him heave and choke on his blocked airway. The officer convulses and gurgles for five very long minutes, before he stops twitching altogether.
Make powdered charcoal to clean the toxins

You master crafter conducts every crew member as a perfectly synchronised orchestra. "Not just any charcoal will do — it needs to burn at a very high temperature, and we don't have much time!" An airtight clay oven is set up and smoking in the blink of an eye. Not an hour has passed before the powdered charred coconut shells are being fed to the agonising officer, cleansing his body of every toxin.

Your crew's ineptitude proves fatal. Even though the doctor insists that the charcoal must have been burnt at a very high temperature for it to absorb the poison from the body, all they can think of is setting up a bonfire and charring some driftwood. After making the officer snort the hastily powdered coals, the patient starts bleeding profusely out of his mouth and nose, choking and writhing in agony. There is nothing your crew can do for the man but put him out of the misery they aggravated.

Every word that blurts out of your first mate's mouth makes the man fret more violently. Your crew members can but watch, helpless and distraught, as the agonising officer's lips turn purple, then blue, while the first mate continues to screech at him to "just calm down and breathe in". The look of panic in the man's eyes pierces the souls of every man and woman present just before he falls unconscious. Nothing can be done for him.
The Inspector

'I do hope you've nothing to hide?' smirks the Royal Inspector, as his soldiers help him aboard from the row boat. Sailors twitch. Your ship is certain to contravene her majesty's law, since it has encroached into demilitarised waters.
Quickly forge an official document

'Very good', grimaces the Royal Inspector, scarcely concealing his displeasure at having to let you off the hook. His remonstrations with his soldiers as he wobbles aboard the row boat are a great source of amusement for the crew in days to come.
Threaten him and his soldiers

The Inspector's lip wobbles. 'I beg you,' he says, 'I have a gift, if only you will spare us.' Sure enough, the gift is brought aboard as promised. But it is only once the Inspector and his soldiers are gone, that it feels safe enough to inspect the new acquisition.

The Inspector's face pales as he eyes the tigerish crew. He bows, and takes a half-step backward - a signal for his soldiers to disembark with him. Once gone, the crew breathe a great sigh of relief, knowing it to have been a close shave.
'This is far from over!' the Inspector snarls as he evacuates his men to the row boat. Sure enough, back aboard the royal clipper, he is seen making preparations to attack.
Set sail and try to outrun them
Slippery as an eel, steady navigation keeps your ship on the windward side, just out of the Inspector's clutches. After a tense pursuit he is forced to give up, to the crew's great relief.
Though the ungainly clipper is outmanoeuvred, the expedition is now many miles off course, and your ship's exhausted navigators must summon all their remaining stamina to get things back on track.

It's upsetting that the Inspector's clipper is near out of sight, when a hopeful last shot finds its mark, crashing in the main deck of your ship, and killing a luckless sailor. Despite having escaped, the crew are rattled by such ill luck.
Complete confusion among the navigators makes your ship a sitting duck, and the Inspector's clipper gleefully riddles it with cannonfire. Many die or are wounded, and the ship is left in shreds.
Sink the toad!

The last they expect is a quick counter. Surprised and windless, they're an easy mark. Your cannons flog the Inspector's clipper without reply, and before long, it is bubbling to the depths. The relieved crew scout the flotsam for spoils.

Though the royal clipper has it worse, it also deals significant damage to your ship in the chaotic exchange. With casualties and repairs on both sides, the ships agree to part, so that they may lick their wounds.

The speed and power of the royal clipper is impossible to match despite best efforts. Your ship takes significant damage, and a young sailor is killed by shrapnel. Retreat is the only option. Mercifully the Inspector chooses not to make pursuit.

The superior clipper chews through your ship with its dread bank of cannons - the ruthless Inspector intent on bringing traitors to their knees. 'We surrender!' the crew cry, but the plea falls on deaf ears. Once he has shredded the ship to bits, the smug Inspector turns his clipper about, and disappears into the distance.

There is a commotion and the Inspector's soldiers are already among the crew. Being exceptionally well-drilled, they quickly force the crew to drop their weapons. 'Now,' says the Inspector, 'if you are quite finished, I'd like to continue my inspection of your vessel!'
Allow him to inspect the ship

'Though this appears to be a trade vessel,' the Inspector says, 'Combat was a consideration when these sails were fashioned - unacceptable in Her Majesty's seas. Unless…' he winks grotesquely, '...we can come to some arrangement?'
Trade with the Inspector (Bribe)
'Load these crates aboard the clipper! What are you waiting for?' he huffs to his men. When they are done, he smirks and offers the merest of bows, before sailing away with the plunder.
Take consequences

'You will remain here until they are dismantled...' trills the Inspector, '...those perverse modifications to your sails contravening sovereign law of the sea.' As the nit-picking Inspector leaves, it is clear an arduous refit is needed before your expedition will be allowed to continue.

'This is obviously a military vessel,' the Inspector says, 'in sovereign sea subject to the amnesty.' He toys with the gold button of his greatcoat. 'There will be severe consequences, unless... I hope you don't intend to offer me a bribe?'
Trade with the Inspector (Bribe)
Take consequences

'I don't know what you were thinking, bringing an armed ship into these peaceful waters,' he says, 'but I take great pleasure in imposing upon you. the longest possible route around.' Once the Inspector has gone, the crew look to one another in dismay.

A disastrous melee ensues, in which the crew do not acquit themselves well. Some are skewered, the rest disarmed. The Inspector calls three captive sailors forward. 'Hang these men,' he says, and they are promptly strung from a beam until dead. Your ship, he decrees, must leave sovereign waters and take the long way round.

A disastrous melee ensues, in which the crew do not acquit themselves well. Some are skewered, the rest disarmed. The Inspector picks out the captive specialist. 'Hang this traitor,' he says, and promptly strings them from a beam until dead. Your ship, he decrees, must leave sovereign waters and take the long way round.
Talk him out of the inspection

"Rather excellent company", says the Inspector over a glass of port, "I've been dying for something to break the tedium of the sea." Surprising even his own soldiers, the Inspector demands a gift be brought over from the clipper to mark the occasion. Of course, when he finally leaves, the crew collapse about in relief.

'Very well,' says the Inspector, after being given the first mate's 'special tour' of nothing in particular. He silently surveys the vessel for a torturous moment, before declaring 'it all seems above board.' Of course, as soon as he and his soldiers have disembarked, the crew of your ship collapse about in grievous relief.
'Save your breath, windbag,' says the Inspector, with an air of a man accustomed to weaselling. 'Show me the damn ship, or I shall become vexed!'

'You've talked yourself into very serious trouble,' the Inspector sneers, pointing to three unlucky sailors. 'Hang them,' he says, and they are promptly strung from a beam until dead. Your ship, he decrees, must leave sovereign waters and take the long way round.

'You've talked yourself into very serious trouble,' the Inspector sneers, and points at your specialist. 'Hang this traitor,' he says, and promptly strings them from a beam until dead. Your ship, he decrees, must leave sovereign waters and take the long way round.
The Trial

The crew face the bloody customs of foreign lands. After a night of feasting, the sailors believe that meeting the foreign prince and his sea-travelling court is the highlight of their trip. However, morning comes with news of a sudden death among the court, as your crew find themselves immediately accused of murder. The prince demands a trial by combat, and your men are left with little freedom but the choice of the challenge's nature.
Send your strongest fighter for a brawl

What could a lord do against a sea-forged champion? The prince's warrior is nothing more than a scarecrow in shiny armor, and your own cotton-clad fighter scoffs at his tacky opponent. The walking wardrobe is tripped, grabbed, and thrown overboard in a single movement. As per foreign laws, your crew receives compensation and their name is cleared.

No word is brutal enough to describe your opponent. If his plate armor is scaled to match the man inside, then that man is a giant. The human mountain reaches to grab your fighter and crushes his skull like he would an apple. Word of your crew's feebleness and alleged crimes is sent for all cities to know and spread.
Send your best shot for a pistol duel

Your gunslinger shoots faster than his own shadow. His opponent drops to the ground before anyone can see or even understand that a gun has been fired, and only the banging sound and fuming barrel testify to the attack. The prince wonders how lucky your sharpshooter is, then reluctantly graces the crew and presents them with compensation for his offence.

Speed is not in your gunslinger's vocabulary. The prince's duelist, displaying the look of men who fill graves but never dig them, is the sharpest shooter your sailors have ever seen. Your best shot is dead before he even touches the handle of his gun. Judging his passing to be too low a price, the prince randomly selects men among your crew and has them hanged for good measure.
Send your brightest officer for a trial of wits

The foreigners are drawn in by your officer's pace. He inspects the body, noticing knife cuts of varying depths and bleeding. Through methodical questioning, the officer presses the foreigners and reveals the deception: each wound was made by a different hand, the victim was killed by all of them! The prince buys the sailors' silence and they leave wondering what could have motivated the curious murder.

A mute would have pleaded better. The officer engages in a battle of arguments with the prince's vizier, and each of his meager claims are met with factual evidence of their contrary. The prince cuts the exchange with exasperation and has the officer taken to be quartered till torn apart as a final judgement for the supposed crime. No scream ever matches the ones heard that day.
Tavern Troubles

These hoodlums are asking for it. To each harbour its own ill-famed tavern, and this one is no exception. While your crew enjoys a beer at the counter, the tavern's door slams open, the bartender stiffens and the volume of conversations dwindles: the newcomers are regulars of the bad kind. One of the scruffy men elbows your doctor and gasps as the alcohol splashes on his unkempt clothes. He immediately grabs your sailor by the collar, and demands an apology.
They want to fight? Let them come!

Your crew crushes them. The collar-grabbed doctor slaps away the hand of the hoodlum, seizes his sleeve and pulls him over his shoulder, sending him crashing into a table. With a roar, the other thugs pounce on your sailors, who greet them with jabs to the chin and sternum, downing the attackers with no more than two hits per man - the seconds for the pleasure of good fighting form. The tavern applauds the action, and the bartender offers a round to celebrate a well deserved beating.

The crew overestimated themselves. As he calls for the other sailors to help, the doctor gets his head smashed into the counter. His crewmates scream for revenge, and look like toddlers agitating their little arms to try and hit the big bad guys. The thugs are not in the mood to play along, and one of them stabs a bawling sailor in the liver to make them shut up. They slowly die as the thugs depart, leaving the tavern in a stupor.
Offer them a drink to ease the tension

The language of alcohol is universal. The thugs take you up on your offer, and eye the sailors' purses as they pass the money around to pay for the beers. As the first round arrives, one of the hoodlums speaks up and announces that they will have a drinking contest with the crew. The idea is one-sided, and weirdly different from their previous aggressive attitude.
Show them the drinking ability of seafarers

They call that cat piss strong? There's no question regarding who wins the drinking contest: your crew are still standing and enjoying the beers long after the thugs have hit the ground, curled into whatever their stomach rejected. The pungent smell of vomit and cheap ale does not deter the sailors, who casually finish their steins, pay for them, and drag the hoodlums to the closest man of law.

What kind of liquid fire do they make this with? The crew are used to strong drinks and exotic ales, but the tavern's special mixture of bourbon, sugar and Ricard is way past what they can handle. The thugs are accustomed to this local horror and barely wobble, while your sailors pass out one after the other. When they wake up, obviously, their purses are missing.
Drug their drinks to avoid the confrontation

War anaesthetics are remarkably useful against small-time thugs. After a few rounds spent boasting their virile resistance to any kind of liquor, the crew notice the drop in attention of their opponents, and their doctor seizes the opportunity, lacing the incoming mugs with just the right dosage of chloroform. The snoring hoodlums are delivered to the local authorities, who enjoy the unexpected present.

The dosage doesn't put the thugs to sleep: it kills them. The doctor sidles among the thugs, lacing their drinks and snickering in expectation. Soon the effects appear: the gang shows drowsiness, then nausea, before losing control of their movements and tumbling against the counter, their faces taking on a waxy yellow color. The crew can do nothing as the hoodlums break into seizures and foam at the mouth. They win the drinking contest by default, as murderers of their opponents.

Bribing them with alcohol doesn't seem to work. Your crew invites the men to sit and share a beer, on them, to try and bring the tension down. The thug doesn't let go of the doctor, and points at the aligned liquors behind the bartender. A glass of all of these, he says, and a bottle of your best whatever. That's way more than they can drink - and way more than your sailors can afford.
If it's a fight they want, they'll get one
Pay up

The crew are humiliated. They empty their purses trying to pay for the excessive demands of the thugs. Ale. Stew. Liquors. Meats. When sunrise pushes the hoodlums to leave the tavern, the sailors are stuck with cooking, dishwashing and dust-wiping until the bartender considers their debt paid.
This is a waste of time - simply apologise

Your sailors apologise through gritted teeth. Pleased by their groveling, the thugs don't pester them anymore, yet the heavy stares of the other clients push your crew to leave the tavern. Next time, they'll show them. Next time.
Snow Globe

Sails frozen, food rotten, and a ship on the brink of breaking. It's a blizzard! All notion of time and direction has long been lost: a never-ending tempest of snow surrounds the ship, blurring the limits between night and day, or sky and sea. Stalactites have imprisoned your sails, binding them to the masts and making them creak under the unexpected weight. Your crew fear they might break, but should anyone venture outside while violent winds whip the upper deck?
Climb the mast and detach the frozen sails

The ship can safely withstand the blizzard. Several sailors of impressive build climb your masts to unhook and detach the heavy sails, and despite the slippery wood and tightly frozen ropes, they manage to free the masts of the dangerous weight. The barren poles stand tall against the receding storm. Morning light soon pierces the clouds - a good omen to salute your crew's efforts, and accompany their celebration.

The task is far from easy. Your sailors have good strength, and are used to climbing the masts, but they lack either luck or skill when it comes to speed. Before they can reach the foremast, the foresail breaks out of its bounds and flaps wildly against the weakened mast, while the other sails continue to foster stalactites of increasing length and weight. The foremast emits a shrilling sound of protest.
Aim at the ties holding the rogue sail

The rogue sail is taken down! Precise shots take out its ties without so much as scratching the foremast, and the sail is sent to disappear into the storm. The lack of the sail's furious whipping seems to be enough for the mast to hold its ground. When the blizzard recedes, your ship is lacking a sail, but nothing more.

Alas, your mast is not spared. Your sailors shoot at the ties of the foresail, but the task is too meticulous for them: they shoot at the ropes, the poles, and the mast itself. The raging sail is swallowed by the storm, while the foremast collapses and crushes the starboard. In a final irony, the storm soon calms down, letting your crew see how a lack of meddling would have caused less damage.
Fire all guns and shake off the ice

The stalactites are dealt with. In a bold act of defiance towards logic and prudence, your artillery men fire their cannons to send precisely gauged vibrations throughout your ship. The foremast protests but resists, while the pikes of ice parasitising its sails break and rain on the deck in a cacophony of tingling sounds. Your maimed ship has but to wait for the blizzard to run out of breath now.

Reckless, and proportionately paid. Gauging the difference between power which might break the stalactites only, and power which might also break the mast is beyond the understanding of most humans, your artillery men included. The tremor of the cannons shakes the whole ship, provoking the crashing fall of the foremast. Ironically, the blizzard reacts by calming down, leaving the sailors to their broken ship.

A resounding failure. Your sailors clearly don't have the ability to climb the masts, whether in this storm or in clear weather - how could they even be allowed on a ship? As they bicker over their deficiency, the main mast beckons their attention: its base is entirely frozen, and the wood screams against the invading cold.
Strengthen the mast with chains and planks

A straightforward, if rough solution. Planks and poles are erected around the masts, and bound by ropes and chains in the hope that the swaying barricade will prevent the masts from breaking. Despite its movement, the construction is sturdy, and actually accompanies the masts as they move in the wind, giving them a welcome support. When the blizzard leaves, your ship is plucked naked, but its masts still stand.

The trigger of catastrophy. Your sailors tie planks and poles around the masts, pulling chains around them as tightly as they can, oblivious to the carpentry laws that apply to the movement of towering objects. The masts try to break free of their man-made prisons, and soon do, crashing onto the deck one after the other. As if chased by the hysteria below, the blizzard flees, lettings its sunrays fall on the barren carcass of your ship.
Boil seawater to gather ice-melting salt

Somehow, it works. Your sailors take the time to slowly distil seawater in order to avoid improper condensation. The salt is acquired faster than anticipated, and spread over the base of the main mast, forcing the ice back to its liquid form. The blizzard keeps filling the sails until it runs out of breath and recedes, but the furious weather was enough to greatly maim the ship. There will be extensive repairs.

There was no chance of success. To gather salt, your sailors keep away from the wind and bury below the deck to light a fire under a pot of seawater. Their condenser is poorly handled, and causes the water to fall back into the pot, leaving the crew to believe the fire isn't burning hard enough. They fan the flames. Hell rises. The blizzard is fed gusts of murky smoke, and spits it back out before receding, revealing the half-burnt carcass of your ship.
Stay inside and hope the supplies last

Prudence and faith pay off. Your sailors huddle together in the lower deck, resisting the temptation to go check the masts and their frozen sails. Time trickles away as the storm recedes, and when the blizzard is no more than a light drizzle, the sun emerges to illuminate your ship. It's perfectly unscathed, and slowly drifts towards the coast, where a harbour is already in sight.

Your sailors' feeble trust is not enough to fuel their patience. The storm lingers, and with each new gust of raging wind the main mast complains and moans, until the distinct sounds of breaking wood resonate through the ship. That's enough waiting! Several sailors rush to the upper deck in the hope of either strengthening or defrosting the mast.
Protect the steamship in any way you can

You have a hardy legion indeed. They rush to the tarpaulins, and with commendable teamwork and physical strength in the challenging conditions, are able to pull them over the ship's most sensitive instruments and machinery. Heading below deck to relax, the heroes wait out the storm in luxury with buttered currant buns and hot tea.

Their defence of the steamship is a little half-hearted. Initially the men show willing, but the blizzard quickly wears them down, and they retreat inside claiming that their work is done. After the worst of it has passed, the officers survey the ship. Beneath a poorly affixed and feeble tarpaulin, the engine is found to have suffered damage, albeit fixable. One has to wonder if they are cut out for these kinds of challenges.

Tragic youthful over-exuberance. Your sailors drain a bottle of strong rum before going back out, perhaps believing machismo will keep them warm. They batten the hatches in the white flurry, stumbling, belching and laughing. The hilarity continues when one of the lads slips and loses his footing — that is, until the steel rim of the funnel meets his head with a clomp. He dies instantly.
Send an expert diver to unclog the propellers of ice

The thrill-seeking diver relishes the task. Covering themselves in bear fat and brandishing a sharp pick, they enter the water without a splash, resurfacing no more than five minutes later to the embrace of a pre-warmed towel. "All clear!" your diver says. Cheers go up below at the sound of the engines at full power once more.
At The End Of A Rope

A perilous plunge! Your expedition is walking along a narrow ridge in the rainforest interior, when they become entranced by the scintillating blue of 'Le Cotinga des Mezoas'. Perhaps it is the distraction of looking up at the extraordinary bird that causes someone to misstep. They fall suddenly through the floor, and tumble into fresh air, only an elastic tangle of vines sparing them the drop. The problem now is that they're suspended above a ravine, and it's a long way down...
Shout down, "Slash with your sabre!"

It's a sword-swishing masterclass! Your champion contorts to cut the liana above their right arm, and once free, cuts one daringly close to their neck, so that with a trapeze-like ripple they may dismount to the floor of the ravine. "Simple!" they declaim, straightening up, "Follow me if you dare!" There are hoots and cheers from the gallery above as the rest swing down on lianas, like an army of spider monkeys.

A very lucky escape. Trying to be cautious, your soldier makes a cut in one of the vines. The harness suddenly lurches down a further ten feet. Still, it seems a long way down. Another cut, and they are in freefall towards the bottom of the gully. Though cushioned somewhat the impact causes a nasty ankle injury.

You have lost one of your bravest.The first cut is wild, and sends them into a second tumble: there are gasps from above as your soldier clutches desperately at the foliage, but try as they might, they are unable to find anything to grip. The poor soldier pinwheels to the very bottom of the ravine.
Call down, "Unpick the knot!"

It turns out to be an enjoyable puzzle. The knot is examined in tense silence, until the light of revelation falls across their face. A tug here, a loosening there, and then voila! A slipknot forms that allows a breezy absail to the foot of the gorge. Your escapalogist bows to the exultant gallery.

An infuriating tangle — by the expression of your trapped expeditioner at least. Every tug seems to tighten the gordian knot further. "Just cut it at the root!" they shout up. "Are you sure?" "Absolutely." When the lianas are cut, there are mere seconds of freefall before the impact. Though slightly cushioned — like a fork wrapped in spaghetti verdi — the drop results in a nasty back injury.

A deadly conundrum. The unfortunate victim tries pulling at different strands until one has an effect. The tangle of vegetation falls away but for a loop around the neck, which closes after only a few seconds of freefall, resulting in instant death.
For Whom The Bell Atolls

Your ship is pinned on the razor-sharp coral that fringes an underwater volcano. Since she has rolled onto her side, freeing your ship will require surgical precision if you're to prevent gallons of water from flooding in. If you do not wish to send a team of divers to cut the ship free, you may instead be able to make or use something clever to break free.
Use your diving bell

The bell rings true. Despite plonking into the water at an angle to which it is unaccustomed — the ship being at such a slant — the diving bell descends easily to the scene of your troubles. Through the little glass window, a forest of living pastel appears, of which some of the more beautiful examples are embedded in the hull. Once your divers have detached the lifelinks constraining your vessel, your crew are free to resume what is becoming a fascinating journey.
Send free divers down to remove the coral

Your divers take to the sea like fish to water, having had some dive training with the navy. Still, the others worry when five or six pass, and they still have yet to surface. Suddenly the boat begins to wobble — they've been cut free! Soon after, your heroes emerge from the water giddy and glistening, brandishing the magnificent coral in their hands.

They can barely hold their breath for long enough to reach the coral floor, and as such, they're forced to cut the ship free in relays. Error creeps in to their work along with feelings of lightheadedness, and one of the divers slices his foot open on a shank of coral. Everyone is too absorbed in their task to notice, but once the ship is free and back at sea, the pustulent swelling of the man's foot becomes increasingly difficult to ignore...
Tend to the diver's foot

Although your medic does take immediate action, vigorously scrubbing the wound and flushing with fresh water and vinegar, the coral cut takes a surprisingly long time to properly heal. "Will I die? Is this the end?" the injured officer complains, as if an invalid to be waited on hand and foot. Thankfully, eventually the swelling reduces, and everyone can get on with their lives.

Someone puts bandages around the wounds in a haphazard fashion, as if they were mere scratches. "Change the bandages every few days" is the advice, but the abscess that has formed beneath soon bursts, and the vile infection spreads. The man dies in his sleep. For the others, their negligence will forever remain a source of great shame — for no man is an island, and the death of one man diminishes the whole.
Tell him to grin and bear it.

The diver develops a fever. The abscess does not disappear, and a nasty infection spreads up the arm causing it to become swollen. He will be of no use on the ship for the remainder of the expedition, instead serving only as an unpleasant reminder of the officers' inhuman disregard for the welfare of their crew.

It is clumsy. Out of breath and struggling weakly against a strong current, your divers bludgeon blindly at the coral, sending clouds of particles up through the water. Little do they realise how fragile the hull has become. With one misplaced blow, it implodes, and the water comes gushing in. The crew must count themselves lucky that the tide proceeds to sweep the unhappy vessel to the shore. It seems you have shipwrecked on a coral atoll.
Find a cunning way to free the ship

Your ship looks a sensation now she has coral poking from her keel. Like doctors treating a foreign object, your fine craftsmen utilise a panoply of tools to reach under the hull and fragment the coral. They are then nimbly able to dress the wound in the hull before very much water gets in. The few naughty pieces of coral that remain wedged in the keel look rather fetching!

They use a lot of spare materials, but it works. Fighting against the slant of the ship, they are able to fragment the coral with a long pole they have constructed out of wood and rope. It is extremely heavy, however, and as the ship judders free, your men cannot stop it from sliding into the sea. It feels like a waste, and there's only just enough wood left to repair the breach in the hull.

There is a lot of head-scratching below deck, as your confused carpenters try to fight the flood. They have neither the tools nor creativity to do much more than smash the coral that has ripped through the ship. When the vessel judders free, it has almost no buoyancy, and the crew count themselves lucky when the lumbering ship is swept ashore on the tide. It seems you have shipwrecked on a coral atoll.
Send in your specialist diver

Your diver takes to the sea like a fish to water, having ample experience. Still, the others worry when after five or six minutes, he still has yet to surface. Suddenly, the boat begins to wobble — it has been cut free! Soon after, your hero emerges from the water giddy and glistening — and brandishing some magnificent coral in their hands.

The accident with the coral reef as left the expedition shipwrecked on an atoll. For a time your crew feel like children again — dancing along the sand and bathing in the sun, as they await a verdict on the damaged hull. When it comes, the news is not good: an extensive repair is needed, and with supplies so short, there is considerable disagreement. Why concentrate on repairs, given how long that may take, when you could scout for food and water.
The Coral Island
The Minefield

At the cry of 'mines!', all rush to the prow. Sure enough, several of the conical terrors bob seductively below. 'Who knows how many of these infernal machines have passed us by, or yet await us. A false move, and this sea shall be a lake of fire! What the devil do we do?'
Use dynamite to start a chain reaction

'The way ahead is clear as the eye can see!' says the delighted officer, folding up his telescope. As the last motes of fire trail down into the waves and fizzle, the crew can but admire such brave use of dynamite. 'Better than fireworks!' says another, 'The men have never been so entertained!'
Try to navigate the minefield

'We are masters of the sea!' sing the triumphant crew, as the ship weaves easily beyond the last line of mines. 'Even Odysseus, when faced with Scylla and Charybdis, lost men. We have lost none of our company, and our bonds only strengthen!' Soon, a special bottle is being uncorked, and toasts raised to the continued success of the expedition!

'What was that noise?' gulps the helmsman, but fortunately a metallic scraping is not the prelude to a mighty boom. As the ship is fitfully steered betwixt the mines, hearts palpitate, and sailors wring sweat from their jerseys. When the all clear is finally given, there is not a sailor who fails to offer up a prayer to their goddess.

While at first plain sailing, the minefield is now gooey with danger. A line of densely-packed mines stand between the ship and freedom. "With a makeshift device, we might be able to clear the path ahead," explains the officer, "either that, or we just try our best to weave through it."
Build a device

'She survived! It worked!' calls the lookout, as makeshift grapples trailing behind the little dinghy are able to hook the mines aside. Relief only comes, of course, once the expedition ship is clear of this last line of mines. 'How did we get in such a pickle?' says one. 'At least we're out of it,' says another.

A nervous sailor rows towards the line of mines. The makeshift grappling hooks trailing behind his dinghy are intended to drag mines out of the path of the expedition ship. Unfortunately the sailor is a sacrificial goat. A grapple shatters the horns of a nearby mine, and the boat and its sailor explode in plume. Safe passage means nothing to those from whom a good friend was taken.

The idea is a terrible one from the start. The lengthy poles, comprised of other poles, are unwieldy and inaccurate, even in the hands of a several strong men. The crew's attempt to poke mines away when they draw near is suicide. Two booms come in succession, and a few feeble cheers at escape are drowned by the deafening wails. Few are left to bail water, when so many lie dead or injured.
Try to weave through the minefield

"What was that noise?" gulps the helmsman, but fortunately a metallic scraping is not the prelude to a mighty boom. As the ship is fitfully steered betwixt the mines, hearts palpitate, and sailors wring sweat from their jerseys. When the all clear is finally given, there is not a sailor who fails to offer up a prayer to their goddess.

The awfulness has barely begun. Restless waves conceal a thickening of the mines, and the ship's haphazard path makes impact inevitable. "Brace!" comes a scream from port-side, just prior to a shower of men and timber being propelled violently upward. That no further detonations follow is of little relief to a crew who've lost a good many sailors, and sustained such significant damage to their ship.

The awfulness has barely begun. Restless waves conceal a thickening of the mines, and the ship's haphazard path makes impact inevitable. 'Brace!' scream port-side, just prior to a portion of men and timber being propelled violently upward. That no further detonations follow is of little relief to a crew who have lost many good sailors, and sustained such significant damage to their ship.
Go through diplomatic papers in search of any clues

The search is a fruitful one. The well-organised diplomatic library includes a comprehensive folio of papers on nearby mine positions. This enables the navigators to chart a safe course through the waters. The very same paper remarks that the mines were moored during the war, in order to protect a now-disused outpost. You stop by the outpost and pick up anything that looks useful.

The search is worthwhile. After a few hours scouring the diplomatic archives, a paper on nearby mine positions is found. This gives the navigators the difficult task of charting a safe course through the waters. No-one is quite sure if the information given is up-to-the-minute, but when the last line of mines is cleared, all are suitably relieved.

The documents in the ship archives at first seem exact. A map is discovered showing the mine positions. It is only once a course has been plotted, and your ship is sailing at speed on its supposedly safe track, that a magnificent bang has the whole crew scrambling. The speed seemed to soften the mine's devastation, but there is still a nasty hole in the hull. A second glance at the map shows it is rather out-of-date. The reckless blunder has cost no lives, but the significant task of repair greatly wearies the crew.

Optimism makes way for abject terror, as the map of mines that is found and used for navigation turns out to be completely false. Terrible detonations devastate the ship's timbers, and countless lives are lost. 'Misinformation is worse than no information,' an officer laments, as his tears bleed the ink of the erroneous chart, which as it happens, refers to a different stretch of water.
Turn around and try to escape
A few saintly volunteers approach, offering to scout back the way you came and ease your escape. Asked if they aren't afraid of the cone-shaped mines, they reply 'The lord will see us through.'
Allow them to go ahead

The volunteers exude calm, as their lone dinghy traces a path much akin to that which got you into this mess. Although their silent vigil transports you to safety, all agree they should never have ended up in a minefield in the first place.

While the path the volunteers cut is a true one, it does not account for the difference in size between the two ships. It only takes a narrow graze to explode one of the mines, and though no lives are lost, the damage to your ship is significant. The crew are dismayed by the situation.

For the godless dinghy, doom seems inevitable the moment it drops and a man slops overboard. This inauspicious beginning foreshadows the disaster to follow. Prayers unheard, steering in the rough current proves impossible. The little boat is last seen careening towards the sinister cones it sought to avoid. 'The terrible loss of life shall remain with me all my days,' says a devastated officer.

It is horrifying that most significant members of the crew are aboard this fragile dinghy. Of course one would not wish a mine to explode any loyal man, but when it bellows up below a collection of your finest, death stings all the more. The crew are understandably devastated at the destruction they have witnessed first-hand. Life feels as if it may never be the same again.
Tell them to stay on the ship
Your faith goes untried in the nervous silence, as the ship escapes the mine trap the same way it entered. All agree they should never have ended up in a minefield in the first place.

Your faith does not go untried. The sinister cones have moved about over time, and no matter how truly the ship follows its original course, it is inevitable a mine will burst into the hull. Luckily when the blast comes, no man dies. Still, the burdensome schedule of repair disheartens the crew.

None of it is of any use. Your godforsaken crew do not realise how the sinister cones move about over time. No matter how true the course, more than one mine shakes the ship's belly as it limps clear. Many lives are lost, and the damage to the ship is severe.
Lost in the Desert

The map of these endless dunes is a swindle. The first officer turns to berate the guide from whom they were purchased, but the fellow is already gone, as if the sands had swallowed him up. A solitary well offers a slight dribble of consolation, but your men must otherwise come to terms with being rather lost.
Use a reflective object to signal help

A local rider comes to the rescue. He saunters over on his camel, and explains the well is part of a lost city, accessible over a small rise. The crew are enchanted by the grand quarry, swept over by the sands of time, observations of which shall no doubt bring them fame on their return. After proof of their remarkable discovery has been gathered, the rider is only too glad to lead the elated crew back to more familiar dunes.
Navigate by the stars

Clear desert nights are perfect for astronomers. Beneath a black cloak lucid with the constellations, your expert navigators school the remainder in mankind's relation to the heavenly bodies. It is a moment of realisation for many. Enlightened, the crew return to the ship filled with the wonder of the desert and their place in the universe.

Something of a path appears, though as much by luck as star-gazing. A little way along it, a silhouette crenellates the night - an imposing fortress. Too tired for trouble, you wonder if it is worth knocking at the grand door.
Ask at the fort for help

The occupant Sultan welcomes you in. He introduces himself in his own tongue, and is impressed by your interpreters. "You are far from what you seek. Stay, replenish for the journey ahead." Thus the crew enjoy the Sultan's hospitality while they can, for it will ease the last stretch of their journey.

You lack the means to communicate. Believing you to be an invasion force, the paranoid Sultan orders hot oil be poured from the ramparts. There is no escaping for one, eaten alive by the molten cascade. Resuming your desert path is the only option. The journey is a wearying lament for a fallen friend, meandering slowly back to civilisation.
Ignore the fort and continue along the path

It is a long and draining journey. Finally the crew limp exhausted into a settlement, from where it will no doubt be possible to procure the appropriate charts. Most would be happy never to see those grumpy old camels ever again.
The "stars are fickle", say your officers by way of excuse. After travelling for a while, the familiar shape of the well appears in the darkness. Your men have been walking in a circle.

The stars utterly perplex your party. With romantic notions dashed, the crew look around for some landmark, but instead find a featureless wasteland. They are desperately lost. Water, food and hope are in increasingly short supply. But even in a desert, there must be a way...
Follow the local wildlife

Desperate thanks are due to a dung beetle. As it scuttles along, those less capable in coleopterology cast doubt on the value of pursuing it. There is a minor scuffle in the sand before at last the bloody-nosed experts are listened to. The jolly beetle leads to owl dung, and owls in turn to farmland. Thus the embittered and exhausted crew are saved from desiccation.

A wild goose chase to desolation. Though the ostrich your crew have found cannot fly, it lollops along at surprisingly high speed. They try in vain to follow, but the sun is twice its usual size, and the bird is gone. Hot sand melts soles, and feet begin to swell. The water is out. Those that make it must have some evolutionary adaptation, because for most the desert is to be their graveyard.
Divine for Water
Your reprobates have no knowledge of desert mysteries. The divining rod has wasted enough of your time, and your caravan is nearly through the water.

A pretty price for divine mercy. The Y-shaped stick leads all on a meandering path. One insists on stopping to dig, and is left behind. It is a wasted, and fatal effort. After two days of hardship, the rest stumble over a crest to discover the wide blue sea, their mocking ship upon it.
Move bravely on

The sun is unspeakably hot. As the bedraggled lumber back to civilisation, there are wiltings among them. It is too much for the others to turn their heads. Bodies slumping to ash and dust, lost to the waves of a powder sea.
Wait for a sign of the true path

Star of wonder, star of light! Your wise magi are stirred by an unusually bright celestial body, that is surely a sign! It foretells a spiritual pilgrimage through the desert leading to a Garden of Eden. A grove of flowing streams, orange and incense, where like-minded devotees congregate. Your crew feel blessed, and the expedition can resume with new-found devotion.
Are the gods testing you? You wait and wait but there is not yet a sign.

The omen is a ravaging howl. "Water in the desert?! it's coming from everywhere!" Already up to their necks in strong current, the weak swimmers flounder like ants in a bathtub. Those that do not drown must wait until morning to look upon the aftermath. "A flood from heaven, to punish the wicked," say the survivors, as they trudge back to civilisation.
Walk stubbornly in one direction

You are extremely lucky to survive. The crew whinge and whine the whole way about scattergun strategy. After a day without shade, a fight even breaks out. But sticking to the fixed heading eventually leads, not before time, back to some kind of reality.

Your expedition boils. Further and further it goes, into the desert's incandescent interior. Each soul more and more convinced that redemption is over the next dune. But it is not. Three days later, the party might have felt relief at the sight of a caravan, but instead end up wishing they had died with their comrades.
Scylla and Charybdis

Your crew attempts the crossing of a vicious strait. Like Odysseus along the coasts of Sicily, they see a subsidiary current running counter to the main flow, its strength so wild it brings fish with deformed eyes and luminescent bellies to the surface. What creatures are not swallowed by this whirlpool end up impaled on the shore's nasty teeth.
Avoid the whirlpool and maneuver to dodge the shore

Odysseus didn't have the ability of your navigators. Through a series of tight maneuvers and expert understanding of the furious currents, they drive the ship between the whirlpool and the shore, using the provided momentum to dash ahead. The moment is as brief as it is intense, and the crew rejoice, laughing like children under the cold droplets of crashing waves.

The maneuver is even more complicated than expected. The ship is driven alongside the whirlpool and flirts with the shore, the racket of the water covering the orders shouted by officers. The current speeds up, inexorably pulling the ship towards the reef.
Spin the ship to take the damage on its flank

A frontal crash is avoided, but it is a crash nonetheless. The whole ship protests against the unnatural movement, its rudder straining against the current and its hull complaining loudly against the maneuver until the impact silences it. The repairs are much lighter than they could have been.

Your navigators cannot control the wild ship. The maneuver sends it spinning and it plunges into the reef prow first. If it weren't for the metal cast protecting the vessel, the crew would have been crushed as well. The repairs, which take place both in the swirling waters and on the knife-like rocks, are excruciating.
Bombard the shore in an attempt to slow the ship

Power faces power in a risky but successful attempt. All cannons are fired in the shore's direction, in a surprisingly efficient effort to slow the ship down. The ship lands on the devastated coast and the hull is barely grated by the remains of the broken stone spears.

What did they expect, attacking nature itself? The massive teeth of stone barely tremble under the cannon's fire, and the recoil is a futile strength against the voracious current. The rock jaw catches the ship and grinds the upper deck, sending several sailors to be served as the strait's daily food.

Fear clouds the navigators' readings. Unable to choose between several possible courses which could all end in disaster, they opt for a stunned silence and let the crew maneuver on their own. The ship crashes on the shore in an explosion of metal and wood which sends a dozen men overboard and straight into the rock fangs of the coast. It is more a wreck than a ship which escapes the deadly strait.
Avoid the shore and hope the whirlpool won't suck the ship in

The sailors' fright gives them wings. The crew reacts to each order with unparalleled speed, too occupied to plead the heavens to think of discussing the risky manoeuvres that are asked of them. When at last the whirlpool is passed, their belief that the Almighty might have his eyes on this ship is stronger than ever.

There are only so many disasters faith can prevent. When they understand that the whirlpool is a monster none should face, the sailors fall to their knees to pray and beg, abandoning what meaningless impact they could have had on the ship's trajectory. Like Circe prophesied to Odysseus, the currents attack the ship, the men, and a hero.
The Volcano

Tremors, ash rain, and an oddly bright night: it's an eruption! The island was too lush and bountiful to be harmless. The lava responsible for the fertile ground creeps from the mouth of the waking volcano, and towards the jungle where a party of your men had erected camp for the night.
Go back to the ship despite the darkness.

The ship is quickly found. The burning lights of the volcano illuminate the jungle, and a handful of seasoned explorers lead the rest of the sailors back to the ship, zigzagging between shadows and fleeing animals. The vessel departs as the island is engulfed by flames, a vision as terrible as it is magnificent.

The sailors are swallowed by the jungle's maze. Dense trees, moving shadows, screeching animals and the crew itself, whose silhouettes are deformed by the scorching heat - too many visions allow panic to spread among the men, who cannot recognise the path, and never make it back to the ship.
Find shelter against the incoming lava

Shelter! The crew finds a decrepit stone chapel, the remains of a colonialist power, and deems it better refuge than their cloth-made tents. An officer estimates that the lava will be on them soon: there's no choice but to spend the night here.
Pray for the chapel to hold

The chapel miraculously stands its ground. Lava rolls against its walls and forks around the white stone, melting its paint and parching its plaster. Nestled on the only facade left untouched by the flow, the chapel's wooden door seems like the most fragile object the sailors have ever seen. When day comes, they are safe and elated, and all kiss the blessed door before leaving.

Their faith is nothing but hypocrisy in need. The crew remembers old prayers from their worshipping days, but the years have eroded both their memory and their beliefs. They can only watch as the lava packs against the chapel's stained glass and breaks through. The spray of molten stone and broken glass scars all of them but kills none: a bite to remind them of their lack of dedication.
Dig trenches in the holy ground

The trenches are dug with military efficiency. Despite the darkness and the imminent danger, the sailors manage to dig deep trenches in no time, and the pits redirect the lava as it flows down the hill. The sailors bunker down in the chapel as the lava runs around the outside, illuminating the stained glass, leaving them to rejoice in the warm comfort of their shelter.

Too much pressure and too little grit. The sailors can dig little more than scattered and knee-deep pits, which have a negligible impact on the lava's course. As the crew scurries inside the chapel, so to does the lava, its smoke burning throats and forever robbing the men of their voices.

Your crew are lost and perplexed. Even your most committed explorers cannot wrap their heads around the complexity of the jungle, which changes with every newly burnt tree. It seems that every path might end in lava-devoured dead ends.
Follow a random animal and trust its instincts

The animals run to the beach, and your crew follows. Tracking down the herd of shrill, squealing, screeching critters could be done with eyes closed, and the sailors are led to the shore where they had beached. The ship departs in a hurry, leaving the animals to die in the ruthless volcano fire.

Your hunters find no pattern in the animals' frenzy. The sailors run in a display of panic and poor judgment, mimicking the animals' desperate behavior. The crew still on the ship can only watch in horror as the island's greatest predator burns all its prey, be they beast or human.
Pick a random path and trust your instincts

Fear is the most reliable instinct. The sailors scamper through the jungle, chasing after their lava-lit shadows. They stumble upon the beach by pure miracle, and hop on the ship with molten tongues on their heels. The ship departs with a slightly charred hull, but a safe crew.

Fear is a treacherous adviser. Seeing that the only unburnt path is up, the sailors climb the jungle's trees in an attempt to escape the lava flow. Ground, then bark, then branches, then humans: everything burns. In the distance, the ship's remaining crew stay transfixed as they witness the volcano island devouring itself.
Selfless Deeds

"They steal your children?" The air hangs heavy around the sailors as their question withers in the hut. Their hosts consider the explorers, half-hopeful, half-guilty from the certitude that non-paying jobs are not the ones your crew enjoys. One child has to be offered with each new moon, an elder explains as she gestures towards the nearby river, or else bandits raid the surrounding settlements. Tomorrow, the bandits' steamboat will come to claim this village's due.
Board the bandits' steamer with your gunboat

Your assault is swift, and without a single casualty. The kidnappers offer no resistance, as their carcass of a craft faces your own fresh-from-the-factory gunboat. They reluctantly lead you to their hideout - a sweatshop with no employees other than the stolen kids. Your crew sets the hideout afire, heads back to the village, and returns the children to their exultant parents. Though they can offer no reward but tears and smiles, your crew basks in the warmth of this priceless payment.
Shadow the kidnappers back to their hideout with a river skiff

Your crew navigates through the mangrove with aplomb. The unusual environment doesn't manage to stop their steady rowing, and the sailors soon reach an outpost marking the entrance of the bandits' camp. Sobbing children are taken from the kidnappers' steamboat, and dragged towards a distant barn. Half a dozen armed men guard the building.
Attack the bandits before they reach the barn

The bandits don't know what hit them. Using the element of surprise to their advantage, your sailors break into the camp and stifle the children's escorts before they can call for help. They hush the kids, and squat behind what few bushes offer protection, monitoring the other bandits. The attack wasn't noticed.
Go all out on the bandits and save the remaining children

The sailors and kids create a breathtaking chaos. The crew shoots and skewers, while the children kick and bite their former oppressors, calling for others to do the same. A deluge of shrieking kids and young adults emerge from the barn and attack the guards, thrilled by your crew's display of strength. The band of unlikely fighters seize the bandits' steamboat, helping themselves to its supplies, before triumphantly returning to the coast.

Audacity does not make up for their lack of numbers. The crew manages to take down five guards before the noise attracts more armed bandits, and the sailors are driven back to their boat before they can liberate any more children. They flee to the village, and share what they've discovered with the villagers, glad to have freed some kids, but all too aware that many more remain captive.
Acknowledge the danger, and leave with the children you've already saved

The decision to run is not a simple one. The sailors recognize how dangerous the assault could be, and retreat to the village along with the few children they've saved. They share what they've discovered with the villagers - and maybe another day, with a subtler approach, more men, and more planning... things could be different. As the ship leaves, the crew focuses more on the good they did, rather than what they could have done.

The sailors are unfit for a swift assault. Their unchoreographed clumsiness and dissonant roars drives their opponents back not because of their strength, but because of the unconventional display. After an instant of bafflement, the kidnappers shout for others to join them, and the whole gang soon surrounds your crew. They part to let their leader, a beast of a man, face the puny intruders.
Fight the brute

Your sailors' cause fuels their victory. Driven by their will to save the children, your sailors do not waver in front of the bandits' leader, all muscles and swords with rage in his eyes. It takes six fighters to face the man, piling up on him in a torrent of dust and groans until he finally stops rampaging. Disheartened by this defeat, and their leader's meaningless pride, the remaining kidnappers are brought to their knees, and the children are freed. The crew returns to the village triumphant!

The mastodon tramples your sailors. The rescuers lack resistance, and are wiped out by the bandits' leader, their corpses sent flying among the children who can do nothing but watch in horror. In an ultimate act of hatred, a young girl is sent back to her village to retell the carnage, and warn future intruders against trying to rescue the children again.
Run away

No sailor is harmed, no child is saved. The crew manage to run back to the village, avoiding the multiple gunshots fired by the kidnappers. That no sailor was wounded is a miracle, but it's hard to celebrate much when the rescue team failed to rescue a single child.
Hide amongst the trees and wait for nightfall

The crew becomes one with the trees. Unseen and unheard, the sailors bury themselves in the forest, and observe their future targets. An opportunity arises when a group of bandits leave their posts to bathe in the river: splashing and talking, they don't hear your men approach.
Steal their clothes to disguise yourselves as bandits

Your sailors use their disguises to orchestrate the children's escape. Dressed in bandits' rough coats and sashes, the crew infiltrates the barn-turned-sweat-shop, where the children are forced to work. One by one, they lead the kids out of the camp and into their skiff, each child carrying stolen supplies. When the boat finally leaves, the camp is left without fuel, food, or ammunition. It will be some time before the bandits can do any more harm.

The poorly-disguised intruders are identified and given chase. When asked by an actual bandit about their shift, one of your undercover sailors tries to answer: they fumble and bumble until the bandit grabs them and shouts, "intruders!". They make a run for it with the others, leaving both kidnappers and children behind.
Capture the men and use them as hostages

A flawless move, from start to finish. After swiftly capturing the naked bandits, the sailors advance, only to discover the camp's true nature: a child-powered sweatshop. It's soon obvious that the bandits' leader is the only one who doesn't care for the hostages, and the man is forcibly exchanged by his crew in return for the promise that your sailors will never set foot in there again. The rescuers return to the village with children on their shoulders, a culprit to be judged, and goods to be shared.

The naked men overpower your fighters. The element of surprise fails to compensate for your crew's lack of strength, and they're easily repelled by the bathing bandits. Instead of killing them, the kidnappers order the sailors to strip, and send them on their way so everyone can see them for what they are - rescuers who were unable to rescue anyone, and who were humiliated in the process.

The sailors are not attuned to the notion of stealth. They argue about the best place to hide, and end up lining up behind what could be the thinnest trees in the entire forest, their bulging shapes attracting more than a little unwanted attention from the kidnappers. Their leader, more beast than man, advances to inspect the intruders, and laughs at the puny men.
Face the brute

The crew are puny indeed, and they are butchered. The bandits' leader needs no help in fighting your rescuers, who spend more time trying to avoid being hit than actually fighting back. They flee the camp, scatter into the woods, and are hunted down like game. The few sailors who make it back to the coast are so disoriented, they can't even remember the location of the kidnappers' camp, making the deaths of their companions pointless.

The terrain is not one your crew are used to. They get stuck in the mangrove roots, and their swearing can be heard all the way to the coast. When they manage to get free, the bandits' steamboat is waiting, its railings lined with guns.
Bluff and pretend backup is on its way

Your bluff works! The kidnappers have a heated discussion before handing over what few children they have onboard, unnerved by the menace your crew just invented. The sailors retreat to the village and return the children to their families, still amazed by their deception, but upset they could save so few.

They do not buy your bluff. Holding your crew at gunpoint, the bandits casually wait for the reinforcements to show up - but they never arrive. To teach your crew a lesson, the kidnappers grab one of the kids onboard, and cut his tongue before throwing it into your raft: a lesson to you liars.
