There are gasps of macabre delight, as the famous detective reveals the only possible solution. 'Elementary you see. Look at this tiny moth wing on the body. Moths are drawn to light, and the sole light this night past issued from... this man's LANTERN!!' The detective lunges across the deck and secures the watchman, who being as impressed with the deduction as everyone else, readily admits to having sought to gain rank by the murder.
Commence an investigation

Careful analysis of the scene reveals two leads. Some believe an autopsy would leave the facts of the case plain, while others reckon the little time available should be spent analysing any evidence at the scene that might establish whodunnit.
Conduct an autopsy of the body

The autopsy is conducted very capably, and confirms the midshipman took his own life. A severe tumour is also discovered on the midshipman's brain. A letter, found later, serves to explain that the fellow knew he hadn't long to live, and wished to face death in his own way. The crew are galvanised on hearing this story of bravery.

The autopsy is sufficient to confirm it was murder. Strangulation was the cause of death, not a slit throat - which was added post-mortem. All else remains unknown. Nevertheless, with the cause of death established, the list of suspects is narrowed down to just a few who had the means and the motive for the crime.
Interrogate until someone confesses

You out the grim truth. The alibi of one sailor does not match his fellows, and he cracks, confessing to the midshipman's murder. It transpires the midshipman had bragged of bedding the other man's wife. The murderer expresses only remorse for his crime, and as the noose is placed around his neck, the crew regret that justice must be so severe.

The interrogation is painfully haphazard. Though it is clear one of the suspects must be the killer, lines of inquiry fail to produce answers. No option remains but to offload all the suspects at the next port to prevent further incident. It is a source of great shame to the crew that fine innocent sailors are certain to be among them.
Beat out a confession

A brutal approach, but one delivering quick results. It seems the midshipman was preparing to whistle-blow unauthorised smuggling below deck, and was killed for it. The ringleaders threatened others with a similar fate if they didn't keep quiet. The culprits are unceremoniously shot, and the vulgar matter is over.

Torture seldom results in happiness. Your victim screams a confession, perhaps in the hope it will end the pain. With nothing else to go on, you scapegoat the poor beggar, and he is keelhauled until dead. The crew are in no doubt that this was the wrong man, and hope to escape your inhuman expedition at the first opportunity.

The autopsy is dreadfully clumsy, and leaves the body almost unrecognisable. The unschooled 'medic' evidently have a point to prove, and insist on defiling it further, despite being a bundle of nerves. By the end the morgue looks like a butchery, and the stricken mortician runs wildly about the ship, scalpel in hand. Several are injured trying to restrain him, but the psychological trauma of an unsolved mystery is twice as damaging.
Fashion a tool for gathering forensic evidence

What innovation! A bright young spark applies some of the latest forensic researches. The knife used to cut the midshipman's neck is placed inside an airtight box along with vapours belonging to the doctor. As if by magic, when removed, clear sets of fingerprints appear on the shaft! When the crew prints are taken, the guilty party is collared in the most satisfying modern fashion!

It's complicated identifying footwear and gait. Ambitious of the crew, then, to attempt to solve both problems with the one device. Still the notched stick-wheel does prove footprints at the scene are suspicious, and that suspects are limited to just a few matches. But how to get to the bottom of this?
Let there be a trial

The trial goes as well as can be expected. The suspects are cross-examined, and proceedings recorded with quill and ink. The shoe-prints belong to a solemn old gent, whose testimony reveals him to be the midshipman's secret lover - the reason he was unforthcoming. He confirms the dead man intended suicide from guilt at their relationship, and was trying to prevent it, but arrived too late. All are grateful that the truth is finally out.

The trial is a farce. Sailors bark questions from the sidelines which the suspects are quite within their rights to leave unanswered. But this obstinacy serves only to rile the shouting mob! They flood through the makeshift courtroom and carry the suspects kicking and screaming to deck, before tossing them over the side.
Put the fear of god into the suspects

It's almost like divine intervention. The priest hears each suspect alone, and once the god-fearing killer breaks down and confesses, he is handed his rope. Still, a lack of forgiveness does not trouble the crew, who are relieved this ungodly chapter is now closed.
These are not god-fearing sailors, and hear the priest's weak plea for the killer to come forward with impassive expressions. Perhaps there is a different approach.
Dump all the suspects at the next port, and be done with it
The Singular Case of the Midshipman

Fragile justice! As your craftsmen stare at an empty drawing board, gormless sailors think they help by tidying up the crime scene. With the investigation fumbled, the killer feels he has to take two more lives before he is finally caught. 'Can't believe how sloppy you are in the art of policing,' he teases, 'I could have killed ten more before you'd found me.' Caught he may be, but the damage is already done.

This lot aren't bloodhounds that's for sure, and turn up nothing even with a strong whiff of murder about it all. With the incompetent investigation ending conspicuously silent, the crew must last the remainder of the expedition in fear they are marked next on the list.
Do nothing, it's suicide - nothing more to be said

Widespread suspicion is the undesirable outcome. Ignorance of the full circumstances surrounding the death has the crew feeling powerless. You must accept that quarrels and accusations will now be routine until the end of this expedition.
You have found a radiant relic! The crew toast the success of your archaeological expedition. May we now better understand what it is to be human!
You have found a radiant relic! The crew toast the success of your archaeological expedition. May we now better understand what it is to be human!
You have found a radiant relic! The crew toast the success of your archaeological expedition. May we now better understand what it is to be human!
You have captured a wild animal! The crew toast the success of your zoological expedition. This can only aid studies of the natural world!
You have captured a wild animal! The crew toast the success of your zoological expedition. This can only aid studies of the natural world!
You have captured a wild animal! The crew toast the success of your zoological expedition. This can only aid studies of the natural world!
You have earned a reward for your altruism! The crew toast a successful rescue, with all returning to the glad comforts of home.
You have earned a reward for your altruism! The crew toast a successful rescue, with all returning to the glad comforts of home.
You have earned a reward for your altruism! The crew toast a successful rescue, with all returning to the glad comforts of home.
You have discovered pirate bounty! With the dread buccaneers blown out of the water, a search of their sunken wreck unearths a well-deserved reward!
You have discovered pirate bounty! With the dread buccaneers blown out of the water, a search of their sunken wreck unearths a well-deserved reward!
You have discovered pirate bounty! With the dread buccaneers blown out of the water, a search of their sunken wreck unearths a well-deserved reward!
You have found a radiant relic! The crew toast the success of your archaeological expedition. May we now better understand what it is to be human!
You have captured a wild animal! The crew toast the success of your zoological expedition. This can only aid studies of the natural world!
You have earned a reward for your altruism! The crew toast a successful rescue, with all returning to the glad comforts of home.
You have discovered pirate bounty! With the dread buccaneers blown out of the water, a search of their sunken wreck unearths a well-deserved reward!
You have found a radiant relic! The crew toast the success of your archaeological expedition. May we now better understand what it is to be human!
The Iron Dragon

Cornered by a fearsome Pyrphorian vessel! Your expedition has reached South America at last, and the crew are looking forward to some well-earned rest. Night has fallen, and your ship is already in the tranquil bay when the look out screams "behind us!". There, looming in the darkness, gleams a dragon of iron, its nostrils livid with fire. "It's the vessel that killed Mr. Goode! But this one must be twice as large! We are at their mercy!" However, the bay is hidden from the bright gaze of the moon, and it is possible the dragon has not yet spotted you. If you choose to show yourself, you cannot expect to be a match for the dragon - only to somehow hinder it long enough to flee.
Fight your way out

Your aim is true, but the dragon is gathering its hot breath. To engage the hulking vessel is a humbling experience — the size, the power, the feet-thick armoured hull that your ordnance seems to only bounce limply off. The crew seem defeated, until they realise their precise fire at the dragon's stern, while showing no external sign of damage, appears to have caused a problem in the engine room. As a response, masked figures rush to prime the beastly mouth — a great cannon of fire! You must act quickly.
Maintain your fire on the weakened engine

Your crew cheer the cannoneers, and one good hit to the same spot does the trick! There are loud rasping noises before the ironclad's engines fall silent, and the great monstrosity drifts to a gentle halt. As your crew escape, they are forced to pass close by the enemy, and see the gnarled and hateful iron of the bows and boards, the army of mocking masks, and the firepit of a mouth that could easily have been their end. The expedition may be free to find Sarmento now, but it is worrying that the Pyrphorians always seem to be one step ahead, and are possessed of such fearful machinery. You set up camp in a secluded inlet further up the coast, confident it will keep you well-hidden.

Your aim isn't quite as good this time. Your shots roll over the solid iron deck like balls of ivory on a bagatelle board, barely making a dent. The iron dragon's mouth yawns wide above your little boat, and from it, the first plume of fire melts the men at the taffrail. The two hulls are close enough for boarding, but there are just too many of the rogues. Your only options are to cause confusion by throwing some of your stink-pot grenados, or to target the flaming cannon itself.
Aim to disable the dreaded cannon

The shot finds its mark. A canister of gas fueling their weapon whistles free of its housing, and blows fire spasmodically about the deck. Some of the mystery of the enemy disappears in that instant, as the cowled crows fight to regain control. As your crew escape, they are forced to pass close by the enemy, and see the gnarled and hateful iron of the bows and boards, the army of mocking masks, and the firepit of a mouth that could easily have been their end. The expedition may be free to find Sarmento now, but it is worrying that the Pyrphorians always seem to be one step ahead, and are possessed of such fearful machinery. Your crew set up camp in a secluded inlet further up the coast, where they begin repairs to the ship.

The shot is good, but it takes too long to line up. Your ship is too close to the dragon's mouth when it's hit, and the eruption of flaming debris is most violent! Your own ship and men are on the receiving end, taking damage and suffering casualties. Luckily, there is chaos enough aboard the Pyrphorian ship for your crew to hightail it out of the bay. The expedition may be free to find Sarmento now, but it is worrying that the Pyrphorians always seem to be one step ahead, and are possessed of such fearful machinery. Your crew set up camp in a secluded inlet further up the coast, where they bury the dead, and begin repairs to the ship.
Aim some grenados toward the enemy deck

The explosion drowns the enemy in a cloud of stench. The coughing and groaning is only the after-effect of the salvo of grenados, whose shrapnel penetrates the crowd of crows. As your crew escape, they are forced to pass close by the enemy, and see the gnarled and hateful iron of the bows and boards, the army of mocking masks, and the firepit of a mouth that could easily have been their end. The expedition may be free to find Sarmento now, but it is worrying that the Pyrphorians always seem to be one step ahead, and are possessed of such fearful machinery. Your crew set up camp in a secluded inlet further up the coast, where they begin repairs to the ship.

One of your sailors can't throw. His grenado springs back from the rigging and onto your own deck, exploding in a stinking cloud of shrapnel. Since both ships are in chaos and have suffered casualties, your quick-thinking steersman takes a chance and sets sail. As your crew escape, they are forced to pass close by the enemy, and see the gnarled and hateful iron of the bows and boards, the army of mocking masks, and the firepit of a mouth that could easily have been their end. The expedition may be free to find Sarmento now, but it is worrying that the Pyrphorians always seem to be one step ahead, and are possessed of such fearful machinery. Your crew set up camp in a secluded inlet further up the coast, where they bury the dead and begin repairs to the ship.
Take the chance to flee the bay

The masterful navigator swings the ship into a serendipitous breeze! Carving up the bay on a beam reach, the billowing sails bearing your company crest leave the iron dragon standing. As your crew pass the enemy, they see the gnarled and hateful iron of the bows and boards, the army of mocking masks, and the fire pit of a mouth that could easily have been their end. The expedition may be free to find Sarmento now, but it is worrying that the Pyrphorians seem a step ahead and possessed of such fearful machinery. You make camp in a secluded inlet further up the coast, confident it will keep you well-hidden.

Your navigator struggles to fill the sails. The iron dragon's mouth yawns wide above your little boat, and from it, the first plume of fire melts the men at the taffrail. The two hulls are close enough for boarding, but there are just too many of the rogues. Your only options are to cause confusion by throwing some of your stink-pot grenados, or to target the flaming cannon itself.

Their aim is embarrassing. Your shots roll over the solid iron deck like balls of ivory on a bagatelle board, barely making a dent. What's more, your attack has given your position away. The iron dragon's mouth yawns wide above your little boat, and from it, the first plume of fire melts the men at the taffrail. The two hulls are close enough for boarding, but there are just too many of the rogues. You can try to target the flaming cannon, or hope you can outrun them before the dragon's breath replenishes once more.
Aim to disable the dreaded cannon

The shot finds its mark. A canister of gas fueling their weapon whistles free of its housing, and blows fire spasmodically about the deck. Some of the mystery of the enemy disappears in that instant, as the cowled crows fight to regain control. As your crew escape, they are forced to pass close by the enemy, and see the gnarled and hateful iron of the bows and boards, the army of mocking masks, and the firepit of a mouth that could easily have been their end. The expedition may be free to find Sarmento now, but it is worrying that the Pyrphorians always seem to be one step ahead, and are possessed of such fearful machinery. Your crew set up camp in a secluded inlet further up the coast, where they begin repairs to the ship.

The shot only seems to rile the dragon — or its operators, at least. The dragon unleashes a second arc of fire, costing another man his life - but perhaps worse for your crew, it also costs you the power of evasion. You'll have to send a team of saboteurs to destroy that cannon before it can be reloaded, or else try to even the odds by slowing the great dragon.
Send a team to sabotage the fiery cannon

Your soldiers leap across like olympians as the two ships pass close by.The Pyrphorians above the iron deck are few. Holes are blown in the gleeful masks of their welcome party, and your men fight their way to the cannon, dispatching its operators with ease before disconnecting the fuel tank and tossing it overboard. More masks come from below, and your men dive into the water. "If not now, we'll take you later," the thwarted enemy cry, as most of your brave saboteurs clamber back aboard, and your ship speeds away. The expedition may be free to find Sarmento now, but it is worrying that the Pyrphorians always seem to be one step ahead, and are possessed of such fearful machinery. Your crew set up camp in a secluded inlet further up the coast, where they bury the dead, and begin repairs to the ship.

It is bold, but the Pyrphorians above the iron deck are stronger. Your soldiers leap across, trying to fight their way to the cannon, but more masks soon emerge from below the gnarled iron deck, and your saboteurs are doomed. To ensure their sacrifice is not in vain, your quick-thinking steersman takes advantage of the chaos and forces your ship past the enemy — just in time to see the army of mocking masks running your men through — and out of the bay to safety. The expedition may be free to find Sarmento now, but it is worrying that the Pyrphorians always seem to be one step ahead, and are possessed of such fearful machinery. Your crew set up camp in a secluded inlet further up the coast, where they bury the dead, and begin repairs to the ship.
Aim at the engine to immobilise the Dragon

The dragon is thwarted, though it catches your ship and crew with one final breath of fire. Nevertheless, your lucky hit to its stern has done the trick. There are loud rasping noises from the ironclad's engines as it noticeably slows and drifts to a gentle halt. As your crew escape, they are forced to pass close by the enemy, and can see the gnarled and hateful iron of the bows and boards, the army of mocking masks, and the firepit of a mouth that could easily have been their end. The expedition may be free to find Sarmento now, but it is worrying that the Pyrphorians always seem to be one step ahead, and are possessed of such fearful machinery. Your crew set up camp in a secluded inlet further up the coast, where they bury the dead and begin repairs to the ship.

The dragon incinerates most of your ship, and only by complete chance does one cannon shot land clean, causing the great beast's engines to begin to splutter. As your crew make a desperate escape, they're forced to pass close by the enemy, and can see the gnarled and hateful iron of the bows and boards, the army of mocking masks, and the firepit of a mouth that very nearly was their end. The expedition may be free to find Sarmento now, but it is worrying that the Pyrphorians always seem to be one step ahead, and are possessed of such fearful machinery. Your crew set up camp in a secluded inlet further up the coast, where they bury the dead, and begin the extensive repairs to the ship.
Try and outrun them while they rearm

The navigators swing the ship into a serendipitous breeze! Almost on a beam reach, the sails billow and the ship evades the iron dragon just in time. As your crew pass, they can see the gnarled and hateful iron of the bows and boards, the army of mocking masks, and the firepit of a mouth that could easily have been their end. The expedition may be free to find Sarmento now, but it is worrying that the Pyrphorians always seem to be one step ahead, and are possessed of such fearful machinery. Your crew set up camp in a secluded inlet further up the coast, hopeful it will keep you well-hidden.

Your navigator struggles desperately to fill the sails, but fails. The dragon unleashes a second arc of fire, costing another man his life - but perhaps worse for your crew, it also costs you the power of evasion. You'll have to send a team of saboteurs to destroy that cannon before it can be reloaded, or else try to even the odds by slowing the great dragon.
Take advantage of the darkness and try to sneak by

Your ship moves in absolute silence, all its lights extinguished. The iron dragon cannot have spotted you, or it would surely have changed course. The darkness makes navigating the bay harder, however, and the crew are under a misapprehension about the depth of the seas. You are almost clear when a loud sound resonates through the ship as the hull touches the bottom; the iron dragon, though some distance away, now begins to turn. You can try to manoeuvre out of the shallows and flee, or turn and face them, still with some element of surprise.
Ambush the Pyrophorian ship

The element of surprise! One good hit from the shadows has done the trick! There are loud rasping noises as the ironclad's engines fall silent, and the great monstrosity drifts to a gentle halt. As your crew escape, they must pass close by the enemy, and can see the gnarled and hateful iron of the bows and boards, the army of mocking masks, and the firepit of a mouth that could easily have been their end. The expedition may be free to find Sarmento now, but it is worrying that the Pyrphorians always seem to be one step ahead, and are possessed of such fearful machinery. Your crew set up camp in a secluded inlet further up the coast, confident it will keep you well-hidden.

Worried about noise, your crew don't load fast enough. One good hit from the shadows would have done the trick, but it's too late now, and your position has been given away. As it approaches, the iron dragon's mouth yawns wide above your little boat, and from it the first plume of fire melts the men at the taffrail. The two hulls are close enough for boarding, but there are just too many of the rogues. You can try to target the flaming cannon, or perhaps trick them into following you into the shallows.
Escape the bay before they can catch you

The masterful navigator swings the ship into a serendipitous breeze! Back-tracking slightly pays off, as they clear the shallows and carve up the bay on a beam reach, the billowing sails bearing your company crest as they leave the iron dragon standing. As your crew pass the enemy, they can see the gnarled and hateful iron of the bows and boards, the army of mocking masks, and the firepit of a mouth that could easily have been their end. The expedition may be free to find Sarmento now, but it is worrying that the Pyrphorians always seem to be one step ahead, and are possessed of such fearful machinery. Your crew set up camp in a secluded inlet further up the coast, confident it will keep you well-hidden.

The dragon is on to your dithering navigators all too soon, so desperate are they to avoid minor bumps from the shallows on their hull. As it approaches, the iron dragon's mouth yawns wide above your little boat, and from it the first plume of fire melts the men at the taffrail. The two hulls are close enough for boarding, but there are just too many of the rogues. You can try to target the flaming cannon, or perhaps trick them into following you into the shallows.
Aim to disable the dreaded cannon

The shot finds its mark. A canister of gas fueling their weapon whistles free of its housing, and blows fire spasmodically about the deck. Some of the mystery of the enemy disappears in that instant, as the cowled crows fight to regain control. As your crew escape, they are forced to pass close by the enemy, and can see the gnarled and hateful iron of the bows and boards, the army of mocking masks, and the firepit of a mouth that could easily have been their end. The expedition may be free to find Sarmento now, but it is worrying that the Pyrphorians always seem to be one step ahead, and are possessed of such fearful machinery. Your crew set up camp in a secluded inlet further up the coast, where they begin repairs to the ship.

The shot is good, but it takes too long to line up. Your ship is too close to the dragon's mouth when it's hit, and the eruption of flaming debris is most violent! Your own ship and men are on the receiving end, taking damage and suffering casualties. Luckily, there is chaos enough aboard the Pyrphorian ship for your crew to hightail it out of the bay. The expedition may be free to find Sarmento now, but it is worrying that the Pyrphorians always seem to be one step ahead, and are possessed of such fearful machinery. Your crew set up camp in a secluded inlet further up the coast, where they bury the dead, and begin repairs to the ship.
Trick the Pyrophorians into following you through the shallows

Fine seamanship. Your crew understand there's no point in hiding now, and light the lanterns again, revealing the true depth of the water. Your helmsmen dance your ship through the shallows in a fluent chassé, zig-zagging ahead of the cumbersome dragon. Once out of the bay, the wind catches the sails, and the Pyrphorians are left stranded. The expedition may be free to find Sarmento now, but it is worrying that the Pyrphorians always seem to be one step ahead, and are possessed of such fearful machinery. Your crew set up camp in a secluded inlet further up the coast, where they begin repairs to the bottom of the ship.

It's a rough ride. Bumped from beneath, and burned from behind, your ship and crew scrape clear of the bay just before the dragon can issue a fatal torching. At the last moment, the wind catches what remains of the sails, and the Pyrphorians are left stranded. The expedition may be free to find Sarmento now, but it is worrying that the Pyrphorians always seem to be one step ahead, and are possessed of such fearful machinery. Your crew set up camp in a seclu,ded inlet further up the coast, where they can bury the dead and begin their extensive repairs to the ship.

They are not discreet enough, some fool still has their lantern lit! You give away your position, and the iron dragon suddenly changes course. Its mouth yawns wide above your little boat, and from it, the first plume of fire melts the men at the taffrail. The two hulls are close enough for boarding, but there are just too many of the rogues. You can try to target the flaming cannon, or attempt to outrun them before the dragon's breath replenishes once more.
Finding Sarmento

"I'll mark her on the map with an S!" says local man Ramón, whom Sir Archibald sent to accompany you. "Why not an X?", says the captain with an air of disappointment. "Sarmento!" says Ramón, his eyes sparkling with life, "Finding her is the key to everything". Having travelled for many days along the New World coast, it is now time to decide how you will travel on from here. Ahead, a broad brown rivermouth invites you upstream, its perils waiting unseen beyond its bends. "Perhaps a route over land will be more forgiving?", says the navigator hopefully. One look at the dark and foreboding line of trees would suggest nothing could be further from the truth. "But which is the lesser of two evils, Admiral?"
Take the ship upriver

The Pyrphorian dragon is back on your tail! It seems hard to believe at first, but the distant chugging of an engine, and the black smudge of smoke above the ragged line of claw-foot mangroves are unmistakable. Your men, who had settled long enough to admire a proliferation of yellow flowers on the southern bank, suddenly find themselves at the mercy of twin horrors! Beyond the next bend are a set of devious rapids frothing down towards you, and with the Pyrphorian dragon fast approaching, time is in short supply. There is a very narrow breach at one side, through which a vessel capably navigated may just about fit. Alternatively, blasting the high cliffs could block the Pyrphorian's way.
Fill the sails and power up the rapids

Your navigator picks up plenty of speed, which is remarkable, since there seems to be little wind on the river today. The line of approach is good too, squeezing your ship between the two craggiest protuberances of rock, as your vessel rides up several tiers of the rapids with little more than a bump. Though a steamer might be better suited to the task, the iron dragon makes no attempt to pursue. Your captain is quick to praise the great skill of your navigator, rather than face the troubling possibility that the Pyrphorians know of a greater danger to come. The river has taken you as far as it can, and you must decide whether to continue across a marsh of uncertain depth, or as Ramón suggests, to head through a nearby network of caves.
Cautiously enter the marshes

Your men know those aren't logs bobbing in the marsh, and decide to wade well clear of the lurking black caiman, who from their chubby bellies appear to have had success in these waters. After a few cheerful hours of tramping, you reach a seemingly unremarkable clearing above the S marked on your map. "But what's this?". A young sailor reveals a mossy bunker in the forest carpet, "Long since deserted," he laughs, "your information must be out of date, Ramón." "Many years out of date," calls a voice from the trees. There is a rustle of foliage, as rifles poke through all around. "You!" a cowled man appears and points in your direction, "come with us." You are shackled and blindfolded, and after a short boat journey, you find yourself before the woman you believe to be Isabel Sarmento. "Who are you," she demands, "and why are you here?"

A wader is too occuped with the myth of fifty-foot anaconda, to see the real danger. The mass of driftwood he reaches for are in fact caiman, sinking their teeth deep into his torso, for which there will be no remedy. Hours of pensive tramping later, your expedition coems to a seemingly unremarkable clearing above the S marked on your map. "But what's this?". A young sailor reveals a mossy bunker in the forest carpet, "Long since deserted," he laughs, "your information must be out of date, Ramón." "Many years out of date," calls a voice from the trees. There is a rustle of foliage, as rifles poke through all around. "You!" a cowled man appears and points in your direction, "come with us." You are shackled and blindfolded, and after a short boat journey, you find yourself before the woman you believe to be Isabel Sarmento. "Who are you," she demands, "and why are you here?"
Find a way through the caves

Several members of the expedition are experienced cavers, and the screech of bats and mountains of guano are about the worst of it. All emerge blinking into a seemingly unremarkable clearing above the S marked on your map. "But what's this?". A young sailor reveals a mossy bunker in the forest carpet, "Long since deserted," he laughs, "your information must be out of date, Ramón." "Many years out of date," calls a voice from the trees. There is a rustle of foliage, as rifles poke through all around. "You!" a cowled man appears and points in your direction, "come with us." You are shackled and blindfolded, and after a short boat journey, you find yourself before the woman you believe to be Isabel Sarmento. "Who are you?" she demands, "and why are you here?"

Ramón apologises, but it's not his fault.You have descended too far, and are forced to squeeze on your bellies through mud and guano. A claustrophobe faints. After a few exhausting hours, all emerge into a seemingly unremarkable clearing above the S marked on your map. "But what's this?". A young sailor reveals a mossy bunker in the forest carpet, "Long since deserted," he laughs, "your information must be out of date, Ramón." "Many years out of date," calls a voice from the trees. There is a rustle of foliage, as rifles poke through all around. "You!" a cowled man appears and points in your direction, "come with us." You are shackled and blindfolded, and after a short boat journey, you find yourself before the woman you believe to be Isabel Sarmento. "Who are you," she demands, "and why are you here?"

Your navigator can gather no speed, which is hardly surprising, since there seems to be little wind on the river today. As a result of his failed attempts to catch the slightest of breezes, the line of approach is also poor, and two of the craggiest protuberances of rock make themselves known. There is a sharp splintering sound as your poor ship's hull suffers what it was never built for, riding up and over the tiered divisions of white water pools. Your damaged hull begins to flood, and though you see the iron dragon turn tail and puff downstream, you must now decide whether to fix or forsake your ship.
Disembark and search for Isabel on foot

Large and luminous eyes light the way now that night has fallen, spare for a few well-known stars that peek through the canopy. An impromptu camp is made for the night somewhere near the S of your map. In the morning, all wake to a seemingly unremarkable clearing. "But what's this?". A young sailor reveals a mossy bunker in the forest carpet, "Long since deserted," he laughs, "your information must be out of date, Ramón." "Many years out of date," calls a voice from the trees. There is a rustle of foliage, as rifles poke through all around. "You!" a cowled man appears and points in your direction, "come with us." You are shackled and blindfolded, and after a short boat journey, you find yourself before the woman you believe to be Isabel Sarmento. "Who are you," she demands, "and why are you here?"

There is not enough expertise to travel on in the darkness, which, apart from the wide eyes that peer out at you from the canopy, is absolute. In their desperation, your company build a great bonfire; small comfort against this thoroughly inhospitable tangle of life. But there is another presence here too, which eventually makes itself known. "You do not belong here," calls a voice from the trees. There is a rustle of foliage, as rifles poke through all around. "You!" a cowled man appears and points in your direction, "come with us." You are shackled and blindfolded, and after a short boat journey, you find yourself before the woman you believe to be Isabel Sarmento. "Who are you," she demands, "and why are you here?"
Repair the ship and continue downriver

Ramón apologises, but it's not his fault.You have descended too far, and are forced to squeeze on your bellies through red mud and guano. A claustrophobe faints. After a few exhausting hours, all emerge into a seemingly unremarkable clearing above the S marked on your map. "But what's this?". A young sailor reveals a mossy bunker in the forest carpet, "Long since deserted," he laughs, "your information must be out of date, Ramón." "Many years out of date," calls a voice from the trees. There is a rustle of foliage, as rifles poke through all around. "You!" a cowled man appears and points in your direction, "come with us." You are shackled and blindfolded, and after a short boat journey, you find yourself before the woman you believe to be Isabel Sarmento. "Who are you," she demands, "and why are you here?"

It would be easier to build a new boat, is the verdict of your carpenters, though they spend hours trying to find the right wood to help with the repairs. The black wood they select is extremely hard to cut, and equally heavy to carry. Yet all the while, they have the feeling they are being watched. Exhausted by the lack of progress, they're taking a moment to recline on a sandy stretch of the river bank when they hear a clicking sound. There is a rustle of foliage, as rifles poke through all around. "You!" a cowled man appears and points in your direction, "come with us." You are shackled and blindfolded, and after a short boat journey, you find yourself before the woman you believe to be Isabel Sarmento. "Who are you," she demands, "and why are you here?"
Fire at the cliff between you and the Pyrphorians

The cannonfire has precisely the desired effect. With a bellowing crack, the high cliff spills several hundred tonnes of orange sandstone into the river. Having contemplated this new obstacle, the iron dragon turns, and disappears back downstream. With the rapids ahead, you are forced to admit the river has taken you as far as it can. You must decide whether to continue across a marsh of uncertain depth, or as Ramón suggests, through a nearby network of caves.

Too little rock falls in time.The small shower of sandstone does not deter the Pyrphorians, and you are left with no choice but to try to sail up the rapids. There is a sharp splintering sound as your poor ship's hull suffers what it was never built for, riding up and over the tiered divisions of white water pools. Your ship begins to flood, and though you see the iron dragon turn tail and puff downstream, you must now decide whether to fix or forsake your ship.
Head into the jungle

An expedition party leaves the ship in capable hands, and sets out into the vast green beyond. It is hard to relate to the enchantment that falls upon these adventurers, to whom this alien world is entirely new, from the whoop and squawk of feathers to the gleeful chattering of capuchin. An ocelot scarpers, a serpent slumbers; a parade of ants bear all the burdens of their kingdom along their leafy conduits, their royal quest in parallel to your own. After several hours of happy tramping, you reach a steep but narrow ravine. If the map suggests some natural bridge across, you do not see it, and the breach in the earth stretches out of sight in both directions. Either you go down and back up with ropes, or try to construct a simple bridge.
Somehow construct a bridge

They have no problem finding a tall enough tree. It is soon felled and hollowed, at least to provide some protection from a fall, and ropes are used to secure it at either end. It's a tidy job, and your expedition passes over it in relative comfort. On the other side, it's not long before Ramón, Sir Archibald's man, alerts you to some prints that have disturbed the red earth. Human ones. Perhaps these lead right to Isabel Sarmento? But that would mean deviating from the route on the map, and the day is beginning to grow dark.
Stick to the map

It proves a good decision. After a cheerful stretch, you reach a seemingly unremarkable clearing above the S marked on your map. "But what's this?". A young sailor reveals a mossy bunker in the forest carpet, "Long since deserted," he laughs, "your information must be out of date, Ramón." "Many years out of date," calls a voice from the trees. There is a rustle of foliage, as rifles poke through all around. "You!" a cowled man appears and points in your direction, "come with us." You are shackled and blindfolded, and after a short boat journey, you find yourself before the woman you believe to be Isabel Sarmento. "Who are you," she demands, "and why are you here?"

Your men don't quite have the expertise to travel on in the darkness, which, apart from the wide eyes that peer out at you from the canopy, is absolute. Your company build a great bonfire for comfort, and wait for morning light - but there is another presence here too, which only now decides to make itself known. "You do not belong here," calls a voice from the trees. There is a rustle of foliage, as rifles poke through all around. "You!" a cowled man appears and points in your direction, "come with us." You are shackled and blindfolded, and after a short boat journey, you find yourself before the woman you believe to be Isabel Sarmento. "Who are you," she demands, "and why are you here?"
Follow the tracks instead

Your beagle follows the faint tracks keenly. After a few cheerful hours of tramping, you reach a seemingly unremarkable clearing. "But what's this?". A young sailor reveals a mossy bunker in the forest carpet, "Long since deserted," he laughs. "Or so you might hope!" calls a voice from the trees. There is a rustle of foliage, as rifles poke through all around. "You!" a cowled man appears and points in your direction, "come with us." You are shackled and blindfolded, and after a short boat journey, you find yourself before the woman you believe to be Isabel Sarmento. "Who are you," she demands, "and why are you here?"

Following them is suspiciously easy. "It feels like we're missing something. Why would rebels in hiding leave such obvious prints? Any old man and his dog could follow them," says your tracker. "Exactly!" calls a voice from the trees. There is a rustle of foliage, as rifles poke through all around. "You!" a cowled man appears and points in your direction, "come with us." You are shackled and blindfolded, and after a short boat journey, you find yourself before the woman you believe to be Isabel Sarmento. "Who are you," she demands, "and why are you here?"

Finding a big enough tree is not the problem. Your men fell the tree and lower it over the chasm, using ropes to secure it at either end. "It looks a little bit wobbly!" says Ramón, Sir Archibald's man. He's right, of course, since there's nothing to cling to but the fragile bark, and several of your expedition come very close to falling, before one eventually loses their footing. "Don't look! She's gone!" Ramón calls out. Resuming their trek, morale is low until someone spots a human bootprint on the forest floor. Perhaps these lead right to Isabel Sarmento? But that would mean deviating from the route on the map, and the day is beginning to grow dark.
Stick to the map

It proves the right decision. After a few tough hours of tramping, you reach a seemingly unremarkable clearing above the S marked on your map. "But what's this?". A young sailor reveals a mossy bunker in the forest carpet, "Long since deserted," he laughs, "your information must be out of date, Ramón." "Many years out of date," calls a voice from the trees. You are shackled and blindfolded, and after a short boat journey, you find yourself before the woman you believe to be Isabel Sarmento. "Who are you," she demands, "and why are you here?"

Your men don't have the expertise to travel on in the darkness, which, apart from the wide eyes that peer out at you from the canopy, is absolute. In their desperation, your company build a great bonfire; small comfort against this thoroughly inhospitable tangle of life. But there is another presence here too, which only now decides to make itself known. "You do not belong here," calls a voice from the trees. There is a rustle of foliage, as rifles poke through all around. "You!" a cowled man appears and points in your direction, "come with us." You are shackled and blindfolded, and after a short boat journey, you find yourself before the woman you believe to be Isabel Sarmento. "Who are you," she demands, "and why are you here?"
Follow the tracks instead

Your beagle follows the faint tracks. After a few hard hours tramping, you reach a seemingly unremarkable clearing. "But what's this?". A young sailor reveals a mossy bunker in the forest carpet, "Long since deserted," he laughs. "Or so you might hope!" calls a voice from the trees. There is a rustle of foliage, as rifles poke through all around. "You!" a cowled man appears and points in your direction, "come with us." You are shackled and blindfolded, and after a short boat journey, you find yourself before the woman you believe to be Isabel Sarmento. "Who are you," she demands, "and why are you here?"

Following them is suspiciously easy. "It feels like we've been idiots and missed something. Why would rebels in hiding leave such obvious prints? Any old man and his dog could follow them?" says your tracker. "Exactly!" calls a voice from the trees. There's a rustle of foliage, as rifles poke through all around. "You!" a cowled man appears and points in your direction, "come with us." You are shackled and blindfolded, and after a short boat journey, you find yourself before the woman you believe to be Isabel Sarmento. "Who are you," she demands, "and why are you here?"
Co-ordinate your way down and back up

Their communication is excellent. The correct knots are used for the guy ropes, and with the experience of soldiering among you the descent is painless. At the bottom, you skip over a small creek babbling towards the mother river, before commencing a successful climb up the other side. Back on track, it is not long before Ramón, Sir Archibald's man, alerts you to prints that have disturbed the red earth. Human ones. Perhaps these lead right to Isabel Sarmento? But that would mean deviating from the route on the map, and the day is beginning to grow dark.

Their communication is appalling. The abseil down is messy, but fortune prevails. Not so on the way back up, when a poor sailor's knot slips, and the jangle of guy ropes sends one of the front-running climbers plunging into the crevasse. "He's gone. Don't look!" cries Ramón. Sir Archibald's man is wise indeed, for the rest manage the climb. Resuming their trek, morale is low until someone spots a human bootprint on the forest floor. Perhaps these lead right to Isabel Sarmento? But that would mean deviating from the route on the map, and it the day is beginning to grow dark.
"We are here on behalf of Her Majesty the Queen!"

"You think I care about your stupid empire?!" curses Isabel, beckoning to two guards to tightly restrain you. "No sooner had we gained independence from La Corona, than we receive an offer too-good-to-be-true from an envoy of your Queen. An 'amazing prospect, Prosperity', he said - and at first it was." Isabel grunts and slams her boot knife into a barrel, from which wine spurts out. "Now that island, our last hope of freedom, is overrun with these masks, these... twisted people, and their fire!" She rushes at you, and forces your lips open for a better answer...
"My father was Samuel Goode. I am here to stop the Pyrphorians!"

Isabel slowly releases her grip. She stabs her boot knife back into the wine barrel, plugging the hole. "Then you are against the Pyrphorians. I heard reports they tried to stop you with an iron dragon." She exhales nervously. "I did not believe it. And yet, you've risked your life to come here..." Isabel motions her guards to release you, "...I should at least hear what you're planning to do about all this."
"My father was Samuel Goode. I am here to take Prosperity back!"

Isabel's eyes flash with anger. "So! They call your father a traitor for selling it to us, the 'pesky rebels', and now you've come here to 'do the right thing' and take it back?! Your father should have thought of that before he sold it. A deal is a deal!" It is a confession that the deal has not, in any respect, been a good one. She picks up the barrel and pours wine over your head, "Maybe I'll take all my rage out on you!"
"Even if it was my father, the Pyrphorians must have forced him to sell!"

Isabel puts the barrel down, stabbing her boot knife in to plug the hole. "Then you are against the Pyrphorians. I heard reports they tried to stop you with an iron dragon." She exhales nervously. "I did not believe it. And yet, you've risked your life to come here..." Isabel motions her guards to release you, "...I should at least hear what you're planning to do about all this."
"Admit it, you conspired with the Pyrphorians to buy it!"
"I don't need to take insults from an imperialist pig," Isabel rages, tossing the barrel aside and raising her boot knife. Better say the right thing this time...
"Can't you see, the Pyrphorians are evil!"

Isabel sighs, and puts her knife down. She rests her hands on the window ledge, to gaze across the turquoise waters. "Then you are against the Pyrphorians. I heard reports they tried to stop you with an iron dragon." She exhales nervously. "I did not believe it. And yet, you've risked your life to come here..." Isabel motions her guards to release you, "...I should at least hear what you're planning to do about all this."
"I am the child of Samuel Goode."

Isabel's eyes flash with anger. "So! They call your father a traitor for selling it to us, the 'pesky rebels', and now you've come here to 'do the right thing' and take it back?! Your father should have thought of that before he sold it. A deal is a deal!" It is a confession that the deal has not, in any respect, been a good one. She picks up the barrel and pours wine over your head, "Maybe I'll take all my rage out on you!"
"The Pyrphorians are after us!"

Isabel sighs. She rests her hands on the window ledge, to gaze across the turquoise waters. "Then you are against the Pyrphorians. I heard reports they tried to stop you with an iron dragon." She exhales nervously. "I did not believe it. And yet, you've risked your life to come here..." Isabel motions her guards to release you, "...I should at least hear what you're planning to do about all this."
Pyrphorian Pursuit

The Pyrphorians are escaping with the contract! The smoke of battle provided the perfect cover for a small craft that's now racing clear of the skirmish! The entire assault must have been a diversion so they could sneak out with the papers! You and Hannah may never know the truth unless you get them back. They have quite a headstart, but you might catch them if you give chase. Alternatively, as few harbours nearby will grant them sanctuary, you can try to anticipate their likely heading.
Let them run, and instead try to establish their likely destination.

"There! We have them," your navigator smiles. "See? Here." Their finger traces a route behind Ventura island. "Remarkable how few options they have. Montoya is the only port they might blend in at for fifty leagues." Sure enough, you intercept one of the tiny vessels off Montoya's twinkling bay. It may be no match for your own ship, but to sink them outright risks losing that precious contract to the water.
Try to disable them

Crackerjack! The perfect shot. Though a slender target, the mast snaps through, burying its operators in debris, and leaving the boat dead in the water. With the freedom of their ship, your crew find an ingenious-looking machine, but no sign of the Prosperity contract. As it's no longer on board, you're certain it must have changed hands in nearby Montoya, and make a beeline for the port.

Only a partial success, as the fire forces the Pyrphorians to turn to face you. Sensing they might still have a chance in a fight, the Pyrphorians prime what few small dragon cannons they have. Your crew must act quickly.
Swing over to their ship and get among them
Continue to target the mast and rigging

Woomph! Your brutes descend like gibbons on lianas. The few cultists aboard are ruthlessly dispatched. With the freedom of their ship, your crew find some arcane Pyrphorian devices, but no sign of the Prosperity contract. As it's no longer on board, you're certain it must have changed hands in nearby Montoya, and make a beeline for the port.

What a rabble! Like some arrhythmic jingle of bell-ringers, your thugs mistime their swings, falling into the channel between the two vessels. The Pyrphorians make their escape, but you know where they're headed. If your crew manage to recover both themselves and their dignity, you'll make a beeline for the port of Montoya.

It works this time. With a shorter range to your target, your competent cannoneers have no trouble picking out the mast. It buries the enemy in debris, and leaves the sail-less boat adrift. With the freedom of their ship, your crew find some arcane Pyrphorian devices, but no sign of the Prosperity contract. Knowing it can only have changed hands in nearby Montoya, you make a beeline for the port.

The Pyrphorian ship is agile. "Never seen an enemy move like that," explains one of your cannoneers, as if to avoid some weeping confession of his inexperience. Sensing they may be a match after all, the Pyrphorians use what firepower they have to give your ship a fair lick of flame. The ensuing panic provides the cover they need to slip away. You'll no doubt pick up their trail again in the port of Montoya, but the fire has caused damage that must be repaired first.

Miles off! Your novice gunners are so desperate to avoid striking the enemy in any meaningful way, a small, inoffensive patch of sea ends up taking the brunt instead. Sensing their tiny ship is a match for yours after all, the Pyrphorians pump flame from their dragon cannons, and give your ship a good licking. The ensuing panic provides the cover they need to slip away. You'll no doubt pick up their trail again in the port of Montoya, but the fire has caused significant damage that must be repaired first.
Try to board them

Your crew lick their lips. You thought they seemed the type to enjoy tussles at close quarters, and so it proves. Cloaks drop all around, and with them dead the ship is yours. Your crew find an ingenious-looking machine aboard, but no sign of the Prosperity contract. Knowing it can only have changed hands in nearby Montoya, you make a beeline for port.

Your sailors cannot disguise what they intend. As your ship readies to join theirs at the hip, the Pyrphorians yank night palls away to reveal a line of signature dragon guns. They will burn anyone who tries to come near...
Snipe the cannon operators one by one

The cowled figures fall like beetles swept from a window ledge. Your marksmen pause to survey the scene, "A fearful desire, these Pyrphorians have, to die for their cause..." says one wistfully. Picking through their ship reveals some arcane Pyrphorian devices, but no sign of the Prosperity contract. Knowing it can only have changed hands in nearby Montoya, you make a beeline for the port.

The shot seems to pass through them, as if beneath their mask and cloak, their bodies are incorporeal, or perhaps your marksmen are drunk. Either way, it allows the Pyrphorians to turn and catch a strong westerly squall. They are halfway to the bay of Montoya before your sailors can reposition. You'll have to rely on picking up their trail when you get there.
Train your main guns on their cannons

Destructive, but effective. A shot explodes onto the Pyrphorian deck, and the weighty flame cannons drop through the boards. With the freedom of the ship, your crew find some arcane Pyrphorian devices, but no sign of the Prosperity contract. Knowing it can only have changed hands in nearby Montoya, you make a beeline for the port.

Your fool cannoneers sank them! Exactly what they weren't supposed to do. Several miserable hours are spent combing the soggy wreckage, with no sign of the contract. "You won't find it," a bloody-mouthed Pyrphorian grins, but his dying taunt is a clue. He implies the contract changed hands before you intercepted the ship. Being the only haven for miles around, you set a course for the port of Montoya.

Your soldiers lack initiative, and it is the Pyrphorians who swing aboard your ship, brandishing torches and firing elegant pocket pistols. Though their zeal cannot be matched, they are outnumbered. By the time they are subdued, they have pinned two, and burned many others. The accomplices in their boat are already halfway to Montoya. Once your groaning survivors have been gauzed-up, you might still find them there.

"Hmmn..." your navigator mumbles awkwardly, realising he has proposed almost every one of the myriad small harbours in the region. Someone coughs. Perhaps all these officers have been summoned to the cabin merely to share in his humiliation? "We've lost them then...", a skeptic pipes up, addressing the elephant in the room. "So what now?! Search every harbour?! Solicit a friendly local power for help?!!"
Check every nearby harbour in the hope of finding them

The clouds finally part over Montoya. Your crew had been about to give up, until by chance, one of them caught sight of a ship. Moored in a secluded corner of the bay, it is the empty, but unmistakable property of the shadowy Pyrphorians you pursued. The contract must still be somewhere here in Montoya.

Needles and haystacks. You exhaust all feasible harbours. Not only is there no sign of your quarry, there is no method of knowing whether they have been and gone from a place, or if they were never there at all. The sea seems godless, wide and deep, and the crew long for it to swallow them up. Instead, however, they must return to Miss Hannah Goode, to explain their failure.
Appeal to nearby local authorities for information

You're made to wait in line. Your diplomats may have done well to remember this local crest as one loyal to the crown, but you are not the only envoys present. Daiquiris, bananas and soft furnishings are small compensation for the time lost. Despite these formalities, the prefect transpires to be loyal. He intimates that Montoya is the only nearby place he has knowledge of that the Pyrphorians have their claws into. You cross your fingers, and head there yourself.

"They must have been in league with the Pyrphorians!" wails your duped diplomat. Having failed to detect local complicity— rooted either in fear or allegiance — your diplomat insists you sail south along the coast. Your expedition continues diligently for three days in that direction without sighting a single human settlement. "Since you're so fine with words," says the lieutenant to the diplomat in question, "perhaps you should explain our failure to Miss. Hannah Goode!"
Trust your lookouts to keep you in range

The lookout never loses them, despite the vessel being nearly out of sight. As its small grey outline rounds an island, the lookout gestures excitedly to starboard. He's seen the golden thread of an inlet which would let you cut the nose off the cape, and intercept the Pyrphorians on the other side.
Take a shortcut via the inlet

You emerge right on top of them! Swinging masterfully through the stone jaws that gate the inlet, your navigators traverse a fantasy lagoon. Bursting beyond it into the bay, the ambush is received with complete surprise. With the freedom of the Pyrphorian ship, your crew find an ingenious-looking machine, but no sign of the Prosperity contract. As it's no longer on board, you're certain it must have changed hands in nearby Montoya, and make a beeline for the port.

It's clear now why the Pyrphorians did not use the inlet themselves. Perhaps they were more willing to admit they didn't have the skill to navigate it without risking their ship. The inlet chokes, and a tooth-like incisor of rock rakes the boards from your hull. Limping out on the other side, you've made up the distance enough to see the Pyrphorians are headed to the port of Montoya. Your crew are very glad, since your ship is now in dire need of repair.
Maintain course, following them around the island

The Pyrphorians realise they must make port or be caught. As you round the cape, you see they're headed for the nearby settlement of Montoya. "Though we may not have caught them by sea," says your navigator, "they may have given away much more by leading us here; the only such haven for miles around."

The lookout loses them. Complacency sets in, when at first you appear to be catching them, but upon rounding a cape, you find they have vanished! Bright white settlements cluster the sound like a fairy circle, and it seems they could have docked in any one of them. "We've lost them!" a skeptic pipes up, "so what now?! Stick a pin in the map?! Solicit a friendly local power for help?!!"
Study the map to guess their most likely docking point

The navigator is as sure of himself as he can be in these circumstances. "If I were Pyrphorian, God help me, I would head for Montoya." his finger circles the large settlement, "It has a large marina where my devilish vessel might be easily concealed." Upon searching Montoya harbour, they indeed find the Pyrphorian ship in a secluded corner of mangrove. That being all well and good, they must hope now they've not lost too much time.

The navigator is as much as a failure as the lookout. Your ship makes a cat's cradle of the sound, as the navigator drags you hopelessly from one port to the next, almost at random. "Since you're so fine with directions," says the lieutenant to the diplomat in question, "perhaps you should explain where we went off course to Miss. Hannah Goode!"
Appeal to nearby local authorities for information

You're made to wait in line. Your diplomats may have done well to remember this local crest as one loyal to the crown, but you are not the only envoys present. Daiquiris, bananas and soft furnishings are small compensation for the time lost. Despite these formalities, the prefect transpires to be loyal. He intimates that Montoya is the only nearby place he has knowledge of that the Pyrphorians have their claws into. You cross your fingers, and head there yourself.

"They must have been in league with the Pyrphorians!" wails your duped diplomat. Having failed to detect local complicity — rooted either in fear or allegiance — your diplomat insists you sail south along the coast. Your expedition continues diligently for three days in that direction without sighting a single human settlement. "Since you're so fine with words," says the lieutenant to the diplomat in question, "perhaps you should explain our failure to Miss. Hannah Goode!"
Montoya

That contract and those Pyrphorians must be here in Montoya, but where? The city sprawls before you under a pastel blue sky, the distinctive white walls and terracotta of Imperial La Corona glowing softly along the narrow estuary where the Mixcoatl meets the ocean. Yet, tranquil it is not. Anxiety is written on every passing face. They must surely know who you are and what you seek, but finding one brave enough to help is a different matter. You can ask around, or instead rely on your own eyes to find clues.
Ask the local Montoyans if they know anything

Your attaché hits it off with the harbourmaster, presenting you (not entirely falsely) as a fellow port official sympathetic to the Pyrphorian problem in the region. "I am sick of it," says the Montoyan, "whenever they come here, it's a nightmare for us! If you're willing to take action, it will be my pleasure to assist." Out on the sun-baked rooftop, he points upriver. "There, at the casona." A large verdant ranch wavers in the distance, the sanctuary of the Pyrphorians.

The only one who may be willing to help you is a Great Plainsman. The softly-spoken giant is hauling thick rope at the dock. "I would be putting my life at risk," he says gravely, looking over his shoulder. He seems to know something.
A little recompense always calms the nerves
The Great Plainsman looks nervously over your goods
Bribe

"That should be enough to get me out of here," he says, inspecting the merchandise. "They've taken the big ranch - they're using it for their gatherings. You'd better be ready if you're hoping to break in, though. See all these people? There's a reason they're afraid." You head for the ranch on the outskirts of Montoya, where darkness awaits.
Cancel
"No!" he says, unwilling to risk his life for such scant reward. He glances around, sweeping back his long dark hair. It seems increasingly unlikely he will co-operate.
Threaten it out of him

He raises his hands, impressed, while remaining wary. "Perhaps you'll be the ones to finally unseat them." he says, pointing upriver, "They've taken the big ranch. They're using it for their gatherings. When you go there, expect trouble." He looks your soldiers up and down again, "Even if you do seem well prepared."

"Seen enough of that in my lifetime," he says with quiet defiance. Your soldiers hang their heads— with the Pyrphorians here, Montoyans hardly need you stirring up more trouble. "If all you have to offer is violence, take it to those who deserve it," he says, gesturing at a decrepit-looking warehouse towards the end of the quay. Then he disappears, without so much as a farewell.
Reassure him

"Your envoy is right," he says, "I can cover my tracks well enough." He nods upriver. "They've taken the big ranch - they're using it for their gatherings. You'd better be ready if you're hoping to break in, though. See all these people? There's a reason they're afraid." You head for the ranch on the outskirts of Montoya, where darkness awaits.

He sighs deeply and rolls his eyes. "If you can't convince me, good luck convincing them to stop what they've begun," he says, gesturing at a decrepit-looking warehouse at the end of the quay. Then he disappears, without so much as a farewell.

Your attaché's weepy plea is better received than anyone who had to hear it could have expected. "Of course we will help you stand against this terrible evil!" A local man says cheerfully, leading you to the end of the pier, where a rather decrepit warehouse stands. "This is it. We're all counting on you!" he whispers encouragingly at the door, before hurrying away.
Smash down the warehouse door and charge in

Of course, the Pyrphorians are ready and waiting. The warehouse appears to be a workshop for the production of devotional sculptures, its tables now flipped into barricades. Bullets ting through the many hundred stone representations of the goddess Pyr, as bodies drop on both sides. Eventually, the cultists prove too few. Having honored the dead, you conduct a search. There is no contract, but a fiery oculus stares up from the floor - it is a Pyrphorian paper tract, an invitation to a rally at the Casado estate.

Your feeble bunch finally edge open the heavy door, only to find the building deserted. That it is owned by the Pyrphorians is clear. Carmine drapes smother the windows, and your people find themselves picking over the cult's instruments, whose purpose is unsettlingly opaque. "What's this oily liquid on the floor," someone says, just as the door slams shut, followed by the hasty rattle of padlock and keys. The Pyrphorian fire will burn bright and long at the quayside this night. Only one of your crew returns home.
Find some way to sneak inside

Your crew stalk noiselessly around the back. Scaling the wall, they find an open window obscured by a heavy carmine drape. Peering beyond it, they see a workshop for the production of devotional sculptures, its tables now flipped into barricades. With the cultists' attentions fixed on the main door, you're able to ambush them before it turns into a gunfight - but that doesn't stop two of your own being shot dead. Having honored the dead, your survivors conduct a search. There is no contract, but a fiery oculus stares up from the floor - it is a Pyrphorian paper tract, an invitation to a rally at the Casado estate.

They thought they'd been as quiet as church mice, but rounding the corner at the back of the warehouse, your crew has a nasty shock. Up on the balcony above, where you might have thought to gain entry to the warehouse, stands a single Pyrphorian clad in heavy garb; in his hands, a long brass pipe, from which erupts a searing cone of fire. Your people spread and dive for the sea, and the Pyrphorians torch your ship. Only one of your crew returns home.
Fan through the city, looking for clues

Your scouts pick up the scent immediately. "We recognised them as the fugitives from the boat we pursued, and followed them through Montoya to its outskirts. Up in the valley, there's a sizeable house on a large estate. They must have taken the contract there." You set off at once.

It seems the Pyrphorians have split. One you trace as far as the church, the other to a house of ill-repute— alternate refuges of the typical criminal. In neither case are the Pyrphorians still in evidence - you'll have to ask one of the respective proprietors instead.
Go to the church and ask the Priest for help

None better than the priest, hidden in shadow, witness to every confession, to guide you. "Yes, the rogues were here, but they are gone now. I am powerless to stop them, just like everybody else." He tells of a darkness that grips at the Montoyan community, their suffering pouring through his doors— a last refuge for the holy. "Many speak of a ranch a little way up the valley, and a beacon, some infernal eye, that holds their wicked congregation rapt," he says. You realise that if the contract is anywhere, it's probably there.

Your crew must trust the man of God. After all, he seems devoted to helping you cleanse Montoya of its heresy. "No, I have not seen them," he begins, "but many of my flock have confessed their fears as of late — their lost faith." He smiles blithely, and leads you from the church to a decrepit warehouse on the dock. "If you too wish to rid yourself of your demons, I encourage you to begin here. Now forgive me, for I cannot abide violence," he says, taking his leave. You can try to break the warehouse door, or you can sneak in around the back.
Go to the den of ill-repute and ask the Madam for help

The Madam is only too happy to help following such charming propitiations. "Yes, the devils were here. They always are." She leads you through a lanterned garden of red dahlia, and points you up the valley to a ranch. "The sort of eye you seek is up there, at the casona," she clutches her wrist suddenly, "searing, burning — the Oculus." Lifting her hand, she reveals a grotesque brand on her skin. Mildly troubled, you set out for the ranch.
The Madam refuses to help without payment. Time is money, and your mumbling mummers are wasting it.
Spend some time in the establishment

All are commendably well-behaved. Your sailors make surprisingly good companions, all paying what they owe. "Now that I have some evidence as to your good character," says the Madam, "I will help you." She leads you through a lanterned garden of red dahlia, and points you up the valley to a ranch. "The sort of eye you seek is up there, at the casona," she clutches her wrist suddenly, "searing, burning — the Oculus." Lifting her hand, she reveals a grotesque brand on her skin. Thanking her for her hospitality, you set out for the ranch.

After an hour, your sailors are all over the place, singing and carousing, with one refusing to pay for services rendered. "Get them out!" screams the Madam. "But what of the information you promised?", "Out!". You have created enough of a scene. Fortunately, two boys waiting outside cheerily agree to help you for a bit of coin. They lead your band to a warehouse from which they claim eerie sounds emanate at night - in their words, like "stakes being driven through the hearts of vampyrs." The door to the warehouse looks breakable.
Threaten her

"Alright, alright," she says bitterly, "Yes, the devils were here. They always are." She leads you through a lanterned garden of red dahlia, and points you up the valley to a ranch. "The sort of eye you seek is up there, at the casona," she clutches her wrist suddenly, "searing, burning - the Oculus." Lifting her hand, she reveals a brand on her skin. Feeling vaguely guilty for adding to the poor woman's woes, you set out for the ranch.

She becomes strangely compliant, as if she is used to empty aggression. "This way," she says with forced sensuality. She takes you back over your own steps to the dock, and gestures a silked sleeve (from which no hand protrudes) to a decrepit-looking warehouse. "There. I must leave you now." The warehouse door looks breakable.

There is no sign of the Pyrphorians, at least not that any of your twits see. Giving up their search, they begin stopping locals in the street. Most shake them off and walk on in a hurry, but they finally seem to strike lucky when two boys cheerily agree to help for a bit of coin. They lead your band to a warehouse from which they claim eerie sounds emanate at night- in their words, like "stakes being driven through the hearts of vampyrs." The door to the warehouse looks breakable.
The House of Pyr

The Prosperity contract must be here. The Casona looks quite modern, with its white walls and pleasant gables. There is even an adjoining orangery, extending naturally towards the neat parterres of the sweet-smelling garden. An arc of white gravel serves as a drive, with long lines of equally white picket fence bordering the acreage in a typically colonial style. Indeed, were it not for the unusual height of this perimeter, and the shelters abutting it at regular intervals — armed guards no doubt stationed in each — it would appear much as any other estate. You consider your plan of entry.
Play it bold, launching an assault on the house

The guards at the main gate are efficiently dispatched, and their keys are taken. Your brigade flood into the ranch in formation, taking cover behind hedgerow and shrubbery, as the scattered enemy attempts to muster. Sure enough, the robes soon begin to flow, and the petit pistols are out.
Persist with a frontal assault

The Pyrphorian defence is short-lived, and you lose no-one. Leaving the dying Pyrphorians to bask in their last light, you enter the house by the front door.
Once inside, your party meets with no resistance - only dread. The vestibule is a large open room, with stairs on either side. A series of Pre-Raphaelite panels depicting Pyr, the fire mother, adorn the walls. In one, she stands beneath a dark and cosmic sky, disciples at her feet, each holding a braid of her flaming hair. The most striking feature of the room, however, is the dome in the centre. At first, from below, it appears convex, but it's painted in every detail as a human eye. The Oculus. A pinprick of sunlight falls from its pupil to an ominous platform, thick with ash. You cannot find that contract soon enough.

Not as easy as your brigade presumes. There is strong resistance from the enemy, who in spite of their religious attire, are well-armed. You lose good people on the way to the front door.
Once inside, however, your party meets with no resistance - only dread. The vestibule is a large open room, with stairs on either side. A series of Pre-Raphaelite panels depicting Pyr, the fire mother, adorn the walls. In one, she stands beneath a dark and cosmic sky, disciples at her feet, each holding a braid of her flaming hair. The most striking feature of the room, however, is the dome in the centre. At first, from below, it appears convex, but it's painted in every detail as a human eye. The Oculus. A pinprick of sunlight falls from its pupil to an ominous platform, thick with ash. You cannot find that contract soon enough.
Keep the combat ranged

The Pyrphorians are soon down, having but hand pistols with which to contend with your crack shots. Leaving the dying Pyrphorians to bask in their last light, you enter the house by the front door.
Once inside, your party meets with no resistance - only dread. The vestibule is a large open room, with stairs on either side. A series of Pre-Raphaelite panels depicting Pyr, the fire mother, adorn the walls. In one, she stands beneath a dark and cosmic sky, disciples at her feet, each holding a braid of her flaming hair. The most striking feature of the room, however, is the dome in the centre. At first, from below, it appears convex, but it's painted in every detail as a human eye. The Oculus. A pinprick of sunlight falls from its pupil to an ominous platform, thick with ash. You cannot find that contract soon enough.

The Pyrphorians are too agile for your marksmen. This is all more drawn out now than it needed to be. You lose good people on the way to the front door.
Once inside, however, your party meets with no resistance - only dread. The vestibule is a large open room, with stairs on either side. A series of Pre-Raphaelite panels depicting Pyr, the fire mother, adorn the walls. In one, she stands beneath a dark and cosmic sky, disciples at her feet, each holding a braid of her flaming hair. The most striking feature of the room, however, is the dome in the centre. At first, from below, it appears convex, but it's painted in every detail as a human eye. The Oculus. A pinprick of sunlight falls from its pupil to an ominous platform, thick with ash. You cannot find that contract soon enough.

The guards at the main gate prove challenge enough already. After finally getting the better of them, your brigade lift their heads to see horses flooding through the garden from the stables. Some are masked, others hired hands equipped with bandoliers. Even the gardeners have downed tools and pulled pistols. This is going to be rougher than you thought.
Draw the enemy out, so you can flank them

A marathon battle style. It works, and the guards are defeated. A few sailors are injured, but now the road to the house is open.
The only question that remains now is: which room to look for?

Your strategy is too clever for your forces, who despite outnumbering the Pyrphorians three-to-one, are still only marginal victors. With a war at stake, you must hurry on to the house.
Once inside, your party meets with no resistance - only dread. The vestibule is a large open room, with stairs on either side. A pinprick of sunlight falls from its pupil to an ominous platform, thick with ash. You cannot find that contract soon enough.
Get behind the senior officer and charge!

There's no keeping your lot down! "We are dragon-slayers", they cry, pulling the enemy from their saddles, until the clamour is suddenly over. You will bury your dead later.

The officer commands no such following, and charges alone to an early grave. After that it is a hard fight, but you scrape through it. You hurry through the violated garden to the house.
Your party meets with no resistance in the vestibule, only dread. It is a large open room, with stairs at either side. A series of Pre-Raphaelite panels depicting Pyr, the fire mother, adorn the walls. In one, she stands beneath a dark and cosmic sky, disciples at her feet, each holding a braid of her flaming hair. The most striking feature of the room, however, is the dome in the centre, which from below appears at first convex, and is painted in every detail as a human eye. The Oculus. A pinprick of sunlight falls from its pupil to an ominous platform, thick with ash. You cannot find that contract soon enough.
Play it sneaky - have your best person go in alone

Your able scout climbs over the fence, darting nimbly between flowerbeds, and under the broad umbrella of a royal poinciana, its blossoms red as blood. The kitchen door on the east side is unguarded, but locked. What will you have your scout do next?
Knock through the glass with a sword hilt to turn the handle

A hole punched with minimal fuss, and the door is open.
Once inside, your infiltrator meets with no resistance - only dread. The vestibule is a large open room, with stairs on either side. The glass does not give, and the noise is alarming. Footsteps follow. Your infiltrator dives for the cover of a cactus bed. A long and agonising wait follows before the coast is clear again, the cactus needle they've plucked serving as a handy pick for the lock. The door opens.

Fashion something with which to pick the lock

There is a satisfying click. Warping the belt-buckle was an inspiration. The house seems deserted.

Much as using a pipe stem seemed a fine idea, it snaps off under the strain, and the lock will no longer budge. Should they risk staying longer?
Knock through the glass with a sword hilt to turn the handle

The glass does indeed break, but it feels a little desperate.
