The glass does not entirely give, and the noise echoes across the yard. Footsteps come from both sides, and your infiltrator is caught. With little time now before the contract is moved on by foot or by horse, the rest of your brigade opens fire. Cloaked figures on horseback flood into the garden from the stables. Even the gardeners have downed tools and pulled pistols. This is going to be rough.
Be safe, leave quickly
Running, your not-so-crafty agent finds themselves in an exposed part of the garden. If they dwell any longer, they'll be caught. What would you have them do?

There's some progress at first; your scout scales the fence, the house draws near. But the weakness of their chosen route suddenly becomes apparent. They find themselves in an exposed part of the garden - if they dwell any longer, they'll be caught. What would you have them do?
Target the nearest guard

Your scout strangles the guard, able to keep him quiet until the end. The whole thing feels a little desperate, but the path to the door is clear.

Your scout manages to climb fast enough to avoid being spotted. With a short jump they're on a balcony, and with a little effort, they enter through an open window. Play it crafty — send someone in dressed as one of the congregation
Everything suggests the masked guard at the gate has been fooled, but then she asks for a password. "A password?" repeats your impostor in the local vernacular, "er..."
Fuego

"Of course," the masked guard says calmly. But the moment your impostor passes the gate, they're seized. With little time now before the contract is moved on by foot or by horse, the rest of your brigade open fire. Cloaked figures on horseback flood into the garden from the stables. Even the gardeners have downed tools and pulled pistols. This is going to be rough.
Diosa

"Correct." The guard sounds almost surprised. Your infiltrator strides unopposed up the long, tree-lined drive, and right in through the main door.

Signal the assault
Search the library

Your infiltrator has the place to themself. For a library, there are very few books - and no sign of that contract under P for Prosperity, S for Sarmento, or anywhere else. The mahogany shelves are mostly home to objet d'art; cast iron animals never before seen, ornate weaponry, marble votives to Pyr, and a perfect diamond, gleaming dully. May as well pocket it, before moving on.
Search the assembly hall

Rejoice! The contract is right here, hidden beneath the hinged cover of the lectern. Hannah will be delighted - with this in your possession, a war may be prevented, and the small trouble it has taken to obtain it will be proven worthwhile. Indeed, there is a further windfall within the lectern - a fine silver ring, which your infiltrator may as well pocket before they make their escape.
Search the study

Rejoice! The contract is right here, waiting on the desk that dominates this sparsely-furnished room. Hannah will be delighted - with this in your possession, a war may be prevented, and the small trouble it has taken to obtain it will be proven worthwhile. Indeed, there is a further windfall among the miscellaneous objects in the drawers - a rare jade pearl, which your infiltrator may as well pocket before making their escape.
Search the assembly hall

Your infiltrator has the place to themself. The large room basks in the natural light of a dozen rectangular window panes. Four empty pews confirm this as a place of congregation, and although there is no sign of that contract among the ritual objects, a brief survey of the lectern reveals a perfect diamond behind a hinged cover. May as well pocket it, before moving on.

The Investigation

Discouraged, the crew are forced to return to Isabel's island. "We lost them", apologises the captain. But a few days later, Isabel receives a letter from one of her scouting parties, "Pyrphorian vessel spotted entering Montoya harbour." With renewed hope, the crew prepare to leave at once. The contract, and those Pyrphorians must be here in Montoya, but where? The city sprawls before you under a pastel blue sky, the distinctive white walls and terracotta of Imperial La Corona glowing softly along the narrow estuary where the Mixcoatl meets the ocean. Yet, tranquil it is not. Anxiety is written in every passing face. They must surely know who you are and what you seek, but finding one brave enough to help is a different matter. You can ask around, or instead rely on your own eyes to find clues.
The Infiltration

The sole survivor succeeds in getting back to Isabel's island. In his panic, he explains that the rest didn't make it, and describes how he traced the enemy back to an estate outside Montoya. The crew are assembled at once. They arrive to find the Casona looks quite modern, with white walls and pleasant gables. The Prosperity contract must be here. An adjoining orangery extends naturally towards the neat parterres of a sweet-smelling garden. An arc of white gravel serves as a drive, with long lines of equally white picket fence bordering the acreage in typical colonial style. Indeed, were it not for the unusual height of this perimeter, and the shelters abutting it at regular intervals — armed guards no doubt stationed in each — it would appear much as any other estate. You consider your plan of entry.
You finally have your hands on the Prosperity contract! Now there's a chance of clearing your father's name, and in doing so, preventing the outbreak of war between Isabel Sarmento and the Queen.
A Royal Progress

It is no coincidence that the trail of roses left in Her Majesty's wake has ended in this pretty continental town. But what could have caused her to cross a narrow sea, poppy-flecked fields, and mythical river valleys? She has not simply waltzed over for the ambience — this is the heartland of her maternal family line, and she is here with a purpose.
She's a Queen, there must be a sign of her somewhere...

A nearby castle or country residence — of course! "Eliminate all other factors, and what remains is the truth," as the sleuths say — the Queen would never be content to stay in town. Calculating you are no more than two days behind the Queen's retinue, you're able to draw a circle on a map that encompasses only a handful of suitably regal stopovers. It is now but a question of exactly which of her landed relatives she came here to visit...
Use your knowledge of the royal family to make a guess

Your familiarity with the Teutonic dynasties stands you in good stead. Whispers at home are growing ever louder on the subject of the Queen's suitors, and her cousin Ernest seems to be one of the front-runners. You visit the outspoken prince consort at his ivy-clad burg, and having presented a letter Sir Archibald gave you, he nods and leads you through its low, rib-vaulted ceilings, past gilt-candelabras and canvas portraits. Though cordial, Prince Ernest seems a little twitchy.

You realise you've made the wrong choice from the moment you walk into the parlour. The Duchess, who is of middle-age, lies half-asleep in a four-posted bed, which from her dishevelled appearance it seems she has not left in days. "Excuse my zurprise," she croaks, "But a Queen, come here? When our zide of the family has been neglected for years?" She feigns a tortured expression. "But now we have darling visitors!" Anxious not to offend, you remain in her company until she eventually tires of her games. She lets slip the Queen is visiting her cousin, Prince Ernest. Following a lengthy trip, the Prince offers you a cordial welcome at his ivy-clad castle, but appears twitchy throughout.
Try to read his thoughts through his twitches

"From your movements, I sense that you too are worried for her welfare." The subtlety of your deduction surprises Prince Ernest. He nods silently, and falls heavily into the ornate chair behind his desk. "She asked me to help trace our shared lineage — to establish the validity of certain claims she thinks she has through her ancestral ties to La Corona." Ernest pauses and crunches nervously on some recently-acquired shortbread. "She had wanted to do it alone for once. But she's taking a great risk, and I have now decided you must go after her. There is to be a masked ball in Monégasque. You will find her there.

Your strange deduction offends Prince Ernest. "From your movements, I sense this is a matter of the heart," is what you'd said, only for Prince Ernest to turn his back on you gothically, shouting — "How dare you! Prying into her personal affairs, as they all did during the crushing confines of her youth!" — before storming into the gardens to sulk. The next day, the Prince seems only very slightly calmer. "She asked me to help trace our family tree. That is all. I will not stop you going after her, in spite of your impertinence — but only because I am concerned for her welfare. There is to be a masked ball in Monégasque. You will find her there."

You can't imagine where she would have stayed in this town, pretty as it may be. You leave and take the road south, stopping beside an orchard to rest. Your knowledge of the local dialect is passable enough to overhear a couple of fruit-pickers talking about a recent distinguished visitor. Curious, you ask them if they are referring to your Queen, at which they fall silent. It seems they've been sworn to secrecy.
Gently encourage them to give up all they know

Your authoritative presence unsettles them into confessing what they know, which frankly, being fruit-pickers, isn't that much more than you. One thing they have heard is that the Queen will be staying in luxury with family — a country residence, or castle with pointy tourelles, no doubt. It is now but a question of exactly which of her landed relatives she came here to visit...

The fruit-pickers don't believe you are who you threaten to be, and if anything, your surly attitude makes them wonder if you're the one the Queen has been running away from. They call out to the rest of the pickers, who stand shoulder-to-shoulder with them in case you should think of taking things any further. Turning miserably back to your carriage in the road, it's only after considerable soul-searching that you re-read Sir Archibald's briefing, "despite her secrecy, a Queen never travels humbly." Of course — how stupid! The Queen must be in one of the countless castles that dominate the hills all around. It's now but a question of exactly which of her landed relatives she came here to visit...
Offer them a suitably regal incentive for the information
If you want to bribe us, it had better be with all the wonders of the high life!

They accept your offer. "She stay with family — at ze castle!" You are astonished to learn that the Queen dragged her skirts through the mud of the orchard, insisting that all her finely-dressed footmen should be fed and watered, and that no-one should know that she or her retinue were there. One of the pickers you bribed laughs, emulating her speech, "I hope you don't zink me too bohemian a Monarch." His friend reminds him with a sharp nudge that mocking the Queen might not be the best idea. It is now just a question of exactly which of her landed relatives she came here to visit...

They refuse. Clearly the fear of divine retribution against those who defy royalty is too strong. They call out to the rest of the pickers, who stand shoulder-to-shoulder with them in case you should want to take things any further. You turn miserably back to the carriage in the road, and it is only after hours of hopeful meandering in this beautiful country that you recall Sir Archibald's briefing: "Despite her secrecy, a Queen never travels humbly." Of course — how stupid! The Queen must be in one of the countless castles that dominate the hills all around. It's now just a question of exactly which of her landed relatives she came here to visit...
Ask a respectable-looking local if they've seen a fugitive Queen...

They don't take much convincing to tell you what they know, especially when you seem so sympathetic to the challenges of peasant life. "Passing foreign queens expect your silence for nothing, and yet it is you who must die in the fields for your masters when the harvest has failed." They grumble in recognition, noting that the Queen considered the town to be beneath her, and went off to stay in a nearby castle. It's now just a question of exactly which of her landed relatives she came here to visit...

The locals are stubborn in their silence. The Queen is a relative of those who own the land they work, and they fear for their livelihoods. However, there are further confirmations that the Queen has passed through, which leads you to the unlikely environs of a cider orchard. Two likely-looking pickers stand at the gate, both unable to disguise that they have recently met royalty — or that they have promised to say nothing about it.
Use deduction to discern which royal the Queen is visiting

You sneak upon proof it is her cousin Ernest she is visiting. While the Prince's welcome is polite, his stiffness of manner alerts your suspicions. When, after tea, he gives you the freedom of the ivy-clad castle, you waste no time seeking signs she was there. You find paper on the desk in a guest bedroom impressed with quill-marks, and make a rubbing. A letter from the Queen to her handmaid! It largely concerns itself with Ernest's handsome looks.When you raise the subject with Prince Ernest, he becomes rather twitchy.

You are led a merry dance. It transpires the Queen has made several visits to family in the region, staying very briefly at each estate before being driven on to the next with her modest retinue. You try to puzzle the ultimate purpose of this, but can deduce nothing, and are instead left to visit each house in a process of elimination before you arrive exhausted at the ivy-clad castle of Consort Prince Ernest. His nervous disposition suggests he knows the Queen's intentions in visiting.
Tell him that your only wish is to help the Queen

"Very well", agrees the Prince, once your persuasive speech has come to an end, "My dear cousin asked me to help trace our shared lineage — and to establish the validity of certain claims she believes she has through ancestral ties to La Corona." He removes a map of the continent from his neatly-arranged bureau. "Your diplomatic immunity may prove important in the days ahead. What she plans may put her at risk." He sighs. "There is to be a masked ball in Monégasque. You will find her there."

You have lost some face in royal circles. "I shall tell you nothing, nothing!" Prince Ernest says curtly, exhausted by your chatter, "Yet another interloper prying into her personal affairs, as so many did during the crushing confines of her youth!" The Queen's cousin then storms into the gardens to sulk. The next day, he seems only very slightly calmer. "She asked me to help trace our family tree. That is all. I will not stop you going after her, in spite of your impertinence — but only because I am concerned for her welfare. There is to be a masked ball in Monégasque. You will find her there."
Bribe
Cancel
Masquerade at Monégasque

Following Prince Ernest's advice, you travel by train along the sparkling Côte Turquoise to a grand station in the sophisticated principality of Monégasque. Ruled for six centuries by the Piedmont family, today the streets of Monégasque are filled with colour and light, for it is the grand opening of its very first casino! The theme is animal masquerade, and you see disturbing furred and feathered costumes at every turn. Convenient for a Queen going incognito... Prince Ernest gave you his own invitation to the casino — but you'll also need a costume.
Splash out on a fancy costume
The costumier waits, hands on hips, her face pale and smooth with crème céleste.
Accept
Cancel

You can't help but feel you paid rather a lot for the last-minute tailoring, which in fairness the costumier hammers out with astonishing calm. You get changed and observe the result in the long mirror — what you see is reminiscent of Alice's cheshire cat, or better, that pussycat famously employed to fetch royal mice. You meow past the casino doormen, and once inside, debate your best bet for finding the Queen.
The costumier turns up her lips in disgust. It seems you can't afford to pay the going rate for a last-minute costume, so you'll have to meet the casino dress code in some other way.
Try to mingle with high society

Your knowledge of royalty does not desert you. In a circle of the most elegantly-dressed people, you spy a beautiful sequined elephant, in whose hand is a foul mixture of claret and malt whisky — the Queen's favourite. Your eyes meet, and hers widen. She drops her glass, and there are gasps as she rushes for the exit. By the time you've forced your way outside, her carriage has set off at speed. You wave another cab down, and get in.

You can't tell anyone here apart — as far as you're concerned, they might as well all be princes, queens and kings! Suddenly a silence falls over the room, and the Prince of Monégasque himself — a man with an improbably thin moustache — makes a long speech about how the casino will bring back the good times for the Piedmont family. "And finally, I notice we have a special guest." he smiles, at which a sequined elephant promptly rushes for the door, "Oh, your majesty, wait!!" But by the time you've forced your way outside, her carriage has set off at speed. You wave another cab down, and get in.
See if you can find her at the gaming tables

Your luck does not desert you, and soon among those drawn to your blessed table, you spy a beautiful sequined elephant. Your eyes meet, and hers widen. She must recognise you! There are gasps as she rushes for the exit. By the time you've forced your way outside, her carriage has set off at speed. You wave another cab down, and get in.

Your luck is dreadful, and you are so preoccupied with the roulette wheel, you fail to notice that your Queen is indeed present. Suddenly a silence falls, and the Prince of Monégasque himself — a man with an improbably thin moustache — makes a long speech about how the casino will bring back the good times for the Piedmont family. "And finally, I notice we have a special guest." he smiles, at which a sequined elephant promptly rushes for the door, "Oh, your majesty, wait!!" But by the time you've forced your way outside, her carriage has set off at speed. You wave another cab down, and get in.
Make a costume of your own

Cunning and resourceful, you acquire and combine every accoutrement needed to give you the appearance of a fox. Twirling your catgut whiskers and dashing up the marble steps, you brush slyly past the casino doormen, and once inside, debate your best bet for finding the Queen.

A shambolic cow costume! You could barely have come up with anything less voguish. The doormen are too serious to laugh, and instead escort you to one side, "This is a society event! It doesn't matter who you are, you can't come in dressed like that!" If you're going to get in and find the Queen, you'll have to settle for a less fashionable route.
Shamelessly walk in without a costume

A few heads turn, but the doormen don't stop you. "I'm a special guest of the Piedmont family," you say with a winning smile, as you brandish the invitation Prince Ernest gave you, "expected to donate great sums to the cause. So you'll forgive my choice of attire." One of the doormen hands you a black eye mask, which you put on, reserved no doubt for exceptional circumstances such as this. Once inside the casino, you debate your best bet for finding the Queen.

It seems they will make no exceptions. "This is a society event," says the doorman in exasperation, "it doesn't matter who you are, you can't come in dressed like that!" If you are going to get in and find the Queen, you'll have to settle for a less fashionable route.
Find a sneaky way in

You show off your powers of mystery. As you stalk around to the promenade behind the casino, you're hit by a warm riviera breeze and the sight of exotic palms. There's a bathroom window open up above. The stucco holds as you shimmy up unseen, swinging your legs over the threshold. Finally inside the casino, you debate your best bet for finding the Queen.

Not as stealthy as you'd imagined. As you stalk around to the promenade behind the casino, you're hit by a warm riviera breeze and the sight of exotic palms. You scale the wall without incident, but then accidentally trip through a skylight. You crunch onto the rug of a guest bedroom in a rain of shattered crystal. Luckily, the guest is downstairs playing craps, and will not discover this mess until much later. Trying to summon whatever remaining grace you have, you make your way inside the casino and debate your best bet for finding the Queen.
Go round the back and force your way in

You show your strength. As you stalk around to the promenade behind the casino, you're hit by a warm riviera breeze and the sight of exotic palms. The doorman on this side looks feeble. You walk up to him and pop him on the nose, taking his plain black eye mask for yourself before sauntering into the casino. Once inside, you debate your best bet for finding the Queen.

Unfortunately, it's a pretty even contest. As you stalk around to the promenade behind the casino, you're hit by a warm riviera breeze and the sight of exotic palms. The doorman on this side looks muscular, at least compared to you. You take a swing at him, catching him by surprise, but he comes back hard, and a scuffle develops. "I yield," he says finally. Dusting yourself off, you take his plain black eye mask to cover your black eyes and bloody nose, and shamble into the casino. Once inside, you debate your best bet for finding the Queen.
Offer the doormen a donation towards the casino
"Oh, so you wish to make a significant donation to the Piedmont family?" says the doorman with a smirk.
Accept
Cancel
"Very well," agrees the doorman, "the Prince of Monégasque kindly accepts your donation, and wishes you a fine evening at his casino." Once inside, you debate your best bet for finding the Queen.

"No, no," one of the doormen shakes his head, "the Prince of Monégasque would not accept such a donation. I'm under strict instructions only to admit those in suitable costume." It seems you'll have to settle for a less fashionable route.
The Cape Of Trelawney

The Queen fled the casino at high speed, and your own carriage is some distance behind. Your driver thinks she's headed up the coast, perhaps to a ship. You can either keep up your pursuit, or else rush to your own ship, which, if the orders you gave to the captain have been followed, should be waiting in the Monégasque marina.
Continue the pursuit

You reach the next bay up from Monégasque, and hopping out of your carriage, see the Queen bustling along a jetty at which a great flagship dubbed "Lap of Victory" is moored. Obviously she has them primed for such an emergency, as they all seem ready to go. You can try to call out to the Queen, or else borrow a vessel to continue your pursuit.
Call out to her

You comport yourself with dignity, "Your Majesty, please, I'm not here to seize you, but to assist you in any way I am able!" The short rotund figure turns, dresses in hand, and a small but shrill voice floats back towards you over the sound of the sea. "Meet me at the Cape of Trelawney!" You find your own ship at the marina, and sail to Trelawney, the southernmost point of the Old World. It was not fifteen years previous that a great naval victory was won here over La Corona by one Admiral Nadasky. The Lap of Victory is there waiting for you, and the Queen receives you warmly aboard. You are finally able to ask her why it is that she has run away.

You cannot keep the irritation out of your voice, "Your Majesty, please, desist from this charade!" The short rotund figure turns, dresses in hand, and a small but defiant voice cuts the sound of the sea. "I am not a child, I am your Queen! Be at the Cape of Trelawney tomorrow, or else." You slink off to find your ship at the marina and head for Trelawney, the southernmost point of the Old World, where not fifteen years previous, a great naval victory was won over La Corona by the heroic Admiral Nadasky. The Lap of Victory is there waiting for you, and the Queen receives you rather icily aboard. With a gulp, you are finally able to ask why it is that she has run away.
Commandeer a nearby vessel

"Your helmsmanship is most impressive!" the Queen calls down to you as you bring the modest sailing ship you have borrowed neatly alongside her flagship."Meet me tomorrow at the Cape of Trelawney!" You find your own ship at the marina, and sail to Trelawney, the southernmost point of the Old World. It was not fifteen years previous that a great naval victory was won here over La Corona by one Admiral Nadasky. The Lap of Victory is there waiting for you, and the Queen receives you warmly aboard. You are finally able to ask why it is that she has run away.

"A limp effort!" the Queen bellows down at you as you bring the leaky fishing boat you have stolen alongside her gigantic flagship. Rather than leave you to flounder, she seems to have taken pity on you and slowed down."Meet me at the Cape of Trelawney, and good heavens, bring a proper vessel!" You slink off to find your ship at the marina and head for Trelawney, the southernmost point of the Old World where not fifteen years previous a great naval victory was won over La Corona by the heroic Admiral Nadasky. The Lap of Victory is there waiting for you, and the Queen receives you rather icily aboard. With a gulp, you are finally able to ask why it is that she has run away.
Get to your ship

Your ship is indeed waiting in the marina. Quickly, you rouse the captain and his crew, and weigh anchor. Before long, twinkling Monégasque is behind you, and from the next bay you spot an impressive ship in the distance. How was she able to leave port so fast? You either can continue to chase Her Majesty, or send her a message of peace with your signal lamp.
Stay in pursuit

"Your helmsmanship is most impressive!" the Queen calls over to you, as you bring your ship up alongside hers."Meet me at the Cape of Trelawney!"You point your ship towards Trelawney, the southernmost point of the Old World where not fifteen years previous a great naval victory was won over La Corona by the heroic Admiral Nadasky. The Lap of Victory is there waiting for you, and the Queen receives you warmly aboard. You are finally able to ask why it is that she has run away.

"A limp effort!" the Queen bellows over at you, as you struggle to bring your ship alongside the gigantic flagship. You would never have caught her had she not taken pity on you and slowed down."You'd better meet me at the Cape of Trelawney, if indeed, you are capable!" Slightly hurt, you point your ship towards Trelawney, the southernmost point of the Old World where not fifteen years previous a great naval victory was won over La Corona by the heroic Admiral Nadasky. The Lap of Victory is there waiting for you, and the Queen receives you rather icily aboard. With a gulp, you are finally able to ask why it is that she has run away.
Send her a message

The Queen takes the time to answer. You flashed "ONLY DESIRE TO HELP MAJESTY" with the Columb light, and received "FOLLOW US!" in reply. You are travelling towards Trelawney, the southernmost point of the Old World where not fifteen years previous a great naval victory was won over La Corona by the heroic Admiral Nadasky. The Lap of Victory is there waiting for you, and the Queen receives you warmly aboard. You are finally able to ask why it is that she has run away.

You receive no answer. Looking at your message again, it does seem a little abrupt – "STOP IN THE NAME OF SIR ARCHIBALD!" You pursue at a great distance towards Trelawney, the southernmost point of the Old World where not fifteen years previous a great naval victory was won over La Corona by the heroic Admiral Nadasky. The Lap of Victory slows to a halt, and the Queen receives you rather icily aboard. With a gulp, you are finally able to ask why it is that she has run away.
A Blizzard At Baffling Island

The first severe blizzard. You've only just caught sight of the Baffling Island littoral, when the headwind suddenly whips up and a dark fringe of cloud appears in the heavens. All take cover below deck, as rock-hard pellets of ice begin striking the ship with such force as to cause lasting damage. There must be something that can be done to protect the ship, but it'd take a hero to go back out into that.

The first severe blizzard. You've only just caught sight of the Baffling Island littoral when the headwind suddenly whips up, and a dark fringe of cloud appears in the heavens. All take cover below deck, as rock-hard pellets of ice begin to pelt the ship with such force as to cause lasting damage. "We've lost control of her," screams the navigator, but it'd take a hero to go back out into that.
Send your best to take down the sails

Several worthy heroes step forward. "We'll do whatever it takes for this crew and this ship," says the burliest of them, before striding out into the storm. Undeterred by the howl and buffeting of the wind, they manage to put the sails 'in their gear' — loosing the sheetlines, and pulling the buntlines through, until the ship is safely running under jib alone. When the storm passes, the crew are delighted that thanks to these mighty efforts, the ship has come through unscathed.

Not easy handling sails at minus thirty, and while those brave enough to take on the ice storm are strong enough, their labour is clumsy. As the snowblasted sails are loosened, your men allow them to catch a crosswind and suddenly they are off! Flapping wildly against a creaking mainmast, the sails are threatening to rip half the ship away.

Twang! The sails flap away into dark drifts of snow. Your able-footed sailor reaches every rope without slipping, the snowflakes crowding his eyes unable to prevent the skillful execution of his art. When the sun rises the next day, the Arctic sky is still once more. "The mast is intact, and we've spare rope and sail," says the carpenter, "we'll be all right."

Your men cannot keep their footing for the ice on deck, and the hard rocking of the ship gives them further excuse to lower their swords. They can only watch as, under the pull of the sails, the mainmast cracks open like grissini, the upper section cartwheeling out to sea, a tangle of rigging behind it. The crew are all accounted for, but the damage to the ship is probably irreparable.
Cut the ropes holding the sails
Let the blizzard do its worst

The mainmast takes much of the brunt, whipped and contorted in every direction by the impassioned sails. When the storm and seizures finally end, the carpenter tallies the cost of your inaction. "There's fissures in the mast. It may hold with enough resin... but then again, maybe not..."

A bunch of wet lettuces. They claim that the rigging is too slippery to grip. If these are your best sailors, Lord help the others, but those sails must come down — the ship is being blown towards some jagged silhouette! You can grab something to aid their climb or get them up there quick.
Risk finding a climbing aid

At least no-one dies. The crew raid stores for ropes and chains so as to climb the rigging safely, before stowing the sails away. The ship slows, but does not completely halt, colliding with that silhouette — a small and craggy island — and damaging the hull. The crew have some lengthy repairs ahead of them.

A disaster of their own fashioning. Instead of finding a proper solution, the crew hurriedly don standard-issue gloves. The leather is so smooth in the palm, it is worse than climbing with no gloves at all. The ship lurches inexorably into that silhouette— a hideously craggy isle — and the impact flings the gripless riggers into the water. Visibility is so poor, and the water so cold, that there's no hope of saving those who fell overboard.
Order the cowards up that mast, quick!

Filled with doubt, they do as instructed. The conditions are dreadful, and they can barely see to work in the sideways slather, what with the waves buffeting the ship. A man falls from the upper rigging, and is found to be only loosely intact. "What are you trying to prove?!" bellows the navigator above the whine of the wind. Finally, the sails are put up and the boat can ride out the remainder of the storm without blowing off course. Your crew are incensed at the coldness of their superiors.
Stay inside and pray

Faith and prudence. Your sailors huddle below, rocked hard, but out of harm's way. They resist the temptation to attend to the creaking ship and its rudder, and instead trust their course to the divine. Soon the grog is flowing, with sailors playing cribbage, and all forget where they are. "Hold! I hear no storm!" a sailor says suddenly. The hatch is opened to reveal stillness and stars, and a harlequin snake of an aurora, smiling down benevolent.

Your sailors will not wait for God. The storm shrieks its name, as sailors muttered frenzied supplications to the nameless. "To hell and damn you all, I want to die living!" the others bellow at them, and so unchained, they rush out into the white. Harsh commands can be heard above, before those voices fall silent. Somehow the ship rides out the storm, but the bodies of your saviours are never found.
Save the propellers from the ice

You have a hardy legion indeed. They rush to the tarpaulins, and with commendable teamwork and physical strength in the challenging conditions, are able to pull them over the ship's most sensitive instruments and machinery. Heading below deck to relax, the heroes wait out the storm in luxury with buttered currant buns and hot tea.

Their defence of the ship is a little half-hearted. Initially the men show willing, but the blizzard quickly wears them down, and they retreat inside claiming that their work is done. After the worst of it has passed, the officers survey the ship. Beneath a poorly affixed and feeble tarpaulin, the engine is found flooded with slush that must now be cleared. One has to wonder if they are cut out for these kinds of challenges.

Tragic youthful over-exuberance. Your sailors drain a bottle of strong rum before going back out, perhaps believing machismo will keep them warm. They batten the hatches in the white flurry, stumbling, belching and laughing. The hilarity continues when one of the lads slips and loses his feet — that is, until the steel rim of the funnel meets his head with a clomp. He dies instantly.
Send an expert diver to unclog the propellers of ice

The thrill-seeking diver relishes the task. Covering themselves in bear fat and brandishing a sharp pick, they enter the water without a splash, resurfacing no more than five minutes later to the embrace of a pre-warmed towel. "All clear!" your diver says. Cheers go up below at the sound of the engines at full power once more.
Baffling Island
Resume the expedition under clearer skies...

"Sir!" cries the lookout, "Dark shapes on the ridge!" A group climb the icy escarpment. At the top they find a companionable trio of driftwood boards plugged into three man-sized heaps of snow. Sunlight hits the scritchings in the wood: "Sacred to the memory of Joseph Braine, who departed this life New Year's Day 1846 on board of H.M. Styx." The others named are "John Gore" and "Francis Seeley." Your men tremble at the idea of disturbing the graves.
Baffling Island
Dig up the graves, no matter the crew's fears

The crew agree to draw lots. A scrawny man gets the shovel, and clears the snow to reveal Braine's face, who might look asleep but for his skin of leather. In his pocket, there is a letter to his wife.
"Dearest Elaine,
I've few breaths left. I die never having found the Passage — but then, no glory awaits any servant of Sir John. He was certain the ice would not thicken around us in the spring. The fate of the expedition now rests on circumnavigation of Terrier Island by short, perilous west shore, or by long, open east channel. I fear I know what Sir John will prefer.
Farewell, my Elaine."
Search around the graves instead

A mere hundred metres from the graves, the men discover the remains of a camp at which the lost expedition wintered. They built a cairn — a small stack of stones — under which a tin cylinder containing a tightly-rolled letter is found. "They left a note of their progress," says the Captain. Lady Faithful recognises her husband's writing immediately.
"May 28th, 1847 { H.M. ships 'Styx' and 'Hades' wintered in the ice lat. 70˚ 05' N; long. 98˚ 23' W. Previously wintered in 1846-7 at Baffling Island, lat. 74˚ 43' 28" N; long. 91˚ 39' 15" W, after having sailed Wailing Channel to lat. 77˚, and returned by the west side of Cornell Island. Total loss by deaths to date: 3 men due to sickness — Braine, Gore and Seeley, God rest their souls. Leaving tomorrow for Terrier Island. Aim to reach Passage by end of June; we must be close now. John Faithful, Commander, HMS Styx."
Circle the island along the west coast
Circle the island along the east coast
The ship is now headed for the west coast of Terrier Island. The crew hope to find Sir John and his men soon, and pray no more obstacles will be thrown in their way.
The ship is now headed for the east coast of Terrier Island. The crew hope to find Sir John and his men soon, and pray no more obstacles will be thrown in their way.
Over The Ice To Huddlesome Bay

As you near the coast, a large human construction delineates itself, "Most probably an abandoned trading post of the Huddlesome Bay company." It leans hard into the wind, its once red boards now scoured pale. If Sir John and his crew came this way, they would likely have stopped here. "How are we going to get there, sir?" says the ship's boy. He has noticed that an ice sheet lies between your ship and the trading post.
Take the safest route by avoiding the cracks

Your crew's instincts are solid. Keeping just the right distance apart, they move at a purposeful speed, avoiding the cracks and dark splodges indicative of thinner ice. They reach the abandoned building without incident.

Their knowledge is shaky. One of your groups avoids the gaping holes, but fails to notice the darker patches of thin ice. Cracking can be heard, but none of the group dare move. They hit the water with a woosh as the brûlée snaps. It is freezing, and they'll struggle to climb out on their own. If not rescued quickly, they'll die of hypothermia.
Haul the sailors out with a rope

The rope team keep balance. Lying down, and spreading out to distribute their weight, they throw ropes to those in the water, who thrash to bind themselves under their armpits. On a count of three, they are hoisted clear of the water. Wet and chattering with cold, your expedition takes refuge in the old trading post.

Forget strength, what they needed was teamwork. The rope team disregard their own safety and pull as they would on dry land. The ice was never going to hold, and it soon collapses beneath them. Some manage to crawl free of the water and save themselves, but others slip away to fertilise the ocean bed. The survivors trudge for the thin comforts of the disused trading post.
Offer some words of encouragement

They make it. They're okay! The survivors are cheered across the line in a spirit akin to the finish of a cross-country race at school back home. Nobody left behind then, and nobody left behind now. Wet and chattering with cold, your expedition takes refuge in the abandoned building, offering up prayers of gratitude.

To those in the water the encouragement sounds noticeably strained. Convulsing as they slip down between part-frozen cuboids, their resolve fades with the voices, the light above ever more distant. Knowing they could have done more, the survivors trudge on for the thin comforts of the disused trading post.
Measure the thickness of the ice

The ship's carpenters improvise with a rotary drill. It takes a fair bit of effort to get it turning, suggesting the ice is pretty solid. The first measurement is 11 inches — no hazard even for a sizeable group to pass over. Every few steps a new reading is taken, but it proves a mere formality, since the readings change very little. They make the abandoned building without incident.

It was never going to work, using a heavy, blunt instrument to make the hole. Lucky as it happens that the carpenter is alone when his sledgehammer comes down, as it sunders the ice all about him and casts him into the freezing water. Turns out the ice is fairly thick, but that won't save the poor fellow now. The others trudge on for the thin comforts of the disused trading post in disbelief.
Risk walking over it

The inevitable splosh. Despite the cold wind, it is still summer in the Arctic, and the weight of a large group of bodies would test thicker ice than this. Halfway across the sheet, there is a rasping crack, and your men are deposited into the water. In their struggle to escape they have to kick off their snow boots. Chattering, they make it to the thin comfort of the abandoned trading post with their feet in a terrible state.
Huddlesome Bay
At the abandoned trading post...

"At least it's a shelter," the Captain remarks. The men shut the doors on the wind, to find the building interior licked with frost. Rusted hooks hang from the beams, relics of the short-lived fur trade. "Comforts are few and far between out here. I doubt Sir John would have passed it by." There must be some evidence of the lost expedition here.
Huddlesome Bay Trading Post
Search for signs of recent use

No sign at all. Undisturbed in ten years or more, these cabins are just as they were when the traders left. There should be prints in the dust, objects out of place, but there aren't. Everyone concedes it is very unlikely Sir John's expedition came this way.
Find information about the local area

Something to go on at least. Whoever the fur traders were, they left in a rush. Papers and maps are strewn about, some trodden and sodden into mush, a precious few dry and intact. Dockets are found relating to consignments received from a nearby Inuit settlement named Ivujivik, which also happens to be marked on a fragment of map. "The Inuit are sure to have noticed anyone passing through," says the Captain, "we should visit them."
Go back and head west to Baffling Island
The crew return to the ship. Once at Tchilling Sound, they head west.
Continue south toward the Inuit settlement of Ivujivik
The crew mark the position of the Inuit settlement of Ivujivik on the map, and set sail.
Ivujivik
An Arctic Welcome

It is late summer when the expedition reaches the Tchilling Sound, and yet the conditions in these icy seas are already challenging. The wind only has to pick up, and the men are tugging up their collars and tramping below deck. It seems hopeless to think Sir John Faithful's men could have lasted three winters here. Beyond Tchilling Sound, the seaway divides. To the west lies a chain of small islands separated by partially melted ice. To the south: a long, dark headland crowned with snow that hazes out of sight.
Go West
Go South
Nanuk's Way

The route to the Inuit settlement of Ivujivik is a two day trek by foot across exposed ice flats. A small expedition party set off, leaving the rest at sea to await their return.
Although the going is tough, it is not that which preoccupies the crew. As night falls, they are sure something has been following them.
Stop for the night and keep watch

Your sharp-eared watchman keeps vigil. In the small dark of the Arctic summer, he catches the scratch of a bear's unretractable claws on ice. It is trying to approach discretely, but the watchman is ready. At the sound of his gun the rest wake with a jolt, only to find a big dead bear at his feet. They celebrate their trophy, and are soon back en route to Ivujivik.

A mother polar bear! Your watchman isn't used to such long days, struggling to keep his eyes open beside the hypnotic fire. A loud growl. Mother bear digs her claws deep into his spine and drags him away. Moments later, she is back for more!
Organise and defend yourselves

Years of ambush drills pay off. Quickly forming a circle, your men level their guns into the half-light. Sensing the danger they pose, mama bear grows more cautiously, and after a single circuit of your camp, disappears out of sight.
Full of adrenaline, your scout party reach the Inuit camp.

Hands trembling with fear, the men grab for their rifles, but mama bear smells their nerves and is upon them. Finally, someone gets a shot away, and though it misses, it scares her momentarily. Her white coat is lank with the blood of several men. Those still standing flee. The Inuit are startled when your party arrive at Ivujivik the next afternoon looking especially bedraggled.
Use cunning to trick the bear

Your men know they have to stand tall to face down a polar bear, and waving their coats above their heads like flags, they succeed in driving the bear away. Full of adrenaline, your scout party reach the Inuit camp.

Mama bear looks angry. Your men had assumed that staring might make her back down, but she has taken it as a display of aggression. Her white coat is soon lank with the blood of several men. Those still standing flee. The Inuit are startled when your party arrive at Ivujivik the next afternoon looking especially bedraggled.
Continue to walk despite being cold and exhausted

The men are strong and dedicated. They tramp through the half hour of pitch-black darkness normally reserved for sleep, keeping good pace. Whatever was following them has soon given up. Gazing upwards, the party find themselves to be lucky observers of the aurora borealis.
They reach the Inuit settlement the following lunchtime with a sense of wonder.

One of the men struggles to keep up with his unsympathetic comrades. He is the runt, the weakest of the pack, and the polar bear knows it. The rest of the group hear a piercing scream, followed by the sound of crunching and tearing. Moments later mama bear is bounding across the snow towards them, hungry for more!
Ivujivik
At the Inuit settlement...

Ivujivik is a semi-permanent settlement. The Inuit appear worried, but nevertheless offer your men every hospitality, inviting them into a large iglu where they are served a hearty Suaasat— a meat stew— under the silent gaze of what feels like the whole village. A girl, Tapeesa, is able to translate, and the others warm up when they hear the story of your journey over the ice flats. Soon the subject turns to Sir John's lost expedition. Tapeesa shows you items that look like they belonged to the missing men.
Offer to trade for the relics
They were strange men. Who doesn't want to eat when they've been out in the cold...?
Accept Trade
Decline, and ask how they got them.

Silver cutlery embossed with the names Hades and Styx. These are from Sir John's expedition ships! There are also cufflinks belonging to Sir John engraved with assorted marsupials, and a knife handle with the emblem of the Arctic council. Tapeesa says that about a year ago, some men came wanting to know about channels through the ice, and traded their things for information. She points to the west coast of Terrier Island on your map.
Ask how they got hold of them

Tapeesa patiently explains that they traded with men like yours about a year ago. The men wanted to know about channels through the ice, and traded their things for information. She points to the west coast of Terrier Island on your map.
Stranded Off Terrier Island

Your ship is stranded on an iceberg! It is night along the east coast of Terrier Island. The meek light of your vessel seems to dissolve into the moonless blackness. Even at easy sail and under constant vigil, your ship runs the risk here, for slumbering ice giants leer from the darkness in all directions. "Dead ahead!" comes the cry, but it's too late! A low growl shakes the boat, as a wave dumps it atop a iceberg — in the shape of an upturned molar — beaching it there. The ship is undamaged, if only it could be returned to the water...
Terrier Island (East)
Break free with dynamite

Nothing in nature can prevail against human endeavour, it would seem. The crew watch with trepidation as the fuses burn down to the stick, before an ear-splitting series of detonations rings across the vastness, sundering the icy claws that had held your ship hostage. A small blizzard of debris blankets the deck, to the delight of all aboard, for they are free once more!
Bombard the icy prison

Ice crumbles around such firepower. Any cannon that can be swiveled at the target is put to use, chipping away at the icy dungeon in which the ship has become wedged, until the vessel breaks free. Like a cheerful sea lion, the fair vessel slips down an escarpment and plops back into the water. The crew cheer and continue on their way.

The iceberg fights back. Though the way is almost clear, the relentless cannonfire seems to have woken the ogre below, and to the horror of the crew the vast iceberg rolls slightly to one side. Great shards of ice detach and bounce over the deck, injuring your men. Quick action is needed.
Get out and push the ship free

Your men live for such challenges, and scarcely need telling what to do. Leaping down from the boat, they get behind her, knotting guy ropes as fast as they can. The iceberg still rumbles ominously, but it is your quick-thinking crew who prevail. Once clear of the ice field, the crew will be able to treat their wounds.

It's an uphill struggle. The pitching of the unstable iceberg does not help one jot, as the men tumble and slide as they struggle to find their grip. Such is the effort required to pull the ship successfully down from the iceberg into the sea, no-one notices that one of the teams is missing. It appears they have fallen through a thin part of the ice to their deaths.
Let the rolling iceberg toss you into the sea.

Your ship performs a rather messy dismount. After its initial roll, the iceberg halts long enough to suggest it wants to stay in its new position — but then everything happens all at once. The iceberg spins violently, and the ship with it! The ship strikes the water at such an angle that serious damage is done to much of the lee-side. Fortunately, the crew emerge unharmed.
Build something to help you escape

The crew assembles a dozen hardy levers to free the ship. Flexible hickory planking is cut and reshaped into wedges, before being inserted into the ice at intervals of five paces, until they surround the stern. On a count of three the men lift — and to their surprise, so does the hull! Once it starts moving, there's no stopping it, and it clatters through all icy obstructions to the sea. Your sailors embrace — they have been very resourceful.

The wrong wood is selected for the task. It is a decorative mahogany veneer, stripped from the Captain's cabin. "Whatever it takes," the Captain says with laudable magnanimity, but the whole business is futile. Despite the wedges being placed in great number at the stern of the ship, no amount of pressure from the crew can encourage the ship to move, since the levers lack the requisite spring. They'll need to find another way off this iceberg.
Search for Sir John along the east coast

Free of the iceberg, the crew manage to circumvent Terrier Island via its easterly shore. However, they have found no trace of the lost expedition. You'll have to try the west coast, next.
Sir John must have taken the risky option.
The Narrows

The west coast of Terrier Island is snaggled up with monstrous horns of ice. Navigation is going to be tricky. Will the narrows lead back once more to open water, or will your ship end up stuck? You can navigate carefully, get a better view of the channels from a nearby rock, or send scouts ahead in rowboats to see.
Terrier Island (West)
Find a path through the narrows

To their relief, your crew reach the open sea on the other side. As there is a lack of consensus on magnetic north at this time, your navigators decide to ignore the compasses and trust their instincts, saving them a collision on more than one occasion.

The crew enters King William Sound, a majestic carpet of water leading up to its seat, King William Island. Sensing something, Lady Faithful suddenly emerges from below deck, and voices the determined hopes of her heart...

The compass readings are confusing. After several wrong turns, the crew realise magnetic north is not where they — or where anyone else imagined. Your ship finds itself alongside the run-off of a sizeable glacier, which, as it's spring, is melting. There are cracks, then an almighty rumble as the entire wall of ice threatens to separate and topple into the water!
Full sail ahead!
Full steam ahead!

Your crew escape! In mere moments, the masts are dropped almost horizontal to catch every last ounce of wind, giving you just, just enough extra speed to avoid the mountain of ice that comes crashing down into the channel. Waves from this rare natural event form a new avenue, leading out into the open sea.

The crew enters King William Sound, a majestic carpet of water leading up to its seat, King William Island. Sensing something, Lady Faithful suddenly emerges from below deck, and voices the determined hopes of her heart...

Your crew escape! The engine room takes the initiative ahead of the orders from the bridge and stoke the fires. The ship picks up just, just enough extra speed to avoid the mountain of ice crashing down into the channel. Waves from this rare natural event form a new avenue leading out to the open sea.

The crew enters King William Sound, a majestic carpet of water leading up to its seat, King William Island. Sensing something, Lady Faithful suddenly emerges from below deck, and voices the determined hopes of her heart...

Your navigators panic. Though the sails catch the breeze, the men fail to adjust course out from under the falling wall. Blocks of ice the size of cows tumble onto the deck and explode to powder. A death and several injuries result. The rest are lucky that large waves from the icefall form a new avenue leading out to the open sea.

The crew enters King William Sound, a majestic carpet of water leading up to its seat, King William Island. Sensing something, Lady Faithful suddenly emerges from below deck, and voices the determined hopes of her heart...

They are too close to the falling ice wall. Your engines are fired up but the resulting turn is not a sharp one. Blocks of ice the size of cows tumble onto the deck and explode to powder. A death and several injuries result. You are lucky that giant waves from the icefall form an avenue of escape out to the open sea.

The crew enters King William Sound, a majestic carpet of water leading up to its seat, King William Island. Sensing something, Lady Faithful suddenly emerges from below deck, and voices the determined hopes of her heart...
Brace for impact!

"Ha! Let it rain!" the captain bellows, as blocks of ice the size of cows tumble onto the deck and explode to powder. Your powerful vessel surges through to safety! Waves from the icefall form a new avenue leading out to the open sea.

The crew enters King William Sound, a majestic carpet of water leading up to its seat, King William Island. Sensing something, Lady Faithful suddenly emerges from below deck, and voices the determined hopes of her heart...

Your ship is no icebreaker. There are cries as blocks of ice the size of cows tumble onto the deck and explode to powder. A death and several injuries result. You are lucky that giant waves from the icefall form an avenue of escape out to the open sea.

The crew enters King William Sound, a majestic carpet of water leading up to its seat, King William Island. Sensing something, Lady Faithful suddenly emerges from below deck, and voices the determined hopes of her heart...
Send men up the slope for a better view

The men are used to hard climbs like these and are up in no time to survey the labyrinth ahead. They report back with an easy route forward that leads to open sea once more.

The crew enters King William Sound, a majestic carpet of water leading up to its seat, King William Island. Sensing something, Lady Faithful suddenly emerges from below deck, and voices the determined hopes of her heart...
Your men say the climb is too steep, or at least, no-one is daredevil enough to attempt it with the limited equipment they have. Everyone is exasperated. You must find another solution.
Send scouts ahead in rowboats to check

Follow the seals, that's the answer! Seals and more besides. From their rowboats your scouts are even able to follow a baleen whale as she surfaces for air. She leads them to open water, and your expedition ship follows.

The crew enters King William Sound, a majestic carpet of water leading up to its seat, King William Island. Sensing something, Lady Faithful suddenly emerges from below deck, and voices the determined hopes of her heart...

No-one returns with a definitive clue. "Ivory gulls were circling above what looks like a large glacier," says one, "it may lead us to open water..." It's the best you've got, but soon your ship finds itself alongside the run-off of a sizeable glacier, which it being spring, is melting. There are cracks, then there is an almighty rumble as the entire wall of ice threatens to separate and topple into the water!

This folder contains all pools used at the same time for trade pools, expedition pools and for quest reward pools. Please don't change them without keeping that in mind; Don't forget the item unlock; and don't include items that are supposed to be unique rewards for certain moments in the game. They are organized per rarity, per theme, and transversal pools for specific features are in "Additional Pools".

Archie always makes the most fuss over the smallest things…
Every time I ask Archie, I fear his insides combust.
The best thing is, dear old Archie never need know.
When a Queen asks you to do something…
I'm issuing you a royal decree.
I am the Queen after all.
Yes, I jolly well think you will accept.
Bon Voyage, as it is the fashion to say.
Well done, you have my tender affections!
I think we've both earned tea and a slice of sponge cake.
What a daring young one you are!
What gallantry! Though not quite worth a medal.
As reliable as my guards with the funny hats.
I was an obstinate child, and as such can empathise.
And there was I believing I'd found a loyal dachshund.
Need I tell you that you desert your nation!
Like my coronation, a farce from beginning to end.
My father would have had your head!
Don't be afraid to hurry, we are happy to wait!
Queens usually like things done quickly.
At least bring me some tea if nothing else!
You have served your Queen well, will you serve her again?
It is a trying time for the Empire, and we need you yet...
Your support is a comfort we would much like to continue.
Who could possibly be more important than your Queen?
I have not left the Palace in haste to be denied!
Have you succeeded in your mission?
Has my loyal subject returned?
I am told you may have something for me?
I'll call upon you, subject, if I need you.
There's nothing to keep you occupied here but my puppies.
Dear Archie has everything under control.
Oh do stop, Archie. Is this tiny fleet all I have to sink to get my island back?
Who are you, to speak up without permission?
So Edvard is the traitor! I certainly never authorised that silly-billy to act on my behalf. I declare the contract null and void.
Then I suppose we'll not be sinking any ships today. Not even as a deterrent?
Well in that case I hereby declare Prosperity returned to the Goode children—to compensate the dead father, thereby ensuring Miss Sarmento and co. are safe from this Pyrphorian nuisance.
What is that tinseled marionette talking about, Archie? We are safe here, aren't we?
Look at all those subjects! How enthusiastic they seem! Do you think they celebrate me, their royal highness?
And you are absolutely sure this Samuel Goode was innocent?
Let's heal it then, and be off.
My sincerest condolences, children of Samuel. For the loss of the father you loved, and for the tragedy caused by the unfortunate actions of your uncle.
For your unquestionable loyalty and bravery you shall be knighted, and bequeathed the island of Bright Sands from now and forevermore!
Hahaha... Forgive me, I always laugh at funerals!
But another tiresome prophet of doom, Archie. How dreary!
These rebels, whoever they are, will pay the penalty for challenging my sovereignty!
The time has come to take that territory back by force.
Funny, ending a war over a bit of paper!
I must admit, I am too fond of my sailors.
I understand this means the end of a rebellion on the island, very good.
So is it Isabel who is nice, or the Pyrphorians?
As long as we have Prosperity back, that business with your father can be forgotten.
So Edvard was the nasty one, and Samuel was the one with the dandruff?
Fancy forging a signature. People can be terrible, can't they?
I'm surprised that Isabel gave it back without a fight.
Once built, your Court of Justice shall inaugurate a new era of peace and prosperity for Empire.
This trial should be a celebration! A toast to all things civilised.
I don't normally attend trials so this one must be important.
You now own the highest court in the land!
The Court of Justice, magnificent!
Is the Court of Justice finished yet? Not quite?
I can't wait to play judge and give the gavel a sharp tap!
Did Archie tell you I planned to visit? I hope there's a convenient mooring for my flagship. I don't like long walks.
Treat me as you would any other guest.
Just so you know, I am not fond of garlic or profiteroles.
One approves! And it is nice to get out and about.
It all sounds very cheery so far. Make it cheerier.
Mind you, I do like it when things are special. You can do special?
May I express my gratitude for your sterling work preserving peace on the continent.
So this is the funny little island that's hosting the trial! Jolly good.
Now I'm here, I am of course impatient for the trial to begin.
A modern Queen must show she is able to dispense mercy. The man must be given fair hearing.
Where are all the witnesses?
Now we are finally all present, let this long overdue trial commence!
And where's the defendant?
This is all rather unusual. We are safe here?
This is unexpected. You are taking care of those beastly malefactors, aren't you?
A few angry hoodlums can't overthrow an Empire, can they?
I thought they must be after fame or riches, but they want to kill me.
I wonder what has become of the royal fleet…
Tell me they are not attacking this island? The one we are on?
I surrender myself wholly to your security arrangements.
I suppose then, my safety is in your hands.
When we get out of this I promise you a whole duchy. Although, no, I can't actually promise that.
We are so happy to be finally allowed to leave this island. And for your heroism of course.
Under different circumstances, you might have called it a pleasant visit!
I'm sure we can make Isabel's tiny little chunk a protectorate of some sort.
It makes one feel frisky and alive!
We ARE amused!
This suits us very well.
How wonderful to have it our own way!
How mischievous one feels!
It has all gone off very satisfactorily!
All is much as it should be.
Be strong in business, and become a pillar of our nation.
You continue to be of the greatest use to us.
Your successes must be a source of pride.
We appreciate your efforts.
Parliament commends you exceedingly.
You slide easily about the board like the rook!
You are a very able servant of the realm.
We are not amused!
The Queen regrets this distressing affair.
Another Queen may have turned to execution by now.
It is gravely injurious to our nation.
One wants prompt action against such outrage.
It is a time of discord for those of my station.
One of the many threats to my position.
The Queen finds your conduct inexcusable!
My father would have had you executed!
You WILL do better!
What a perilously selfish subject you are!
Your Queen is displeased with you.
Parliament will discuss what shall be done with you.
Tantamount to treason!
If it please an all-powerful deity to place me on the throne, it shall certainly please you...
I am your Queen. What further introduction is needed?
Have you met Nelson? Why he's a chestnut stallion with an Arabian head.
Oh pooh to 'your highness', call me ma'am.
I was beginning to enjoy being alone for once.
I long for some gaiety - a play or an opera.
I am fond of pleasant society, are you that?
No interruption fatigues, if it benefits the nation.
The dogs bite traitors and loyal alike, so they aren't much help.
A discretionary fleet for national emergencies.
I want to be a spearhead not a figurehead.
We do not solicit violence, yet under my rule it seems as constant as the crashing waves.
I do not forget the sacrifice of these sailors on my account.
Then we owe our gratitude.
It is much admired.
Sincere thanks for attending to this matter.
It would be prudent to accept.
Oh, we are only too happy to agree.
We shall be delighted.
Apparently my father disliked babies. I think I shall be as decisive, but slightly less mad.
It doesn't matter what you think of me, it is what I think of you.
Archie has been like a father to me, his company fills me with all those paternal hopes and comforts.
Archie never stops me eating jam, and will suffer the subsequent indigestion for me too!
If not for Archie, the rest would still be leading me up and down stairs like an infant.
Lady Margaret Hunt, née Harlow, is a respected voice on the Royal Council.
Sarmento is a strong woman, let us hope she keeps no secrets from us.
Anne Harlow must know that no injustice can excuse her own crimes.
Jean La Fortune is a pirate whose name I too-commonly hear.
The council has agreed my prison reforms, so I hope Mr. Bleakworth will bend a little.
Miss Jorgensen is a distant relative. Although all my relatives are quite distant.
I understand we have visiting royalty in Princess Qing. She's a gentle soul.
Willie Wibblesock? A made-up name surely?!
It's Mr von Malching. I will never offer that awful man a barony.
The presence of Vicente Silva is clearly an attempt by La Corona to challenge my authority here.
Shame Queens can't chop heads anymore.
Heaven forbid!
If that is a joke, it is not a funny one.
Pull up your braces, and thrust into the unknown!
If you pop off now, you'll be back in time for tennis!
Know that any assistance may influence Her Majesty's sphere!
Alas, my bowels churn afresh and I must beg your expertise...
Now here is a vital matter, of Queen and country!
Righty-ho!
Jolly Roger!
Buckaroo!
That really is first-rate.
I am quite penetrated by your kindness.
Bish-bang-bibbly, there she blows!
Ideally, one should keep one's promises.
Now, now. You oughtn't waste people's time.
Didn't finish? Ah. Um…hmmn…
Failed? I feel a ghastly surge coming on.
Caught trousers down? Happens to the best of us!
Her Majesty has little patience, I'd skip to it if I were you!
Have you heard the expression, 'a stitch in time saves nine' …
Resting? Perhaps you'd like my latest; male torso in rosewood!
Much has moved since we spoke, but I can still count on you?
I fear I must call upon you again, in spite of your good work.
I confess these unseemly troubles gurgle on, hope you don't mind?
Loyalty to the crown really should come above all else …
Only Her Majesty has your best interests at heart.
Oh, you're ready?
Had a rip-roaring time of it?
Brought some joy?
Nothing just now, but we value your eagerness!
If you return a little later, I may have something…
Pop back another time, and I'll fill your stocking.
Apart from security, I appreciate the company!
Two's the charm!
Well well, chosen for a royal escort!
I'm here if ever you need a steady, albeit somewhat arthritic, hand to guide you.
Sir Archibald Blake, Her Majesty's moist mouthpiece!
One-piece underwear suits? Too prickly! I find singleton shorts and vests to be tried and true!
Weird and wonderful!
I'm sure ma'am shall be delighted!
Superlative!
Suitably regal!
Her Majesty might approve!
Comforting as a moist and springy sponge!
Well that certainly settles the stomach!
You're a credit to the Empire!
You're constant, and that is key!
Perhaps a peerage is on the cards?
Majesty will soon be mentioning you.
I knew you'd come through!
You're flourishing!
You're a national treasure!
Her Majesty will be discomfited…
There's an unpleasant waft in the air.
Heavens, what shall I tell her majesty?
Oh, horsefeathers.
This brings on my indigestion.
I'm suddenly hot under the collar.
Pshaw, I shan't sleep at all.
You put me in a difficult position…
I wouldn't wish to accuse you of disloyalty…
Perhaps think again on the situation?
I fear you've made things awkward…
Might I advise against your current course?
Now we don't want to have a contretemps.
It's not that we don't trust you entirely…
I present my humble duty to you, and am confident you'll transcend your present circumstance!
I am a humble servant of Her Majesty, called upon for delicate occasions such as these.
Taking the initiative - excellent!
What a jolly, jolly surprise.
Ah yes, the bright young sapling!
I present my humble duty to you.
Don't tell me I've missed another appointment?
Sir Archibald Blake, how may I serve?
Anyone for croquet?
We prepare for the worst but hope for the best.
Our humble little Empire.
The King is dead, long live the Queen!
The street layout was positively Byzantine until recent times.
Her Majesty's finest!
A lustrous jewel in the crown!
Every ship needs a stiff rudder!
An Empire covers both land AND sea!
Ma'am and I are much obliged!
A royal acknowledgement is due!
Sir Archibald gives his thanks.
Naturally!
But of course!
Oh, most assuredly!
I fear that may be impossible.
The thought makes me wince!
Oh my aching organs, no.
As a boy, I was chased through the palace by a disgruntled goose, honking and hissing! I had its egg, you see. Once I'd given it back, the goose and I became firm friends.
Tolerance, sympathy, understanding. Supreme qualities in a monarch wishing for a happy reign.
Her Majesty rarely needs guidance - ah, a little here and there - I think she simply likes to have my company.
Ever carved a lovespoon from walnut? I did have an amour once, but matters of state drew us apart.
As Her Majesty's adjutant, I must be quietly attentive. The merest smile on her face is enough!
Viscount Guffington-Hawkmoth, wounded at his own estate. It brings to light Her Majesty's very present vulnerability.
Bless Her Majesty, she eats so fast, but when she stops, so must we!
Her Majesty's rare gift is a soft heart and a hard mind. With monarchs, it is too often the reverse!
Anne Harlow's fall from grace was stormy and unpleasant, a bit like my bowels.
George Smith has a marvellous walking cane of alder, with tasteful silver flourishes.
Aha...Jean La Fortune. We'd like to have helped, but it's rather gone beyond that now.
Isabel Sarmento? You should probably be careful where you speak that name.
Mr. Bleakworth may seem a blinkered horse, but is very well-suited to his task at the prison.
When running errands for Her Majesty, I often find myself in Madame Kahina's exquisite company.
Miss Jorgensen is a far relation of Her Majesty, if I'm not mistaken. They do both share a certain boldness...
We have made every conceivable dispensation for Princess Qing, as we are compelled to do with visiting royalty!
We auditioned this Wibblesock for Her Majesty's fifteenth birthday, sadly the rabbit didn't survive the hat.
Beryl O'Mara has flies on the wall, as I only dream our own discrete services might.
Her Majesty wearies of Mr. von Malching's pinguid claims to a non-existent barony.
I worry Artur Gasparov might one day appear at the palace better-dressed than her majesty.
Pure pleasure …
All in Her Majesty's name.
More flexible than you imagined!
The royal seal upon it!
I can finally let go that pent-up gas!
Customs and excise, eh!
Duty done, time for a kip!
Oh dear, lost your flagship? Well, I'll see what I can rustle up...
We can't deny it's a difficult time. The sale of Prosperity was highly destabilising for Her Majesty.
Debt free? Spiffing, just the dib-dab. One splendid licence we shall draw up forthwith.
As to the debt, my hands are tied — but it may warm her majesty's heart to see a new enterprise taking shape.
Did he really…? Oh dear, best leave these poor people with me. I will tell Edvard that the debt between you is quite settled…
What is it you are bringing?
I will let Edvard know that I have granted you your shipping licence.
We also hear on the grapevine, of your commendable intention to establish your own shipping company…
Her Majesty warmly invites you to trade in sovereign harbours, at your own discretion of course.
So you build ships like your father? Well, the Queen is in the direst need of ships.
Supporting her will go some way to healing the wounds of the past.
These reinforcements will please Her Majesty! Though it remains my hope no war will be necessary.
I read in the papers you build ships like your father. His actions have likely led to war, so it would be strangely fitting if you were to supply the Queen's fleet.
You are doing Her Majesty a great service in these difficult times.
How are those ships coming along? Her Majesty will be pleased.
Her Majesty wants only warships. It is after all important in such times that she defends her sovereignty.
We rely more and more on captains of industry to steer us to happy futures.
This symbol is a death threat?! But Her Majesty received one identical! Upon a plain envelope, with a stamp from the colonies!
We still don't know how your father was involved in all this, but I fear the answer lies west.
Your father sold Prosperity to the leader of the rebels Isabel Sarmento.
The sale of Prosperity, made in Samuel's name, has weakened Her Majesty's position greatly.
Ever since the deal, Isabel has been hiding from us. But you may be the one to find her.
After the excellent work you are doing for the fleet, I think you're entitled to pursue the odd personal matter.
I wish as much as you that your father were innocent in this.
Those very serious accusations against your father are hard to dismiss without proof to the contrary.
You digging around in state matters isn’t ideal, but in this case may be necessary.
That these ''Pyrphorians'' may have spread their influence in the New World is grave news indeed.
The situation closer to home is already difficult. Her Majesty has come under increasing scrutiny from many sides.
Her Majesty may go to war with Isabel. That is why she is mustering a fleet.
Isabel will be cagey, but I think she with time may listen to us.
